memory.definition: Capricorn is the sign of the goat and occurs on January 1st.
memory.mnemonic: The goat in the cap and coat played the horn (Capricorn and goat) on stage but only the janitor was watching.
memory.question: What zodiac sign is represented by a goat and occurs on January 1st?

memory.definition: Aquarius is the sign of the water bearer and occurs on 1st February.
memory.mnemonic: Aqua various – Water into beer – Fed into Brewery
memory.question: What is the zodiac sign associated with the water bearer and occurs on 1st February?

memory.definition: Pisces is the sign of the fish and occurs on the 1st March.
memory.mnemonic: The fish marched around the pie.
memory.question: What zodiac sign is represented by the fish and occurs on the 1st of March?

memory.definition: Sign of the ram, occurs on April 1st.
memory.mnemonic: The ram took a blue pill (April) and jumped crazily up in the air (Aries).
memory.question: What is the zodiac sign associated with April 1st?

memory.definition: Taurus is the sign of the bull and occurs on May 1st.
memory.mnemonic: The bull tore up stuff so they tied him on the maypole.
memory.question: What zodiac sign is represented by the bull and occurs on May 1st?

memory.definition: Gemini is the sign of twins and occurs on June 1st.
memory.mnemonic: In June the twins always ski on their gem-encrusted skis down dunes.
memory.question: What is the zodiac sign that features twins and occurs on June 1st?

memory.definition: Cancer is the sign of the crab and occurs on July 1st.
memory.mnemonic: To get away from the crab who seemed to crush everything including cans, he had to lie in his hammock.
memory.question: What zodiac sign is associated with July 1st?

memory.definition: Leo is the sign of the lion and occurs on the 1st of August.
memory.mnemonic: Leo the lion produces all the gusts of wind that are produced in the world.
memory.question: What is the star sign associated with the 1st of August?

memory.definition: Virgo is the sign of the virgin and occurs on September 1st.
memory.mnemonic: The Virgin Mary walks away (virgin goes) from the septic tank member.
memory.question: What astrological sign occurs on September 1st and is represented by the virgin?

memory.definition: Libra is the sign of the scales and occurs on October 1st.
memory.mnemonic: It was almost impossible to weigh the octopus on the scales while she was trying to read books from the library.
memory.question: What is the zodiac sign represented by scales and occurs on October 1st?

memory.definition: Scorpio is the sign of the scorpion and occurs on November 1st.
memory.mnemonic: The scorpion decided to write a novel about an adventure in a rainforest.
memory.question: What zodiac sign is represented by a scorpion and falls on November 1st?

memory.definition: Sagittarius is the sign of the archer and occurs on December 1st.
memory.mnemonic: She opened her Christmas present and had been given an archery set but the string was all saggy.
memory.question: What is the zodiac sign associated with the archer that occurs on December 1st?

chemistry.definition: Protons are positively charged subatomic particles.
chemistry.mnemonic: Protons (peas) are positively charged.
chemistry.question: What are protons?

chemistry.definition: Neutrons are neutral and have no charge.
chemistry.mnemonic: Neutrons (newts) are neutral and have no charge.
chemistry.question: What characteristic do neutrons have regarding their electric charge?

chemistry.definition: Negatively charged particles.
chemistry.mnemonic: Electrons (electronic robots) are negatively charged.
chemistry.question: What are electrons?

chemistry.definition: The atomic number tells you how many protons the element has.
chemistry.mnemonic: The atomic number is a tom cat with only a pea to eat (proton).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.10 Atomic number memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What does the atomic number indicate about an element?

chemistry.definition: The mass number is the number of protons plus the number of neutrons in the atom. It is always the biggest number and is roughly double the atomic number.
chemistry.mnemonic: The mass number is represented by a bull mastiff eating a bowl of peas (protons) and newts (neutrons). All the live yummy bits, not electronic robots (electrons), because who wants to eat an electronic robot!
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.11 Mass number memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is the mass number in an atom?

chemistry.definition: The atomic number is the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom, which determines the element. The mass number is the total number of protons and neutrons in an atom's nucleus.
chemistry.mnemonic: A bull mastiff (mass) dog is sitting on top of a tom (atomic) cat. The mass number is always the bigger number.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.13 Mass is always bigger memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What do the atomic number and mass number represent in an atom?

chemistry.definition: Protons have a relative mass of 1.0073 amu.
chemistry.mnemonic: Protons (peas) have a mass of one.
chemistry.question: What is the relative mass of protons in atomic mass units?

chemistry.definition: Neutrons have a relative mass of 1.0083 amu, but weigh the same as protons.
chemistry.mnemonic: Neutrons (newts) weigh the same as protons (peas), so also have a mass of one.
chemistry.question: What is the relative mass of neutrons compared to protons?

chemistry.definition: Electrons have a very small weight, 0.00054 amu, and are often ignored in mass calculations.
chemistry.mnemonic: Electrons (electronic robots) weigh almost nothing whatsoever… they’re empty inside!
chemistry.question: What is the relative weight of electrons in atomic mass units?

chemistry.definition: Atoms of the same element with a different number of neutrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: The newts (neutrons) are skating ‘on top’ of the ice (‘ice on top’ – isotope).
chemistry.question: What are isotopes?

chemistry.definition: Electrons orbit the nucleus of an atom in shells.
chemistry.mnemonic: To help you remember that electrons are arranged in shells, imagine our electronic robot (electron) hatching out of a shell.
chemistry.question: What are electron shells in an atom?

chemistry.definition: Electrons occupy shells or orbits around the nucleus, where each shell can hold a specific number of electrons: the first shell holds 2, the second holds 8, and the third holds 8.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember how many electrons are allowed in each shell, think of two fat ladies (2, 8, 8) on a beach covered in shells.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.39 Electronic shell obit mnemonic (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What are electron shells in atoms?

chemistry.definition: Atoms or molecules that carry an electric charge, created when a neutral atom loses or gains electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remind you, here’s an image of electronic robots (electrons) playing a round of golf using golf irons (ions).
chemistry.question: What are ions?

chemistry.definition: Valency is the number of bonds an atom can make with other atoms, usually based on the number of electrons in its outer shell.
chemistry.mnemonic: To help you remember that valency is about an atom’s potential to bond, imagine a bride who’s told to lift her 'veil and see' (valency) how many grooms want to 'bond' with her.
chemistry.question: What is valency in chemistry?

chemistry.definition: The relative atomic mass of an element is equal to its mass number or the average of the mass numbers of the isotopes, taking their relative abundances into account.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of all the relatives (relatives), of the bull mastiff (mass number).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.62 Relative mass number memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is the relative atomic mass?

chemistry.definition: A British chemist who created a table of known chemical elements.
chemistry.mnemonic: Newlands decided to arrange elephants (elements) on his table in order of their mass, but he left no gaps for new elephants that had not yet been discovered.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.77 Newlands introduced periodic table image (2).jpg
chemistry.question: Who was Newlands?

chemistry.definition: A Russian chemist who rearranged the periodic table to leave gaps and grouped elements with similar properties together.
chemistry.mnemonic: By mending and leaving (Mendeleev) gaps in the table, Mendeleev was able to keep elephants (elements) with similar houses (properties) together on the table.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.81 Mendeleev rearranged the table image.jpg
chemistry.question: Who was Mendeleev, and what is he known for in chemistry?

chemistry.term: Groups and Periods of the Periodic Table
chemistry.definition: Groups run along the top of the table and periods are found down the side.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember that groups run along the top of the table, imagine a table with musical groups on top of it. Heavy metal groups are on the left and string groups (non-metals) are on the right. Different periods of time are illustrated on the table leg, indicating that the periods are found down the side of the periodic table.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.83 Metal left non metals right memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: How are groups and periods arranged on the periodic table?

chemistry.definition: Elements in Group 1 of the periodic table including potassium and sodium.
chemistry.mnemonic: We were all very nervous because we had to go down a back street full of drunks, all the alkies were lying down with their metal beer cans.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.84 Alkali metals memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What are alkali metals?

chemistry.definition: Elements in Group 2 of the periodic table including magnesium and calcium.
chemistry.mnemonic: Looking down, I saw that the street itself was paved with bottles and cans of alcohol in lines in the earth.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.85 Alkali earth metals memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What are alkaline earth metals?

chemistry.definition: Elements found in the middle section of the periodic table including gold and iron.
chemistry.mnemonic: We were so worried about walking that we drove through instead, in a transit van.
chemistry.question: What are transition metals?

chemistry.definition: Also known as the boron group containing elements such as boron and aluminium.
chemistry.mnemonic: We drove safely out of the alley and a very expensive jewellery store caught my eye – it was selling high cost gems.
chemistry.question: What is another name for the boron group containing elements such as boron and aluminium?

chemistry.definition: Also known as the carbon group containing elements such as carbon and lead.
chemistry.mnemonic: The most impressive thing they were selling was a glittering necklace made of crystal.
chemistry.question: What are crystallogens?

chemistry.definition: Also known as the nitrogen family containing elements like nitrogen and arsenic.
chemistry.mnemonic: But, as I watched, thieves suddenly ran up and smashed the glass! The necklace quickly got nicked!
chemistry.question: What are pnictogens?

chemistry.definition: Also known as the oxygen family containing elements such as oxygen and sulphur.
chemistry.mnemonic: I could see the poor store owner inside, adding up what had been taken on his calculator.
chemistry.question: What are chalcogens?

chemistry.definition: Elements in Group 7 of the periodic table including chlorine and bromine.
chemistry.mnemonic: What happened next was incredible! An angel swooped down and caught one of the thieves by snaring him with her halo!
chemistry.question: What are halogens?

chemistry.definition: Elements in Group 0 of the periodic table including helium and neon.
chemistry.mnemonic: The angel presented the thief she had caught to the mayor. His clothes made him look very noble.
chemistry.question: What are noble gases?

chemistry.definition: The elements in group 1 of the periodic table known for reacting violently with water, having a single electron in their outer shell, being soft and less dense than water, having low melting points, and forming oxides and hydroxides.
chemistry.mnemonic: Following a raid on the alley, where the alkies were lying down with their metal beer cans, the alkali metals (along with their electric robots)*, were deemed dangerous and criminal.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.93 Alkali metals electron memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What are alkali metals?

chemistry.definition: Halogen molecules always have two atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: The halo brigade always consists of one hero and one sidekick. There are always two.
chemistry.question: What is distinctive about halogen molecular structure?

chemistry.definition: Gases are at the top of their column of the periodic table, solids are at the bottom.
chemistry.mnemonic: They protect the air in the sky above and the solid ground below.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.101 Gas top solid bottom image.jpg
chemistry.question: What are the states of the halogens in the periodic table?

chemistry.definition: Halogens all have coloured vapours.
chemistry.mnemonic: When danger threatens, the halo brigade flies up to deal with it. As they fly, they leave coloured trails behind them.
chemistry.question: What characteristic is shared by the vapours of all halogens?

chemistry.definition: Halogens higher up in the table displace the ones that are lower in the table.
chemistry.mnemonic: The more powerful hero angel wants a piece of the action first, so she shoves her less powerful sidekick out of the way.
chemistry.question: What is displacement in halogens?

chemistry.definition: Halogens react with hydrogen to make poisonous acids.
chemistry.mnemonic: The threat is quite often a high dragon (hydrogen). When the two of them fight, the wounded dragon spills poisonous, acid blood.
chemistry.question: What happens during a reaction with hydrogen involving halogens?

chemistry.definition: The large group of elements in the middle of the periodic table between groups 2 and 3. They are hard and dense, less reactive than group 1 & 2 metals, conduct heat and electricity well, have high melting points, are used as catalysts, form colorful ionic compounds, and some can form more than one ion.
chemistry.mnemonic: Once upon a time, a gorilla (silver Ag) tried to park his transit van (transition metals) but because there wasn’t much room, he had to lift it into the space. For a human, this would have been impossible. However, for the gorilla, because he was so hard and strong, it was no trouble at all. The man in the car next to him was not happy as the gorilla had blocked him in. 'What do you think you’re doing?! Are you dense?!' he yelled. It didn’t end there. He got out of his car and the conversation began to get heated. The man was so livid that he threw a punch at the gorilla. The gorilla tried to defend himself, but his reactions were too slow and he ended up getting hurt. Luckily, a benevolent cheetah happened to be running past. When she saw that the gorilla had been hurt, she was keen to assist (Cat-assist, catalyst). The pair’s bust-up was holding up the traffic. A bus stopped and its conductor got out to see what all the commotion was about. The conductor’s bus was anything but ordinary; it was painted with bright colours. On the top deck of the bus was a group of robots on their way to the local golf course. They each had golf bags containing one, two, or three irons.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.106 Transition metal group chart.jpg
chemistry.question: What are transition metals?

chemistry.term: Reactivity of alkali metals and halogens
chemistry.definition: Alkali metals become more reactive as you go down group 1 due to weaker attraction between the nucleus and outer electron. Halogens become more reactive as you go up group 7 due to stronger attraction.
chemistry.mnemonic: Drunks fall down, angels rise.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/4. Periodic Table/2.4.105 Reactivity in groups 1 and 7 image.jpg
chemistry.question: How does the reactivity of alkali metals and halogens change within their respective groups?

chemistry.definition: A single particle made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: The electronic robot (electrons), the newt (neutrons) and the pea (protons) all carried the atom bomb (electrons, neutrons and protons make up an atom).
chemistry.question: What is an atom?

chemistry.definition: The smallest part of an element.
chemistry.mnemonic: An elephant (element) is looking at the smallest atom bomb.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/1. Types of Particle/2.1.1 Atom memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is the smallest part of an element?

chemistry.definition: A substance made up of only one type of atom.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of an element as being an elephant.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/1. Types of Particle/2.1.2 Element memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is an element in terms of chemistry?

chemistry.definition: A substance made up of atoms chemically bonded together. The atoms can be the same or different elements.
chemistry.mnemonic: The atoms that make up a molecule can be of the same or different elements.
chemistry.question: What is a molecule?

chemistry.definition: A compound is a substance made up of different types and numbers of atoms, all chemically bonded together.
chemistry.mnemonic: Compounds are made up of atoms of more than one type of element
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/1. Types of Particle/2.1.4 Compound memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is a compound in chemistry?

chemistry.definition: A mixture is made up of two or more elements that are not chemically bonded to one another.
chemistry.mnemonic: Here, two different elephants are not bonded to each other.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/1. Types of Particle/2.1.5 Mixture memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is a mixture?

chemistry.definition: Elements that typically indicate metals, with exceptions such as helium, deuterium, and tritium.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember this, picture an aquarium filled with metal fish.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/15. Naming Chemicals/2.15.1 IUM is metals memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: Which type of elements often end in '-ium' and are usually metals, excluding examples like helium?

chemistry.definition: Molecules ending with -ite contain fewer oxygen atoms than those ending with -ate.
chemistry.mnemonic: The opera singer complained that her tight (-ite) corset prevented her from getting enough oxygen. When she removed it, her lungs could inflate (-ate) and she could breathe in more oxygen.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/15. Naming Chemicals/2.15.2 ITE has fewer oxygen than ATE image.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the difference between molecules ending in -ite and -ate?

chemistry.definition: If a compound ends in ‘ide’, it contains only two elements.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remind you, these two elephants (elements) are holding only one ID card (together they form a compound).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/15. Naming Chemicals/2.15.3 IDE compounds have 2 elements.jpg
chemistry.question: What does it mean when a compound ends in -ide?

chemistry.definition: Indicates there are two atoms of a particular element in a compound.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of a dyed (di) pair (two) of brightly coloured shoes (shoe = two)
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/15. Naming Chemicals/2.15.4 Di in a compound means 2 of the same atom.jpg
chemistry.question: What does the term "Di" indicate in a chemical compound?

chemistry.definition: The syllable ‘tri’ indicates that a compound contains three atoms of an element.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember this, think of a triceratops (tri) riding a three-wheeled tricycle.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/15. Naming Chemicals/2.15.5 TRI is three atoms of the same element image.jpg
chemistry.question: What does the syllable ‘tri’ indicate in a chemical compound?

chemistry.definition: Molecules that consist of two atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: Diatomic molecules include hydrogen (H2), oxygen (O2), and chlorine (Cl2).
chemistry.question: What are diatomic molecules?

chemistry.definition: Chemical compound with the formula Fe₂O₃, formed when iron is exposed to water.
chemistry.mnemonic: Rusty iron oxen fetch shoes (two) from an Orange tree (Fe₂O₃).
chemistry.question: What is iron oxide, commonly known as rust?

chemistry.definition: Commonly known as salt, it is an ionic compound with the formula NaCl.
chemistry.mnemonic: Sodium chloride is represented by the pine of a mountain of salt (NaCl).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/7. Chemical Formulae/2.7.2 Sodium chloride memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is sodium chloride commonly known as?

chemistry.definition: A gas compound of nitrogen and hydrogen with the formula NH3.
chemistry.mnemonic: The Mona Lisa (Ammonia) at the Natural History Museum (NH3).
chemistry.question: What is ammonia?

chemistry.definition: Limestone, chalk, limescale and marble are chemically the same, all forms of calcium carbonate.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of calcium carbonate as being milk (calcium, Ca) on a car bonnet, along with items associated with calcium carbonate: • Limes in the back of the car are singing scales (limescale) • The wheels on the car are marbles (marble is formed from highly pressurised limestone) • Chalk tyre marks on the road (chalk is mainly limestone) • The car is swerving around a stone that looks like a lime segment (limestone)
chemistry.question: What are limestone, chalk, limescale, and marble all forms of?

chemistry.definition: A white chalky deposit found in kettles and pipes, chemically known as calcium carbonate (CaCO3).
chemistry.mnemonic: A cacophony is produced by three (CaCO3) limes playing scales (limescale).
chemistry.question: What is limescale?

chemistry.definition: C2H5OH, a flammable liquid that is consumed.
chemistry.mnemonic: Yes, ethanol is a drunk poodle.
chemistry.question: What is ethanol (alcohol) known as in chemical terms?

chemistry.term: H (as a prefix in chemical formulas)
chemistry.definition: If a compound's formula begins with H, it is usually an acid, except when it's H2O (water).
chemistry.mnemonic: If you end up spilling acid on yourself, it will hurt!
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/7. Chemical Formulae/2.7.9 H is an acid image (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What does the prefix "H" indicate in chemical formulas?

chemistry.definition: Hydrochloric acid is a very corrosive acid.
chemistry.mnemonic: Hydrochloric acid is a Highly Corrosive liquid (HCl).
chemistry.question: What is hydrochloric acid known for?

chemistry.definition: HNO₃
chemistry.mnemonic: Knife trick accidents Hurt Nobody Outside Our Office (HNO₃)
chemistry.question: What is the chemical formula for nitric acid?

chemistry.definition: Covalent bonding is where atoms share electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of two people (non-metal) cooperating and covered by a veil (covalent) and deciding to share the rest of their lives together.
chemistry.question: What is covalent bonding?

chemistry.definition: Simple covalent molecules are mainly liquids and gases.
chemistry.mnemonic: The married couple finally share a bath of water.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.11 Covalent bonds are liquid and gas image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What are simple covalent structures?

chemistry.definition: Substances with simple covalent structures have low melting points. Most are gas or liquid at room temperature due to weak intermolecular bonds.
chemistry.mnemonic: A cool looking ice cube in glass with shades and shoes represents the low melting point of simple covalent structures like H₂O.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.12 Covalent bonds between atoms are strong image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What are the properties of simple covalent structures?

chemistry.term: Simple covalent structures do not conduct electricity
chemistry.definition: Simple covalent molecules cannot conduct electricity as they lack free electrons or ions.
chemistry.mnemonic: A man in the bath with a very happy toaster illustrates that pure water does not conduct electricity well.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.15 Covalent bonds cannot conduct electricity resized.jpg
chemistry.question: Why do simple covalent structures not conduct electricity?

chemistry.definition: The transfer of electrons between atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: It is represented by someone putting a transfer on a t-shirt of an electronic robot and ironing on it (ionic). Ionic = transfer
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.27 Ionic bonding image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: The transfer of electrons from a metal to a non-metal.
chemistry.mnemonic: Ionic bonding is the transfer of electrons from a metal (iron) to a non-metal (t-shirt).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.28 Ionic transfer between metal and non-metal resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: A type of chemical bonding that occurs between metals and non-metals, as seen in ionic compounds like sodium chloride.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember that salt is an example of an ionic compound, think of a salt shaker wearing the robot t-shirt (electron transfer).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.29 Sodium chloride is Ionic bonded resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: All ionic compounds are salts except oxides (metal + oxygen) and hydroxides (metal + hydrogen).
chemistry.mnemonic: All the salt shakers wear transfer t-shirts (ionic bonding).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.34 All ionic compounds are salts resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What are ionic compounds?

chemistry.definition: The electrostatic force of attraction between a positively charged metal and a negatively charged non-metal.
chemistry.mnemonic: The iconic (ionic) man attracted lots of women.
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: Ionic bonding is the formation of a bond because a metal and non-metal are attracted to each other.
chemistry.mnemonic: A metal and non-metal person were attracted to each other. How ironic – how ionic.
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: Ionic bonding forms ionic compounds like sodium chloride (salt).
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember that salt is an example of an ionic compound, think of a salt shaker wearing the Einstein tee-shirt with women attracted to him.
chemistry.question: What is ionic bonding?

chemistry.definition: All ionic compounds are salts except oxides (metal + oxygen) and hydroxides (metal + hydrogen).
chemistry.mnemonic: All the salt (NaCl) shakers wear Einstein tee shirts with women attracted to him (ionic bond).
chemistry.question: What are ionic compounds?

chemistry.definition: A reaction that involves the transfer of electrons between elements and then an immediate bond.
chemistry.mnemonic: The word 'REDOX' is made from words that describe the two reactions: reduction and oxidation.
chemistry.question: What are redox reactions?

chemistry.definition: Oxidation is the loss of electrons and reduction is the gain of electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is the Loss of electrons, Reduction Is the Gain of electrons.
chemistry.question: What is oxidation and reduction?

chemistry.definition: Metallic bonding occurs between metals and involves strong metallic bonds and a 'sea of electrons'.
chemistry.mnemonic: The robots (electrons) form a ‘sea of electrons’.
chemistry.question: What is metallic bonding?

chemistry.definition: Metal atoms are held together by strong metallic bonds due to a sea of delocalised electrons that are attracted to the positive nuclei.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a sea of electrons holding metal atoms together strongly.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.40 Metal atoms are held together strongly resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is metallic bonding?

chemistry.definition: A type of chemical bonding that occurs in metals, characterized by a sea of shared electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: The heavy metal band was made up of coppers.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.42 Copper memory aid resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is metallic bonding?

chemistry.definition: Free electrons in metallic substances reflect light, making them shiny.
chemistry.mnemonic: Copper can be made to look shiny.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.43 Metal is shiny image resized2.jpg
chemistry.question: Why are metals shiny?

chemistry.definition: Metallic bonding allows molecules to slide over one another, making metals malleable so they can be bent, hammered, pressed, or rolled into shape without breaking.
chemistry.mnemonic: Copper can be bent into shape.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/3. Chemical Bonding/2.3.44 Metal can be bent.jpg
chemistry.question: Why are metals like copper considered malleable?

chemistry.definition: A substance with a pH of less than 7.
chemistry.mnemonic: A seed (acid) is driving a car that won't go any faster than 7 MpH (acids are less than 7 on the PH scale) because it is so small it can't push the accelerator pedal down any further (so an acid pH is from 1 to 7).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.4 Acids 7 or less on ph image Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the pH range of acids?

chemistry.definition: An acid will always be in a water solution.
chemistry.mnemonic: A seed (acid) always needs water to survive.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.5 Acids need water image Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What state is an acid typically found in?

chemistry.definition: All acids contain hydrogen.
chemistry.mnemonic: Inside a seed (acid) is a high dragon (hydrogen).
chemistry.question: What do all acids contain?

chemistry.definition: A base can neutralise an acid.
chemistry.mnemonic: A bass (base) drum can stop (neutralise) a seed (acid).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.7 Bases neutralise acids mnemonic Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is a base in chemistry?

chemistry.definition: Metal oxides are basic; they react with water to form bases such as hydroxides.
chemistry.mnemonic: Metal + Ox hide (oxide) = Base drum (base)
chemistry.question: What are metal oxides?

chemistry.definition: When metals react with acids, they produce a salt and hydrogen gas.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of MASH (Metal + Acid = Salt + Hydrogen).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.9 Metal makes salt exposed to acid Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens when metals react with acids?

chemistry.definition: When acids react with bases, they produce a salt and water. This is known as a neutralisation reaction.
chemistry.mnemonic: When a seed (acid) played her bass (base) drum she became very upset and began to cry salty tears (salt + water).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.10 Acid and base give salt and water Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens when an acid reacts with a base?

chemistry.definition: Ionic compounds, excluding oxides and hydroxides.
chemistry.mnemonic: All the salt shakers wear transfer t-shirts (ionic bonding).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.12 All salts are ionic compounds Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What are salts in chemistry?

chemistry.definition: A combination of dyes used to indicate the pH of a substance and whether it is an acid or an alkali.
chemistry.mnemonic: The indicator (universal indicator) of a car in space (universe) is flashing as it turns towards ‘alkali’ or ‘acid’.
chemistry.question: What is a universal indicator?

chemistry.definition: Acids turn red when an indicator is added.
chemistry.mnemonic: You would try to kill a zombie with a bath of acid, which would turn red if you did! (Acidic solutions turn universal indicator red).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.14 Acids turn red memory aid Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens to the color of the indicator when acids are present?

chemistry.definition: A neutral solution (like water) will turn green
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of a gear stick sticking out of a chameleon; when the gear stick is in the neutral position, the chameleon turns green.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.15 Neutral substances turn green mnemonic Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens to a neutral solution in terms of color?

chemistry.definition: An alkaline solution will turn universal indicator blue or purple.
chemistry.mnemonic: Bleach (an alkaline) comes in a blue bottle.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.16 Alkali substances turn blue purple mnemonic Resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What color does an alkaline solution turn on a universal indicator?

chemistry.definition: The pH scale is used to determine the strength of an acid or alkali. It is numbered from 0 to 14, with each number associated with a particular colour.
chemistry.mnemonic: Remember the old saying ‘Richard Of York Gave Battle In Vain’.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.20 The pH scale with examples graphic.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the pH scale used for?

chemistry.definition: An acid is formed when the number of H+ ions in water is thrown out of balance.
chemistry.mnemonic: Too many H+ ions (hippo) makes water unbalanced.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.27 Imbalance in H ions makes acid resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is acid formation?

chemistry.definition: H+ ions make acids reactive and attack most things they come into contact with because they are hungry for electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: The hippos (H+ ions) attack things because they are hungry for electric robots (electrons).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.28 H ions are hungry memory aid resized.jpg
chemistry.question: Why are H+ ions significant in making acids reactive?

chemistry.definition: H+ ions latch onto H2O molecules temporarily until they find something to attack.
chemistry.mnemonic: The hippo (H+) doesn’t like being alone so it gets a piggyback on a bucket of water until it can find something to attack.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.24 Cations latch onto onto water molecules resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What do H+ ions do when they are not attacking other substances?

chemistry.definition: An H⁺ ion is a hydrogen atom that has lost its electron, making it equivalent to a proton.
chemistry.mnemonic: It turns out that the Hippo (H⁺) was a pea (proton) in disguise all along!
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.30 H ions are protons in disguise image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is an H⁺ ion?

chemistry.definition: Substances that give away a proton (H+ ion) when they react with something.
chemistry.mnemonic: You can remember this by seeing a pea (proton) being given as a present (given away).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.31 Acids donate protons memory aid resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What are acids in terms of their chemical reaction properties?

chemistry.definition: Water dissolves acids, removing the hydrogen atom and producing a hydrogen+ ion, also known as a roaming proton.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a seed (acid) about to be broken up by water.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.32 Water removes H ion resized.jpg
chemistry.question: How does water interact with acids on a chemical level?

chemistry.definition: A method for determining the concentration of a substance in a solution by gradually adding another substance until a reaction occurs.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember titration, think of a classroom where the pupils are ties (titration). Some ties are concentrating harder than others (they are at different levels of concentration).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/5. Acids, Alkali, Bases and Salts/2.5.33 Titration mnemonic resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is titration?

chemistry.definition: A chemical compound containing only carbon and hydrogen atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: Picture a high dragon landing on a burning car.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.1 Hydrogen and carbon memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What is a hydrocarbon?

chemistry.definition: 1 carbon atom
chemistry.mnemonic: Me teeth eating a bun (Meth = 1)
chemistry.question: What is the shortest parabolic formula for Meth in organic chemistry?

chemistry.definition: 2 carbon atoms
chemistry.mnemonic: Death wearing bright shoes (Eth = 2)
chemistry.question: What does "Eth" represent in terms of carbon atoms?

chemistry.definition: 3 carbon atoms
chemistry.mnemonic: Propeller in a tree (Prop = 3)
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/How to remember hydrocarbons/Prop has 3 carbon atoms 1.jpg
chemistry.question: How many carbon atoms are in a prop molecule?

chemistry.definition: 4 carbon atoms
chemistry.mnemonic: Beautiful person in doorway (But = 4)
chemistry.question: What is the prefix for an alkane with 4 carbon atoms?

chemistry.definition: Single carbon bond
chemistry.mnemonic: Walking canes standing in a shingle beach (single (bond) = anes)
chemistry.question: What type of bond is found in alkanes?

chemistry.definition: Double carbon bond
chemistry.mnemonic: Our two Queens need two James Bonds (Double Bond = ene)
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/How to remember hydrocarbons/Propene molecular bonds.jpg
chemistry.question: What type of bond characterizes alkenes?

chemistry.definition: Alkanes have single covalent bonds.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember this, think of some canes (alkanes) on a shingle (single) beach.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.20 Alkanes have single bonds memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What type of bonds do alkanes have?

chemistry.definition: Alkenes have a double carbon bond.
chemistry.mnemonic: We think of an alkene as being a queen. Our queens have two James Bonds (a double bond).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.21 Alkenes have double bonds mnemonic.jpg
chemistry.question: What structural feature characterizes alkenes?

chemistry.definition: Molecules beginning with ‘meth’ have only one carbon atom.
chemistry.mnemonic: 1 = bun, meth = me teeth
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.22 Meth has one carbon memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What does the prefix "meth" in chemistry indicate about the structure of a molecule?

chemistry.definition: Molecules with the prefix ‘eth-’ contain two carbon atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: ‘Eth’ is the grim reaper (the mascot of death) wearing two shoes.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.23 Eth has 2 carbon memory prompt.jpg
chemistry.question: What does the prefix "eth-" indicate in molecules?

chemistry.definition: Molecules of propene or propane have three carbon atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remind you that there are three carbon atoms in hydrocarbons starting with ‘prop-’, here is a propeller stuck in a tree (three).
chemistry.question: What does "prop" in hydrocarbons indicate about the number of carbon atoms?

chemistry.definition: Molecules beginning with ‘but-’ have four carbon atoms.
chemistry.mnemonic: To remember how many carbon atoms are in hydrocarbons beginning with ‘but-’ (pronounced ‘bute’), think of a beautiful man looking over a stable door (four).
chemistry.question: What does the prefix "but-" indicate about the number of carbon atoms in a molecule?

chemistry.definition: An alkene with the molecular formula C4H8, containing four carbon atoms and a double bond.
chemistry.mnemonic:
But- → beautiful → door → four → 4 carbon atoms
-ene → Queen → two James Bonds → double bond → double carbon bond
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.46 Butene molecular bonds image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is butene?

chemistry.definition: CH3OH, a hydrocarbon with one carbon atom and an OH attachment.
chemistry.mnemonic: Meth = Me teeth eating a bun = Meth is 1 carbon. Anol means OH is attached.
chemistry.question: What is methanol?

chemistry.definition: A hydrocarbon with 2 carbon atoms and an OH attachment.
chemistry.mnemonic: Eth - Death - with red shoes = Eth is 2. 'an old' - pharaoh = OH
chemistry.question: What is ethanol?

chemistry.definition: A hydrocarbon with 4 carbon atoms and an OH attachment.
chemistry.mnemonic: 4 = Door = Beauty in doorway = But. OH = Pharaoh = An old = Anol
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.59 Butanol molecular bonds image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is butanol?

chemistry.definition: Compounds ending in -anol which means the formula ends in -OH.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of an old pharaoh (OH) who is an alcoholic (alcohol).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.26 Alcohols end with anol memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What are alcohols?

chemistry.definition: Methanol is a chemical compound with the formula CH3OH, consisting of one carbon atom and an OH group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Methanol is remembered as 'me teeth' for 'meth-' (1 carbon atom), and 'an old pharaoh' for '-anol' (OH group).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.50 Methanol molecular bonds image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the chemical composition of methanol?

chemistry.definition: Ethanol, with the chemical formula C2H5OH, is a type of alcohol with two carbon atoms and one hydroxyl group (OH).
chemistry.mnemonic: Eth- → death → shoe → two → 2 carbon atoms; -anol → an old → an old pharaoh → pharaoh → OH
chemistry.question: What is the chemical structure of ethanol?

chemistry.definition: Propanol is an alcohol with the chemical formula C3H7OH, consisting of three carbon atoms and an OH group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Prop- → propeller → tree → three → 3 carbon atoms; -anol → an old → an old pharaoh → pharaoh → OH, making propanol C3H7OH.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.56 Propanol molecular bonds image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the chemical structure of propanol?

chemistry.definition: C4H9OH
chemistry.mnemonic: But- → beautiful → door → four → 4 carbon atoms; -anol → an old → an old pharaoh → pharaoh → OH.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/9. Hydrocarbons/2.9.59 Butanol molecular bonds image resized.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the chemical formula for butanol?

chemistry.definition: Isomers are chemicals that have the same molecular formula but a different arrangement of atoms. This results in different physical properties due to variance in the strength of bonds (intermolecular forces).
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of ice in summer (is-omer). The ice cubes in the image are arranged differently like the atoms in isomers.
chemistry.question: What are isomers?

chemistry.definition: Electrolysis is “splitting” a liquid with DC (direct current) electricity.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of an electric trolley (electrolysis) “splitting” liquid, like Moses parting the sea in the Old Testament.
chemistry.question: What is electrolysis?

chemistry.definition: If the liquid contains hydrogen, it will form at the cathode and be released as gas unless the solution contains a metal less reactive than hydrogen.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a high dragon (hydrogen) clinging to the roof of a cathedral (cathode).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/11.Electrolysis/2.11.18 Hydrogen given off by cathode memory aid.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens during electrolysis when the liquid contains hydrogen?

chemistry.definition: If the solution being electrolyzed contains a halogen (e.g., chlorine or bromine), the halogen forms at the anode. If no halogen is present, oxygen forms at the anode.
chemistry.mnemonic: When a solution contains halogens (angels with halos), they are attracted to the annoyed android (anode) as they want to soothe him and stop him being so annoyed.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/11.Electrolysis/2.11.20 Halogens form on the anode image.jpg
chemistry.question: What happens at the anode during electrolysis if the solution contains halogens?

chemistry.definition: The anode is positive and the cathode is negative in electrolysis.
chemistry.mnemonic: Positive Anode, Negative is Cathode (PANIC)
chemistry.question: What is the mnemonic for remembering the charges in electrolysis where the anode is positive and the cathode is negative?

chemistry.definition: The electrolyte is the liquid that “splits” when electricity is passed through it.
chemistry.mnemonic: Think of an electric troll light (electrolyte) swimming underwater (liquid).
chemistry.question: What is an electrolyte?

chemistry.definition: An electrode where the anode is positive and the cathode is negative.
chemistry.mnemonic: PANIC: Positive Anode, Negative Is Cathode
chemistry.question: What are cathode and anode described as in terms of charge?

chemistry.definition: In electrolysis, cathodes give out electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: The electronic robots (electrons) are booted out of the cathedral (cathode) because robots are not allowed in the cathedral.
chemistry.question: What is the role of a cathode in electrolysis?

chemistry.definition: Oxidation is the loss of electrons, reduction is the gain of electrons.
chemistry.mnemonic: Remember OIL RIG – Oxidation is loss, reduction is gain.
chemistry.question: What are oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer?

chemistry.definition: takes place at cathodes
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine that a red duck shone (reduction) a light on the cathedral (cathode).
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/11.Electrolysis/2.11.25 Reduction takes place at the cathode image.jpg
chemistry.question: In electrochemistry, where does reduction take place?

chemistry.definition: takes place at the Anode
chemistry.mnemonic: Anode is oxidation is AN OX.
chemistry.question: What occurs at the anode during a redox reaction?

chemistry.definition: A cation is a positively-charged atom or ion.
chemistry.mnemonic: Cations have a pawsitive (positive) charge.
chemistry.question: What is a cation?

chemistry.definition: An anion is a negatively-charged atom or ion.
chemistry.mnemonic: Therefore, anions have a negative charge.
chemistry.question: What are anions?

chemistry.definition: Positively charged ions that move towards the cathode during electrolysis.
chemistry.mnemonic: Cats (cations) swimming towards the cathedral (cathode) during electrolysis. And, because cations are pawsitive (positive), the cathode must be negative.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/11.Electrolysis/2.11.27 Cations are attracted to the cathode .jpg
chemistry.question: What are cations?

chemistry.definition: Electrodes are normally made of inert (unreactive) materials such as graphite or platinum.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine people electing a toad (elect toad, electrode). The toad shows no emotion at the result – he’s unreactive, or inert – unlike the losing candidates.
chemistry.question: What are electrodes usually made of, and why are these materials chosen?

chemistry.definition: A process where components of a liquid dissociate from each other.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine you had a cup of tea in front of you, and the components in the water – tea, milk and sugar – got out and started running away, dissociating themselves from each other.
chemistry.question: What is electrolysis?

chemistry.definition: A mole is a number equal to 6x10^23, known as Avogadro's Constant.
chemistry.mnemonic: On the 6th day, God created mole and man. The mole did a high ten with God and thanked Her. Then there were two. And then they made three.
chemistry.question: What is a mole in chemistry?

chemistry.definition: A mole of an ideal gas occupies a volume of 24 liters at room temperature and pressure (RTP).
chemistry.mnemonic: The mole had an upset (gas-filled) tummy and had to go to bed for 24 hours.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/12. Moles/2.12.15 Remembering a mole of ideal gas.jpg
chemistry.question: What is the volume occupied by a mole of an ideal gas at room temperature and pressure (RTP)?

chemistry.definition: An ideal gas is any atom or molecule that exists with a full outer shell.
chemistry.mnemonic: Ideally, the gasoline tank is completely filled.
chemistry.question: What constitutes an ideal gas?

chemistry.definition: A chemical element with a lit wooden splint making a popping sound in its presence.
chemistry.mnemonic: A lit wooden splint makes a popping sound in a test tube of hydrogen.
chemistry.question: What is the test for Hydrogen?

chemistry.definition: A gas that will relight a glowing wooden splint.
chemistry.mnemonic: A glowing ox (oxygen)
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/6. Laboratory Tests/2.6.2 Test for oxygen memory aid (2).jpg
chemistry.question: What is the test for oxygen?

chemistry.definition: When carbon dioxide (CO2) is bubbled through lime water, the lime water will turn cloudy white.
chemistry.mnemonic: A car (carbon) driven by two oxen (oxygen) through a burning hoop into cloudy white water full of crocodile-like limes (lime water).
chemistry.question: What is the test for carbon dioxide?

chemistry.definition: The structure of the earth is made up of three parts: the core, mantle, and crust.
chemistry.mnemonic: The crust from a slice of bread is surrounding a mantelpiece (mantle) whilst an apple core burns underneath.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/13. Earths Structure/2.13.1 Three layers of the earth mnemonic.jpg
chemistry.question: What are the three main parts of the structure of the earth?

chemistry.definition: The lithosphere includes the earth’s crust and the upper mantle and is broken into tectonic plates.
chemistry.mnemonic: Lifting a sphere (lithosphere) onto a mantelpiece (mantle) was done by a crusty crab (crust).
chemistry.question: What is the lithosphere?

chemistry.definition: The surface of the Earth is split up into a number of large sections of rock called tectonic plates.
chemistry.mnemonic: There’s a new drink in town and only the plates know about it. It’s a cocktail containing tequila and tonic (known as Tectonic).
chemistry.question: What are tectonic plates?

chemistry.definition: Rock formed by the action of heat and pressure on sedimentary or igneous rocks over long periods of time.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine you met someone who morphed (metamorphic) from a punk rocker to a glam rocker.
chemistry.question: What is metamorphic rock?

chemistry.definition: Limestone turns into marble over millions of years from large pressures.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine squeezing a lime fruit, and it coming out of the squeezer as a very hard marble.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/13. Earths Structure/2.13.5 Limestone forms marble image.jpg
chemistry.question: How does limestone transform into marble?

chemistry.definition: Shale can turn into slate with the right amount of pressure and heat over millions of years.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a mud pie being placed in an oven and coming out as a roof slate.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/13. Earths Structure/2.13.6 Shale forms slate image.jpg
chemistry.question: How does shale transform into slate over time?

chemistry.definition: Igneous rock is formed when molten rock cools down and solidifies.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a gran who knits (granite). She is in a bath on a sea of lava, with a pumice (pumice) stone and bath salts (basalt) on the side of the bath.
chemistry.image: /images/user/base/Chemistry/13. Earths Structure/2.13.7 Volcanoes create igneous rock image.jpg
chemistry.question: What is igneous rock?

chemistry.definition: Sedimentary rocks are formed from layers of sediment, such as shells, sand, mud, and pebbles, that drop to the bottom of lakes or seas and are compacted over millions of years. Examples include limestone and sandstone.
chemistry.mnemonic: Imagine a cemetery (sedimentary) for shellfish at the bottom of the ocean where the gravestones are limestone that has formed over the years from the shells deposited on the bottom.
chemistry.question: What are sedimentary rocks?

chemistry.definition: Can dissolve other molecules; can break apart another molecule to form a solution
chemistry.mnemonic: The mood was solemn at the event (solvent) after the rain water washed everything away.
chemistry.question: What is a solvent?

chemistry.definition: Compound/solid that breaks down into a liquid
chemistry.mnemonic: The car has so much looted (solute) from it. It started as a solid car but it's been broken down because it's in a rough area.
chemistry.question: What is a solute?

chemistry.definition: A solid which becomes incorporated into a liquid to form a solution; absorbed into the liquid
chemistry.mnemonic: This always solves (dissolve) my problems. I just have to watch I don't get absorbed into the bath water.
chemistry.question: What happens when a solid becomes incorporated into a liquid to form a solution?

chemistry.definition: A substance that can be dissolved when mixed with a liquid.
chemistry.mnemonic: I sold you a bull (soluble) and a can of beans (can be).
chemistry.question: What does it mean if a substance is soluble?

chemistry.definition: When a solute is dissolved in a solvent; a liquid mixture where the solute is uniformly distributed within the solvent
chemistry.mnemonic: She thought the solution (solution) to life was to keep drinking a liquid mixture of cocktails.
chemistry.question: What is a solution?

chemistry.definition: Tin is a chemical element with the symbol Sn, located in the basic metals group of the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Tin is represented by a tin of Snails (Sn)
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Tin in the periodic table?

chemistry.definition: Iodine is a chemical element represented by the symbol 'I' and found in the halogens group of the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Iodine is illustrated by an eye dining with another eye (I).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Iodine?

chemistry.definition: Platinum is represented by the symbol Pt on the periodic
chemistry.mnemonic: Platinum is a platypus wearing a wig that has been Plaited (Pt).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Platinum?

chemistry.definition: Gold is represented by the symbol Au in the periodic table and is a transition metal.
chemistry.mnemonic: Gold is a goldfish taking a stroll in the Autumn (Au).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Gold?

chemistry.definition: A transition metal element with the symbol Hg.
chemistry.mnemonic: Mercury is illustrated by a thermometer in the middle of a bear Hug (Hg).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Mercury?

chemistry.definition: Lead is represented by the symbol Pb on the periodic table
chemistry.mnemonic: Lead is a pencil in a jar of Peanut butter (Pb).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Lead?

chemistry.definition: Radon is a chemical symbol represented by the symbol 'Rn' on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Radon is illustrated by a radio on a Run (Rn).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Radon?

chemistry.definition: Uranium is a chemical element represented by the symbol 'U' on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Uranium is represented by UFOs from Uranus (U).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Uranium?

chemistry.definition: Represented by H on the periodic table, it is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe.
chemistry.mnemonic: Hydrogen is represented by a High dragon (H).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Hydrogen?

chemistry.definition: Helium is the first noble gas and has the lowest boiling point of all the elements.
chemistry.mnemonic: Helium is illustrated by someone inhaling helium from a balloon and laughing: ‘He he he!’ (He).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Helium?

chemistry.definition: Lithium is represented by the symbol Li on the periodic table
chemistry.mnemonic: Lithium is a lethal mum with her baby wearing Lipstick (Li).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Lithium?

chemistry.definition: Beryllium is represented by the symbol Be on the periodic table and is a very rare element in the universe.
chemistry.mnemonic: Beryllium is represented by a bear ill in Bed (Be).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Beryllium?

chemistry.definition: Boron is a low abundance material in the universe and a semimetal element represented by the symbol 'B' on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Boron is a boar on a Ball (B).
chemistry.question: What is a semimetal element with low abundance in the universe, represented by the symbol 'B' on the periodic table?

chemistry.definition: Carbon is a chemical element displayed as C on the periodic table; it is in the non-metal group (14) period 2 and is the 4th most abundant element in the universe.
chemistry.mnemonic: Carbon is illustrated by a car burning in the sea (C).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical element represented by the symbol C, known for being in group 14, period 2, and the 4th most abundant element in the universe?

chemistry.definition: A non-metal element that can exist in gas, liquid, or solid forms.
chemistry.mnemonic: Nitrogen is the Trojan horse at Night (N).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Nitrogen?

chemistry.definition: Oxygen is represented by the symbol O on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Oxygen is an oxygen mask worn by an Ox (O).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Oxygen?

chemistry.definition: A noble gas that is very abundant in the universe and emits light when exposed to an electrical field.
chemistry.mnemonic: Neon is illustrated by a neon arrow pointing to a knee (Ne).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Neon?

chemistry.definition: Sodium is represented by the symbol Na on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Sodium is a soda bottle surrounded by gnats (Na).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical element represented by the symbol "Na" and known for being a very reactive metal in the alkali metal group of the periodic table?

chemistry.definition: Magnesium is represented by the symbol Mg on the periodic table
chemistry.mnemonic: Magnesium is represented by Maggots in a bun (Mg).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Magnesium?

chemistry.definition: Aluminium is represented by Al on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Aluminium is a can being crushed by an Alligator (Al).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Aluminium?

chemistry.definition: Silicon is represented by the chemical symbol Si on the periodic table
chemistry.mnemonic: Silicon is a Silly convict (Si).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Silicon?

chemistry.definition: Phosphorus is an element on the periodic table, shown as P in the non-metals group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Phosphorus is a fossil having a Pee (P).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Phosphorus?

chemistry.definition: Sulphur is represented by the symbol 'S' on the periodic table and belongs to the non-metals group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Sulphur is represented by a Sultan wearing a fur coat with a Snake (S).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Sulphur?

chemistry.definition: Argon is a noble gas that is non-reactive, represented by chemical symbol Ar.
chemistry.mnemonic: Argon is a pirate exclaiming that his coins are ‘Ar rrr gone!’ (Ar).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Argon?

chemistry.definition: A chemical element represented by the symbol K, belonging to the alkali metals group in the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Potassium is the potato King (K).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Potassium?

chemistry.definition: Calcium is an element represented by the symbol 'Ca'.
chemistry.mnemonic: Calcium is represented by a skeletal Cat drinking milk (Ca).
chemistry.question: What is the symbol for the element Calcium?

chemistry.mnemonic: Titanium is the sinking Titanic covered in Ties (Ti).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Titanium?

chemistry.definition: Chromium is a transition metal represented by the symbol Cr.
chemistry.mnemonic: Chromium is represented by a chrome car emblem in the shape of a Crow (Cr).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Chromium?

chemistry.definition: Manganese is represented by the chemical symbol Mn on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Manganese is illustrated by a Manga Man who has hurt his Manga knees (Mn).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Manganese?

chemistry.definition: Iron is represented by the chemcial symbol Fe on the periodic table
chemistry.mnemonic: Iron is someone ironing with their Feet (Fe).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Iron?

chemistry.definition: Cobalt is represented on the periodic table with the symbol Co and belongs to the transition metals group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Cobalt is represented by a bolt joining together two Cobras (Co).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Cobalt?

chemistry.definition: Nickel is a chemical element symbolized by Ni on the periodic table and is part of the transition metals group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Nickel is someone holding a pair of really big knickers (Ni).
chemistry.question: What is symbolized by Ni on the periodic table and is part of the transition metals group?

chemistry.definition: Copper is a transition metal with the symbol Cu.
chemistry.mnemonic: Copper is a copper saying 'See you (Cu) in court!'
chemistry.question: What is the symbol for the transition metal Copper?

chemistry.definition: A chemical element with the symbol Zn, found in the transition metals group.
chemistry.mnemonic: Zinc is illustrated by a sinking boat containing a Zulu and a little nun (Zn).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical element with the symbol Zn, often associated with a sinking boat containing a Zulu and a little nun?

chemistry.definition: Bromine is a chemical element represented by the symbol Br.
chemistry.mnemonic: Bromine is represented by a mean Brother (Br).
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Bromine?

chemistry.definition: Silver is a chemical element represented by the symbol 'Ag' on the periodic table.
chemistry.mnemonic: Silver is represented by two silver-backed gorillas being Aggressive (Ag) or just think of it as A Gorilla.
chemistry.question: What is the chemical symbol for Silver?

biology.definition: The classification of living things.
biology.mnemonic: You can remember this if you think of a class of car (classification) called “taxi” (taxonomy).
biology.question: What is taxonomy?

biology.definition: Swedish botanist who developed taxonomy ranks in the 18th century.
biology.mnemonic: Taxi ranks are basically car (Carl) lines for us (Linnaeus), to see where the taxis park.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.2.26 Taxi rank graphic to help remember Carl Linnaeus.jpg
biology.question: Who was Carl Linnaeus?

biology.definition: The ordered ranks from kingdom to species used in taxonomy.
biology.mnemonic: Keep Ponds Clean Or Fish Get Sick
biology.question: What are the ordered ranks in taxonomy called, ranging from kingdom to species?

biology.definition: A system invented by Linnaeus, meaning 'two-part name'. The two names used are derived from genus and species.
biology.mnemonic: The genius (genus) who wrote the king’s speeches (species) became very fat due to his habit of eating several times a day at the best restaurants. The king came up with a special diet for him – the Buy No Meal system (binomial) that allowed only two named dishes a day made by the king’s own cook.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.2.35 Image to remember the binomial system.jpg
biology.question: What is the binomial system?

biology.definition: Felis catus
biology.mnemonic: Imagine a cat feeling a cactus (Felis catus).
biology.question: What is the scientific name for a domestic cat?

biology.definition: Ficus elastica
biology.mnemonic: Imagine a group of fighters with elastic bands (ficus elastica) on their faces, inviting people to 'come and fight us' at the rubber plant where they work.
biology.question: What is the scientific name of the rubber plant?

biology.definition: Bellis perennis
biology.mnemonic: Imagine a daisy flower made of bells. Each bell is perennially (bellis perennis) ringing (ringing forever).
biology.question: What is the scientific name for the common daisy?

biology.definition: Latin names used to universally identify species, with the first part of the name in upper case and the second part in lower case.
biology.mnemonic: At an airport in Latin America (Latin), the upper case was loaded into the taxi first, and the lower case was put in second.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.2.44 Mnemonic showing how to write Latin names.jpg
biology.question: What are binomial names?

biology.definition: A group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring.
biology.mnemonic: Speeches (species) can only be made off a spring (offspring) board that’s fertile.
biology.question: What defines a species in biological terms?

biology.definition: A dichotomous key helps to determine the identity of animals, plants, and other living things. It consists of a series of choices, each with just two possible answers that lead the user to the correct name of a given item.
biology.mnemonic: A dyed cotton mouse with keys (dichotomous keys) has to unlock the door that best describes an aspect of her anatomy to move closer to identifying what she is.
biology.question: What is a dichotomous key used for in biology?

biology.definition: Animals with backbones. They include bony fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals (including humans).
biology.mnemonic: Imagine the human backbone as being a vertical brace (vertebrate) holding the body upright.
biology.question: What are vertebrates?

biology.definition: The five classes of vertebrates include fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals, and birds.
biology.mnemonic: Another useful mnemonic to help remember the five classes of vertebrates is FARM BIRDS.
biology.question: What are the five classes of vertebrates?

biology.definition: An animal that can regulate its body temperature by means such as perspiring, shivering, and adjusting blood flow to the body surface areas. These are known as 'warm-blooded' animals.
biology.mnemonic: Think of a domestic cat that’s lost its fur having to turn up its built-in thermostat to stay warm at home. You could call it a home-meow-therm (homeotherm).
biology.question: What is a homeotherm?

biology.definition: An animal that cannot regulate its own body temperature and changes temperature according to its environment; also known as cold-blooded.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine that a snake murdered someone in cold blood by biting and poisoning them. At the snake’s trial, the judge hands down a poison killer term (poikilotherm) of 35 years – and the snake wonders how it will manage to stay warm for so long in a cold cell.
biology.question: What is a poikilotherm?

biology.definition: Any animal species that gives birth to live young.
biology.mnemonic: Vive la Paris! (viviparous) – This Paris maternity hospital specialises in live births.
biology.question: What does it mean if an animal is viviparous?

biology.definition: Animals that lay eggs.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine birds laying eggs over Paris (oviparous).
biology.question: What does oviparous mean?

biology.definition: Animals without backbones (opposite of vertebrates).
biology.mnemonic: To remember the term invertebrate, imagine an earthworm goes to a building site for a job, but is told that because it doesn’t have a backbone, it will have to insert a brace (invertebrate) to make it stronger.
biology.question: What are invertebrates?

biology.definition: Arachnids, such as spiders, have 8 legs.
biology.mnemonic: Think of a group of kids wearing anoraks (anorak kids – arachnids) climbing a gate (eight).
biology.question: What characteristic do all arachnids share?

biology.definition: Most crustaceans have 10 legs.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine bread with hard crusts (crustaceans) being pecked by a big hen (ten).
biology.question: What is a notable characteristic of crustaceans?

biology.definition: Myriapods have 20 or more legs.
biology.mnemonic: Think of a group of mirrors (myriapods) with lots of legs, playing in a football match, all hoping to score (score is an old word for the number 20).
biology.question: What are myriapods?

biology.definition: Fish are separated into two main types depending on what their skeleton is made of. Bony fish have skeletons made of bone, while cartilaginous fish have skeletons made of cartilage.
biology.mnemonic: The bony (bones) fish was driving a very powerful go kart (cartilage).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.3.54 Mnemonic to remember bony and cartilaginous fish.jpg
biology.question: What are the two main types of fish based on their skeleton composition?

biology.definition: Fish with five to ten sets of gill slits, unlike bony fish which have plates that cover their gills.
biology.mnemonic: If you look closely at the go kart (cartilage) you will see it is shaped like a shark and has five slits down its side.
biology.question: What distinguishes cartilaginous fish from bony fish in terms of their gills?

biology.definition: Bony fish possess an organ called a swim bladder which can alter buoyancy to maintain or adjust their position in the water.
biology.mnemonic: The bony fish had to go and relieve its bladder.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.3.61 Mnemonic of bony fish with swim bladder.jpg
biology.question: What unique organ do bony fish possess that allows them to adjust their buoyancy in water?

biology.definition: A fin located on the back of a fish, used for stability in swimming.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine on the top of the fish a Door Sail (Dorsal) instead of a fin.
biology.question: What is the dorsal fin on a fish used for?

biology.definition: The humerus is the bone between the shoulder and the elbow of vertebrate animals, and it is under the bicep.
biology.mnemonic: The woman had biceps so enormous that everyone thought they were humorous (humerus).
biology.question: Which bone is located between the shoulder and the elbow under the bicep in vertebrates?

biology.definition: The femur is the bone within the thigh.
biology.mnemonic: Feel my (femur) leg on the thigh.
biology.question: What is the femur?

biology.definition: The clavicle is your collar bone.
biology.mnemonic: They all have epaulettes on their shoulders apart from one who has classic vehicles (clavicles) on hers.
biology.question: What is the clavicle commonly known as?

biology.definition: The sternum or the breast bone has two clavicles attached to it and seven sets of ribs.
biology.mnemonic: The witch took the breast bone from a skeleton because she needed something that looked like a spoon for her cauldrons in order to stir them (sternum).
biology.question: What is the function of the sternum in the human body?

biology.definition: The scapula is the shoulder blade.
biology.mnemonic: Scrap your car (scapula) by pushing it off the cliff with your shoulder blades.
biology.question: What is the scapula?

biology.definition: The radius goes from the elbow to the wrist on the thumb side of your hand.
biology.mnemonic: You cannot change stations on wrist radios without using your thumb. (Thumb side)
biology.question: What is the radius?

biology.definition: The ulna is a long bone that goes from the elbow to the wrist on the little finger side of the hand.
biology.mnemonic: An old nurse (ulna) sews an elbow patch on her old jumper.
biology.question: What is the ulna?

biology.definition: One of the two bones in the forearm, connected to the thumb side.
biology.mnemonic: ‘Hooray,’ (radius) she said, and then put her thumb up.
biology.question: What is the radius?

biology.definition: The carpals are the bones in the wrist. There are 8 bones.
biology.mnemonic: I do car pulls (carpals) through the gate (8) using the strength of my wrists.
biology.question: What are the carpals in the human body?

biology.definition: The metacarpals are the 5 bones in the palm (middle) of your hand. They are between the carpals and the phalanges (fingers).
biology.mnemonic: I met a car pull (metacarpal) team in action right next to the car pull (carpal) sign.
biology.question: What are the metacarpals?

biology.definition: The tarsal bones are in your feet.
biology.mnemonic: A woman stepped in tar with the soles (tarsals) of her feet.
biology.question: Where are the tarsals located in the body?

biology.definition: The metatarsals are the five bones in the middle of your foot next to the tarsals and the phalanges (toes).
biology.mnemonic: Her girlfriend met her and looked at her tarred soles (metatarsals) which were next to other tarred soles (tarsals).
biology.question: What are the metatarsals?

biology.definition: The phalanges are the bones in your hands that make up your fingers and the bones in your foot that make up your toes.
biology.mnemonic: Flanges (phalanges) can be done up by standing on my toes and using my fingers.
biology.question: What are phalanges?

biology.definition: The tibia is your shin bone and runs from your knee to your ankle.
biology.mnemonic: I have a fifty pence tip for ya (tibia) if you lend me your shin pads.
biology.question: What is the tibia?

biology.definition: The fibula is your calf bone and runs from your knee to your ankle.
biology.mnemonic: You can tell this calf will fib a lot (fibula) because its nose has grown!
biology.question: What is the fibula?

biology.definition: The patella is the knee cap.
biology.mnemonic: The patio fella (patella) has to use knee pads.
biology.question: What is the patella?

biology.definition: The pelvic girdle comprises your hips. Your legs attach to it on each side.
biology.mnemonic: All the hurdlers need to get their pelvis over the hurdle (pelvic girdle).
biology.question: What is the pelvic girdle?

biology.definition: The back bone is made up of small bones called vertebrae.
biology.mnemonic: A woman broke her back, so she has to go to hospital and have a vertical brace (vertebrae) fitted.
biology.question: What are the small bones called that make up the backbone?

biology.definition: The first 7 vertebrae called cervical vertebrae.
biology.mnemonic: She finds it difficult to feed herself so her food is served by a vicar (cervical), who also prays to heaven (7) for her to get better.
biology.question: What are the first 7 vertebrae called?

biology.definition: The next 12 vertebrae in the spine, part of the thorax supported by ribs where the heart and lungs are contained.
biology.mnemonic: She hears Thor singing some 12 Bar Blues while he works and she thinks: Thor and his axe at it (thoracic) again!
biology.question: What are thoracic vertebrae?

biology.definition: The next 5 vertebrae are the lumbar vertebrae.
biology.mnemonic: The lumber (lumbar) crashes into the hospital, bringing a hive (5) with it which was hanging in the tree.
biology.question: What are the lumbar vertebrae?

biology.definition: The sacrum is a large triangular bone made of fused vertebrae, located at the lower end of the spine, and is where nerves exit the spinal canal.
biology.mnemonic: Thor gets the sack and runs (sacrum) away from the hospital with the lumber.
biology.question: What is the sacrum?

biology.definition: The coccyx is the last vertebrae in the spine and is connected to the sacrum.
biology.mnemonic: The police finally catch up with Thor and put him in jail. Now all he can do is watch the clock tick (coccyx) in his cell and tell people his tale (tail).
biology.question: What is the coccyx?

biology.definition: A skeleton that is internal and inside the body, such as in mammals.
biology.mnemonic: Endoskeleton              =          Enter In          =          Inside               =          Internal
biology.question: What is an endoskeleton?

biology.definition: A skeleton that is external and outside the body, such as in insects and crustaceans.
biology.mnemonic: Exoskeleton                 =          Exit                  =          Outside            =          External
biology.question: What is an exoskeleton?

biology.definition: Chitin is a rigid modified glucose that forms around an organism and is a component of exoskeletons.
biology.mnemonic: The crab had hold of a kite made of tin (chitin), but the kite flew out of the exit (exoskeleton) door.
biology.question: What is the primary component of exoskeletons, such as those found in crabs, called?

biology.definition: The ossicles are three bones within the ear consisting of the malleus, incus, and the stapes.
biology.mnemonic: ‘Can you hear that horse coming?’ It’s a horse on a cycle (ossicles) which is bringing the mail to us (malleus) for our ink (incus) and staples (stapes).
biology.question: What are the ossicles in the human ear?

biology.definition: Muscles which work in pairs and opposites. The agonist muscle causes the action, while the antagonist relaxes. These roles reverse when the action works the other way.
biology.mnemonic: The antagonism she cause with a stick (antagonistic) was beyond belief she should have used her stick but although they were a pair of twins they were complete personality opposites.
biology.question: What are antagonist muscles?

biology.definition: The muscle that moves the bone.
biology.mnemonic: A simple way to remember the agonist and antagonist is to think of one muscle being in agony (agonist) when lifting something heavy.
biology.question: What is the role of an agonist muscle in movement?

biology.definition: The relaxed muscle in an antagonistic pair.
biology.mnemonic: The relaxed muscle is anti-lifting (antagonist).
biology.question: What is the antagonist muscle?
