biology.definition: A broad, flat muscle that stretches to the sides of the middle and lower back.
biology.mnemonic: A latch is a must on doors, I (latissimus dorsi) can see one, but it's very low down on the back of the door.
biology.question: What is the latissimus dorsi?

biology.definition: A broad flat muscle covering the neck, upper back, and shoulders.
biology.mnemonic: A way to remember this is to realise that the trapezius is named for its trapezoidal shape.
biology.question: What is the trapezius muscle?

biology.definition: Two muscles positioned on the back of the lower leg
biology.mnemonic: She wasn't a typical calf (calf); she had strong muscles on the back of her lower legs that allowed her to stand up.
biology.question: What are the calf muscles?

biology.definition: Muscle positioned on the sides of the torso which assists body rotation and bending
biology.mnemonic: It's going to be a bleak (oblique) winter. It's freezing outside but inside (side of the body) it's warm.
biology.question: What is the function of the oblique muscles in the body?

biology.definition: The muscles that connect the front of the chest to the bones of the upper arm and shoulder
biology.mnemonic: The bird sitting on his shoulder pecked and tore all (pectoral) his shirt away around his chest.
biology.question: What are pectoral muscles?

biology.definition: A muscle in the jaw that provides power for chewing
biology.mnemonic: It was massive and tough (masseter). The steak made my jaw muscles ache from chewing.
biology.question: What is the masseter muscle responsible for in the jaw?

biology.definition: A muscle group positioned on the rear of the thigh or the tendons which attach this muscle to the bone.
biology.mnemonic: I tied a piece of ham with string (hamstring) around the back of my leg. Why? I was starting a new trend.
biology.question: What is the hamstring?

biology.definition: Muscle group located on the inner thighs which serve to bring the legs toward the centre of the body
biology.mnemonic: A conductor (adductors) used his inner thigh muscles to stay on the miniature train.
biology.question: What are the adductors?

biology.definition: A large muscle group positioned on the front of the thigh
biology.mnemonic: She rode a quadbike to the wedding reception (quadricep) and wore thigh high leather boots.
biology.question: What is the quadriceps muscle group located on the front of the thigh?

biology.definition: A muscle group which runs the length of the back, from the neck to the pelvis
biology.mnemonic: To erect a statue on her own, the spy needs (erector spinae) strong back muscles. She was actually just putting the statue back.
biology.question: What is the erector spinae?

biology.definition: The main muscle of the shoulder allowing movement and stability in the joint.
biology.mnemonic: The boxer dealt a powerful blow that the other fighter couldn't avoid (deltoid). The power came from the shoulder muscle and rotation.
biology.question: What is the main muscle of the shoulder that allows movement and stability in the joint?

biology.definition: Muscle positioned centrally on the front of the body between the ribs and the pelvis
biology.mnemonic: Her abdomen was all (abdominal) muscle. Between her ribs and pelvis was an impressive six-pack.
biology.question: What muscle is centrally located on the front of the body between the ribs and the pelvis?

biology.definition: A group of muscles that form the buttocks
biology.mnemonic: They were glued to the steel (gluteal) bar stool by their buttocks.
biology.question: What are the gluteal muscles?

biology.definition: Muscle that covers part of the forehead and is responsible for elevation of the eyebrows
biology.mnemonic: On the front lines, you're a target, so listen (frontalis) to your commander and keep your forehead down.
biology.question: What is the frontalis muscle responsible for?

biology.definition: The muscle which connects to the end of the shoulder blade (scapula) and to the upper arm (humerus) to facilitate shoulder movement.
biology.mnemonic: I hope this parachute doesn't tear easily, or else there'll be a major (teres major) problem. I'll have to land on top of those flats (on top of the lats).
biology.question: What is the Teres Major muscle and its function?

biology.definition: The tendons are tough bands of fibrous tissue that connect muscle to bone.
biology.mnemonic: Ten dons (tendons) sit between a muscular woman (muscle) and a bony man (bone) for an interview at a university.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.32.54 Tendon location of shoulder and bicep.jpg
biology.question: What are tendons?

biology.definition: Ligaments are tough bands of fibrous tissue that connect and bind one bone to another.
biology.mnemonic: A ligature is meant (ligament) to stop bleeding, but instead it is used to tie these two paper bones together.
biology.question: What are ligaments?

biology.definition: The biceps muscle lies on top of the humerus and is used to bend and curl the arm. The triceps muscle lies underneath the humerus and is used to straighten the arm.
biology.mnemonic: B is curly and T is straight. The arm curls when biceps contract and it straightens when triceps contract.
biology.question: What roles do the biceps and triceps play in arm movement?

biology.definition: The plant kingdom is divided into two main groups: plants that make spores and plants that make seeds.
biology.mnemonic: The best way to plant seeds is to wear a kilt with a sporran (plants = spores or seeds).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.4.1 Remember how plants are categorized mnemonic.jpg
biology.question: How is plant categorization defined in terms of reproduction methods?

biology.definition: Plants that reproduce from seeds can be divided into conifers and flowering plants.
biology.mnemonic: The seed (seed) that was planted grew into a very strange tree that produced ice cream cones (conifers) and beautiful flowers (flowering plants) on the other half.
biology.question: How are plants classified in seed categorisation?

biology.definition: Flowering plants are called angiosperms and are split into two categories: monocotyledons (monocots) and dicotyledons (dicots).
biology.mnemonic: The flowers all look like angels (angiosperms) and they sprinkle their angel dust on babies’ cots (cots).
biology.question: What are flowering plants?

biology.definition: Plants that reproduce from spores can be sub-divided into algae, ferns, mosses and liverworts.
biology.mnemonic: The Scotsman with the sporran kept his boss’s garden beautifully but his own garden was a mess. You passed an algae-ridden pond with great big fronds of ferns. The door of his house was covered in moss. When he got into his house, he was given a great big meal of liver by his wife, who had warts on her face (liverworts).
biology.question: Which plants reproduce from spores, including algae, ferns, mosses, and liverworts?

biology.definition: The turning, movement, or growth in plants in response to external stimulus.
biology.mnemonic: The tropical plant is smiling (tropism) and turns to face the award ceremony for the best looking plant.
biology.question: What is tropism?

biology.definition: Movement or growth in response to light.
biology.mnemonic: After the awards ceremony there is a photo opportunity for the tropical plant who is smiling (phototropism). There is much light from the camera flashes.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.14.2 Phototropism movement of plants to light animation.gif
biology.question: What is phototropism?

biology.definition: Movement or growth in response to gravity.
biology.mnemonic: The flash photography startled the tropical plant, causing her to drop the award. Gravity (geotropism or gravitropism) pulled the award towards the ground (gravity) causing it to break as it landed.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.14.4 Geotropism movement of plants to gravity.jpg
biology.question: What is geotropism?

biology.definition: Positive tropism is movement or growth towards a stimulus, whereas negative tropism is the movement or growth away from a stimulus.
biology.mnemonic: The victorious plants looked positively (positive) ecstatic in their photos after they won two awards (towards), while the other nominees looked very negative about the ceremony since they had to walk away empty handed.
biology.question: What is positive and negative tropism?

biology.definition: Tubes that carry water and minerals in plants from the roots up through the stem.
biology.mnemonic: There are water xylophones (xylem carries water).
biology.question: What is the function of xylem in plants?

biology.definition: Tubes that carry food (glucose/amino acids) in plants.
biology.mnemonic: Phloem = Flows with an F for FOOD. F is for FOOD. Food is transported along the river as it flows (phloem).
biology.question: What is the function of phloem in plants?

biology.definition: The vascular tissue in plants that conducts water and dissolved nutrients upward from the root and also helps to form the woody element in the stem.
biology.mnemonic: X-rays always see inside. The xylem which starts with an X for X-ray sits on the inside of the plant.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.24.5 Xylem in phloem out memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What is xylem?

biology.definition: The vascular tissue in plants that conducts sugars and other metabolic products downward from the leaves.
biology.mnemonic: X-rays always see inside. The xylem which starts with an X is on the inside, hence phloem is on the outside.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.24.7 Xylem and phloem in trees cross section.jpg
biology.question: What is the function of phloem in plants?

biology.definition: An organelle present in plant cells and missing in animal cells.
biology.mnemonic: You will never see a vacuum (vacuole) in my brother's hand and that's a great way to remember vacuoles are missing from humans.
biology.question: What is a vacuole?

biology.definition: The parts found inside animal and plant cells
biology.mnemonic: To remember the term, think of an organ in a cell (organelle).
biology.question: What are the organelles found inside animal and plant cells?

biology.definition: The nucleus is the cell’s command centre. It contains genetic material (chromosomes, DNA, and genes) and controls all activities in the cell.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine a nuclear (nucleus) control centre located in a prison cell.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.5.16 Memory aid of a nucleus as command centre.jpg
biology.question: What is the function of the nucleus in a cell?

biology.definition: Ribosomes are the cell’s construction workers, building long chains of proteins from amino acids.
biology.mnemonic: Think of construction workers wearing ribbons (ribosomes), who are professional teenage (“protein”) builders.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.5.18 Memory aid of ribosomes the constuction organelles of a cell.jpg
biology.question: What are ribosomes?

biology.definition: Mitochondria are the powerhouses of the cell, generating most of the cell’s supply of chemical energy called ATP during respiration.
biology.mnemonic: Even the prison guards don’t mess with the Mighty Con Trio (mitochondria). They are powerhouses and rest and perspire (respire) while they work out. The guards even let the Mighty Con Trio turn their cell into A TeePee (ATP).
biology.question: What are mitochondria known for in a cell?

biology.definition: Adenosine Triphosphate, which is the life-giving energy in cells.
biology.mnemonic: ATP is “A TeePee”, but it also stands for Adenosine Triphosphate. To remember the name, imagine a den of sin (adenosine) in a teepee being raided by the police. The police can’t get through the flap, so the leader of the operation says: “Try force mate!” (triphosphate).
biology.question: What does ATP stand for and what role does it play in cells?

biology.definition: Vacuoles are storage bubbles in cells that can contain water, food, or waste.
biology.mnemonic: Think of the bag of a vacuum cleaner (vacuole) as a big bubble of liquid or waste that fills a large part of the machine.
biology.question: What is a vacuole in a cell?

biology.definition: Plants produce ATP during photosynthesis, which takes place in the chloroplasts. They are the food-producing factories of plant cells.
biology.mnemonic: Whenever the mentally disturbed prisoner clawed the plaster off (chloroplast) the prison guards had to take a photo (photosynthesis) for their records.
biology.question: Where does photosynthesis occur in plant cells, acting as the food-producing factories?

biology.definition: The cytoplasm surrounds the organelles, filling all of the remaining internal space in the cell. It is the 'jelly' that fills the cell.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine the sight of a plasma TV filled with giant jelly babies.
biology.question: What surrounds the organelles and fills the internal space in a cell, acting like 'jelly'?

biology.definition: A microscope that uses visible light to magnify images up to about 1,500 times the actual size.
biology.mnemonic: The microscope had a really bright light on it (light microscope).
biology.question: What is a light microscope?

biology.definition: A microscope that uses electron beams instead of light and can magnify up to around two million times.
biology.mnemonic: The electronic robots (electrons) check out the images provided by the electron microscope.
biology.question: What is an electron microscope?

biology.definition: Osmosis is a type of diffusion involving the movement of water across a partially permeable membrane from an area of high water concentration to an area of low water concentration.
biology.mnemonic: An Australian woman, Oz for short, only mows (osmosis) her lawn in the rain (water). When she does so, the grass changes from being very high to being very low.
biology.question: What is osmosis?

biology.definition: Active transport is the opposite of diffusion. Particles move against a concentration gradient, from low concentration to high concentration, using energy.
biology.mnemonic: Actively pushing a car (active transport) up a hill (from low to high, against a gradient), requires energy.
biology.question: What is active transport?

biology.definition: Diffusion is when molecules of one substance spread through another substance, from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration.
biology.mnemonic: You can remember this because of the infusion (Diffusion) between tea and hot water! The tea is spreading through the water, from an area of high concentration (the teabag) to an area of low concentration (the water).
biology.question: What is diffusion?

biology.definition: Blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart.
biology.mnemonic: Archery like an artery is away from the heart. Veins flow into the heart. Arteries flow away from the heart.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.5 Archery like arteries carry blood away from heart mnemonic.jpg
biology.question: What are arteries?

biology.definition: Arteries are thicker than veins.
biology.mnemonic: All archers have to do in a war is fire an arrow, when told. So you put your 'thicker' people into your archery section. Archery section = thicker. So too Arteries = thicker.
biology.question: What are arteries known for compared to veins?

biology.definition: Blood vessels that lead into the heart.
biology.mnemonic: The word Veins contain the word 'in', this will help you remember that they bring blood into the heart.
biology.question: What are veins?

biology.definition: Veins have valves, or more precisely non-return valves, preventing reverse blood flow.
biology.mnemonic: Remember revision guide trying to make remembering veins have valves easier
biology.question: What is a defining feature of veins related to blood flow direction?

biology.definition: The order the blood travels through the heart: Tricuspid, Pulmonary, Mitral, Aortic.
biology.mnemonic: “Tri pulling mi aorta.” Tri = Tricuspid, Pulling = Pulmonary, Mi = Mitral (pronounced My Tral), Aorta = Aortic.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.12 Structure of valves in the heart diagam.jpg
biology.question: What is the order in which blood travels through the heart valves?

biology.definition: Also known as the bicuspid valve, it has two flaps.
biology.mnemonic: The bishops (bicuspid) all wore the mitre (mitral) hats.
biology.question: What is the mitral valve?

biology.definition: The mitral (bicuspid) valve and tricuspid valve, which separate the atriums from the ventricles of the heart.
biology.mnemonic: Atrium and ventricular together makes atrioventricular.
biology.question: What are the atrioventricular valves?

biology.definition: The pulmonary valve and aortic valve that prevent blood flowing back into the heart once it has been pumped away through the arteries.
biology.mnemonic: As you leave the heart, turn the semilunar light off.
biology.question: What are the semilunar valves?

biology.definition: The bicuspid (mitral) valve is located in the left atrium, and the tricuspid valve is located in the right atrium of the heart.
biology.mnemonic: LAB RAT: Left Atrium = Bicuspid, Right Atrium = Tricuspid.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.17 How to remember Bicuspid and Tricuspid LAB RAT mnemonic.jpg
biology.question: Where are the bicuspid and tricuspid valves located in the heart?

biology.term: Blood flow direction (Tricuspid and Bicuspid Valves)
biology.definition: Blood flows first through the tricuspid valve and then through the bicuspid valve.
biology.mnemonic: You learn to ride a tricycle before a bicycle.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.18 How to remember Tricuspid before Bicuspid mnemonic.jpg
biology.question: What is the blood flow direction through the tricuspid and bicuspid valves?

biology.term: Blood flow direction (Tricuspid and Bicuspid Valves)
biology.definition: Blood flows first through the tricuspid valve and then through the bicuspid valve.
biology.mnemonic: Always try before you buy.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.19 Always try before you buy remembrance text.jpg
biology.question: What is the direction of blood flow related to the tricuspid and bicuspid valves?

biology.definition: When the heart muscle relaxes; when blood pressure is at its lowest.
biology.mnemonic: I went on a diet and asked the ice cream man to leave (diastole). My blood pressure lowered as a result. Finally, I could relax.
biology.question: What happens in the heart during diastole?

biology.definition: When the heart muscle contracts, forcing blood out through the arteries.
biology.mnemonic: A nun gives a sisterly (systole) hug to an orphaned kid then tickles (ventricles) him and squeezes him tightly (contract).
biology.question: What happens during systole in the heart?

biology.definition: Blood pressure is given as two numbers: the systolic pressure (when the heart's ventricles contract) over the diastolic pressure (when the ventricles relax).
biology.mnemonic: Remember blood pressure as the red numbers: systolic (maximum pressure) over diastolic (lowest pressure).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.1.23 Systolic and Diostolic blood pressure ratio diagram.jpg
biology.question: What is blood pressure?

biology.definition: Kidneys clean the blood (there are two kidneys).
biology.mnemonic: The kid’s knees (kidneys) need cleaning up of blood (clean the blood). Both knees need cleaning (two kidneys).
biology.question: What is the function of the kidneys in the human body?

biology.definition: Relating to the kidneys.
biology.mnemonic: A nurse has just had her fingers re-nailed (renal) when she notices the kid needs (kidneys) help.
biology.question: What does the term "renal" refer to?

biology.definition: Kidneys control salt and water levels.
biology.mnemonic: The nurse uses salt and water to clean up the kid’s knees (kidneys).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.25.3 Kidneys control salt and water memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What is the function of the kidneys in the body?

biology.definition: Kidneys remove urea from the blood.
biology.mnemonic: The nurse tells the boy: “I’ll also have to clean your ear (urea) because it’s been cut in the fall as well.”
biology.question: What function do the kidneys perform in the human body?

biology.definition: Kidneys produce hormones.
biology.mnemonic: The kid had cut his knees when he fell off his horse. The horse moans (hormones) about any jump she has to complete.
biology.question: What function of the kidneys involves hormone production?

biology.definition: The kidneys are about the size of a clenched fist and are located high in the abdominal cavity. The left kidney is slightly higher than the right, which is also slightly smaller and more medially placed to accommodate the liver.
biology.mnemonic: Remember the kidneys like your hands on your lower back: fists for size, and the left is slightly higher.
biology.question: What is the size and position of the kidneys?

biology.definition: The kidneys are made up of two main parts – the outer part, known as the cortex, and the inner part, called the medulla.
biology.mnemonic: The kid who needed a clean-up was wearing a corset (cortex) and a medal (medulla). Note that the medal (medulla) is in the centre of the corset (cortex).
biology.question: What are the two main parts of the kidney?

biology.definition: The recessed part of the kidney where blood enters and leaves via arteries and veins, and waste products leave via the ureter.
biology.mnemonic: When the boy who came off his horse has been cleaned up, he jumps high with his lamb (hilum) over a gateway to show the horse how it’s done.
biology.question: What is the hilum of the kidney?

biology.definition: Tiny filters in the kidneys that clean up the blood by removing everything except blood cells and proteins, then returning useful substances.
biology.mnemonic: The boy kid who needed the clean-up was the nephew (nephron) of the nurse who treated him.
biology.question: What are nephrons?

biology.definition: A condition where kidneys are diseased or damaged, making them less efficient or unable to filter out wastes from the blood.
biology.mnemonic: The kid’s knees (kidneys) were in a terrible state because she had suffered dire beatings (diabetes). She knew she was about to get another beating, which caused her heart to beat strongly (cardiovascular), which in turn gave her high blood pressure.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.26.2 Diabetes and high blood pressure memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What is kidney disease?

biology.definition: Artificial cleaning of blood when kidneys are diseased. It removes waste materials like urea and balances levels of salts, glucose, and water.
biology.mnemonic: Dial-a-sis (dialysis) is a cleaning company run by a pair of nuns (sisters) who specialise in cleaning up the blood at crime scenes.
biology.question: What is dialysis?

biology.definition: The cleaning of blood by a machine, functioning as artificial cleaning of blood, similar to how kidneys clean it but outside the body.
biology.mnemonic: The he man (haemo) always gave blood but he insisted on using his weight training machine at the same time.
biology.question: What is haemodialysis?

biology.definition: Chemical cleaning of blood performed internally using the peritoneum as a filter.
biology.mnemonic: A girl had a pair of toenails (peritoneal) that were so dirty she had to dial her sis (dialysis) for her to come and wash them clean with a chemical solution.
biology.question: What is peritoneal dialysis?

biology.definition: A liquid solution used in dialysis to transfer waste from the patient's blood to the solution.
biology.mnemonic: After the shootout, the first person on the scene decided to dial the state (dialysate) police, who would have a solution to the murders.
biology.question: What is dialysate used for in dialysis?

biology.definition: The part of the cardiovascular system that carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs and returns oxygen-rich blood to the heart.
biology.mnemonic: Everywhere she went, she pulled her money (pulmonary) with her, which made it hard on her lungs.
biology.question: What is the pulmonary system?

biology.definition: The part of the human body between the neck and the diaphragm, containing the heart and lungs and encased by the ribs.
biology.mnemonic: She had Thor’s axe (thorax) in her chest.
biology.question: What is the thorax in the human body?

biology.definition: A group of muscles found in between the ribs, allowing the ribcage to move during ventilation.
biology.mnemonic: The mussel (muscle) is really into costumes (intercostal) and it hangs all its costumes on the ribs.
biology.question: What are intercostal muscles?

biology.definition: The diaphragm is a dome-shaped muscle separating the chest cavity (thorax) and the abdomen. It is involved in the process of breathing.
biology.mnemonic: She grabbed at the diagram (diaphragm) and used it to build a parachute.
biology.question: What is the diaphragm?

biology.definition: The trachea, or windpipe, is a straight tube that allows the passage of air into and out of the lungs via the mouth and nose.
biology.mnemonic: The windpipe blows air along the tracks (trachea).
biology.question: What is the trachea?

biology.definition: The trachea branches into the lungs into smaller air passages from the bronchus to the bronchi to the bronchioles, like a tree.
biology.mnemonic: The tracks (trachea) lead the air into the branches (bronch-).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.22.16 Passage of air through the lungs 1.jpg
biology.question: What does "bronch" refer to in the respiratory system?

biology.definition: A tiny air sac within the lungs where the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place.
biology.mnemonic: All violas (Alveolus) are in a large sack (sac), they had arrived for the chamber orchestra.
biology.question: What is an alveolus in the lungs?

biology.definition: A thin flap of cartilage at the back of the mouth that covers the entrance to the larynx during swallowing.
biology.mnemonic: A pea got (epiglottis) into a flap (flap) when he got stuck in the throat.
biology.question: What is the epiglottis?

biology.definition: The larynx is the part of your throat that contains your vocal chords.
biology.mnemonic: The French ice hockey team stand on La Rink (larynx) and are told by a woman with a loud voice standing on a box (voice box) to “Get off the ice!” so it can be cleaned.
biology.question: What is the larynx?

biology.definition: The Adam’s apple is the laryngeal prominence. It is a cartilage that protrudes at an angle to protect the larynx.
biology.mnemonic: With a large Adam’s apple he could sing ‘La La La’ all day in jail (laryngeal) before they carted him away (cartilage).
biology.question: What is the Adam’s apple?

biology.definition: The white protective layer of the eyeball.
biology.mnemonic: Her skin was as clear as (sclera) Snow White’s.
biology.question: What is the sclera?

biology.definition: A thin, clear mucus membrane that covers the front portion of the sclera, the cornea, and the inside of the eyelids. It provides protection and lubrication for the eye.
biology.mnemonic: The conjurer made a load of junk (conjunctiva) disappear before a well-lubricated audience.
biology.question: What is the conjunctiva?

biology.definition: The cornea is the transparent layer forming the front of the eye, through which light enters.
biology.mnemonic: The corner shop (cornea) has a great big window.
biology.question: What is the cornea?

biology.definition: An aperture, or hole, in the centre of the eye that allows light through to strike the retina. It is clear but looks black because it absorbs light.
biology.mnemonic: The pupils thought there might be a hole in their education.
biology.question: What is the pupil in the context of the human eye?

biology.definition: Light-sensitive cells lining the back of the eye
biology.mnemonic: The president’s retinue (retina) of security guards were sensitive to every movement in the crowd.
biology.question: What is the retina?

biology.definition: Rods are receptor cells most sensitive to light and dark changes, shape, and movement, but not effective at distinguishing colours.
biology.mnemonic: His fishing rods were only used at night.
biology.question: What are rods in the context of vision?

biology.definition: The cones are not as sensitive to light as the rods, but they are most sensitive to colour and are better suited to detecting fine detail in brighter lighting conditions.
biology.mnemonic: Think of a selection of brightly-coloured ice-cream cones.
biology.question: What are cones in the context of vision?

biology.definition: Dilation means becoming wider, or opening up. The eye’s pupil dilates when it opens wider to let in more light, occurring in darker or dimly lit conditions.
biology.mnemonic: She dialled late (dilate) in the evening to see if the takeaway was still open.
biology.question: What happens to the eye's pupil in darker or dimly lit conditions?

biology.definition: Reduction or increase in the size of the pupil in response to increased or reduced light intensity.
biology.mnemonic: The school pupil’s reflection (pupil reflex) in the mirrors changed in size.
biology.question: What is the pupil reflex?

biology.definition: Pairs of opposing muscles in the iris that control the size of the pupil: the circular and radial muscle layers.
biology.mnemonic: The two mussels (muscles) were antagonistic towards the pupil, first stretching him, then squeezing him to a pinpoint.
biology.question: What are antagonistic muscles in the iris?

biology.definition: Ciliary muscles are focusing muscles that change the shape of the lens. Suspensory ligaments are connectors that join ciliary muscle to the lens.
biology.mnemonic: The silly muscle man (ciliary muscles) was wearing suspenders (suspensory ligaments) and admiring himself so much he hadn’t noticed he’d stood on his glasses’ lenses (lens) and broken them.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.29.33 Ciliary muscles and suspensory ligaments memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What are the ciliary muscles and suspensory ligaments in the eye?

biology.definition: Animals that are preyed upon such as horses, fish, and many birds have monocular vision, with one eye on each side of their head. This gives a wider field of view for spotting predators but poor depth perception.
biology.mnemonic: The horse always wore the monocle (monocular vision) on one side of her face.
biology.question: What is monocular vision?

biology.definition: Humans and some other predatory animals have two forward-facing eyes located side-by-side. This allows for stereoscopic vision, making what we see more three-dimensional and gives better perception of distance.
biology.mnemonic: The binoculars (binocular vision) gave the wolf excellent forward vision of the sheep.
biology.question: What is binocular vision?

biology.definition: Long-sighted people can see long distances.
biology.mnemonic: Long-sighted people can see the long queue of traffic stretching into the distance.
biology.question: What is long-sighted vision?

biology.definition: Short-sighted people can see short distances.
biology.mnemonic: A short-sighted eye can see the shortbread.
biology.question: What does it mean to be short-sighted?

biology.definition: Photosynthesis occurs in green plants and is the conversion of carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen in the presence of chlorophyll and light.
biology.mnemonic: Cows Eat Wet Grass Outside. (Carbon dioxide + Energy + Water = Glucose + Oxygen)
biology.question: What happens during photosynthesis in plants?

biology.definition: A process where plants use light energy, carbon dioxide, and water to produce glucose and oxygen.
biology.mnemonic: After the photographer photos this cow (photosynthesis) she collects the poo to make glue (glucose). The photographer makes glue (glucose).
biology.question: What is photosynthesis?

biology.definition: Respiration uses glucose to create energy for muscles to move in animals and for plant cells to grow. It occurs in mitochondria to produce ATP.
biology.mnemonic: In resting after perspiring (respiration) at the gym, there is only one thing to do and that is to have a big drink of glucose to replenish the energy used.
biology.question: What is the process of respiration?

biology.definition: The molecular formula for glucose is C6H12O6.
biology.mnemonic: The glue caused (glucose) problems for the Cabbie (C6) as the Hippopotamus (H12) got stuck and they couldn’t even get her out using an Oilcan (O6).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.10.6 Graphic to remember the glucose formula 1.jpg
biology.question: What is the molecular formula for glucose?

biology.definition: Respiration with oxygen, converting glucose into carbon dioxide, energy (ATP), and water.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine an heir to the throne wearing robes being taken quickly (aerobic) through his fields on an ox (with oxygen).
biology.question: What is aerobic respiration?

biology.definition: Respiration without oxygen, converting glucose into carbon dioxide, energy (ATP), and ethanol.
biology.mnemonic: The anaconda wrapped itself in rows. It would be a quick (anaerobic) death for the ox without oxygen.
biology.question: What is anaerobic respiration?

biology.definition: Anaerobic respiration in yeast used to make bread and alcoholic drinks, producing carbon dioxide and ethanol.
biology.mnemonic: Fermentation is used to make bread. The carbon dioxide released in respiration of yeast is used by bakers to make bread rise. The ethanol is evaporated away.
biology.question: What is fermentation?

biology.definition: Anaerobic respiration in yeast used to make alcoholic drinks, producing carbon dioxide and ethanol.
biology.mnemonic: The ethanol released in anaerobic respiration from yeast is used to provide the ethanol in alcohol content drinks such as beer and wine.
biology.question: What process is used by yeast in anaerobic respiration to produce alcoholic drinks?

biology.definition: Anaerobic respiration
biology.mnemonic: That fur was meant for my latest creation (fermentation) but now the anaconda has gone and wrapped the bear in rows of coils and it will be a quick (anaerobic) death.
biology.question: What is fermentation?

biology.definition: 'With oxygen' - Aerobic respiration uses oxygen and glucose to create energy in the form of ATP molecules.
biology.mnemonic: Imagine an heir to the throne wearing robes being taken quickly (aerobic) through his fields on an ox (with oxygen).
biology.question: What is aerobic respiration?

biology.definition: Anaerobic respiration does not involve oxygen and occurs when there's insufficient oxygen supply during vigorous exercise. It breaks down glucose into lactic acid and energy (ATP).
biology.mnemonic: The anaconda wrapped itself in rows. It would be a quick (anaerobic) death for the ox without oxygen.
biology.question: What is anaerobic respiration?

biology.definition: The liver is a very important organ responsible for producing bile used in digestion. It regulates chemical levels in the blood and produces bile to help break down fat.
biology.mnemonic: Stand and deliver (the liver) – the highwayman has stolen a lot of money.
biology.question: What is the function of the liver in the human body?

biology.definition: The primary function of the gallbladder is to store and concentrate bile. Bile is released as required into the small intestine to help break up fats in our food.
biology.mnemonic: The Highwayman uses his money to buy all (bile) the tall ladders (gall bladder).
biology.question: What is the primary function of the gallbladder?

biology.definition: A digestive fluid that breaks up fats in the small intestine.
biology.mnemonic: The highwayman’s day job is a painter and decorator and he uses a tall ladder (gall bladder) and emulsion (emulsify – break up fats) on the walls.
biology.question: What is the function of bile in the digestive system?

biology.definition: The process by which bile neutralises the acid from the stomach, providing alkaline conditions needed in the small intestine.
biology.mnemonic: The highwayman is caught whilst painting emulsion and a new trial is set (neutralises) by a seedy (acid) judge.
biology.question: What is the process of neutralisation in the digestive system?

biology.definition: An enzyme that chemically breaks down carbohydrates in the mouth.
biology.mnemonic: An army laser (amylase) team, hanging off the ridges inside the mouth, attack and break down chips (carbohydrates) as they come into the mouth.
biology.question: What role does amylase play in the digestive process?

biology.definition: An enzyme in the stomach that chemically breaks down proteins in an acidic environment.
biology.mnemonic: The protesting teenagers (proteins) won’t get into the fluid because it burns them. All the protesting annoys the life guards and disturbs them drinking pepsi all day (pepsin). So the life guards throw them out.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.23.10 Hydrochloric acid and digestion memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What is the role of the protease enzyme called pepsin in the stomach?

biology.definition: In the small intestine every enzyme is used on all the food; enzymes like amylase, lipase and protease (trypsin) which are all produced in the pancreas. Bile also acts on the food to break it down and to neutralise the stomach acid.
biology.mnemonic: Everything from the pan (pancreas) is mixed together to break food down.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.23.12 Digestion in the small intestines image.jpg
biology.question: How does digestion occur in the small intestine?

biology.definition: Digestion is the breakdown of food into smaller components.
biology.mnemonic: Di Chest (digest) is a famous celebrity with her own clothing brand, especially colourful, dyed blouses which she always wears (hence the name Di Chest). Di Chest gets locked in her gingerbread ranch house one day and can’t get out. In the end she gets so hungry with the need for FOOD that the only way she can get out is to break down the front door.
biology.question: What is digestion?

biology.definition: One of the three main components of food.
biology.mnemonic: She runs down the road, but by the front entrance there are protesting teenagers (proteins) and she doesn’t want to go past them.
biology.question: What are proteins in the context of food?

biology.definition: Proteins consist of long chains of amino acids.
biology.mnemonic: Di Chest sees a farmer with his tractor and trailer full of seeds who finds his way to work blocked – he is a mean old seed farmer (amino acid).
biology.question: What are the building blocks of proteins?

biology.definition: Carbohydrates include starch and sugars which are all saccharides.
biology.mnemonic: Di Chest drives in her posh car to the high gates (carbohydrates) at the rear entrance of her ranch.
biology.question: What are carbohydrates?

biology.definition: Starch is a carbohydrate.
biology.mnemonic: When Di Chest arrives at the high gates she gets out to admire the star arch (starch) over the gates.
biology.question: What type of macromolecule is starch?

biology.definition: Sugar is a carbohydrate.
biology.mnemonic: Near to the rear gate Di Chest feeds her horses sugar.
biology.question: What is sugar classified as in terms of macronutrients?

biology.definition: Carbohydrates – starch and sugars are saccharides.
biology.mnemonic: After this, Di Chest puts a sack on her horse and goes for a ride. We could call it a sack ride (saccharide).
biology.question: What are saccharides, including starch and sugars?

biology.definition: Most saccharides will be turned into glucose in the body.
biology.mnemonic: Unfortunately when Di Chest’s horses can no longer cope with a sack ride (saccharide) some go to the glue factory (glucose).
biology.question: What do most saccharides get converted into in the body?

biology.definition: Another component of food.
biology.mnemonic: Fat Mama lives next door to Di Chest.
biology.question: What is another component of food that is represented by "Fats"?

biology.definition: Fats are lipids.
biology.mnemonic: Fat Mama has big, fat lips (lipids).
biology.question: What are lipids?

biology.definition: Lipids are broken down into fatty acids and glycerol.
biology.mnemonic: Fat Mama loves eating fatty seeds (fatty acids) and glistening rolls (glycerol).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.19.12 Fatty acids and glycerol memory aid.jpg
biology.question: How are lipids broken down?

biology.definition: Protein with biuret added turns purple.
biology.mnemonic: The protesting teenagers (proteins) said: “We’ll buy your eggs” (biuret), but the shop would not sell them any because they would be used for protesting. The protesting teenagers turned purple with rage.
biology.question: What happens to protein when biuret is added?

biology.definition: Add Benedict’s solution and boil. If glucose is present, it turns green (trace amounts), then orange-red (higher concentration).
biology.mnemonic: If glucose is drunk by him, Big Ben predicts (Benedict’s) that the traffic lights at his foot will change to green then orange and red.
biology.question: How can the presence of glucose be tested in a solution?

biology.definition: Add orange-brown iodine; presence of starch changes color to blue-black.
biology.mnemonic: I could see stars (starch) after I was beaten black and blue, just because I dined (iodine) on oranges!
biology.question: What happens when you add iodine to test for starch?

biology.definition: Fats go cloudy white when mixed with ethanol and water.
biology.mnemonic: Fat mama (fats) and her white poodle (ethanol) are in the rain (water) and Fat Mama’s lips (lipids) turn white.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.19.19 Fats mixed with ethanol memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What test result indicates the presence of fats (lipids)?

biology.definition: A liquid containing salts or minerals that conducts electricity.
biology.mnemonic: Think of an electric troll light (electrolyte) swimming under water (liquid). The electric troll light was being used to find an electric cable (conducts electricity) but all it could find was a giant salt pot (salts).
biology.question: What is an electrolyte?

biology.definition: Molecules that have split apart.
biology.mnemonic: This association (dissociation) has split us apart.
biology.question: What does dissociation mean in a chemical context?

biology.definition: The gleaming white part of the tooth that you can see; it is the hardest substance in the body.
biology.mnemonic: She changes into an animal (enamel).
biology.question: What is the enamel on a tooth?

biology.definition: Underneath the layer of enamel lies the yellow dentine, which is harder than bone but not as hard as enamel.
biology.mnemonic: Today this animal happens upon a yellow den for teens (dentine).
biology.question: What lies underneath the enamel in a tooth?

biology.definition: The living centre of the tooth.
biology.mnemonic: The animal tears the teens’ den and pulp fiction into pulp.
biology.question: What is the pulp of a tooth?

biology.definition: The first eight teeth just inside the opening of your mouth: four on the top and four on the bottom.
biology.mnemonic: Just inside a (incisor) cave mouth a woman stopped and ate (8) a meal of fruit.
biology.question: What are incisors?

biology.definition: The canine teeth are the four pointy teeth that sit alongside the incisors, often called the vampire teeth.
biology.mnemonic: Four dogs from the canine world suddenly gathered around her. They were all snarling with vampire teeth. It was their cave.
biology.question: What are the canine teeth?

biology.definition: There are 8 premolars before the molars and they adjoin the canine teeth. Two behind each canine.
biology.mnemonic: The dogs chased her off, which left her fruit on the table but they hated fruit so no dog ate (8) the food. This was pre-mould (premolars) before it had gone mouldy.
biology.question: What teeth are located before the molars and adjoin the canine teeth, with two behind each canine?

biology.definition: Molars are the teeth at the back of the mouth, and there are twelve of them.
biology.mnemonic: Twelve months went by and boy was the fruit mouldy (molars).
biology.question: What are the teeth at the back of the mouth called that total twelve in number?

biology.definition: The wisdom teeth are the third molars located at the back of the mouth, appearing between ages 17 to 21.
biology.mnemonic: So when the wise man (wisdom) went into the cave mouth he took a lunch of four (4) fruits as he knew no dogs would steal it.
biology.question: What are wisdom teeth?

biology.definition: A nerve is a bundle of axons (the long, thread-like extensions of neurone cells).
biology.mnemonic: As the dentist entered with a bunch of axes (axons) a nerve was hit and the patient went through the ceiling.
biology.question: What is a nerve?

biology.definition: The nerve that carries visual information from the retina to the vision centers of the brain.
biology.mnemonic: The optic was empty, his nerves and vision were shot and his brain was wasted (the optic nerve carries visual information to the brain).
biology.question: What does the optic nerve do?

biology.definition: The longest individual piece of 'wiring' in the human body, with its axon going from the base of the spine to the big toe, around one metre long.
biology.mnemonic: So that they could do their science in the attic (sciatic), the amateur boffins had to take a long wire from downstairs right up to their nerve centre of computers.
biology.question: What is the longest nerve in the human body, extending from the spine to the big toe?

biology.definition: Neurones are the body’s messengers – specialised cells that transmit signals around the body. They are made up of dendrites, the cell body (also known as the soma), the axon and the axon terminal.
biology.mnemonic: The keep-fit fanatic planned a new run (neurone): she came out of her flat, straight past the lion’s den on the right (dendrite). The lions told her where to go next to where they sell bodies (cell body) with axes (axons) in their hand. They cost a lot of money at the cash terminal (axon terminal).
biology.question: What are neurons/neurones?

biology.definition: Nerve cells that control muscles and glands, carrying signals from the CNS to effectors.
biology.mnemonic: The keep-fit fanatic bought a new bodyguard who drove her motor (motor neurone) alongside her, shouting messages from her muscle car (muscle control) for her to run faster.
biology.question: What are motor neurones?

biology.definition: Cells that carry signals from sense organ receptors to the central nervous system.
biology.mnemonic: Sensory man (sensory neurone) was working in a hotel, taking messages from the reception (receptors) desk.
biology.question: What are sensory neurones responsible for?

biology.definition: Neurons that carry messages around the CNS, connecting sensory and motor neurones.
biology.mnemonic: A relay (relay neurone) runner ran between Sensory Man (sensory neurone) and the motor (motor neurone).
biology.question: What are relay neurones used for within the CNS?

biology.definition: Long, thread-like extensions of neurones that conduct electrical impulses.
biology.mnemonic: There was an axe on (axon) stage conducting an electric guitar orchestra. There were cables everywhere.
biology.question: What is an axon?

biology.definition: Axon terminals transmit chemicals from one neuron to another. Positioned at the opposite end of the neuron to the dendrites.
biology.mnemonic: When an axe goes through a terminal (axon terminal) it transmits a signal and sounds an alarm to check that the buyer is over 18 years old.
biology.question: What is the function of an axon terminal in a neuron?

biology.definition: Dendrites form the branched ‘reception area’ of a neurone. They receive stimulation and conduct electrical messages to the neurone cell body.
biology.mnemonic: The den on the right (dendrite) had a clever lion in it – sitting at a desk, working as a receptionist (reception area).
biology.question: What are dendrites in the context of a neurone?

biology.definition: An impulse is an electrical signal that travels along the axon of a neuron.
biology.mnemonic: The imp that pulsated (impulse) red and green every minute was used instead of the normal electrical signal while the traffic light was repaired.
biology.question: What is an impulse in the context of neuroscience?

biology.definition: A fatty white sheath around the axons that provides electrical insulation and protection, helping to increase the speed of impulses.
biology.mnemonic: My violin (myelin) had to be played in a well-insulated room.
biology.question: What is the myelin sheath?

biology.definition: A group of cells that detect changes in the environment (stimuli) and turn them into electrical impulses, located in sense organs such as the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin.
biology.mnemonic: The Sensory Man (sensory neurone) working in reception (receptors) could sense the changes in the environment as he worked near the door.
biology.question: What are sense organ receptors?

biology.definition: The body's electrical wiring and control system, including both the central and peripheral nervous systems.
biology.mnemonic: The disposal expert was nervous about cutting the system (nervous system) of electrical wiring on the bomb. Was it the red or blue wire which controlled (control system) the bomb?
biology.question: What is the nervous system?

biology.definition: The complex of nerve tissues in the brain and the spinal cord.
biology.mnemonic: The brains and spinal cords were heading for Central (central nervous system) Park.
biology.question: What makes up the central nervous system (CNS)?

biology.definition: Parts of the body that produce a response to signals carried by nerve cells, such as a muscle contracting to move an arm or a gland contracting to release a hormone into the blood.
biology.mnemonic: Her muscles gave off sound effects (effectors).
biology.question: What are effectors in the body?

biology.definition: A response is any action performed by an effector arising from a signal from the nervous system.
biology.mnemonic: The Rapid Response vehicle was drive by Action Man.
biology.question: What is a response in the context of the nervous system?

biology.definition: A near-instantaneous response to a stimulus that does not involve the brain.
biology.mnemonic: The reflection (reflex action) in the mirror did not involve the brain.
biology.question: What is a reflex action?

biology.definition: The 'short-cut' route taken by the signal for a reflex action, which leaves out the brain. It is the nerve pathway involved in a reflex action.
biology.mnemonic: The sun reflects off the ark (reflex arc) and goes straight to the mussel (muscle).
biology.question: What is a reflex arc?

biology.definition: An action initiated in the cerebral cortex of the brain; a deliberate, conscious action such as standing up or walking.
biology.mnemonic: After some thought, the young men raised their arms to volunteer for action (voluntary action). They had deliberated (deliberate) the risks and were fully conscious of what they were doing.
biology.question: What is a voluntary action?

biology.definition: Gaps in an axon’s insulating sheath of myelin which help speed up the signal sent along the axon.
biology.mnemonic: Loads of reindeer (nodes of Ranvier) when they were young were made to jump a gap full of axes (axons) to see if they would eventually be good enough to be Santa reindeer.
biology.question: What are the nodes of Ranvier?

biology.definition: The synapse is the minuscule gap between the axon terminal and the dendrite of the next neuron, where impulses cross by diffusion of a neurotransmitter.
biology.mnemonic: There’s a sigh as she naps (synapse) between the gap.
biology.question: What is the synapse?

biology.definition: Chemical messengers that transmit signals across synapses, from one neurone to another.
biology.mnemonic: The new row of transmitters (neurotransmitters) all had chemical messages on them.
biology.question: What is a neurotransmitter?

biology.definition: A tiny sac or pouch that releases neurotransmitters to carry messages across the synapse between neurons.
biology.mnemonic: A sailor sighs as she naps on a vessel (synaptic vesicle) and is told she’s being sacked (sac) for sleeping when she should have been on duty.
biology.question: What is a synaptic vesicle?

biology.definition: Receptor molecules in the membrane of a neurone that bind with chemicals diffusing across the gap from the previous neurone to create an electrical impulse.
biology.mnemonic: The reception moll (receptor molecule) had a chemical reaction with a visitor from outside.
biology.question: What are receptor molecules in the context of neurons?

biology.definition: The part of the nervous system responsible for carrying motor and sensory information to and from the central nervous system. It is made up of nerves that connect to the sensory organs and all skeletal muscles, responsible for nearly all voluntary muscle movements and processing sensory information.
biology.mnemonic: The woman was so-minded (somatic) to volunteer (voluntary) as a helper in the soup kitchen.
biology.question: What is the somatic system responsible for?

biology.definition: Part of the nervous system that controls internal organs and body functions without conscious input.
biology.mnemonic: Her automatic (autonomic) response to the cold weather was to shiver violently.
biology.question: What is the autonomic system responsible for?

biology.definition: Where an organism lives.
biology.mnemonic: A plaice (place) tries on a nun’s habit (habitat).
biology.question: What is a habitat?

biology.definition: All the plants and animals living in a habitat.
biology.mnemonic: The commute (community) started by taking all the plants and animals from one place.
biology.question: What is a community in ecology?

biology.definition: The study of a community in their natural habitat
biology.mnemonic: The eco warrior showed the community how their recycling habits (habitat) could be improved.
biology.question: What is ecology?

biology.definition: Everything surrounding an organism that can affect it, such as light, air, soil, water, etc.
biology.mnemonic: Environment = Env IRON ment. Change the way you say environment in your mind to Env Iron Ment to remember it.
biology.question: What does the term "environment" encompass?

biology.definition: Individual influences that surround an organism which may affect it.
biology.mnemonic: Factories (Factors) sneezing with influenza (influences).
biology.question: What are environmental factors?

biology.definition: An organism which kills and consumes animals to obtain energy.
biology.mnemonic: The one who is praying (prey) is the victim. The other must therefore be the predator and thus the killer.
biology.question: What is a predator?

biology.definition: An animal which is hunted for food by other animals.
biology.mnemonic: The one who is praying (prey) is the victim. The other must therefore be the predator and thus the killer.
biology.question: What is a prey?

biology.definition: An organism which consumes dead animals to obtain energy.
biology.mnemonic: The vulture didn’t want to pay for a scarf, but the scarf vendor (scavenger) said “over my dead body (corpse) am I giving these away”.
biology.question: What is a scavenger?

biology.definition: An animal that only eats plants.
biology.mnemonic: The herd of four (herbivore) cows only eat plants; they are not even tempted by all the other food around.
biology.question: What is a herbivore?

biology.definition: An animal that eats only meat.
biology.mnemonic: The car was a voracious (carnivore) eater of animals.
biology.question: What is a carnivore?

biology.definition: Area defended/protected by an individual or group of animals.
biology.mnemonic: The terrier (territory) defended the penalty area.
biology.question: What is a territory in the context of animal behavior?

biology.definition: Group of individuals from one species within a habitat.
biology.mnemonic: The pop (population) group were made of one sort (one species) of cola.
biology.question: What is a population in ecological terms?

biology.definition: Long-term weather, typical weather
biology.mnemonic: The climber's mate (climate) wouldn’t go up the mountain with her because of the weather.
biology.question: What is the term for long-term weather patterns?

biology.definition: Organism that eats both plants and animals
biology.mnemonic: Omm, omm, omm (omnivore) was the noise coming from the huge mouth as it ate its way through everything.
biology.question: What is an omnivore?

biology.definition: Decomposers are organisms such as bacteria and fungi that extract their energy from dead plant and animal matter using biochemical reactions without the need for any internal digestion.
biology.mnemonic: The composer (decomposer) selected what fish he wanted to eat in the restaurant, but he always chose the dead fish no matter what the waiter advised him.
biology.question: What is a decomposer?

biology.definition: Man-made influences on other living things, eg farming, building activity or pollution
biology.mnemonic: The cult sure (culture) was mad when they discovered their stone commandment tablets were actually man made and not sent by god.
biology.question: What does "Culture – Man-made" refer to in terms of its impact on living things?

biology.definition: between
biology.mnemonic: They were about to be interred (inter) but there were many people between the coffins, trying to pay their respects.
biology.question: What does the prefix "inter" mean?

biology.definition: Intra – within.
biology.mnemonic: The in-tray (Intra) only had one piece of paper within the tray.
biology.question: What does "intra" mean?

biology.definition: This is competition between individuals of different species.
biology.mnemonic: Interspecific contains 'er' in the middle, as does ‘different’. So interspecific competition is different species in competition.
biology.question: What is interspecific competition?

biology.definition: Competition within the same species.
biology.mnemonic: Intraspecific contains the letter a in the middle of it, as does ‘same’.
biology.question: What is intraspecific competition?

biology.definition: Sequence of feeding in an ecosystem.
biology.mnemonic: The food is chained (food chain) in the sequence in which it’s eaten – linked together like a chain.
biology.question: What is a food chain?

biology.definition: Primary means first.
biology.mnemonic: Primary school is your first school.
biology.question: What does primary mean?

biology.definition: Primary consumers are the first organisms to consume another in an ecosystem.
biology.mnemonic: My first primary school teacher was a caterpillar.
biology.question: What is a primary consumer?

biology.definition: Secondary means second.
biology.mnemonic: Secondary school was my second school.
biology.question: What does secondary mean?

biology.definition: Tertiary means third.
biology.mnemonic: The turtle fairy (tertiary) couldn’t stop jumping on the three piece suite.
biology.question: What does the term "tertiary" mean?

biology.definition: The organism that eats (consumes) the secondary consumer.
biology.mnemonic: The turtle fairy (tertiary) jumping on the three seater sofa wasn’t aware that every time it jumped it attracted a hawk that swept down to grab him.
biology.question: What is a tertiary consumer?

biology.definition: In biology, 'trophic' refers to nutrition and feeding.
biology.mnemonic: The trophy (trophic) was made out of peoples favourite foods.
biology.question: What does the term "trophic" refer to in biology?

biology.definition: The interactions of two species affecting the evolution of both.
biology.mnemonic: The cog revolution (co-evolution) of one cog affects the revolution of another cog.
biology.question: What is co-evolution?

biology.definition: Relationship where one species benefits but the other appears unaffected.
biology.mnemonic: They commenced a listen to a silent disco to see how it would benefit one species but leave everything else unaffected by noise.
biology.question: What is commensalism?

biology.definition: Role and position a species has in the ecosystem and environment.
biology.mnemonic: A nice quiche (niche) rolled off the table to take pole position on the starting grid.
biology.question: What is a niche in an ecosystem?

biology.definition: Something that can prevent/restrict population growth.
biology.mnemonic: Limit factories (limiting factors) was the chant from protestors who wanted to restrict production of pop (population).
biology.question: What are limiting factors in ecology?

biology.definition: Relationship where both species benefit.
biology.mnemonic: The relationship counsellor had to mute (mutualism) both sides so they could benefit from hearing her advice without being interrupted.
biology.question: What is mutualism?

biology.definition: In biology, bio means life or living.
biology.mnemonic: The Biro (bio) pen suddenly came into life.
biology.question: What does "bio" mean in biology?

biology.definition: Biotic factors are actions of living things which influence others.
biology.mnemonic: The bachelor decided to buy a tick (biotic) as the central art piece to go in the middle of his living room to impress other (influence others) people when they visited.
biology.question: What are biotic factors?

biology.definition: Non-living influences such as temperature, moisture, light, pollution, etc.
biology.mnemonic: The letter ‘A’ tied in a knot (not) of rope will help you remember.
biology.question: What are abiotic factors in an ecosystem?

biology.definition: The total mass of an organism multiplied by the number of that organism in a trophic level.
biology.mnemonic: Biomass means the mass of life.
biology.question: What is biomass?

biology.definition: A biome is a major ecosystem. Examples include coral reefs, rainforests, deserts, arctic tundra, and savanna grasslands.
biology.mnemonic: Buying a home (biome) meant a big decision for the major as he had to decide in what ecosystem he wanted to live.
biology.question: What is a biome?

biology.definition: All ecosystems together make up the biosphere.
biology.mnemonic: Buy a sphere! A giant spherical piece of artwork that shows all the ecosystems of the world, yelled the major.
biology.question: What encompasses all ecosystems on Earth?

biology.definition: Number of species in an ecosystem; the measure of diversity within an ecosystem.
biology.mnemonic: Bio means life or living, biodiversity is the life or living diversity.
biology.question: What does biodiversity refer to in an ecosystem?

biology.definition: The number of offspring produced per 1000 of the population each year.
biology.mnemonic: The photocopier reproduced (reproduction rate) thousands of baby (offspring) pictures for a calendar each year.
biology.question: What does the term "reproduction rate" refer to?

biology.definition: Physical features of an organism’s anatomy that help it survive and reproduce.
biology.mnemonic: Put a hat on me (anatomical), said the adaptor (adaptation), it will be a big advantage and keep me warm in the Arctic weather.
biology.question: What are anatomical adaptations?

biology.definition: Change in the base sequence of DNA that can be passed on (inherited).
biology.mnemonic: The mute (mutation) girl enjoyed base jumping (DNA base) but liked to change where she jumped from all the time.
biology.question: What is a mutation?

biology.definition: Physical features of an organism’s anatomy that help it survive and reproduce.
biology.mnemonic: Put a hat on me (anatomical), said the adaptor (adaptation), it will be a big advantage and keep me warm in the Arctic weather.
biology.question: What are anatomical adaptations?

biology.definition: The probability of an organism surviving and reproducing within its environment.
biology.mnemonic: A tailor fits Nessie (fitness) for a new suit (suitability).
biology.question: What does fitness refer to in biology?

biology.definition: Physical differences between individuals of the same species caused by environmental factors, not hereditary.
biology.mnemonic: She acquired (bought) lots of cartoon characters after giving birth to decorate the baby’s room.
biology.question: What are acquired characteristics?

biology.definition: Organisms with adaptations that enable them to survive in a range of different habitats.
biology.mnemonic: The general listed (generalist) the many places (many habitats) he had lived in.
biology.question: What are generalists?

biology.definition: Organisms with highly adapted features to survive in a specific habitat.
biology.mnemonic: At the restaurant the chef brought out a specials list (specialist). On that list was only one thing.
biology.question: What are specialists in the context of ecology?

biology.definition: Organisms adapted to live in environments with severe conditions, like super-hot volcanic vents.
biology.mnemonic: A stream of files (extremophiles) were living in a volcanic stream (live in extreme environments) of lava.
biology.question: What are extremophiles?

biology.definition: Not naturally occurring, man-made.
biology.mnemonic: The man made himself a new artificial leg so he could run faster.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.21.30 Artificial man made factors memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What does the term "artificial" mean?

biology.definition: Process by which humans select individuals from a population with desirable characteristics to breed together in order to increase the characteristics’ prevalence within the population.
biology.mnemonic: The art gallery officially (artificial) selected (selection) a man made of bread (bred) as their star attraction at the new exhibit.
biology.question: What is artificial selection?

biology.definition: Process by which organisms with adaptations that are more suited to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
biology.mnemonic: In nature’s election (natural selection) the best candidate wins.
biology.question: What is natural selection?

biology.definition: A pictorial genetic diagram in a grid form used to illustrate the basic rules of heredity.
biology.mnemonic: He punted (Punnett) the ball into the gridiron (grid).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.18.23 Memory aid of a punnett square.jpg
biology.question: What is a Punnett square?

biology.definition: In biology, 'homo' can mean the same in genetics (from Greek) or man (from Latin, used in binomial nomenclature).
biology.mnemonic: When you think of homo, think of two homosexual men that have fallen in love. Homo- the same.
biology.question: What does the term "Homo" mean in biology?

biology.definition: Hetero means different in biology.
biology.mnemonic: Two het up rowers (hetero) in the same boat wanting to row in different directions.
biology.question: What does "hetero" mean in biology?

biology.definition: -zygous (pronounced zeye-guss) refers to the pairing of alleles (letters) in genetic terms: homozygous means two of the same alleles, and heterozygous means two different alleles.
biology.mnemonic: The gust (-zygous) of wind blew away two letters.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.18.29 Zygous is a pairing of chromosomes.jpg
biology.question: What does the term "zygos" refer to in genetics?

biology.definition: Gametes are the sex cells that fuse together during fertilisation in sexual reproduction. Female gametes are called ova or eggs, and male gametes are sperm or pollen.
biology.mnemonic: A sperm whale and an egg take on a goat at a game of cards. They love gambling and place an opening gambit (gamete). The whale has pulled on (pollen) mitts and the egg is oval (ova) shaped.
biology.question: What are gametes?

biology.definition: Fertilisation or sexual reproduction occurs when the female (egg) and male (sperm or pollen nucleus) gametes fuse together.
biology.mnemonic: The sperm whale and egg refuse (fuse) to fold and go all in as the goat raises the stakes.
biology.question: What happens during fertilisation?

biology.definition: When a sperm and an egg meet and fuse together they form a cell called a zygote.
biology.mnemonic: The sperm whale and the egg sigh as the goat (zygote) turns over her cards revealing a winning hand.
biology.question: What forms when a sperm and an egg meet and fuse together?

biology.definition: Mitosis is a type of cell division that produces two new cells that are identical to each other and to the parent cell. It is used for growth, repair of damaged tissue, and replacement of old cells.
biology.mnemonic: My toesies (mitosis) are all the same size on two identical feet (two identical cells).
biology.question: What is mitosis?

biology.definition: When gametes are formed by meiosis, four cells are produced from the original cell. Each gamete cell contains half the number of chromosomes as a normal cell.
biology.mnemonic: When my old sis (meiosis) walks on all fours (produces 4 gamete cells), she is half my height (half the number of chromosomes).
biology.question: What happens during meiosis in relation to gamete formation?

biology.definition: Di means two; indicates there are two sets of chromosomes.
biology.mnemonic: Think of a dyed (di) pair (two) of brightly coloured shoes (shoe = two)
biology.question: What does the term diploid mean in genetics?

biology.definition: Ha means half; indicates one set of chromosomes.
biology.mnemonic: Ha is short for half.
biology.question: What does haploid refer to?

biology.definition: A human diploid cell contains 46 chromosomes, one set of 23 from the mother and another set of 23 from the father. Two sets in all.
biology.mnemonic: Always deploy (diploid) two sets of chrome (two sets of chromosomes) dumbbells; one for you, one for your mate.
biology.question: What does "diploid" refer to in terms of human cell chromosome numbers?

biology.definition: DNA stands for deoxyribonucleic acid
biology.mnemonic: The Ox (De-oxy) rides on (ribo) nuclear acid (nucleic acid) rain.
biology.question: What does DNA stand for?

biology.definition: DNA has a double helix structure. Sections of DNA called genes control the development of characteristics such as height, eye color, and hair color.
biology.mnemonic: DNA's double helix looks like a twisted ladder with rungs.
biology.question: What is the structure of DNA and its role in controlling characteristics like height and eye color?

biology.definition: Each nucleotide contains three parts: a phosphate, a sugar, and a base. They form the structure of DNA.
biology.mnemonic: Nucleotides make up DNA's structure like rungs on a ladder.
biology.question: What are the building blocks of DNA that each contain a phosphate, a sugar, and a base?

biology.definition: The DNA bases are cytosine, adenine, guanine, and thymine
biology.mnemonic: Base jumping is great but choose a site (cytosine) carefully. Make sure you don’t have to jump over an adder (adenine) like this base jumper. She chose her site so badly she landed in guano (guanine). In guano right up to her thighs (thymine).
biology.question: What are the bases of DNA?

biology.definition: Co-discoverer of DNA's double helix structure.
biology.mnemonic: A jam doughnut being spin-bowled by Dr Watson at Dr Frankenstein’s cricket playing monster. As the doughnut spins away it creates a double helix in the air.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.12.19 Francis Crick discovered the double helix.jpg
biology.question: Who was Francis Crick?

biology.definition: Co-discoverer of DNA's double helix and helped establish the human genome project.
biology.mnemonic: Eventually James Watson gave his jam doughnut to a garden gnome (genome).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.12.20 James watson established the human genome project.jpg
biology.question: Who is James Watson?

biology.definition: Females have two X chromosomes.
biology.mnemonic: Two female cheerleaders stood in an X position with pom-poms.
biology.question: What are the female sex chromosomes?

biology.definition: Males have an X and Y chromosome.
biology.mnemonic: Leonardo Da Vinci’s 'Proportions of Man' or 'Vitruvian Man' stood in an X pose wearing Y-fronts.
biology.question: What is the composition of male sex chromosomes?

biology.definition: An inherited disease affecting the shape of blood cells, making them sickle-shaped and reducing their ability to carry oxygen.
biology.mnemonic: The sick cell red blood cell is sickle shaped.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.16.3 Various veiws of a normal and sickle red blood cell.jpg
biology.question: What is sickle cell anaemia?

biology.definition: A brain disease causing mental deterioration with symptoms like shaking, memory loss, and mood swings, caused by a dominant allele.
biology.mnemonic: Hunting a brain.
biology.question: What is Huntington’s disease?

biology.definition: A segment of DNA which codes for the production of a specific trait such as eye colour or height.
biology.mnemonic: An orange segment wears jeans (genes).
biology.question: What are genes?

biology.definition: A version of a gene, usually represented by one letter.
biology.mnemonic: An eel (allele) can look like a letter.
biology.question: What is an allele?

biology.definition: The father's and mother's gene segment that defines a characteristic, usually represented by two letters.
biology.mnemonic: The jeans can type (genotype) two letters at once.
biology.question: What does genotype refer to in genetics?

biology.definition: An allele is a variant form of a gene. Dominant alleles override recessive alleles when both are present.
biology.mnemonic: The capital B dominates (dominant) the lower case b, so the lower case b retires to a small recess (recessive).
biology.question: What is the difference between a dominant allele and a recessive allele?

biology.definition: The physical appearance, trait, or characteristic the offspring ends up with. Examples include blue eyes, short fingers, or a long nose.
biology.mnemonic: Feed no typewriter (phenotype) otherwise outcomes a letter.
biology.question: What is a phenotype?

biology.definition: The genome is made up of all the chromosomes, which contain all the genetic information needed to build and develop an organism.
biology.mnemonic: The Genies home (genome) had many chimneys.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.17.1 Genome is home to all genes.jpg
biology.question: What does the genome consist of?

biology.definition: Each chromosome contains one complete strand of DNA.
biology.mnemonic: Many crows made homes (chromosomes) in the chimneys of the genie's home.
biology.question: What do chromosomes contain?

biology.definition: DNA is made of two strands that twist around each other in a double helix structure.
biology.mnemonic: The crows did not like dogs so put up signs saying Dogs Not Allowed (DNA).
biology.question: What structure is characterized by two strands that twist around each other in a double helix?

biology.definition: Genes are an inherited code within a section of DNA that tells a cell how to make a particular protein. Proteins can form enzymes, hormones, and physical structures within the body or a cell.
biology.mnemonic: An orange segment (segment of DNA) wore tight jeans (genes) while walking her dog past the Dogs Not Allowed signs.
biology.question: What are genes?

biology.definition: Made up of a deoxyribose sugar, a phosphate, and a base.
biology.mnemonic: After walking her dog the nuclear tides (nucleotides) at the beach offered the perfect surfing for the orange segment in jeans.
biology.question: What are nucleotides composed of?

biology.definition: The nucleotides that form the DNA strand are made of a phosphate, sugar, and a base.
biology.mnemonic: Fossil mates (phosphate) were also surfing in the nuclear tide, one wave was so big it washed them very high up on the top of a sugar mountain. They thought the quickest way to get down would be to base jump.
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.17.11 Phosphate sugar and base memory aid.jpg
biology.question: What are the building blocks of DNA that consist of a phosphate, sugar, and a base called?

biology.definition: Protein is a long chain of amino acids. Proteins form many things including structural components like muscle, hair, body tissue, and functional components like enzymes, hormones, antibodies, haemoglobin.
biology.mnemonic: Protesting teens (protein) block the path of a mean old seed (amino acids) farmer who has seeds chained together in his trailer.
biology.question: What is the structure of a protein composed of?

biology.definition: A chemical compound containing key elements of nitrogen, carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. Human proteins are made up of 20 different amino acids.
biology.mnemonic: Actually, they were not teens at all, they had just turned 20 (there are 20 amino acids).
biology.question: What is an amino acid?

biology.definition: DNA is split apart and an enzyme helps form messenger RNA (mRNA).
biology.mnemonic: People tried to remove the Dogs Not Allowed (DNA) sign so the sign was held down by a nail – in fact, by Mr Nail (mRNA).
biology.question: What process involves DNA being split apart to form mRNA with the help of an enzyme?

biology.definition: tRNA has 3 permanent bases and an amino acid attached. Ribosomes then use the tRNA to create proteins.
biology.mnemonic: The Tyrannosaurus rex (tRNA) is so big it can play 3 bases at once; a mean old seed (amino acid) farmer was so impressed he stood and watched.
biology.question: What is the role of tRNA in protein synthesis?

biology.definition: mRNA pairs by replacing T bases with U bases.
biology.mnemonic: U follows T in the alphabet. The base pairs are C with G and U with A.
biology.question: How does mRNA pair with DNA?

biology.definition: U stands for Uracil.
biology.mnemonic: You are silly (uracil) if you can’t remember!
biology.question: What does the "U" stand for in RNA?

biology.definition: Diseases caused by pathogens – microorganisms that enter the body and reproduce, spreading easily through direct or indirect contact.
biology.mnemonic: Infectious diseases are easily spread: imagine easily spreading a disease just like you spread butter on bread with a knife.
biology.question: What causes infectious diseases?

biology.definition: Diseases caused by dietary deficiency, meaning the body is deprived of one or more essential vitamins or minerals.
biology.mnemonic: There was a deficiency of food (deficiency disease) on the woman’s plate.
biology.question: What are deficiency diseases?

biology.definition: Genetic diseases are caused by abnormalities in a segment of DNA – your genes.
biology.mnemonic: A gene (jeans) is a segment of DNA. Abnormalities in jeans (genes) cause genetic diseases.
biology.question: What causes genetic diseases?

biology.definition: Physiological diseases are caused by body malfunction.
