biology.mnemonic: Even the club physio’s logical (physiological) approach to the problem couldn’t put right the player’s body malfunction.
biology.question: What causes physiological diseases?

biology.definition: Pathogens are disease-causing microorganisms. They cause infectious diseases.
biology.mnemonic: A path of gin bottles (pathogen) was built over the sea, which was diseased (disease), making a causeway (causing). This allowed a woman in a micro skirt, whose earrings were tiny organs (microorganisms), to walk across the water.
biology.question: What are pathogens?

biology.definition: Two main types of pathogen: Bacteria release toxins, and viruses damage our cells.
biology.mnemonic: The women on the path of gin (pathogen) had a tattoo on her back of a tear (bacteria). Before she could make it across the sea she had to run the gauntlet, “Via us!” (Virus) said the path of gin (pathogen).
biology.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1.27.10 Two main types of pathogen image.jpg
biology.question: What are the two main types of pathogen?

biology.definition: Toxins are poisonous substances released by many types of pathogenic (harmful) bacteria. These toxins are the causes of many different types of disease.
biology.mnemonic: A witch tossed in some poison to make whoever drank the potion feel ill.
biology.question: What are toxins?

definition.Host: An organism that another organism lives in or on.
definition.Parasite: An organism that lives in or on another organism and steals nutrients at the other’s expense.

biology.mnemonic: The air hostess (host) had a flea (parasite) living on her and she said: “You might as well come and live in my home.” But she soon wanted to get rid of him when she found out he was stealing her money (stealing nutrients).
biology.question: What defines the relationship between a host and a parasite?

biology.definition: Transmissible diseases are ones that can be caught by others (passed on to others).
biology.mnemonic: Imagine a radio transmitter (transmissible disease) sending out a series of viruses and bacteria that are easily caught and passed on.
biology.question: What is a transmissible disease?

biology.definition: The body has barriers to prevent pathogens from entering, described as 'pathogen stoppers'.
biology.mnemonic: The path of gin (pathogen) stopped at the Great Barrier Reef (barrier).
biology.question: What are the barriers to disease?

biology.definition: Physical barriers to pathogens, such as nostril hairs, skin, and scabs.
biology.mnemonic: The mechanic (mechanical barriers) fended off pathogens with his skin, nasal hair and scabs.
biology.question: What are mechanical barriers in the context of the human immune system?

biology.definition: Includes stomach acid, mucus in the lungs, and chemicals in tears that kill or block pathogens.
biology.mnemonic: The chemist (chemical barriers) killed off pathogens, brought into her shop by customers, with mucus, tears and stomach acid.
biology.question: What are chemical barriers in the body's defense system?

biology.definition: A slimy substance secreted by animals for lubrication and protection against pollutants and organisms.
biology.mnemonic: A moo cusses (mucus) because it’s stepped into a pool of slime which stops everything getting through the gateway.
biology.question: What is the purpose of mucus in animals?

biology.definition: The immune system comprises the body’s tools for fighting pathogens.
biology.mnemonic: An emu used its system of tools (immune system) to smash up the path of gin (pathogen).
biology.question: What does the immune system do?

biology.definition: White blood cells defend against pathogens.
biology.mnemonic: The white cell (white blood cell) contained the path of gin (pathogen) so it couldn’t do any harm.
biology.question: What is the primary function of white blood cells?

biology.definition: Phagocytes are white blood cells that ingest and absorb foreign matter and dead cells. Lymphocytes produce antibodies and antitoxins.
biology.mnemonic: Two jailers guard the white cell. One jailer has a limp and bad eyesight (lymphocyte), and a pet with an ant’s body (antibody) that wears ant socks (antitoxin). The other jailer is smoking a fag and has bad eyesight (phagocyte).
biology.question: What are phagocytes and lymphocytes?

biology.definition: The action of a phagocyte white blood cell ingesting and absorbing foreign and dead matter.
biology.mnemonic: The jailer who likes a fag on site (phagocyte) sometimes plays with the fire hoses (phagocytoses). Although it looks like he is smoking, it is actually a sweet cigarette and he has already consumed half of it.
biology.question: What is phagocytosis?

biology.definition: An antibody is a protein that latches on to pathogens to make them ineffective. An antitoxin makes a toxin ineffective.
biology.mnemonic: A protesting teen (protein) riding on an ant’s body (antibody) with its ant socks on (antitoxin) fastened the latch on the door and stopped the pathogen and its toxic mate in their tracks.
biology.question: What is the difference between an antibody and an antitoxin?

biology.definition: The antigen is the chemical of a pathogen that tells your body it is being attacked. It is a protein on the surface of the pathogen.
biology.mnemonic: The ant on the gin path (ant on gin – antigen) was warning that it was about to attack.
biology.question: What is an antigen?

biology.definition: Vaccination is artificially acquired immunity that involves introducing a killed, weakened, or partial pathogen into the body to stimulate antibody production.
biology.mnemonic: Vaccination is like faxing the nation – putting a copy of a germ into everyone to prevent them catching a disease.
biology.question: What is vaccination?

biology.definition: After an infection, 'memory' lymphocytes are produced and remain in your body for many years – so you are protected against a pathogen.
biology.mnemonic: An emu with nits, drinking a cup of tea (immunity), has a memory of the time she had her own jailer with a limp and poor eyesight (lymphocyte) who used to pick the nits from her feathers.
biology.question: What is immunity?

biology.definition: Also referred to as acquired active immunity, or just active immunity, this type of immunity is developed after infection by a pathogen.
biology.mnemonic: A choir of emus that have nits and drink tea (acquired immunity) didn’t get the choirmaster’s cold because they’d had that particular variety before, and so were immune.
biology.question: What is acquired immunity?

biology.definition: Short-term immunity provided by antibodies that come from outside the body – from another person or animal.
biology.mnemonic: An emu with nits is passed through a sieve (passive immunity). It only stays there for a short term as it soon leaks out through the holes.
biology.question: What is passive immunity?

biology.definition: Cleanliness to prevent disease.
biology.mnemonic: A high genie (hygiene) was employed at the hospital to ensure every ward was perfectly clean.
biology.question: What is hygiene?

biology.definition: Autoimmunity is when the immune system attacks healthy cells in the body.
biology.mnemonic: The electrically powered auto emu (autoimmunity) attacked its own battery cell and put itself out of action.
biology.question: What is autoimmunity?

biology.definition: An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks and destroys beta cells in the pancreas, which produce insulin.
biology.mnemonic: The auto emu that attacked its own battery has a dyed beak (diabetes) to show that its autoimmune disease is diabetes.
biology.question: What is Type 1 diabetes?

biology.definition: A skin condition that causes redness and irritation as well as thick, flaky, silver-white patches.
biology.question: What is psoriasis?

biology.definition: A drug that kills or prevents the growth of bacteria.
biology.mnemonic: The ant bought her tick (antibiotic) and stood with her back (bacteria) to the wall before being killed by the firing squad.
biology.question: What is an antibiotic?

biology.definition: A condition where the immune system attacks the myelin sheath around axons, slowing or disrupting impulses and affecting muscle use.
biology.mnemonic: I made a mess (MS) of my violin (myelin) practice but my tutor cheered me up with multiple scarlet roses (multiple sclerosis).
biology.question: What happens in Multiple Sclerosis?

physics.definition: Speed is a measure of how fast something is moving and is calculated as distance divided by time.
physics.mnemonic: Speed cameras get dirty (distance) over time.
physics.question: What is speed?

physics.definition: A change in velocity. It depends on how quickly its velocity/speed changes. Units are usually metres per second per second (m/s/s) or metres per second squared (m/s²).
physics.mnemonic: Accelerator pedal to the floor changes speed to stay on time.
physics.question: What is acceleration?

physics.definition: Force must be applied to an object to alter its speed or change its direction of movement. It is calculated using the formula Force = mass x acceleration. Force is measured in Newtons (N).
physics.mnemonic: Force the mammoth (mass) away (acceleration) but she just lifted me up by the nose (Newton).
physics.question: What is force and how is it calculated?

physics.definition: Pressure is a continual force applied on or against an object's surface by something in contact with it.
physics.mnemonic: The pressure washer forced water over a wide area.
physics.question: What is pressure?

physics.definition: The standard unit of pressure in the International System of Units (SI), equal to one newton per square meter.
physics.mnemonic: The personal assistant (Pa) sprayed her Pa (Pa) with the pressure washer because he accidentally got in the way.
physics.question: What is the standard unit of pressure in the International System of Units (SI) named after Blaise Pascal?

physics.definition: Work done is a measure of what is required to move an object over a distance. It is equal to the energy transferred to the object in order to move it.
physics.mnemonic: Work makes me MAD (mass x acceleration x distance)
physics.question: What is work done?

physics.definition: The energy possessed by an object due to its position in a gravitational field, calculated as mass x gravitational field strength x height moved. GP=mgh
physics.mnemonic: Gold plate even my grand house.
physics.question: What is gravitational potential energy?

physics.definition: Gravitational potential energy is measured in Joules (J).
physics.mnemonic: Everything was gold plated but my jewels.
physics.question: What is the unit for measuring gravitational potential energy?

physics.definition: The speed (velocity) at which a wave is travelling.
physics.mnemonic: Speeding along she frequently (frequency) waved at length.
physics.question: What is wave speed?

physics.definition: Electrical current within a circuit is the flow of electrical charge over time. The formula for calculating electrical charge is Q = It, where Q is charge, I is current, and t is time.
physics.mnemonic: A bull charges into the IT department.
physics.question: What is the formula for calculating electrical charge in a circuit?

physics.definition: Coulombs is the unit of electrical charge.
physics.mnemonic: The bull charges into columns (Coulombs) of computers.
physics.question: What is the unit of electrical charge?

physics.definition: Voltage is the electrical pressure within a circuit that causes current to flow. It is measured in volts, and 1 volt = 1 joule per coulomb. Voltage = IR
physics.mnemonic: Vault (volt) into an Indian (I – current) Restaurant (R – Resistance).
physics.question: What is voltage in an electrical circuit?

physics.definition: The rate at which electrical energy is transferred in a circuit, or the rate at which energy is consumed by an item in a circuit. E=VI
physics.mnemonic: Electrical power turned me into the village idiot.
physics.question: What does electrical power refer to in a circuit?

physics.definition: Power is the measure of how much work is done (the distance an object is moved multiplied by the force required to do so) in a given time.
physics.mnemonic: The Power lifter worked the weights to the top but it took over 3 minutes. Alternatively, the Power lifter worked out in the gym over time to build his physique.
physics.question: What is power in terms of work and time?

physics.definition: Energy needed for work in an electrical circuit, calculated as Electrical energy = voltage x current x time.
physics.mnemonic: No energy? You need vitamins! (VIt)
physics.question: What is electrical energy?

physics.definition: Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by a moving object.
physics.mnemonic: Kin had good etiquette (kinetic energy) by always leaving half the mash and vegetables for a square man.
physics.question: What is kinetic energy?

physics.definition: Weight is the result of gravity on an object's mass and is calculated as mass multiplied by acceleration due to gravity.
physics.mnemonic: Weight of a massive gun (weight = mg) held by a newt (units in Newtons).
physics.question: What is weight in terms of physics?

physics.definition: Weight is a force measured by the pull of gravity on an object and is measured in Newtons.
physics.mnemonic: The newt weighed a ton (weight is in Newtons).
physics.question: What is weight?

physics.definition: Mass is the amount of matter in an object. Mass is measured in kilograms (KG).
physics.mnemonic: At mass, the Killer Granny (mass in KG) took the sermon.
physics.question: What is mass?

physics.definition: Density is a measure of how tightly packed the molecules of a solid, liquid, or gas are. It is calculated as mass divided by volume.
physics.mnemonic: The dense city (density) was so dense they built motorways over any vegetation.
physics.question: What is density?

physics.definition: Density is defined as mass divided by volume.
physics.mnemonic: Another way to remember the formula for density is to recall that it's 'dense to love'. The m forms the top of the heart, and the V forms the bottom of the heart.
physics.question: What is the formula for density?

physics.definition: The Combined Gas Law is an equation that combines Boyle's, Charles', and Gay-Lussac's laws, represented as (P1V1)/T1 = (P2V2)/T2.
physics.mnemonic: Potato and Vegetable on top of Table
physics.question: What is the Combined Gas Law?

physics.definition: Boyles, Charles, and Gay Lussac's laws each relate to the formula (P1 * V1) / T1 = (P2 * V2) / T2, with each having a different constant.
physics.mnemonic: Boy, That Charles Picks Gay Videos!
physics.question: What are the Gas Law Constants?

physics.definition: temperature remains constant
physics.mnemonic: Once you start boiling a liquid the temperature remains constant.
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Gas laws/boyles law - beaker liquid to vapour 2 .jpg
physics.question: What condition does Boyle's law require to remain constant?

physics.definition: Pressure remains constant
physics.mnemonic: Prince Charles is under pressure all the time but must remain constantly in control.
physics.question: What remains constant in Charles' law?

physics.definition: A concept in physics where a big tank of water is used as an analogy for a battery, with a pipe representing the wiring and a reduction in the pipe's size representing resistance.
physics.mnemonic: Think of a big tank of water as the battery, and coming off the tank, a pipe with a slight reduction in size in one section (resistance) running with water (current).
physics.question: What is the concept in physics that uses a big tank of water to illustrate the function of batteries and resistance in circuits?

physics.definition: The brown wire in a plug is live.
physics.mnemonic: Brown is live and you'll be burnt brown if you touch it.
physics.question: What is the purpose of the brown wire in a plug?

physics.definition: The blue wire in a plug is neutral.
physics.mnemonic: Blue is the colour of water and the pH of water is neutral.
physics.question: What function does the blue wire serve in a plug?

physics.definition: The green wire in a plug is earth.
physics.mnemonic: Green grass grows on the earth.
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Electricity/wiring a plug/green gass grows on earth.jpg
physics.question: What is the function of the green wire in a plug?

physics.definition: Green for Earth, Black for Neutral, Red for Live.
physics.mnemonic: Touch red and you will be dead. Touch brown and you will also go down.
physics.question: What were the old UK wiring colours?

physics.definition: Current is symbolized by the letter 'I' and is measured in Amps. One Amp is defined as 6.24×10^18 electrons per second passing through a point in a circuit.
physics.mnemonic: Currently you're under investigation by the C.I.A.
physics.question: What is electrical current?

physics.definition: Resistance is a measure of how much a component reduces the electric current flow in a circuit. It is often visualized as a restriction in a water pipe.
physics.mnemonic: Oh my (Ohm) this is heavy but I know I am causing a resistance
physics.question: What is resistance in an electrical circuit?

physics.definition: Voltage is the potential difference required to push electrons through a circuit. It can be thought of as the 'height' necessary to drive electron flow.
physics.mnemonic: Voltage is like the height that you have to vault to in order that you can crash down to push an electron through.
physics.question: What is voltage?

physics.definition: V = I * R, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance.
physics.mnemonic: Resistance say Oh my (Ohm's) he is heavy.
physics.question: What is Ohm's Law?

physics.definition: The speed of the electrons through the cable.
physics.mnemonic: Currently I'm not travelling very fast.
physics.question: What does the term "current" refer to in electrical circuits?

physics.definition: Measured in volts.
physics.mnemonic: Voltage comes from volting from a height.
physics.question: What is voltage measured in?

physics.definition: Ohm's Law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points. The formula is V = IR, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance.
physics.mnemonic: Ohm got so tired that she decided to have a rest by Vaulting into an Indian Restaurant.
physics.question: What does Ohm's Law state, and what is its formula?

physics.definition: The relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) expressed as V = I x R.
physics.mnemonic: Vault into an Indian Restaurant
physics.question: What is Ohm's Law?

physics.definition: A device that measures both the direction of the current and its magnitude in the circuit.
physics.mnemonic: I was galvanised into action. I wanted to meet her (galvanometer), I knew the direction, but I couldn't get past the current.
physics.question: What is a galvanometer?

physics.definition: A measuring instrument used to measure the magnitude of the current in a circuit. Electric currents are measured in amperes.
physics.mnemonic: An ammeter measures amperes of current in a circuit.
physics.question: What does an ammeter measure in a circuit?

physics.definition: Metals that are highly susceptible to magnetism, such as iron, steel, cobalt, and nickel.
physics.mnemonic: Imagine a knight wearing steel armour has nicked all the irons. The colt he was riding bolted.
physics.question: What are ferromagnetic metals?

physics.definition: Permanent magnets are made from 'hard' ferromagnetic materials such as iron, nickel, cobalt and steel (which contains iron).
physics.mnemonic: Permanent magnets are like 'HARD' workers; once they start working, they stay magnetized.
physics.question: How are permanent magnets manufactured?

physics.definition: Magnetic fields have the convention that they travel from north to south on a magnet.
physics.mnemonic: Santa in RED LEAVES the NORTH POLE. LINES LEAVE THE MAGNET AT RED AND NORTH.
physics.question: What is the convention for the direction of magnetic field lines on a magnet?

physics.definition: In electromagnetism, the right-hand grip rule is used to determine the direction of the magnetic field around a current-carrying wire. If you point your right thumb in the direction of current flow, the curl of your fingers shows the direction of the magnetic field.
physics.mnemonic: GRIP IS RIGHT HAND ON A WIRE. All the R's go together.
physics.question: What does the right-hand grip rule help you determine in electromagnetism?

physics.definition: The creation of something, used in terms such as 'electrical induction' and 'magnetic induction'.
physics.mnemonic: In the duct (induction) they found a new creation.
physics.question: What does induction refer to?

physics.definition: A measuring instrument used to measure the magnitude of the current in a circuit.
physics.mnemonic: Electric currents are measured in amperes, hence the name ammeter.
physics.question: What is an ammeter used for?

physics.definition: A galvanometer measures both the direction of the current and its magnitude in the circuit. A positive reading shows current travelling in one direction, and a negative reading shows it travelling in the other.
physics.mnemonic: I was galvanised into action. I wanted to meet her (galvanometer), I knew the direction, but I couldn't get past the current.
physics.question: What does a galvanometer measure in a circuit?

physics.definition: A rule used to predict the direction of force in an electromagnetic field when both the direction of current and magnetic field are known.
physics.mnemonic: First finger (Field) points in the direction of the magnetic field, second finger (Current) points in the direction of the current, and thumb (Motion) shows the direction of the force on the rod.
physics.question: What is Fleming's Left Hand Rule?

physics.definition: A magnet inducing a current in a wire experiences a force which opposes any movement.
physics.mnemonic: Lenz's law = OPPOSE CHANGE. You have to wear lenses (Lenz's) but she opposed the change.
physics.question: What does Lenz's law state in terms of a magnet inducing a current in a wire?

physics.definition: A device used to reverse the flow of an electric current.
physics.mnemonic: Commuters hated her (commutator) because everywhere she went in her electric car she went in reverse.
physics.question: What is a commutator?

physics.definition: An armature is a rotating coil or coils of a dynamo or electric motor.
physics.mnemonic: Her arm sure (armature) felt heavy as the snake rotated coils of itself around her arm.
physics.question: What is an armature in the context of a dynamo or electric motor?

physics.definition: A device which turns motive power (mechanical energy) into electricity, either alternating current (A.C.) or direct current (D.C.).
physics.mnemonic: GEnErators produce ElEctricity. Unlike Motors produce Movement or Motors produce Mechanical power.
physics.question: What is a generator?

physics.definition: Creating Direct Current (DC)
physics.mnemonic: Dine a moment (Dynamo) with the Disney Characters (DC).
physics.question: What is the purpose of a dynamo?

physics.definition: When light or other waves pass from one medium to another at an oblique angle, the light slows down and changes direction.
physics.mnemonic: He made reference to wanting more action (refraction) and so there was a change in direction from all of them.
physics.question: What is refraction?

physics.definition: When light travels from air to water or glass, it slows down and changes direction towards the normal line.
physics.mnemonic: Think of the ray of light as a tractor moving from a fast road onto a slow muddy, grassy field. The first wheel hits the muddy grass and slows down. The other side is still travelling well on the road. This makes the tractor slow down and change direction.
physics.question: What happens during refraction when light travels from air into water or glass?

physics.definition: The bending of light as it passes across the boundary between materials with different speeds of light.
physics.mnemonic: FAST TO SLOW = TOWARDS THE NORMAL, SLOW TO FAST = AWAY FROM THE NORMAL
physics.question: What is refraction?

physics.definition: Snell's Law relates to the refraction of light as it passes through different mediums, defined by the refractive indices and angles of incidence and refraction.
physics.mnemonic: SNAILS RACE = SNELL'S LAW
physics.question: What is Snell's Law?

physics.definition: Refraction is the change in direction of a wave passing from one medium to another due to its change in speed.
physics.mnemonic: REFerence ACTION = REFRACTION
physics.question: What is refraction?

physics.definition: The extent to which light is refracted (changes direction) when it enters a medium.
physics.mnemonic: HIGH N° n = Much bend (HIGH bend) towards normal line LOW N° n = Little bend (LOW bend) towards the normal line
physics.question: What is the refractive index?

physics.definition: Two common defects of the eye where myopia refers to short-sightedness and hyperopia refers to long-sightedness.
physics.mnemonic: Myopia sounds like 'my O (oh) pia' - focus too close; Hyperopia sounds like 'hyper-pia' - focus too far.
physics.question: What are myopia and hyperopia?

physics.definition: A condition where close objects are seen clearly, but distant ones are blurry.
physics.mnemonic: Sight short (is great), Focus short, Word short (myopia). My old piano (Myopia)
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Myopia and hyperopia short and long sight/how to remember/how-to-remember-myopia-and-hyperopia-eye-22.9a0b693.jpg
physics.question: What is myopia?

physics.definition: A condition where distant objects are seen more clearly than close ones.
physics.mnemonic: Sight long (is great), Focus long, Word long (hyperopia). Hyper-active = Overly long excitement = Hyperopia
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Myopia and hyperopia short and long sight/how to remember/how-to-remember-myopia-and-hyperopia-eye-22.9a0b693.jpg
physics.question: What is hyperopia?

physics.definition: A thing will not change its state of motion or rest unless an external force acts on it. Known as the law of inertia.
physics.mnemonic: Newton kicks a cow and because it hurt her (inertia), she walked a few metres.
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Newtons laws of motion/How to remember Newton's laws of motion/newtons-1st-law.10186be.jpg
physics.question: What is Newton's 1st Law?

physics.definition: A force applied is equal to mass times acceleration (F=ma).
physics.mnemonic: Newton kicks the cow again and the cow screamed MAAAAA.
physics.image: /images/user/base/Physics/Newtons laws of motion/How to remember Newton's laws of motion/newtons-2nd-law.25b3d7d.jpg
physics.question: What does Newton's 2nd Law state?

physics.definition: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces are found in pairs.
physics.mnemonic: Newton kicks the cow for a third time, but this time the cow kicks Newton back with an equal and opposite force.

maths.mnemonic: Raise a toe (ratio) to every (to every) one.

maths.definition: A ratio is a relationship between two numbers indicating how many times the first number contains the second. The scale of a map is a ratio.
maths.mnemonic: Think of the two people raising their toes (ratio) to the holiday they are going to have (see map on the wall). They raised a toe to everyone (ratio is to every) because they were going on holiday. Do you see the map?
maths.question: What is a ratio?

maths.definition: Two quantities are inversely proportional when one quantity increases, the other decreases. The product of the two quantities is constant.
maths.mnemonic: In the book of verse (inverse). Was just lots of multiplication signs.
maths.question: What is inverse proportion?

maths.definition: Indices (or index) indicate how many times to use the number in a multiplication, called a POWER.
maths.mnemonic: In the seas, (indices) remember who has the POWER.
maths.question: What are indices in mathematics?

maths.definition: An exponent is another word for indices and power.
maths.mnemonic: In the seas (indices) remember who has the power, until “It’s your ex phoning (exponent) sir.”
maths.question: What is another term used for indices and power in mathematics?

maths.definition: Any non-zero number raised to the power of zero is equal to one.
maths.mnemonic: Remember the picture 'it doesn't matter how many people there are there is only one sun' which means 2^0 = 1.
maths.question: What is 2^0?

maths.definition: The x-axis is the horizontal axis on a graph.
maths.mnemonic: X is a cross, so the x axis is across. Therefore, the y axis is vertical.

maths.definition: The Z axis in math is mainly thought of as depth. It is always 90° (perpendicular) to the x axis and y axis.
maths.mnemonic: A deep sleep (depth) is lots of Z's (Z-Depth)
maths.question: What does the Z axis represent in math?

maths.definition: x comes before y in coordinate system
maths.mnemonic: You have to walk across (x) the hall before you can go up (y) the stairs.

maths.question: What is the order of axes in a coordinate system?

maths.definition: The gradient of a line is calculated as the ratio of 'rise' to 'run'.
maths.mnemonic: It's grey (gradient) and then the sun rises overhead (rise over) as we go for a run (run).
maths.question: What is the gradient of a line defined as?

maths.definition: The equation of a straight line is given by y = mx + c, where m is the slope/gradient and c is the y-intercept.
maths.mnemonic: Why (y) have you made (m) egg (x) and cress (c) sandwiches in a line?
maths.question: What is the formula for a straight line in mathematics?

maths.definition: To work out the gradient (m) of a line you divide the change in y by the change in x.
maths.mnemonic: There is a large gradient on a mountain (m). Put your friend's Y fronts over the eggs (y over x) to stop the eggs from cracking if you're going to roll your eggs down a mountain.
maths.question: What is the formula to calculate the gradient (m) of a line?

maths.definition: A pictorial representation of data shown using parallel bars of varying heights. The bars do not touch as the data is about categories.
maths.mnemonic: Bar charts display data but there are gaps between bars (just like in a jail) (there are gaps between the data).

maths.definition: A pictorial representation of data shown in equal intervals with no spaces between the intervals.

maths.definition: A diagram that uses overlapping rings or circles to represent sets and their relationships.
maths.mnemonic: The vending (venn) machine only gives out rings.

maths.definition: The relationship of lines, angles, curves, surfaces, solids and points.
maths.mnemonic: Gee will it fall on me, the tree? (geometry)

maths.definition: The radius is the straight line extending from the centre of a circle to the outside edge.
maths.mnemonic: The radius radiates like rays from the centre of the sun, just like the radius does from the centre of a circle.

maths.definition: The straight line passing from side to side through the centre of a circle.

maths.definition: The distance around the outside of a circle.

maths.definition: Any shape made of straight edges/sides – many sides.
maths.mnemonic: Polly the parrots were many and everywhere.

maths.definition: Sides in a polygon.
maths.mnemonic: Gone are the sideburns he’d had for years.

maths.definition: A shape with 4 sides that has a pair of opposite sides that are parallel.
maths.mnemonic: A trap with a void (trapezoid) for a lobster is shaped like a trapezoid.
maths.question: What is a trapezium?

maths.definition: All four sides have equal length, opposite angles have equal measure and opposite sides are parallel. They look like a diamond.
maths.mnemonic: She rammed the bus (rhombus) into a diamond store.

maths.definition: A polygon with 8 sides.
maths.mnemonic: An octopus (octagon) has 8 tentacles (8 sides).
maths.question: What is an octagon?

maths.definition: A polygon with 9 sides.
maths.mnemonic: Nine of them sounds like nonagon so makes this easy to remember. If none are gone (nonagon) then a cat has nine lives.
maths.question: What is a nonagon?

maths.definition: A polygon with 10 sides
maths.mnemonic: In a deck of cards the highest number is a 10 (Dec has the same word root as decade which is 10 years).
maths.question: What is a decagon?

maths.definition: A polygon with 4 sides
maths.mnemonic: A quad bike has four wheels as quadrilateral has four sides.
maths.question: What is a quadrilateral?

maths.definition: All angles are equal and all sides are equal – everything equal.
maths.mnemonic: Regularly every day she measured the length of her plant. It was always the same.
maths.question: What does it mean when a shape is regular?

maths.definition: Identical parts facing each other. The simplest type is a mirror.
maths.mnemonic: See metal tick (symmetric) with a mirror. (Mirrors always provide a symmetrical view in reflection.)
maths.question: What does it mean for something to be symmetric?

maths.definition: Not identical on both sides of a central line.
maths.mnemonic: The letter ‘A’ joined to a word means not.
maths.question: What does asymmetrical mean?

maths.definition: A shape is said to be tessellated if an infinite number of that shape can be put together with no gaps.
maths.mnemonic: The first time I failed my driving test was when I turned up late (tessellation). I’ve repeatedly failed my test hundreds of times (repeatedly).
maths.question: What is tessellation?

maths.definition: A Tangent is a line that touches a curve at one point without cutting across it.
maths.mnemonic: Tanned when she gently (tangent) touched the circle.
maths.question: What is a tangent in geometry?

maths.definition: A Segment is the area of a circle made by a line and an arc.
maths.mnemonic: A segment of orange is shaped like a segment.
maths.question: What is a segment in a circle?

maths.definition: A chord of a circle is a straight line whose endpoints both lie on the circumference.
maths.mnemonic: A cord of rope thrown across a circle between two friends and pulled tight is a chord.
maths.question: What is a chord of a circle?

maths.definition: Two shapes are congruent when you can turn, flip, and/or slide one so it fits exactly on top of the other (identical size and shape).
maths.mnemonic: The con grew ants (congruent), but they all looked exactly the same.
maths.question: What does it mean for two shapes to be congruent?

maths.definition: In Geometry, two shapes are similar when the only difference is size (and possibly the need to move, turn, or flip one around).
maths.mnemonic: She used Simcity (similar) and constructed exactly what she saw outside her window but a small size.
maths.question: What does it mean for two shapes to be similar in geometry?

maths.definition: At an angle of 90° to a given line (or plane or surface).
maths.mnemonic: Purple dictionary sat on the book shelf at 90° angle.

maths.definition: An angle that is less than 90° (a sharp angle).
maths.mnemonic: A cute (acute) animal is always small (less than 90°), but watch out! It has very sharp teeth (a sharp angle).
maths.question: What is an acute angle?

maths.definition: A right angle is an angle that measures exactly 90°.
maths.mnemonic: They stood at an upright angle (right angle).
maths.question: What is a right angle?

maths.definition: An angle that is greater than 90° but less than 180°.
maths.mnemonic: Obese (Obtuse) – Obtuse think obese, which is a big angle.
maths.question: What is an obtuse angle?

maths.definition: An angle more than 180° but less than 360°.
maths.mnemonic: She looked in her reflexion and flexed her arm over.
maths.question: What is a reflex angle?

maths.definition: A radian is the angle made when the radius is wrapped around a circle.
maths.mnemonic: To remember a Radian - Think radius and angle.
maths.question: What is a radian?

maths.definition: A radian is a radius on a circumference to give an angle.
maths.mnemonic: A raid (radian) by a radius on a circumference.
maths.question: What is a radian?

maths.definition: The total interior angles of a triangle = 180°
maths.mnemonic: The triangle scored three treble twenties in her darts game which gave a combined score of 180.

maths.definition: The angle formed between any side of a polygon and a line extended from the next side. The exterior angle and the interior angle add up to 180°.
maths.mnemonic: EXTERIOR think EXTEND. Concentrate on the beginning of the word, 'EXT'.
maths.question: What is an exterior angle in a polygon?

maths.term: Area of a trapezium (or trapezoid or parallelogram)
maths.definition: The formula for the area is half the sum of the parallel sides times the distance between them.
maths.mnemonic: Sing: Half the sum of the parallel sides. Times the distance between them. This is how to calculate, the area of the trapezium.

maths.definition: There are four ways to transform an object in mathematics: Re-sizing (Enlargement, contraction), Reflection (Mirrored), Rotation (Around a point), Translating (Sliding).
maths.mnemonic: Think of a Transformer with enlarged eyes after a night out. So put on reflective mirrored glasses, put them on upside down (rotate), even when they were the correct way up they still slide off (translate).
maths.question: What are the four types of transforming an object in mathematics?

maths.definition: To slide an object elsewhere without rotating it or changing its size.
maths.mnemonic: Can you translate a single word that heat convector (vector) says?
maths.question: What does it mean to translate in geometry?

maths.definition: Reflection in geometry involves creating a mirror image of a shape across a specific line known as the mirror line. The object and its image are the same size, same distance from the mirror line, and perpendicular to each other.
maths.mnemonic: On any mathematical reflection question, think.. Where shall I put my mirror line.
maths.question: What is reflection in geometry?

maths.definition: A process in which the size of a shape is increased proportionally without altering its form.
maths.mnemonic: What an enlargement and she's covered in scales get her to the health CENTRE.
maths.question: What is an enlargement?

maths.mnemonic: Wow was she frustrated (frustum) she lost the whole of the top of her ice cream cone. (The frustum is the bit that fell on the floor).

maths.definition: The complete group (that we are interested in).
maths.mnemonic: The population is all the people. The complete group of people.

maths.mnemonic: Sensors (census) were fitted to the whole population to monitor their health.

maths.definition: A systematic error in a survey that can influence and skew the outcome of the data in a certain direction.
maths.mnemonic: The two Asses (bias bi=two) divert the questions in a specific direction.
maths.question: What is bias in the context of surveys?

maths.definition: A method of sampling a population by dividing into subcategories and then taking samples from every subcategory.

maths.definition: Selecting every Kth subject from a list.
maths.mnemonic: Every 10th time the toilet system (systematic) flushed the toilet burst into song.

maths.definition: Add up all the numbers and divide by the number of numbers. It is the most commonly used mathematical measure of average.
maths.mnemonic: Mean is the meanest because it takes the most maths to figure it out.
maths.question: What is the mean in statistics?

maths.definition: Once the numbers are in order, the median is the one in the middle. If there is an even number of data points, the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.
maths.mnemonic: The spiritual medium was in the middle, between our world and the spirits.
maths.question: What is the median in a set of numbers?

maths.definition: The thing that occurs most often.
maths.mnemonic: MOdes there the MOst
maths.question: What is the mode in a set of data?

maths.definition: The thing that occurs most often.
maths.mnemonic: She mowed the lawn almost every day. She was the most prolific mower. Most people thought she was crazy. It’s what she spent most of her spare time doing, but she wanted the most beautiful lawn.
maths.question: What is the mode in a set of data?

maths.definition: One event influences the outcome of the other, also known as conditional probability.
maths.mnemonic: The baby is dependent on the mother. If the mum has influenza then the baby will get it too.
maths.question: What is dependent probability?

maths.definition: Independent probability – one event DOES NOT affect the outcome of the other.
maths.mnemonic: This woman is not dependent on anyone else to survive, she will never catch influenza (influence). Independent probability - NOT Influenced.
maths.question: What is independent probability?

maths.definition: Events that cannot happen at the same time.
maths.mnemonic: Two mutants (mutually) are excluded (excluded) from entering the club together by time.

maths.definition: A measure that is used to quantify the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
maths.mnemonic: Jay Z was sick and late (68%) which got him fired from his nine to five (95%) job, giving him 99 problems but 7up (99.7%) wasn’t one.

maths.definition: The power on 2 that equals 8.

history.question: What were Mulberry harbours used for during World War II?

history.definition: The German invasion of the Soviet Union beginning on June 22, 1941.
history.mnemonic: The barber rose up (Barbarossa) in Germany and said: "We are going to give the Soviet Union a haircut!"
history.question: What was Operation Barbarossa?

history.definition: An operation to provide aerial supply of weapons and other materials to resistance fighters in occupied Europe during World War II.
history.mnemonic: Dropping carpets and bags (Operation Carpetbagger) out of planes to French resistance fighters.
history.question: What was Operation Carpetbagger during World War II?

history.definition: Evacuation of Allied soldiers during World War II from the beaches of Dunkirk in the North of France over nine days between May 26 and June 4, 1940.
history.mnemonic: Being dunked in the sea irked him (Dunkirk) but as soon as he dined for a moment (Dynamo) he felt better.
history.question: What was Operation Dynamo – Dunkirk evacuation?

history.definition: An operation by the USA to capture the Japanese-held southern portion of the Marshall Islands during World War II.
history.mnemonic: The Flintlock gun (Operation Flintlock) was used by the Marshall (Marshall Islands).
history.question: What was Operation Flintlock?

history.definition: A failed attempt during World War II to take Rhine bridges and penetrate Germany.
history.mnemonic: The market in the garden was a failure. There was mud everywhere. People just used the bridge over the market. That way they believed the mud wouldn't harm them (bridge at Arnhem).
history.question: What was Operation Market Garden during World War II?

history.definition: A successful British deception to make Hitler think that Greece and Sardinia would be invaded instead of Sicily.
history.mnemonic: "Can I have some mincemeat?" (Operation Mincemeat) she said, but the British Army Officer said: "Sister, don't be silly (not Sicily), what you need is greasy sardines." (Greece and Sardinia instead)
history.question: What was Operation Mincemeat?

history.definition: An Anglo American invasion of French North Africa led by General Dwight Eisenhower.
history.mnemonic: The torches (Operation Torch) shone on the map where the Allies would invade North Africa.
history.question: What was Operation Torch?

history.definition: In Germany, the word Panzer means tank. The Panzer series of military battle tanks was fielded by the German army in the 1930s and '40s.
history.mnemonic: The Pink Panther (Panzer) was driving the tank.
history.question: What does the term Panzer refer to in a military context?

history.definition: A system for detecting the presence, direction and distance of objects. Radar is an acronym of 'radio detecting and ranging'.
history.mnemonic: In the raid in the dark (radar), a thief stole a radio, but police detection and a wide-ranging enquiry resulted in its return (radio detection and ranging).
history.question: What is radar used for?

history.definition: A paradummy used as a deception, causing the enemy to shift focus during the D-Day Landings of World War II.
history.mnemonic: Rupert the bear (Rupert) was dropped in France on D-Day.
history.question: What was Rupert used for during the D-Day Landings of World War II?

history.definition: The swastika was used as a symbol and emblem of the Nazi party.
history.mnemonic: Two swan stickers (swastika) in the shape of the Nazi emblem.
history.question: What was the swastika used as a symbol and emblem of?

history.definition: Night time bombing raids on London and other British cities during World War II
history.mnemonic: A blizzard of bits (blitz) is the aftermath of Germany's bombing campaign.
history.question: What was The Blitz during World War II?

history.definition: In November 1942, the Germans attempted to capture the French fleet at Toulon, but the French scuttled their ships to prevent their use by the Nazis.
history.mnemonic: Held up for too long (Toulon) at the base's entrance, thus allowing the French to blow up their own ships.
history.question: What happened with the French Fleet at Toulon during World War II?

history.definition: An agreement to prioritize the destruction of German aircraft and submarine manufacturing facilities during WWII.
history.mnemonic: They pointed out of planes as they dropped blankets directly over (Pointblank Directive) German factories.
history.question: What was the Pointblank Directive during WWII?

history.definition: The official Nazi name for the authoritarian government in Germany from January 1933 to May 1945.
history.mnemonic: The third door on the right (Third Reich) led to the third empire.
history.question: What was the Third Reich?

history.definition: A strategically important port on the Mediterranean coast of Libya in North Africa, known for its prolonged fighting and changing hands during World War II.
history.mnemonic: When the two brooks (Tobruk) came together Rommel pushed back the allies.
history.question: What is Tobruk?

history.definition: Meeting of senior Nazi officials held in Wannsee, Berlin, to implement the Final Solution (Jews and others deported to camps and murdered)
history.mnemonic: A onesie (Wannsee) was worn by all the Nazi officers as they discussed the implementation of the Final Solution.
history.question: What was the Wannsee Conference?

history.definition: The combined name of the Heer (army), the Kreigsmarine (navy), and the Luftwaffe (airforce); the combined German forces.
history.mnemonic: The Germans were marker (Wehrmacht) crazy: they drew an eagle on all their uniforms.
history.question: What was the Wehrmacht?

history.definition: The government may not force U.S. citizens to shelter soldiers in their homes.
history.mnemonic: No soldiers in here because 'three's a crowd'.
history.question: What does the 3rd Amendment to the U.S. Constitution prohibit?

history.definition: U.S. citizens have the right to a trial by jury.
history.mnemonic: Seven fingers of Bill
history.question: What does Amendment 7 of the U.S. Constitution guarantee?

history.definition: Associated with manufacturing and industrial power during the American Civil War.
history.mnemonic: North = Nuts and bolts
history.question: What was the North known for during the American Civil War?

history.definition: The Southern States of America known for producing two-thirds of the world’s supply of cotton in 1860, and growing large quantities of tobacco and rice with little manufacturing.
history.mnemonic: Think of the South in terms of S for Seeds, thereby associating it with farming.
history.question: Which region of the United States was known for producing two-thirds of the world’s cotton supply in 1860, as well as large quantities of tobacco and rice?

history.definition: The North won the American Civil War.
history.mnemonic: You can easily recall which side won the American Civil War by associating North with No. 1 – because the North won!
history.question: Who won the American Civil War?

history.definition: The region that lost the American Civil War.
history.mnemonic: SOUTH = SLAVERY = EVIL = MUST LOSE
history.question: What region is referred to as having lost the American Civil War?

history.definition: The side in the American Civil War that wore blue uniforms.
history.mnemonic: North = nuts and bolts = manufacturing = blue
history.question: Which side in the American Civil War wore blue uniforms?

history.definition: The South mostly wore brown and grey during the American Civil War.
history.mnemonic: South = seeds = farming = grey and brown (mostly)
history.question: What colors did The South mostly wear during the American Civil War?

history.definition: The Northern states were called the Union.
history.mnemonic: North = nuts and bolts = manufacturing = labour Union
history.question: What were the Northern states called during the Civil War?

history.definition: The South during the American Civil War.
history.mnemonic: Corn-fed-my-mates = Confederates
history.question: What was the term used for the South during the American Civil War?

history.definition: President of the United States during the Civil War who wanted all the states to remain part of the Union.
history.mnemonic: Lincoln wanted the link between all the states to continue (Lincoln). He tried to hold all the states together.
history.question: Who was Abraham Lincoln?

history.definition: President of the Confederate States from 1862 to 1865, after which he was imprisoned for two years
history.mnemonic: He was jettisoned (Jefferson) out of the jail after two years of day visits (Davis) from friends.
history.question: Who was Jefferson Davis?

history.definition: Commander of the Union armies, 1864-1865
history.mnemonic: You will see (Ulysses) that everything the North wanted was granted (Grant).
history.question: Who was Ulysses S. Grant during the years 1864-1865?

history.definition: Commander of the Confederate armies
history.mnemonic: Lee had lean times because he fought for the South.
history.question: What was Robert E. Lee's role during the American Civil War?

history.definition: The American Civil War started in the year 1861.
history.mnemonic: Before the war they FiSHeD (the American Civil War started in 1861).
history.question: When did the American Civil War start?

history.term: Duration of the American Civil War
history.definition: The American Civil War continued for four years.
history.mnemonic: Then there was a ROW for four years.
history.question: How long did the American Civil War last?

history.definition: The war started in 1861 and ended in 1865.
history.mnemonic: 1. NORTHERN STATES 1 (won) = 1861, 2. SOUTHERN STATES ZILCH = 1865
history.question: When did the American Civil War take place?

history.definition: The last major battle of the American Civil War where Ulysses S. Grant accepted General Robert E. Lee's surrender.
history.mnemonic: All opposing sides put down their mattocks (Appomattox), which were used for digging in, and put down their weapons.
history.question: What was Appomattox Court House known for in the American Civil War?

history.definition: American civil war battle in and around the town of Gettysburg that had the largest number of casualties in the entire war. The Union army defeated the Confederates.
history.mnemonic: Getting his burgers (Gettysburg), he bought the largest number he could get on the tray (largest number of casualties).
history.question: What was the American Civil War battle at Gettysburg known for?

history.definition: Union Army strategy by General Winfield Scott to block ports and advance down the Mississippi River to cut the South in two, suffocating the victim like an anaconda snake.
history.mnemonic: The anaconda snake (Anaconda Plan) was let loose around the ports and came down the Mississippi River. To ensure the snake stayed and the Union were the winners, a Scottish man (Winfield Scott) had hold of its head.
history.question: What was the Anaconda Plan in the American Civil War?

history.definition: The last name of the 16th President of the United States, Abraham Lincoln.
history.mnemonic: Link on another L - Linc on with another L - Lincoln
history.question: What is the last name of the 16th President of the United States, Abraham?

history.definition: The location where the American Civil War began when it was taken by the Confederates.
history.mnemonic: The Confederates fought to surmount and terrorise (Fort Sumter) the fort.
history.question: Where did the American Civil War begin when it was taken by the Confederates?

history.definition: General Sherman's Union troops marched through Georgia from Atlanta to Savannah, laying waste to Confederate war supplies and railroads.
history.mnemonic: Think of a Sherman tank marching (Sherman's March), ripping a wide section of earth all the way to Savannah.
history.question: What was Sherman's March during the Civil War?

history.definition: Described by Lincoln as the key to winning the Civil War; by Jefferson Davis as the nail that held the South's two halves together. Vicksburg sits on the Mississippi river.
history.mnemonic: The Vicar's burger (Vicksburg) contained a key (Lincoln's key) and a nail (Jefferson Davis's nail). The Vicar didn't eat the burger hinting at the fact that, after 42 days of being under siege with no food the confederates surrendered.
history.question: What significance did Vicksburg hold during the Civil War?

history.definition: 1st President of the USA, inaugurated in 1789
history.mnemonic: Ties (tie = 1) – we were washing them by the ton (Washington)
history.question: Who was the 1st President of the USA, inaugurated in 1789?

history.definition: 1st President of the United States, served starting in 1789.
history.mnemonic: Ties (1), we were washing them by the ton (Washington), but when you saw how many there were you said: “I give up” (789 = 1789).
history.question: Who was George Washington?

history.definition: 2nd President of the USA
history.mnemonic: Noah’s (2) Ark was going to be boarded by the Addams (Adams) Family but Noah wouldn’t let them on. He held them off with a cup hook (797 = 1797) he had wrenched off his kitchen wall.
history.question: Who was the 2nd President of the USA?

history.definition: First name of John Adams
history.mnemonic: Noah wouldn’t let the Addams Family on the Ark because they hadn’t been baptised – so the family got John the Baptist (John) to baptise them. John the Baptist used Noah’s cup for the baptism.
history.question: What is the first name of John Adams?

history.definition: 3rd President of the USA, 1801
history.mnemonic: “Ma!” (3) said the chef’s son (Jefferson), “I’ve cooked this feast (801 = 1801) for you.”
history.question: Who was the 3rd President of the USA in 1801?

history.definition: 4th President of the USA, became president in 1809
history.mnemonic: The father was rowing but he got mad at his son because he kept trying to beat him on his vespa.
history.question: Who was James Madison?

history.definition: 5th President of the United States, started his term in 1817.
history.mnemonic: The law (5) caught up with Marilyn Monroe (Monroe) as she collapsed after drinking another bottle of vodka (817 = 1817).
history.question: Who was James Monroe?

history.definition: 6th President of the United States, became president in 1825.
history.mnemonic: The type of shoe (6) the Addams Family (Adams) were wearing was vinyl (825 = 1825). A pair of the Addams Family's shoes were borrowed by John the Baptist (John). The shoes kept the water out as he baptised baby quins in the sea (Quincy).
history.question: Who was John Quincy Adams?

history.definition: 7th President of the United States, became president in 1829
history.mnemonic: The cow (7) wanted to dance like Michael Jackson (Jackson), so she decided to phone up (829 = 1829) and ask him how to do it.
history.question: What position did Andrew Jackson hold starting in 1829?

history.definition: 8th President of the United States, served in 1837.
history.mnemonic: It tripped over the ivy (8), but the van that was blue and could run (Van Buren) carried on and won the race and became famous on every newsstand in the world where you could view a mag (837 = 1837). The van that was blue and could run (Van Buren) was driven by a Martian (Martin).
history.question: Who was Martin Van Buren?

history.definition: 9th President of the United States, served in 1841.
history.mnemonic: A bee (9) had a hairy son (Harrison) who did a fart (841 = 1841) on stage which flew up his long hair... but the hairy son (Harrison) carried on and gave his rendition of William Shakespeare (William).
history.question: What position did William Henry Harrison hold in the United States government?

history.definition: 10th President of the United States, served in 1841.
history.mnemonic: Although he could only use his toes (10), he was the best tiler (Tyler) in the country. On the latest job, they wanted a fruit (841) scene in the kitchen.
history.question: Who was John Tyler?

history.definition: 11th President of the United States, became president in 1845
history.mnemonic: They saw a dot (11) coming round the corner... It turned out to be the President wearing his polka (Polk) dot overall (845 = 1845).
history.question: What role did James K Polk serve beginning in 1845?

history.definition: 12th President of the USA in 1849
history.mnemonic: Only a president can get a tan (12), be measured by a tailor (Taylor) and have a fry-up (849 = 1849) all at the same time.
history.question: Who was Zachary Taylor?

history.definition: 13th President of the United States, became president in 1850.
history.mnemonic: It was taking a long time (13) for the candy man to fill more (Fillmore) of her container with candy floss (850 = 1850).
history.question: Who was Millard Fillmore?

history.definition: 14th President of the USA, became president in 1853
history.mnemonic: The tar(tar) (14) on the patient's teeth was so thick the dentist couldn't pierce (Pierce) it with his drill; it was a solid film (853). The patient whose tartar the dentist couldn't pierce (Pierce) was actually Frankenstein. Frankenstein has a scar, like a line, on his forehead (Frank + line = Franklin).
history.question: Who was the 14th President of the USA who became president in 1853?

history.definition: 15th President of the United States, 1857
history.mnemonic: The tail (15) of the squirrel trembled as he peeped inside the blue cannon (Buchanan) while the flag (857 = 1857) fluttered over the battlefield.
history.question: Who was James Buchanan?

history.definition: 16th President of the United States, served in 1861
history.mnemonic: A tache (16) was once grown by Abraham Lincoln. He fished (861) often, but the fishing hook got caught in his moustache, so he shaved it off.
history.question: Who was the 16th President of the United States?

history.definition: 17th President of the United States, became president in 1865
history.mnemonic: A tack (17) held up a notice in the loo where the john's son (Johnson) was having a facial (865 = 1865)
history.question: Who was Andrew Johnson?

history.definition: 18th President of the United States, became president in 1869
history.mnemonic: The dove (18) received a grant (Grant) to learn to fly, but she spent it on a fish pie (869=1869). You wasted your grant you silly (Ulysses) bird, her parents said.
history.question: Who was Ulysses S Grant?

history.definition: 19th President of the United States, served in 1877.
history.mnemonic: Under the tap (19) he cooled himself down. In the heat haze (Hayes) he had worn his thick wig (877 = 1877) and he had overheated. Through the haze (Hayes), an old Ford with a rudder (rudder Ford – Rutherford) appeared. It was a taxi to take him home.
history.question: Who was Rutherford B. Hayes?

history.definition: 20th President of the United States in 1881
history.mnemonic: "That's my nose (20)!" Garfield the Cat (Garfield) said, but the man denied theft (881 = 1881).
history.question: Who was James A Garfield?

history.definition: 21st President of the USA, became president in 1881.
history.mnemonic: A net (21) was what the thief used to take the sword away. King Arthur (Arthur) spotted it and shouted 'Theft!' (881 = 1881) to raise the alarm.
history.question: What did Chester A. Arthur become known for in 1881?

history.definition: 22nd President of the United States, took office in 1885
history.mnemonic: A nun (22) in Cleaver Land (Cleveland) was watching out for flying cleavers! She passed a youthful (885) skateboarder who was looking backwards and risked running right into a flying cleaver.
history.question: What role did Grover Cleveland assume in 1885, marking him as the 22nd in U.S. history?

history.definition: 23rd President of the United States, 1889
history.mnemonic: Nemo (23) isn't best pleased with the five hairy sons (Harrison) as all five pee (889 = 1889) into his bowl.
history.question: Who was Benjamin Harrison?

history.definition: 24th President of the United States, also served as the 22nd president.
history.mnemonic: He was the winner (24) again because his cleaver landed (Cleveland) closest. In fact, it was so close she dropped an F-bomb (893 = 1893).
history.question: Who was the 24th President of the United States and also served as the 22nd president?

history.definition: 26th President of the United States, became president in 1901.
history.mnemonic: He ate nachos (26) while he waited for his new rose belt (Roosevelt) to come through the post (901).
history.question: Who was the 26th President of the United States, who became president in 1901?

history.definition: 27th President of the United States, became president in 1909.
history.mnemonic: Around his neck (27) he wore a taffeta (Taft) scarf because, although his pea soup (909 = 1909) was warm, the house was cold.
history.question: Who was William Howard Taft?

history.definition: 28th President of the United States, serving from 1913
history.mnemonic: A country's navy was left by a dictator in his will to his son (Wilson). Giving the navy to his son was the last item at the bottom (913 = 1913) of the will.
history.question: Who was Woodrow Wilson?

history.definition: 29th President of the USA, took office in 1921.
history.mnemonic: The president took a nap (29) after fitting new hard (Harding) wood flooring to the oval office, but he didn't notice the spilt paint (921 = 1921).
history.question: Who was Warren G. Harding?

history.definition: 30th President of the United States, served starting in 1923
history.mnemonic: The moose (30) guided his ship carrying cool fridges (Coolidge) along the Panama (923) Canal.
history.question: Who was Calvin Coolidge?

history.definition: 31st President of the USA, became president in 1929
history.mnemonic: Cleaning a mat (31) isn't the only use of a Hoover (Hoover): some find them so attractive they use them as a pin-up (929 = 1929).
history.question: Who was Herbert Hoover?

history.definition: 32nd President of the United States, began presidency in 1933
history.mnemonic: Money (32) was offered for an exclusive report on Frankenstein's rose belt (Franklin D. Roosevelt). Money was no motivator for Frankenstein – he just liked pretty things like his rose belt and now he wanted the boom mike (933 = 1933).
history.question: Who was Franklin D Roosevelt?

history.definition: 33rd President of the United States, became president in 1945
history.mnemonic: They all performed a mime (33) of the true man (Truman) with a barrel (1945).
history.question: Who was Harry S Truman?

history.definition: 34th President, became president in 1953
history.mnemonic: They could hammer (34) out 1,000 eyes an hour (Eisenhower) at the false eye factory. Each eye weighed about the same as a plum (953 = 1953).
history.question: Who was the 34th President of the United States who became president in 1953?

history.definition: 35th President of the United States, served in 1961.
history.mnemonic: As he went to collect his mail (35), the man who lived by the Kennedy Space Center (Kennedy) wondered why no one else had built a beach hut (961 = 1961) there.
history.question: Who was the 35th President of the United States, serving in 1961?

history.definition: 36th President of the United States, became president in 1963.
history.mnemonic: His dad ate mash (36) as he sat on the john, while the john's son (Johnson) was used by the pyjama boy (963 = 1963).
history.question: Who was Lyndon B Johnson?

history.definition: 37th President of the United States, became president in 1969.
history.mnemonic: The mic (37) was placed in front of the president who had just knickers on (Nixon) while he did a pushup (969).
history.question: Who was Richard Nixon?

history.definition: 38th President of the USA, became president in 1974
history.mnemonic: All the people watching the movie (38) at the drive-in cinema drove Ford (Ford) cars, which was strange seeing as the film was about a biker (974=1974).
history.question: Who was the 38th President of the USA who became president in 1974?

history.definition: 39th President of the United States, inaugurated in 1977
history.mnemonic: The map (39) was used as he stood on the cart (Carter) as the peacock (977=1977) pulled him along so rapidly.
history.question: Who was the 39th President of the United States, inaugurated in 1977?

history.definition: 40th President of the USA, took office in 1981.
history.mnemonic: The rose (40) on the table changed when the ray gun (Reagan) was fired at it. It turned into a buffet (981=1981).
history.question: What position did Ronald Reagan hold starting in 1981?

history.definition: 41st President of the United States, served starting in 1989
history.mnemonic: The rat (41) got drenched as the gardeners Heavily Watered Bush (H W Bush) dripped over him causing his fur to puff up (989=1989).
history.question: Who was George H W Bush?

history.definition: 42nd President of the United States, served starting in 1993
history.mnemonic: The rain (42) poured down as the Klingon (Clinton) went to the puppy home (993 = 1993) to collect his new dog.
history.question: Who was the 42nd President of the United States, starting his term in 1993?

history.definition: 43rd President of the USA, took office in 2001
history.mnemonic: A ram (43) planted a White Bush (W Bush) at the seaside (001=2001).
history.question: Who was George W Bush?

history.definition: 44th President of the United States, became president in 2009
history.mnemonic: There was a roar (44) from the old barber's (Obama) shop as the water rushed through the Stainless Steel Pipe (009=2009) before spurting from the tap.
history.question: Who was Barack Obama?

history.definition: 45th President of the United States, assumed office in 2017
history.mnemonic: As the train sped along the rail (45) tracks the President played his trumpet (Trump) hoping someone would pull the stick (017=2017) to divert the train.
history.question: Who was the 45th President of the United States, assuming office in 2017?

history.definition: Connect Trump to Donald
history.mnemonic: He hoped the trumpet (Trump) would get people's attention before Donald Duck (Donald) ran him over in the train.
history.question: What is a way to connect the surname Trump with the first name Donald?

history.definition: 46th President of the United States, 2021
history.mnemonic: He was rich (46) that was obvious, and the President decided he needed to buy new dentures (Biden) but was told: don't worry, Santa (021=2021) will probably sort you out.
history.question: Who is Joe Biden?

history.definition: The mountain sculpture depicting four U.S. presidents.
history.mnemonic: Imagine having to rush more (Mount Rushmore) to finish the sculpture of the presidents.
history.question: What is Mount Rushmore?

history.term: Order of Presidents on Mount Rushmore
history.definition: The order of presidents from left to right: Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt, Lincoln.
history.mnemonic: Sometimes, as a president, you have to get up in a rush (Rushmore) but you must quickly wash (Washington) first. As a president, one of the benefits is that you can have a chef available to make you breakfast but as she's away, you can use the chef's son (Jefferson). I don't care what people say so today I'm going to put a rose (Roosevelt) in my hair. I'm then going to link-on (Lincoln) with all the other presidents and walk out the door.
history.question: What is the order of presidents on Mount Rushmore from left to right?

history.term: Order of Presidents on Mount Rushmore
history.definition: Remembering the sequence and position of the presidents carved on Mount Rushmore.
history.mnemonic: If you really know your presidents then remember that the two T's are together in the middle.
history.question: What is the order of presidents on Mount Rushmore?

english.definition: Behave in a way that belittles or degrades (someone)
english.mnemonic: A baseball (abase) player behaved in a way that belittled his opponents.
english.question: What does it mean to abase someone?

english.definition: Become less intense. To reduce in amount. Lessen or diminish.
english.mnemonic: A pile of bait (abate) was reduced in size because his son kept eating it.
english.question: What does "abate" mean?

english.definition: A building occupied by a community of monks or nuns.
english.mnemonic: There was a bee (abbey) farm in the building occupied by monks.
english.question: What is an abbey?

english.definition: To take someone away illegally by force or deception.
english.mnemonic: Abba were bound with duct (abduct) tape by a crazed fan who had taken them away by force.
english.question: What does it mean to abduct someone?

english.definition: A departure from the normal; could be a mistake or an out-of-character action, a fault in a mechanical device, or a biological deviation.
english.mnemonic: A bear caused a sensation (aberration) when entering the departure lounge of the airport. The other passengers thought it was far from normal.
english.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/1. Aberration is a departure from the normal. 1.jpg
english.question: What is an aberration?

english.definition: A state of not being used at the moment
english.mnemonic: At the bay, she saw at a glance (abeyance) it was completely empty – it was not being used at all at the moment.
english.question: What does "abeyance" mean in terms of usage?

english.definition: To accept willingly
english.mnemonic: She's a bride (abide) I'm able to accept willingly.
english.question: What does it mean to abide?

english.definition: Dire, as bad as it can get. Used to indicate extremely bad situations or conditions, or to describe a person being completely without pride or dignity.
english.mnemonic: The fitness fanatic had to have his abs injected (abject) because he was in a bad way after his punishing gym routine.
english.image: /images/user/base/uncategorised/2. Abject indicates that a situation is very bad..jpg
english.question: What does the term "abject" mean?

english.definition: Very unpleasant
english.mnemonic: A bomb in a bull (abominable) would be very unpleasant.
english.question: What does the term "abominable" mean?

english.definition: Exist in large amounts
english.mnemonic: A bound (abound) book, especially one bound in leather, is a great gift and there's a huge amount to choose from in this store.
english.question: What does it mean to abound?

english.definition: Shorten; condense
english.mnemonic: A bridge (abridge) shortens your walk.
english.question: What does it mean to abridge?

english.definition: a swollen area within body tissue containing an accumulation of pus
english.mnemonic: I thought I had great abs, but my doctor says (abscess) it's just a swollen area containing an accumulation of pus.
english.question: What is an abscess?

english.definition: To leave hurriedly
english.mnemonic: The absent scone (abscond) left in a hurry when it was about to be eaten.
english.question: What does it mean to abscond?

english.definition: Grant pardon, declare someone free of guilt, punishment, or blame
english.mnemonic: Her abs solved (absolve) her problem with the judge. The Judge said: 'I'll grant you a pardon if you show me how you got such great abs!'
english.question: What does it mean to absolve someone?

english.definition: Not doing things for pleasure, especially not drinking alcohol or eating rich food.
english.mnemonic: "Want to improve your abs? Team up with us! (abstemious) You know our motto - eat less, drink less, smile less."
english.question: What does it mean to be abstemious?

english.definition: the practice of restraining oneself from indulging in something
english.mnemonic: I used to consume an absurd amount of sustenance (abstinence), but now I'm restraining myself from indulging.
english.question: What is abstinence?

english.definition: difficult to understand; obscure
english.mnemonic: It was absurd, but we agreed to a truce (abstruse) despite finding it difficult to understand each other.
english.question: What does the word "abstruse" mean?

english.definition: Illogical, stupid and unreasonable, laughably foolish or false
english.mnemonic: Abs were heard (absurd) to say: "You look ridiculous!"
english.question: What does the term "absurd" mean?

english.definition: 1. Relating to education; 2. Not of practical relevance; only theoretical interest
english.mnemonic: Kids hacking other computers is an epidemic (academic). You think they are doing something relating to education, but they think school has no practical relevance.
english.question: What does "academic" mean?

english.definition: A place of study or training in a special field
english.mnemonic: A cadet learns about the enemy (academy) and receives special training in a place of study.
english.question: What is an academy?

english.definition: 1. agree to a request or demand 2. to take a position of power
english.mnemonic: The knight actually succeeded (accede) in slaying the dragon, so the people asked him to become king. He agreed to this request and took the position of power.
english.question: What does the term "accede" mean?

english.definition: Loud and enthusiastic approval
english.mnemonic: A clam that was drawn for a new animation (acclamation) won loud and enthusiastic approval from the movies production team.
english.question: What does acclamation mean?

english.definition: 1. To fit in with the needs or wishes of an individual, group or organization. 2. (of a building or other area) provide lodging or sufficient space for.
english.mnemonic: She wasn't a common candidate (accommodate). She promised to meet everyone's wishes by providing new homes with sufficient space for five occupants.
english.question: What does it mean to accommodate someone or something?

english.definition: 1. A musical part which supports or partners an instrument, voice, or group. 2. Something that goes well with or complements something else.
english.mnemonic: This was a company of musicians, which meant (accompaniment) you had to support each other. Each musician chooses someone who they work well with.
english.question: What is an accompaniment in music and in a general sense?

english.definition: A person or associate who helps another commit a crime.
english.mnemonic: Accompany me to the police (accomplice) station – the dog as well, because she helped commit the crime.
english.question: What is an accomplice?

english.definition: To finish successfully
english.mnemonic: I like to accompany this Polish (accomplish) guy. He's sure to finish successfully.
english.question: What does it mean to accomplish something?

english.definition: 1. To be in harmony 2. To grant power or status
english.mnemonic: The accordion (accord) was in perfect harmony with the orchestra, and the judges granted her the status of lead player.
english.question: What does the term "accord" mean?

english.definition: 1. in a way that is appropriate to the particular circumstance 2. as a result; therefore
english.mnemonic: The accordion was exceedingly (accordingly) loud; as a result, he was asked to play at a volume more appropriate to the particular circumstances.
english.question: What does the term "accordingly" mean?

english.definition: To approach and speak to someone in a bold or aggressive way
english.mnemonic: You would be making a costly (accost) error if you approached a boxer and spoke in an aggressive way.
english.question: What does it mean to accost someone?

english.definition: Officially recognised or authorised
english.mnemonic: A credit rating (accredited) of three stars gave her official recognition of how good she was.
english.question: What does it mean when something is accredited?

english.definition: Gradually increasing in amount over a period of time.
english.mnemonic: A crew grew and grew over time.
english.question: What does it mean to accrue?

english.definition: A person or group charged with, or on trial for a crime
english.mnemonic: A cue he used (accused) to beat his victim was produced as evidence when he went on trial months after being charged with causing grievous bodily harm in the snooker hall.
english.question: What does the term "accused" refer to in a legal context?

english.definition: make someone familiar with new conditions
english.mnemonic: A custom (accustom) amongst our people is to make visitors familiar with the new conditions.
english.question: What does it mean to accustom someone to something?

english.definition: Spoken or written to be cruel, spiteful or scathing; tasting sour or bitter.
english.mnemonic: Acid monsters bicker (acerbic) all the time. They are constantly cruel to each other in writing and speech.
english.question: What does the term "acerbic" mean?

english.definition: A conclusive test of the success or value of something.
english.mnemonic: The acid was tested (acid test) on the metal. It didn't dissolve, so it was a conclusive test of success.
english.question: What is an "acid test"?

english.definition: Make someone aware or familiar with someone or something
english.mnemonic: A quaint house (acquaint) introduced herself to the house next door. They soon made themselves familiar with each other.
english.question: What does it mean to acquaint someone?

english.definition: Make someone aware or familiar with someone or something
english.mnemonic: If you are going into deep water then an aqualung ain't (acquaint) something you can use immediately – you need training to become familiar with the equipment.
english.question: What does it mean to acquaint someone with something?

english.definition: To accept or agree to something, often unwillingly
english.mnemonic: A quick kiss (acquiesce) from his aunt he accepted, but unwillingly.
english.question: What does it mean to acquiesce?

english.definition: Feelings of anger between people who disagree strongly
english.mnemonic: A criminal with lots of money (acrimony) said that crime always pays, but it caused lots of anger among people who disagreed strongly with him.
english.question: What does acrimony refer to in the context of relationships or disagreements?
