english.mnemonic: A lie the bull (libel) published damaged the reputation of the farmer.
english.question: What is libel?

english.definition: 1. Allowing many different types of beliefs or behaviour 2. To give generously 3. To have political freedom 4. Sharing wealth and power in society
english.mnemonic: To remember the various meanings, see in your mind's eye the Statue of Liberty having all (liberal) the hints of its meanings surrounding the statue.
english.question: What does the term "liberal" mean?

english.definition: 1. An uncertain period of awaiting a decision or resolution 2. A dance/game in which the aim is to pass forwards under a low bar without falling or dislodging the bar
english.mnemonic: They were certainly limber, but would they both (limbo) pass under the bar without dislodging it? There was an uncertain period where we awaited the resolution of the contest.
english.question: What does the term "limbo" refer to, both as a state of uncertainty and a popular dance?

english.definition: Soft fluff made up of tiny fibres which separate from cloth or yarn. Also, soft fabric used for dressing wounds.
english.mnemonic: She leant (lint) against the Van de Graaff generator and her hair fluffed up.
english.question: What is lint?

english.definition: Say you agree but do nothing
english.mnemonic: The lip came to serve us (lip service). We asked for food. The lip said 'yes', but did nothing. It just stood there.
english.question: What does it mean to give lip service?

english.definition: Having a thin, supple and graceful body
english.mnemonic: Listen to Mum (lissom) if you want to have a thin, supple body.
english.question: What does the term "lissom" mean?

english.definition: a long, repetitive list or series
english.mnemonic: Lit by many (litany) candles, he read out his long, repetitive list of grievances.
english.question: What is a litany?

english.definition: Legal action. Brought before a court of law
english.mnemonic: He lit up a gate (litigate) and so they took legal action and he was brought before a court of law.
english.question: What does it mean to litigate?

english.definition: A whole or entire period of time, usually seeming to take a long time to reach the end
english.mnemonic: The tortoise had lived a long (livelong) life of several hundred years! The eulogy took up the whole period of the funeral service, and it felt like it took a long time to reach the end.
keywords: felt like it took a long time
english.question: What does "livelong" mean?

english.definition: Unhappy and bad-tempered
english.mnemonic: Liver and fish (liverish) for dinner every day had become so boring – it made her unhappy and bad-tempered.
english.question: What does it mean to be liverish?

english.definition: A lazy person who avoids work
english.mnemonic: She loaded her gopher (loafer) with shopping because she was a lazy person who avoided work.
english.question: What is a loafer?

english.definition: Repulsive – something that causes hatred or disgust.
english.mnemonic: Loaves, some (loathsome) of them looked disgusting and tasted repulsive.
english.question: What does the term "loathsome" mean?

english.definition: A person who temporarily fulfils duties of another, especially a physician or clergyman.
english.mnemonic: Can someone local come (locum) and fill in while the other doctor is sick?
english.question: What is a locum?

english.definition: The organised movement of materials, goods and sometimes people
english.mnemonic: My little lodger kept statistics (logistics) of all my movements in the house, including all the materials and people I moved in and out.
english.question: What is logistics?

english.definition: Long life, long continuous service
english.mnemonic: A long jetty (longevity) for people who have had a long life, because they have had more time to afford a bigger boat.
english.question: What is longevity?

english.definition: A long, bounding stride.
english.mnemonic: He came across a low lying P (Lope) so he bounded over it in a single stride.
english.question: What is a lope?

english.definition: Tending to talk a lot
english.mnemonic: Locating us (loquacious) by talking a lot was the only way the blind people could find us.
english.question: What does loquacious mean?

english.definition: Sad because the person you love does not love you
english.mnemonic: The love the gardener felt for his lawn (lovelorn) made him feel sad because the lawn could not love him in return.
english.question: What does it mean to be lovelorn?

english.definition: Easy to understand; expressed clearly
english.mnemonic: The loo slid (lucid) and everything was clear to be seen.
english.question: What does the term "lucid" mean?

english.definition: Another name for Satan or the Devil
english.mnemonic: Lose their fur (lucifer) was Cruella De Vil's (devil) scheme.
english.question: What is another name for Satan or the Devil?

english.definition: Producing a great deal of profit
english.mnemonic: Their loo was creative (lucrative) and the fees they charged people to use it produced a great profit.
english.question: What does the term "lucrative" mean?

english.definition: Very foolish; stupid; Causing laughter because of absurdity
english.mnemonic: It was lewd to cross (ludicrous) in so few clothes and stupid because it was so cold, but it caused her to laugh.
english.question: What does "ludicrous" mean?

english.definition: Looking or sounding sad and gloomy
english.mnemonic: Lugging all this goo beat us (lugubrious). The others were so much bigger and better than us. It made me sad and gloomy.
english.question: What does lugubrious mean?

english.definition: To make someone feel calm or sleepy
english.mnemonic: She sang a lullaby (lull) and so the child calmed down and fell asleep.
english.question: What does it mean to lull someone?

english.definition: a clumsy, stupid person
english.mnemonic: This lumberjack mucks (lummox) everything up. He's a clumsy, stupid person.
english.question: What does the term "lummox" describe?

english.definition: The glow of reflected light off a surface; sheen
english.mnemonic: It looked like she was flustering (lustre) over nothing, but she always had to polish her front step until it glowed with the light reflecting off it.
english.question: What is lustre?

english.definition: Disturbing because concerned with death; morbid or gruesome.
english.mnemonic: Ma carved (macabre) cows in half for a Damien Hurst exhibition. Is it all about death?
english.question: What does "macabre" mean?

english.definition: A plot or scheme
english.mnemonic: One match and the nation (machination) will change. Well, that was the plot, but no one had a match.
english.question: What is a machination?

english.definition: Study of financial systems at a regional, national or global level
english.mnemonic: Big Macs in a row can be used for economics (macroeconomics) studies of financial systems, and stock exchange comparisons.
english.question: What is macroeconomics?

english.definition: Generous or forgiving, especially towards a rival
english.mnemonic: A Magnum gun was pulled on us (magnanimous) but we are generous and forgiving so just handed him some flowers.
english.question: What does it mean to be magnanimous?

english.definition: A person of great influence and wealth
english.mnemonic: His magnificent eight (magnate) rings were evidence that he was a person of great wealth and influence.
english.question: What is a magnate?

english.definition: The original surname of a married woman
english.mnemonic: The maiden didn't know the name (maiden name), so she said "Open sesame", but the door would only open if she used her mother's birth name.
english.question: What does "maiden name" refer to?

english.definition: In cricket, an over in which no runs are scored.
english.mnemonic: The maiden fell over (maiden over) so no runs were scored.
english.question: What is a maiden over in cricket?

english.definition: 1. The work needed to keep a vehicle, road, machine, or building in good condition. 2. Money given for a person's living expenses.
english.mnemonic: The main ten ants (maintenance) work on keeping the nest in good condition, while the queen gives them money for living expenses.
english.question: What are the two meanings of maintenance?

english.definition: Failing to cope with normal life; maladjusted people have been raised in a way that does not prepare them for society's demands.
english.mnemonic: The mallet adjusted (maladjusted) her coping mechanism. She was now failing to cope with normal life.
english.question: What does it mean when someone is described as maladjusted?

english.definition: clumsy, awkward and unskilled
english.mnemonic: The mallard droid isn't (maladroit) as good as a real duck because it walks clumsily and is awkward.
english.question: What does "maladroit" mean?

english.definition: Meaningless talk; nonsense
english.mnemonic: The mother lark keeps (malarkey) talking nonsense.
english.question: What does the term "malarkey" mean?

english.definition: A person who is dissatisfied and rebellious.
english.mnemonic: As they drove down the mall away from the palace, they were no longer content (malcontent) to be members of the royal family. They were dissatisfied and rebellious.
english.question: What is a malcontent?

english.definition: A person who commits a crime
english.mnemonic: A malfunction was the factor (malefactor) for them being caught committing a crime.
english.question: What is a malefactor?

english.definition: The desire to harm someone
english.mnemonic: Ma leased everything I owned just to teach me a lesson and harm me.
english.question: What does malice mean?

english.definition: Evil in nature or effect
english.mnemonic: Ma's ligament (malignant) was very harmful and bad. No wonder she had problems walking.
english.question: What does malignant mean?

english.definition: Pretend to be ill in order to avoid having to work
english.mnemonic: The man lingered (malinger) in bed to avoid going to work.
english.question: What does it mean to malinger?

english.definition: Smelling very unpleasant
english.mnemonic: The mallard's odour made us (malodorous) run away. He smelt very unpleasant.
english.question: What does malodorous mean?

english.definition: Treat (a person or thing) cruelly or with violence
english.mnemonic: She used a mallet on the patients who came in for treatment (maltreat) - it was cruel and violent.
english.question: What does it mean to maltreat someone or something?

english.definition: Influential Person
english.mnemonic: The man would ring (mandarin) all the people he thought were influential.
english.question: What is the definition of the term "Mandarin" when referring to a person?

english.definition: Give authority to do something. An official order to take action.
english.mnemonic: Be a man and go ask her for a date (mandate). As your friend, I'm commanding you.
english.question: What does it mean to have a mandate?

english.definition: Required by law, compulsory
english.mnemonic: The man tore the tree down (mandatory): he had to do it because it was compulsory when a tree exceeded the height limit.
english.question: What does the term "mandatory" mean?

english.definition: Mental illness characterised by excessive emotion
english.mnemonic: The main road nearby (mania) doesn't have cars on it only people running around with mental illness and excessive emotions.
english.question: What is mania?

english.definition: To show, become visible or obvious. Clearly true.
english.mnemonic: The man's vest (manifest) made him visible although it was clearly true that he was invisible.
english.question: What does it mean to manifest something?

english.definition: A public declaration of policies and aims, especially before an election
english.mnemonic: "Every man will have enough pesto" (manifesto), said the politician while making a public declaration of policies before the election.
english.question: What is a manifesto?

english.definition: 1. Many types 2. A pipe or chamber branching into multiple openings
english.mnemonic: "Man! You can fold (manifold) paper into many types of animals."
english.question: What is a manifold?

english.definition: 1. Many types 2. A pipe or chamber branching into multiple openings
english.mnemonic: Or you could just fold paper into a pipe with many holes.
english.question: What are the two primary meanings of the term "manifold"?

english.definition: The female of a horse or other equine animal (donkey or mule)
english.mnemonic: The mayor (mare) was unconventional – she insisted on travelling around the city on a very female horse.
english.question: What is a mare?

english.definition: Related to or found in the sea or sea transport
english.mnemonic: The submarine (marine) is the only form of sea transport in which you can observe everything found in the sea.
english.question: What does the term "marine" refer to?

english.definition: Connected with the sea, especially in relation to seaborne trade or naval matters
english.mnemonic: They got married during their time (maritime) at sea in the navy.
english.question: What does "maritime" refer to in relation to trade or naval matters?

english.definition: Mammals who are born incompletely developed and are typically carried in a pouch until developed.
english.mnemonic: On Mars, the animals ate soup for every meal (marsupial). They kept it in their pouches.
english.question: What is a marsupial?

english.definition: To chew food
english.mnemonic: The broken mast indicates (masticate) that something has been chewing it.
english.question: What does it mean to masticate?

english.definition: 1. becomes real or true; happen 2. suddenly appear
english.mnemonic: The material I wanted to utilise (materialise) was nowhere to be found, but my mum always makes my wishes become true and suddenly it appeared.
english.question: What does the term "materialise" mean?

english.definition: Caring more about material things than people
english.mnemonic: Material list? (materialistic). Yes, she was obsessed with creating a material list with all her possessions listed. That was all she was concerned about, her material things.
english.question: What does it mean to be materialistic?

english.definition: Relating to a mother; motherly
english.mnemonic: Ma's love is eternal (maternal). Her motherly instincts mean she will never stop protecting and caring for me, no matter what...
english.question: What does "maternal" mean?

english.definition: A woman who is the head of the family
english.mnemonic: May the tree arc (matriarch) and bow to the woman who is the head of the family.
english.question: What is a matriarch?

english.definition: Related to marriage
english.mnemonic: The mat was ceremonial (matrimonial) - it only came out when they celebrated an event related to their marriage.
english.question: What does the term "matrimonial" refer to?

english.definition: Over emotional, exaggerated emotion or sentimentality
english.mnemonic: More kisses (mawkish) than I needed. Ma was far too emotional for my first day of school.
english.question: What does the term "mawkish" mean?

english.definition: A truth or rule
english.mnemonic: Maxim (maxim) isn't short for maximum and that's a truth.
english.question: What is a maxim?

english.definition: Small in quantity
english.mnemonic: Me, I go grrr (meagre) when I get such small quantities.
english.question: What does "meagre" mean?

english.definition: Follow a winding path or river; winding bend of a river or road
english.mnemonic: Me and her (meander) always like to go for a wander down winding paths every night.
english.question: What does it mean to meander?

english.definition: A varied mixture of people or things
english.mnemonic: "Don't meddle with that; leave (medley) it alone!" The witch wouldn't let anyone touch the mixture she was working on.
english.question: What is a medley?

english.definition: Someone who has an unnaturally strong wish for power and control
english.mnemonic: Shouting through the megaphone at the top of his lungs, this maniac (megalomaniac) had an unnaturally strong wish for power and control.
english.question: What is a megalomaniac?

english.definition: Sadness that lasts a long time (often without any obvious reason)
english.mnemonic: The melon couldn't take her collie dog (melancholy) out because she had no legs. It made her feel very sad.
english.question: What is melancholy?

english.definition: Combine and blend
english.mnemonic: Melt and weld (meld) blend to form meld.
english.question: What does it mean to meld?

english.definition: Refers to something that is sweet sounding and pleasing to the ear.
english.mnemonic: The singing melon flew over us (Mellifluous). Is that what you call 'sweet sounding'?
english.question: What does mellifluous mean?

english.definition: A written message or brief report. A document recording the terms of a meeting or contract.
english.mnemonic: Memory can be random (memorandum) but not when a report has been written recording the terms of the discussion.
english.question: What is a memorandum?

english.definition: Not telling the truth; lying
english.mnemonic: The men slept during the day in a corner of the spacious (mendacious) warehouse when they should have been working. They were asked if they worked today and they were lying when they said 'yes'.
english.question: What does the term "mendacious" mean?

english.definition: Untruthfulness; tendency to lie
english.mnemonic: She must use her 'mend that city' (mendacity) spell because everyone lies in this city.
english.question: What is mendacity?

english.definition: A person's particular way of thinking about things
english.mnemonic: The men tallied cups of tea (mentality). They each had to drink 16 cups of tea per day. It was a particular way of thinking about how to stay hydrated.
english.question: What does the term "mentality" refer to?

english.definition: An experienced and trusted advisor
english.mnemonic: The men tore (mentor) open the box of books. The experienced and trusted advisors then handed them out to the young learners.
english.question: Who is considered a mentor?

english.definition: Engaged in trade. Relating to the business of buying and selling.
english.mnemonic: Merchants on islands (mercantile) love buying and selling.
english.question: What does the term "mercantile" refer to?

english.definition: More concerned about making money than doing the right thing
english.mnemonic: There's no mercy from this person who is so scary (mercenary) in battle. He'll fight for any side – making money is the only thing he's concerned about.
english.question: What does it mean to be mercenary?

english.definition: changeable; changing suddenly and often
english.mnemonic: The mercury in the thermometer all (mercurial) of a sudden dropped. The weather in this area can change suddenly and often.
english.question: What does the term "mercurial" mean?

english.definition: A great change in appearance or character
english.mnemonic: Have you met a morph (metamorphosis) before? It can change appearance and shape easily.
english.question: What is metamorphosis?

english.definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
english.mnemonic: The mutt was ridiculously (meticulous) good at drawing, showing great attention to detail.
english.question: What does it mean to be meticulous?

english.definition: A main city or a very large city, often with a population over 50,000.
english.mnemonic: Metro! . . . Police! (metropolis) . . . This has to be a city.
english.question: What is a metropolis?

english.definition: A small extra floor between two main floors. An intermediate floor with a balcony.
english.mnemonic: What a mess of a scene (mezzanine). On the extra floor was a mess. You could say a mess on the mezzanine.
english.question: What is a mezzanine?

english.definition: Area at the front of a body between the chest and the waist; the human abdomen
english.mnemonic: In the middle of winter her hands drift (midriff) to cover the area between her chest and her waist.
english.question: What is the midriff?

english.definition: A person's appearance or manner, especially as an indication of their character or mood.
english.mnemonic: He looked mean (mien). His appearance was an indication of his character.
english.question: What does "mien" refer to?

english.definition: Slightly annoying or offended
english.mnemonic: They were missing. My gifts (miffed) had been stolen, which made me slightly annoyed.
english.question: What does it mean to be miffed?

english.definition: Favouring confrontational or violent methods in support of a cause
english.mnemonic: The military ant (militant) was in favour of confrontation.
english.question: What does it mean to be militant?

english.definition: Very small amount
english.mnemonic: The minuscule animal (minimal) made a very small amount of noise.
english.question: What does the term "minimal" mean?

english.definition: Extremely small, tiny
english.mnemonic: It was a mini school (minuscule), it was so tiny.
english.question: What does "minuscule" mean?

english.definition: Laughter and merriment
english.mnemonic: The mother, after the birth (mirth), was laughing so happily.
english.question: What does the term "mirth" refer to?

english.definition: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids people
english.mnemonic: She would miss school and throw up (misanthrope) because she disliked meeting other people so much.
english.question: What is a misanthrope?

english.definition: A person who has done something wrong
english.mnemonic: You've missed the ice cream out (miscreant), you've done something wrong.
english.question: What is a miscreant?

english.definition: A minor wrong-doing
english.mnemonic: Mister Meaner (misdemeanor) was forever tripping people up. He couldn't be sent to prison for it, but it needed punishing.
english.question: What is a misdemeanor?

english.definition: A wrong or inaccurate name
english.mnemonic: Miss Gnome (misnomer) is not my name – it is actually Shirley.
english.question: What does the term "misnomer" mean?

english.definition: Dislike of or aversion to marriage
english.mnemonic: Miss my dog but not my mean (misogamy) marriage which I disliked almost from the start.
english.question: What is misogamy?

english.definition: A dislike of women
english.mnemonic: "I miss my dog, genie." (misogyny) "Wouldn't you prefer a woman?" asked the genie "No way," he said, "I prefer a dog."
english.question: What does the term misogyny mean?

english.definition: A letter or some other written communication, usually a long or official one.
english.mnemonic: She would miss the sieve (missive) every time she tried to put something in it, so was sent a written communication telling her she was sacked.
english.question: What is a missive?

english.definition: A legal trial declared invalid through an error in the proceedings
english.mnemonic: The judge missed the trial (mistrial), which was declared invalid due to this error in proceedings.
english.question: What is a mistrial?

english.definition: To make less severe
english.mnemonic: The mit came out of the gate (mitigate) but reduced speed when it saw the oven.
english.question: What does it mean to mitigate something?

english.definition: 1. Headdress/ hat worn by bishops and senior abbots as a symbol of office 2. A joint made between two pieces of wood or other materials at an angle of 90°
english.mnemonic: It was my turn (mitre) to wear the bishop's hat, but it was awkward to wear while making a joint between two pieces of wood at a ninety degree angle.
english.question: What is a mitre?

english.definition: A memory aid
english.mnemonic: The nimble demonic (mnemonic) troll had a sign on it as a memory aid to help me remember how evil it was.
english.question: What is a mnemonic?

english.definition: 1. Adjective: Not an extreme view, amount, size, degree or strength. 2. Verb: Preside over a debate or to ensure fairness.
english.mnemonic: She wanted a model that went at a rate (moderate) some might think is slow - she didn't want anything about it to be extreme. The sales person presided over the debate between husband and wife.
english.question: What does it mean when something is described as moderate?

english.definition: behaviour in which you avoid talking about your abilities, qualities or possessions
english.mnemonic: The price of her modern house is steep (modesty), but she avoids talking about her possessions.
english.question: What is modesty?

english.definition: Fashionable
english.mnemonic: Their mode of transport was a dish (modish). It was very fashionable with all the extra-terrestrials.
english.question: What does the term "modish" mean?

english.definition: 1. to change something, such as an action or process, to make it more suitable 2. To change the style, pitch, loudness etc. of something, such as your voice
english.mnemonic: The model said, "You are late," (modulate). So I said I had to change to a new faster processing camera and change my style.
english.question: What does it mean to modulate something?

english.definition: A thick, dark-brown liquid that is produced during the process of making sugar.
english.mnemonic: A mole with glasses (molasses) loved having the dark-brown liquid poured from the sugar cane.
english.question: What is molasses?

english.definition: Touch or attack someone in a sexual way
english.mnemonic: The gardener decided to mow less (molest) because she was touched and attacked by a mole every time she cut the grass.
english.question: What does it mean to molest someone?

english.definition: Of great importance or significance
english.mnemonic: Looking back, the best moment for us (momentous) was when we had a family photograph. It is of great importance to me and hangs in pride of place.
english.question: What does "momentous" mean?

english.definition: A sovereign head of state, especially a king, queen or emperor.
english.mnemonic: There was a monster ark (monarch) on the King and queen's heads.
english.question: What is a monarch?

english.definition: Sexual relationships or marriage with only one other person
english.mnemonic: In monopoly (mono) there's only one winner.
english.question: What is monogamy?

english.definition: Marriage
english.mnemonic: He has a gammy (gamy) leg, but she saw beyond that and agreed to his marriage proposal.
english.question: What does the term "gamy" refer to in terms of relationships?

english.definition: a design based on someone's initials, usually marked on things they own
english.mnemonic: Even on his monocle, my gramps (monogram) had etched his initials in a fancy design.
english.question: What is a monogram?

english.definition: A long speech by one person. A monologue is a prolonged talk by a single speaker, especially one dominating or monopolizing a conversation.
english.mnemonic: The money log (monologue) showed that he was worth a lot of money. It took the accountant a long time to read it all out.
english.question: What is a monologue?

english.definition: Exclusive control of a service or commodity
english.mnemonic: They played Monopoly (monopoly) and she had possession of every hotel and house on the board. The other players were in fear because she had total control.
english.question: What is a monopoly?

english.definition: Illegally distilled or smuggled alcohol
english.mnemonic: As the moon began to shine (moonshine), it revealed to the police the illegally distilled alcohol that was being smuggled.
english.question: What is moonshine?

english.definition: Concerned with the principles of right and wrong, good or bad
english.mnemonic: 'More! All!' (moral) said the Devil on his shoulder. 'Less! None!' said the Angel on the other side. What's right and what's wrong?
english.question: What does "moral" refer to in terms of principles?

english.definition: The confidence or enthusiasm of a person or group.
english.mnemonic: More alcohol (morale) was drunk and they gained confidence.
english.question: What does the term "morale" refer to?

english.definition: Interest in unpleasant things, especially death.
english.mnemonic: There were more bids (morbid) on the dead people than the live ones. The purchasers were fascinated by death.
english.question: What does the term "morbid" describe?

english.definition: Cruel and criticizing in a humorous way
english.mnemonic: I can understand why more comedians didn't (mordant) say cruel and criticising things about her in a humorous way.
english.question: What does "mordant" mean in relation to humor?

english.definition: also and more importantly
english.mnemonic: I moored the boat over (moreover) there, but also, and more importantly, I've left it secure.
english.question: What does the term "moreover" mean?

english.definition: Near death
english.mnemonic: There is now more abundant (moribund) evidence that the disease has spread, leaving her near death.
english.question: What does the term "moribund" mean?

english.definition: Unhappy, sulky, gloomy, sad and unwilling to speak or smile
english.mnemonic: More hose (morose) just made her more unhappy and gloomy.
english.question: What does the term "morose" mean?

english.definition: 1. (of living things) unable to live forever; having to die 2. (of an injury/wound) causing death
english.mnemonic: It's morbid, but the battle (mortal) will cause death, and we cannot live forever.
english.question: What does the term "mortal" mean?

english.definition: To make someone very embarrassed
english.mnemonic: More to fly (mortify). How can we get any more on the flight? It makes me so embarrassed.
english.question: What does it mean to mortify someone?

english.definition: Consisting of many different types that do not appear to go together
english.mnemonic: The club's motto is "we don't leave (motley) anyone out". It consists of many different types of people that wouldn't usually fit together.
english.question: What does the term "motley" mean?

english.definition: Marked with spots or smears of colours
english.mnemonic: Not bottled correctly (mottled): When it's not bottled correctly the fluid can explode and put smears and spots everywhere.
english.question: What does "mottled" mean?

english.definition: Someone who tricks people out of their money (usually by making false claims about a medical remedy)
english.mnemonic: "In the mountains I have a bank (mountebank). Give me your money and I will look after it for you". But it was a trick to steal people's money.
english.question: What is a mountebank?

english.definition: A vertical bar between the panes of glass in a window
english.mnemonic: She became a multi-millionaire (mullion) selling the vertical bars between window panes.
english.question: What is a mullion in the context of window design?

english.definition: Many in number and type
english.mnemonic: Multiple fairies (multifarious) arrived. They were many different types.
english.question: What does multifarious mean?

english.definition: Very numerous
english.mnemonic: Multiple cats chose tuna for their dinners (multitudinous). There were so many of them that the restaurant ran out.
english.question: What does multitudinous mean?

english.definition: Of or belonging to a town or city
english.mnemonic: Music is a pal (municipal) to everyone who belongs in these towns.
english.question: What does the term "municipal" refer to?

english.definition: Giving large amounts of money or gifts; very generous
english.mnemonic: Your munitions are magnificent! (munificent) and I tell you what I will give you a large amount of money for them.
english.question: What does the term "munificent" mean?

english.definition: Weapons and stores used by the military
english.mnemonic: The mule was kept along with ammunition (munition) in the military stores; it turned out to be one of their best weapons.
english.question: What does the term munition refer to?

english.definition: 1. To think about something carefully and for a long time. 2. A person who is the source of inspiration for an artist.
english.mnemonic: Looking at the exhibit in the museum (muse), he thought carefully for a long time about what it meant. But he knew who had been the source of inspiration for the artist.
english.question: What does it mean to muse?

english.definition: A strong-smelling substance secreted by the male deer for scent marking and is used in perfume.
english.mnemonic: Elon Musk (musk) uses a strong-smelling substance secreted by a male deer to create a perfume.
english.question: What is musk?

english.definition: Smelling unpleasantly old and slightly wet
english.mnemonic: You must erase (musty) all this smelly unpleasant air.
english.question: What does "musty" refer to?

english.definition: Extremely great number
english.mnemonic: The mirrors he had (myriad) in his house were so numerous he couldn't count them.
english.question: What does the term "myriad" mean?

english.definition: 1. The lowest or least successful point in a situation 2. Lowest point reached by a heavenly body, or the point directly below an observer
english.mnemonic: "Nay dear (Nadir)," she said, "you can only kiss my lowest point - my feet."
english.question: What is the meaning of "nadir"?

english.definition: Lacking in experience, too willing to believe.
english.mnemonic: The night Eve (naive) was deceived by the serpent into eating the forbidden fruit. She was too willing to believe the snake was telling the truth.
english.question: What does it mean when someone is described as naive?

english.definition: A person or thing that has the same name as another
english.mnemonic: We changed our names for the sake (namesake) of ease. Having the same name as a sibling is quite confusing.
english.question: What is a namesake?

english.definition: Too much interest in your own physical appearance; Exaggerated sense of self importance
english.mnemonic: "Na! Let's scissor them (narcissism). He was so convinced he looked amazing he believed everyone else should look the same. What an exaggerated sense of self-importance."
english.question: What is narcissism?

english.definition: An addictive drug
english.mnemonic: The anarchist got sick (narcotic) from taking addictive drugs.
english.question: What is a narcotic?

english.definition: Give a spoken or written account of or tell the story of something
english.mnemonic: Nan ate (narrate) while he tried to tell his story!
english.question: What does it mean to narrate something?

english.definition: Not willing to listen to or tolerate other people's views; prejudice
english.mnemonic: The narrow-minded individual was not willing to listen to or tolerate other people's views.
english.question: What does it mean to be narrow-minded?

english.definition: When a government takes over and runs a private company, it is said to nationalize it.
english.mnemonic: The nation can utilise (nationalise) its power to take ownership of a company.
english.question: What does it mean to nationalise a company?

english.definition: Feeling of sickness
english.mnemonic: The Norse Sea (nausea) is where the Vikings sometimes encountered huge waves that looked like sea monsters that made them feel sick.
english.question: What is nausea?

english.definition: 1. Uncivilised and unintelligent person; looks or acts like a caveman. 2. Extinct species of human that existed between about 200,000 and 40,000 years ago.
english.mnemonic: He struck him on his knee and the tall (Neanderthal) man fell to the ground. The unintelligent attacker looked like a caveman.
english.question: What is a Neanderthal?

english.definition: (1) Needy; impoverished (2) Urgent; badly needed
english.mnemonic: Lacking the necessit	ies that most of us (necessitous) take for granted, these impoverished people need urgent help.
english.question: What does "necessitous" mean?

english.definition: Morally bad; wicked
english.mnemonic: Kneeing fairies (nefarious) is wicked.
english.question: What does the term "nefarious" mean?

english.definition: Make ineffective, nullify
english.mnemonic: No gate (negate) any more- the gate is completely useless.
english.question: What does it mean to negate something?

english.definition: Failing to take proper care over something.
english.mnemonic: I gave the house sitter a negative review; he wasn't intelligent (negligent) and had failed to take proper care of it.
keywords: failed to take proper care of
english.question: What does it mean to be negligent?

english.definition: Something that a person cannot conquer; the cause of a person's downfall
english.mnemonic: Following several near misses (nemesis), she thought she could beat the police, but she couldn't beat them, and the arrest brought about her downfall.
english.question: What is a nemesis?

english.definition: The last period of the stone age marked by the use of tools and weapons made from stone
english.mnemonic: We need loads of monolithic (Neolithic) statues of tools and weapons made of stone to worship.
english.question: What was the Neolithic period?

english.definition: The practice, among those with power, of favouring their relatives.
english.mnemonic: Never bother posting a position (nepotism) vacancy; it's a waste of time. It always goes to a member of the family.
english.question: What is nepotism?

english.definition: Profit after tax
english.mnemonic: Fishing with a net (nett) was how the tax officer collected all the tax money. There was little left after the tax officer left.
english.question: What does "nett" mean in financial terms?

english.definition: Irritating; Causing annoyance or difficulty
english.mnemonic: The nettle somewhat (nettlesome) irritated me.
english.question: What does "nettlesome" mean?

english.definition: Behaving strangely in a chronic, worried, irrational or nervous way.
english.mnemonic: New rot (neurotic) had set in which caused him chronic worry and to behave strangely.
english.question: What does it mean to be neurotic?

english.definition: In Greek mythology, the goddess of victory
english.mnemonic: She had the night key (Nike) to the fancy dress shop and would go there late on to dress up as the Greek goddess of victory.
english.question: Who is Nike in Greek mythology?

english.definition: A dark grey cloud that often produces rain or snow
english.mnemonic: You need a nimble bus (nimbus) driver to avoid the dark grey clouds producing snow.
english.question: What type of cloud is a nimbus?

english.definition: 1. A mighty hunter; a legendary biblical figure from the book of Genesis. 2. (in North America) An inept person; an idiot.
english.mnemonic: He was a nimble rod (nimrod) of a person, but what a fantastic hunter. What an idiot though to run around half naked.
english.question: Who is Nimrod, characterized both as a mighty hunter and, in North America, as an inept person?

english.definition: a foolish or stupid person
english.mnemonic: He thought he could make an income from poop (nincompoop) despite everyone calling him a foolish and stupid person.
english.question: What does the term "nincompoop" mean?

english.definition: A state of perfect peace and happiness
english.mnemonic: Who would have the nerve to harm her (nirvana) when she seemed in such an amazing state of perfect peace and happiness.
english.question: What is nirvana?

english.definition: happening in or active during the night
english.mnemonic: We heard a knocking noise and when we turned, we saw all (nocturnal) the ghosts had become active at night.
english.question: What does "nocturnal" mean?

english.definition: 1. In name or thought but not in fact (e.g., a 'nominal' head of an organization doesn't actually do the work). 2. Insignificant in relation to money compared to the expected.
english.mnemonic: The Russian prime minister was nominated by all (nominal) the members of the political party but everyone knew that it was in name only. It was Putin who held the real power. So the prime minister would only get a small part of the usual remuneration.
english.question: What does "nominal" mean in terms of status and monetary value?

english.definition: Not showing interest. Appearing casually calm and relaxed.
english.mnemonic: None shall listen to the ant (nonchalant). Stay calm and show no interest in her.
english.question: What does it mean to be nonchalant?

english.definition: Having no unusual or interesting features or qualities; dull or boring
english.mnemonic: What nonsense, the depressing script (nondescript) was nothing unusual or interesting and the characters were dull and boring.
english.question: What does the term "nondescript" mean?

english.definition: Unimportant person or thing
english.mnemonic: No entry (nonentity) to unimportant people. They use the side door.
english.question: What does the term "nonentity" mean?

english.definition: Surprised, confused and not certain how to react
english.mnemonic: Nonsense, there's a plus you've missed (nonplus) out. The genius mathematician looked surprised, confused and not sure how to react.
english.question: What does it mean to be nonplussed?

english.definition: Relating to a norm, as the standard of correct behaviour
english.mnemonic: He's watched the other dragons gnaw and munch their captives (normative), so the younger dragon considered it to be the standard of correct behaviour.
english.question: What does normative mean?

english.definition: Affection for a period in the past
english.mnemonic: No Stallion could jump (nostalgia) as high. The horse can't do it now but we all look back to the past with affection.
english.question: What is nostalgia?

english.definition: Famous for something bad
english.mnemonic: The note he tore from us (notorious) had a picture on it that was famous for being bad.
english.question: What does the term "notorious" mean?

english.definition: In spite of; Despite the fact
english.mnemonic: I'm not standing with them (notwithstanding) in spite of the fact I'm in the same team.
english.question: What does "notwithstanding" mean?

english.definition: Common sense, practical intelligence
english.mnemonic: Now that Tom the cat caught the mouse (nous), he can relax. It only took a bit of common sense.
english.question: What is meant by the term "nous"?

english.definition: A slight and subtle difference in sound, colour, feeling, appearance, or meaning
english.mnemonic: The new ones (nuance) were only slightly different to the old ones.
english.question: What does the term "nuance" refer to?

english.definition: Of no value or importance
english.mnemonic: The newspaper got the story (nugatory) wrong again. 'That newspaper is of no value or importance,' said the husband to his wife.
english.question: What does the term "nugatory" mean?

english.definition: A mythological creature represented as a beautiful young woman; also a young insect yet to reach maturity.
english.mnemonic: The nimble thief (nymph) caught by the police was a beautiful spirit of nature.
english.question: What is a nymph?

english.definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion
english.mnemonic: Obey due date (obdurate): he stubbornly refused to do any work. He wouldn't change.
english.question: What does it mean to be obdurate?

english.definition: A brief biography of a deceased person.
english.mnemonic: A bit of your story (obituary) is given at your funeral and maybe in a newspaper.
english.question: What is an obituary?

english.definition: a thing aimed for or sought; a goal
english.mnemonic: This object is something I actively (objective) worked towards; it was a goal of mine.
english.question: What is the definition of "objective"?

english.definition: Required by a legal, moral, or other rule; compulsory.
english.mnemonic: We're obliged to put a wig on a tree (obligatory). It's a legal requirement.
english.question: What does "obligatory" mean?

english.definition: make (someone) legally or morally bound to do something
english.mnemonic: He will obviously lie just (oblige) to make people feel morally bound to give him money.
english.question: What does it mean to oblige someone?

english.definition: Neither parallel nor at right angle; slanting
english.mnemonic: Your future is oh so bleak (oblique). The graph shows a line, neither parallel nor at right angles, to the x and y axis but a sharp slanting line.
english.question: What does the term "oblique" mean in geometry?

english.definition: not aware or concerned with what is happening around you
english.mnemonic: It's obvious you like to live with us (oblivious) but you are clearly not aware of your surroundings.
english.question: What does it mean to be oblivious?

english.definition: Very unpleasant
english.mnemonic: The object was knocked (obnoxious) onto the floor and gave off a very unpleasant smell.
english.question: What does the term "obnoxious" mean?

english.definition: Too eager to praise or obey someone
english.mnemonic: Obsessed about seeing the Queen (obsequious) here was his chance to prove how eager to please he was.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as obsequious?

english.definition: no longer produced or used; out of date
english.mnemonic: These are obviously so yesterday. The fleeting (obsolete) moment of popularity is gone, and they're now out of date and no longer produced.
english.question: What does it mean when something is considered obsolete?

english.definition: Related to childbirth and associated processes, including pregnancy.
english.mnemonic: Many obstacles had electric (obstetric) cables sticking out of them, but you need these when monitoring pregnancy and birth processes.
english.question: What does the term "obstetric" relate to?

english.definition: Stubborn and unwilling to change, despite what anyone else says.
english.mnemonic: The hob was stained as I ate (obstinate) - there is no way those marks will come off the hob now. They will be stubborn marks.
english.question: What does the term "obstinate" mean?

english.definition: Noisy and difficult to control
english.mnemonic: The obstruction prepared us (obstreperous) for what was going to be a noisy and difficult-to-control crowd of people.
english.question: What does "obstreperous" mean?

english.definition: Too noticeable in an unwelcome way
english.mnemonic: The object was truly a civil engineering disaster. It was too noticeable and was certainly unwelcome.
english.question: What does "obtrusive" mean?

english.definition: Stupid or slow to understand
english.mnemonic: An object to chew (obtuse) was what the dog was looking for, but it was slow to understand that it was bad behaviour.
english.question: What does obtuse mean when referring to someone's comprehension or intelligence?

english.definition: To close up or block off
english.mnemonic: A clued-up (occlude) lorry driver knew the way ahead was blocked off.
english.question: What does it mean to occlude something?

english.definition: Mystical practices; Magical powers, activities such as witchcraft
english.mnemonic: A colt (occult) was dressed up in witch's gear as if it had magical powers.
english.question: What does the term occult refer to?

english.definition: Extremely unpleasant or repulsive.
english.mnemonic: His odour deeply shocked us (odious). It was repulsive to him and anyone who came near.
english.question: What does the term "odious" mean?

english.definition: 1. An attack on someone or something 2. Causing upset
english.mnemonic: He pushed the cat off the fence with a sieve (offensive) and now it was upset, and launched an attack on him.
english.question: What does the term "offensive" mean?

english.definition: To be in charge of an event, or to perform duties.
english.mnemonic: A fish she ate (officiate) finally after Dad was put in charge.
english.question: What does it mean to officiate an event?

english.definition: Meddlesome; objectionably aggressive in offering one's unrequested and unwanted services.
english.mnemonic: I'm now off fish (officious) because you have interfered and meddled in its making.
english.question: What does the term officious mean?

english.definition: An official appointed to investigate individuals' complaints against a company or organisation.
english.mnemonic: Oh, my bud man! (ombudsman). Can you find out what happened, please?
english.question: What is the role of an ombudsman?

english.definition: A code of silence practised by the mafia
english.mnemonic: Oh please don't murder me tonight (omerta). I promise I won't say anything and will give you my vow of silence.
english.question: What is the code of silence practiced by the mafia?

english.definition: Suggesting that something unpleasant is likely to happen
english.mnemonic: Oh, minus (ominous) on everything. This is going to be bad.
english.question: What does the term "ominous" mean?

english.definition: Volume containing several books previously published separately; a compilation of TV programme episodes
english.mnemonic: On my bus (omnibus) were all my books. It was a mobile library that contained a number of books.
english.question: What is an omnibus?

english.definition: Relating to a task which is difficult to do or requires a great deal of effort
english.mnemonic: The owner made us (onerous) work all day. It required a great deal of effort to keep up.
english.question: What does the term "onerous" mean?

english.definition: Continuing; still in progress
english.mnemonic: I got on a boat going (ongoing) across the ocean, but six months later the journey's still in progress.
english.question: What does "ongoing" mean?

english.definition: The start of something (usually unpleasant)
english.mnemonic: On the television set (onset) there was the start of a really unpleasant show.
english.question: What does the term "onset" refer to?

english.definition: Not able to see through: not transparent
english.mnemonic: Opals make (Opaque) pretty windows but we can't see through them!
english.question: What does the term "opaque" mean?

english.definition: Functioning or producing a desired effect.
english.mnemonic: The operation was effective (operative) in producing the desired effect. He was now a functioning cyborg.
english.question: What does the term "operative" mean when referring to something that is functioning or producing a desired effect?

english.definition: To express an opinion
english.mnemonic: "Only pineapple (opine) should be allowed on pizzas!" He expressed his opinion, but everyone ignored him.
english.question: What does it mean to opine?

english.definition: Person who is certain about their beliefs and expresses them strongly and often.
english.mnemonic: His opinion she hated (opinionated): hers was correct, she was certain he was wrong and she expressed her views strongly.
english.question: What does it mean to be opinionated?

english.definition: To burden people with a harsh exercise of power; to govern people unfairly and cruelly
english.mnemonic: The others press (oppress) down on me in a harsh exercise of power.
english.question: What does it mean to oppress?

english.definition: Best or most favourable
english.mnemonic: The vet opted to fit the animal (optimal) with new legs so it had the best chance of survival and therefore the most favourable outcome.
english.question: What does optimal mean?

english.definition: Believing that the best will happen
english.mnemonic: I opt to miss (optimism) off the t. That way I can believe I can do it and the best will happen.
english.question: What is optimism?

english.definition: Exhibiting wealth; looking grand and expensive
english.mnemonic: Opal aunt (opulent) I call her as she is very rich and covered in opals.
english.question: What does the term "opulent" mean?

english.definition: Relating to the mouth
english.mnemonic: Remember mouth is oral and ear is aural
english.question: What does the term "oral" refer to?

english.definition: A person who is skilled at making public speeches
english.mnemonic: Oranges were eaten by the Senator (orator) before he addressed the public - he was skilled at making speeches, but he said the oranges gave him extra zest.
english.question: What is an orator?

english.definition: To organise something the way you want it
english.mnemonic: The orchestra was in a straight line (orchestrate) just the way she wanted it.
english.question: What does it mean to orchestrate something?

english.definition: Covered with decorations, highly embellished
english.mnemonic: The awning was in a terrible state (ornate), so they covered it with decorations and made it look highly embellished.
english.question: What does the term "ornate" mean?

english.definition: Following acceptable rules or beliefs conforming to established principles
english.mnemonic: The author of the document (orthodox) says you must follow his rules.
english.question: What does it mean to be orthodox?

english.definition: A branch of medicine responsible for the correction of bones and muscles.
english.mnemonic: The author paid for it (orthopaedics) – the bag of bones would help her write some of the details of her latest murder book.
english.question: What is orthopaedics?

english.definition: Apparent. Appearing to be true but not necessarily so.
english.mnemonic: The host was most sensible (ostensible). When it appeared his guests were getting drunk he gave them a cup of coffee.
english.question: What does ostensible mean?

english.definition: Characterized by a showy display, seeking to attract attention. Attracting or seeking to attract attention, admiration, or envy often by gaudiness.
english.mnemonic: The Oz tent was spacious (ostentatious) and had a chandelier and a welcome mat at its entrance. It certainly was showy.
english.question: What does it mean if something is described as ostentatious?

english.definition: Exclude from society or group
english.mnemonic: The ostrich's size (ostracise) meant he was excluded from joining the group.
english.question: What does it mean to ostracise someone?

english.definition: Force out or expel a person from a place or position
english.mnemonic: The owl was stung (oust) and was forced out.
english.question: What does it mean to oust someone?

english.definition: Much more of something than is necessary
english.mnemonic: She was overly skilled (overkill) for the task, having far more expertise than necessary.
english.question: What does "overkill" mean?

english.definition: Not secret; Done in an open way
english.mnemonic: It's over and I'm hurt (overt). It's not a secret anymore. He loves someone else.
english.question: What does the term "overt" mean in terms of actions or behavior?

english.definition: Something that is suggested, but not clearly stated
english.mnemonic: He knew the relationship was over by the tone (overtone) of her voice. It was suggested but not clearly stated that they break up.
english.question: What is an overtone?

english.definition: Bury or drown beneath a huge mass of something; have a strong emotional effect on someone.
english.mnemonic: She was over her cold and well (overwhelm). It now meant that everyone was buried under a huge mass of paperwork as she tried to catch up.
english.question: What does it mean to overwhelm someone?

english.definition: Branch of medicine that deals with children and their diseases
english.mnemonic: Peed in the hat trick (paediatric) – that's what two of the children did.
english.question: What is paediatrics?

english.definition: A person holding religious beliefs other than those of main world religions
english.mnemonic: A paid gun (pagan) was used to protect the followers of the unconventional religion.
english.question: What is a pagan?

english.definition: A procession of people in elaborate, colourful costumes
english.mnemonic: A page of ants (pageant) was revealed when I opened the book. The ants were in a procession in elaborate, colourful costumes.
english.question: What is a pageant?

english.definition: A temple or sacred building (in India, China etc), usually a tower where each level has an upward-curving roof.
english.mnemonic: Her pug's odour (pagoda) was so bad, she went to the towering temple to buy incense sticks.
english.question: What is a pagoda?

english.definition: Pleasant to taste; acceptable idea or proposal
english.mnemonic: The pallet on the table (palatable) was really pleasant to taste.
english.question: What does "palatable" mean?

english.definition: Faint or deficient in colour; pale looking.
english.mnemonic: Pale lids (pallid), pale eyes, pale face, pale skin. He was pale looking all over.
english.question: What does the term "pallid" mean?

english.definition: Unhealthy pale appearance
english.mnemonic: Was she her pal or (pallor) not? Her face turned pale when she realised her supposed friend was talking behind her back.
english.question: What does the term "pallor" refer to?

english.definition: 1. able to be touched or felt 2. (of a feeling or atmosphere) so strong that it seems as if it can be touched or physically felt
english.mnemonic: My pal put a bull (palpable) in my room. It was so large that it was able to touch the ceiling, and I physically felt fear.
english.question: What does "palpable" mean?

english.definition: less than expected or required
english.mnemonic: The number of poultry (paltry) on the farm was far less than required.
english.question: What does the term "paltry" mean?

english.definition: something that will solve all problems or cure all illnesses
english.mnemonic: Look in the pan and see a (panacea) magic potion. It can cure all problems and illnesses.
english.question: What is a panacea?

english.definition: Style, Confidence and elegance
english.mnemonic: A pan of ash (panache) was held by the singer, but she still performed with style.
english.question: What does "panache" mean?

english.definition: Epidemic of infectious disease over several countries or the whole world
english.mnemonic: Peter Pan did a brilliant mix (pandemic) of music and because he flew all over the world, his music spread everywhere.
english.question: What is a pandemic?

english.definition: A simple story used to explain an idea especially a religious one
english.mnemonic: Our Padre was able (parable) to tell us simple stories that have deeper religious meaning.
english.question: What is a parable?

english.definition: A typical example, a model for how something should be done or made
english.mnemonic: The tropical paradise has no crime (paradigm) and is a typical example of how humans should live together.
english.question: What is a paradigm?

english.definition: Seems untrue but is correct.
english.mnemonic: Parrot boxing (paradox) seems untrue, but it is true.
english.question: What is a paradox?

english.definition: A person or thing deemed to be a perfect example of a particular quality or ability.
english.mnemonic: The parrot had gone (paragon) and shat on her shoulder. She didn't make a fuss, she was a supreme example of self control.
english.question: What does the term "paragon" refer to?

english.definition: Organised like a military force but not official. Examples include the IRA and UDA
english.mnemonic: The parrots formed a military (paramilitary) unit but they were not allowed into the army.
english.question: What is a paramilitary organization?

english.definition: The irrational and persistent feeling that people are 'out to get you'
english.mnemonic: The parakeet was more than an annoyance (paranoia) now, it was out to get me!
english.question: What is paranoia?

english.definition: Equipment or apparatus necessary for a particular activity
english.mnemonic: The paramilitary wore fur coats to avoid mission failure (paraphernalia). It was very cold, so the coats were part of the equipment needed for this particular activity.
english.question: What does the term paraphernalia refer to?

english.definition: Express the meaning using different words (often in a simpler, shorter form)
english.mnemonic: The parrot can use phrases (paraphrase) that often express my sentences in a simpler form.
english.question: What does it mean to paraphrase?

english.definition: Equality in pay or position
english.mnemonic: Parrots with tea (parity). It was decided that parrots should be equal with people and have regular tea breaks.
english.question: What does the term parity refer to in a workplace context?

english.definition: Words used by a particular group of people (especially those with a particular job or interest)
english.mnemonic: Pa lanced (parlance) his boil and only a few people understood what he said.
english.question: What does "parlance" mean?

english.definition: 1. Relating to a church parish. 2. Having a limited or narrow outlook; showing interest in a narrow range of matters, especially those that affect your local area.
english.mnemonic: Pa was rowing a boat when it keeled (parochial) over. He was trying to get to church through a narrow opening. 'No matter' (narrow range of matters) 'I'll swim!'.
english.question: What does "parochial" mean?

english.definition: Imitation of the style of a writer, artist, musician, or other performer with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
english.mnemonic: The parrot had a huge body (parody) of one-liners that imitated many different famous people.
english.question: What is a parody?

english.definition: A sudden attack or spasm of emotions; expression of strong feeling.
english.mnemonic: Pa rocks and his rhythms (paroxysm) make me feel a sudden attack of emotion.
english.question: What is a paroxysm?

english.definition: Bias; blind adherence
english.mnemonic: The parties on the sand ship (partisanship) were for girls only –the organisers had a bias towards the female sex.
english.question: What is partisanship?

english.definition: 1) Portraying an idealised version of country life 2) Fields used for grazing of livestock 3) Giving of spiritual advice by a Christian leader
english.mnemonic: She used pastels (pastoral) to portray an idealized version of country life and she drew a beautiful picture of fields. The pastors all (pastoral) handed out leaflets giving spiritual advice.
english.question: What does the term "pastoral" refer to in terms of depicting an idealized country life, fields for grazing, and spiritual guidance?

english.definition: clearly; without doubt
english.mnemonic: The patent was at the lea (leading) edge of technology and was clearly ahead of the game.
english.question: What does "patently" mean?

english.definition: Relating to the father; fatherly
english.mnemonic: Pat eternally (paternal) - that must be my father - He's always doing it to me!
english.question: What does the term "paternal" mean?

english.definition: Study of the origin, nature, and causes of diseases
english.mnemonic: The path had to be studied (pathology) because it was full of diseases.
english.question: What is pathology?

english.definition: A person who supports, especially by giving money
english.mnemonic: He pays tons (patron) of money out all the time supporting people.
english.question: Who is considered a patron?

english.definition: The support given to a person, organisation, or business by someone
english.mnemonic: He patted on me for ages (patronage) but it did show everyone that he supported me.
english.question: What does patronage refer to?

english.definition: To treat someone with kindness while betraying feelings of superiority
english.mnemonic: The patterns made by her eyes (Patronise) were strange. The people asked her if she was OK which was kind, but they were really looking down upon her.
english.question: What does it mean to patronise someone?

english.definition: Trifling sin; A minor offence
english.mnemonic: She pecked, the armadillo (peccadillo), at the trifle. The owner said: "It's a sin to eat that." (Trifling sin).
english.question: What is a peccadillo?

english.definition: Of or relating to money
english.mnemonic: Peck your hairy (pecuniary) head: each time the parrot pecked she pulled out money.
english.question: What does the term "pecuniary" refer to?

english.definition: 1. The record of ancestry of a person or family 2. The record of descent of an animal showing it to be pure-bred
english.mnemonic: Each pet had a degree (pedigree), and were purely bred (pure-bred) to get one. My family's ancestry was recorded through the ages with each pet.
english.question: What is a pedigree?

english.definition: A group of people of approximately the same age, status, and interests.
english.mnemonic: On the pier was a group (peer group), and they were the ones she wanted to be with. The kids were all the same age and obviously had the same interests.
english.question: What is a peer group?

english.definition: 1. A person of similar age, status, or ability, equal. 2. A member of nobility.
english.mnemonic: He peered (peer) at a person who was identical to himself. Everything was equal. What was strange was that next to him was a member of the nobility staring out too but there was no one there.
english.question: What are the meanings of the term "peer"?

english.definition: To say or do something in an irritable way.
english.mnemonic: He peed viciously (peevishly) because he had an irritable bladder.
english.question: What does it mean to act peevishly?

english.definition: Relating to punishment given by law
english.mnemonic: It was the pea's final (penal) warning; next offence would receive a punishment from the law.
english.question: What does the term "penal" refer to in a legal context?

english.definition: Punishment inflicted on oneself to show you are sorry
english.mnemonic: A pen of ants (penance) was what she jumped into to show she was sorry.
english.question: What is penance?

english.definition: A strong liking for something
english.mnemonic: The pond was beautiful as the sunshine shone (penchant). I had a strong liking for this view outside my door and had a tendency to spend ages looking at.
english.question: What does the term "penchant" mean?

english.definition: A strong liking for something
english.mnemonic: The animals in the pens were chanting (penchant) they liked chanting.
english.question: What does the term "penchant" mean?

english.definition: A long narrow triangular flag, especially used by ships as a signal
english.mnemonic: She gave her pen to the infant (pennant). His toy boat needed a mast to attach a narrow triangular flag, signalling it was his.
english.question: What is a pennant, especially used by ships as a signal?

english.definition: Plunged in thought, thinking seriously about something.
english.mnemonic: The Pensieve bowl that Harry Potter used only worked if he plunged his face into the liquid to pull out thoughts.
english.question: What does it mean to be pensive?

english.definition: Held; not released
english.mnemonic: The penthouse is up (pent-up) at the top of the building and I was held there for no reason, I was not released for years.
english.question: What does "pent-up" mean?

english.definition: extreme poverty
english.mnemonic: The pen you really (penury) wanted had to stay in the shop. You couldn't afford it because you are in extreme poverty.
english.question: What does the term "penury" mean?

english.definition: Walk around for pleasure
english.mnemonic: That person is a rambler and usually stays out late (perambulate), but always comes back smiling because she so enjoys walking. It's such a pleasure to her.
english.question: What does it mean to perambulate?

english.definition: A sensitive understanding or insight. Able to see things clearly for what they are.
english.mnemonic: The purse was accepted (perceptive) because she had a clear understanding of everything.
english.question: What does it mean to be perceptive?

english.definition: Expected to be obeyed without question
english.mnemonic: Per empty (peremptory) can, you get 10p. Now go and get some more. I expect you to obey me without question.
english.question: What does "peremptory" mean?

english.definition: Lasting a long time
english.mnemonic: Parent eels (perennial) love their children. Their love lasts a long time.
english.question: What does the term perennial mean?

english.definition: Performed hastily and lacking care.
english.mnemonic: The perfume factory (perfunctory) had staff who just didn't care.
english.question: What does perfunctory mean?

english.definition: Travelling from place to place, in particular working or based in various places for short periods of time
english.mnemonic: The periscope they put up was pathetic (peripatetic). It was stuck in the upright position so you could see where the submarine travelled from place to place.
english.question: What does "peripatetic" mean?

english.definition: The crime of telling lies in a court of law
english.mnemonic: A permanent injury (perjury) occurred in a tennis game and she had to lie in the middle of the court.
english.question: What is the crime of perjury?

english.definition: Allowing excessive freedom of behaviour that other people might disapprove of
english.mnemonic: I didn't give you permission to sieve (permissive) through my rubbish. You might think it's okay, but I disapprove of such behaviour.
english.question: What does it mean to be permissive?

english.definition: Ways in which a set of things can be arranged or put in order.
english.mnemonic: The perm mutation (permutation) was bad, but there are many ways it could be put back in order.
english.question: What is a permutation?

english.definition: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual way
english.mnemonic: The perm was vicious (pernicious). The perm gradually worked its way around the back of the woman who was verbally attacking her, and was going to harm her.
english.question: What does pernicious mean?

english.definition: carry out or commit (a harmful, illegal, or immoral action)
english.mnemonic: He did it on purpose. It was a trait (perpetrate) of his to commit crime.
english.question: What does it mean to perpetrate something?

english.definition: To cause something to continue or last indefinitely.
english.mnemonic: The purring pet you ate (perpetuate) got you into trouble, and you were jailed forever.
english.question: What does it mean to perpetuate something?

english.definition: Make someone feel completely baffled
english.mnemonic: The purple 'X' (perplex) marked the spot where the treasure should have been buried, but no amount of digging could locate it. They were completely baffled.
english.question: What does it mean to perplex someone?

english.definition: A personality that a person presents in specific settings
english.mnemonic: The cat only purrs for her owner (persona). The personality she presents to everyone else is very mean.
english.question: What is a persona?

english.definition: Having an agreeable or pleasing personality; attractive.
english.mnemonic: A person in trouble (personable) with the law will find it helpful to have a pleasant appearance and manner.
english.question: What does it mean to be personable?

english.definition: The combination of characteristics or qualities that form an individual character
english.mnemonic: That person has created a virtual reality (personality) on her computer that combines all the characteristics that reflect her as an individual.
english.question: What is personality?

english.definition: 1. To be a perfect example of something. 2. To treat as a person.
english.mnemonic: This person can fly (personify) and is a perfect example of what man can achieve; in fact, do you treat them as a bird or do you treat them as a person?
english.question: What does it mean to personify something?

english.definition: The people employed in a company
english.mnemonic: The person was hell (personnel). All the people in the company were great except this one.
english.question: What does "personnel" refer to in a company?

english.definition: Clear and understandable
english.mnemonic: The purse was picked from us (perspicuous), but the police officer said not to worry, because she saw it clearly.
english.question: What does "perspicuous" mean?

english.definition: 1. Of a young woman - cheeky 2. Attractively small and well shaped
english.mnemonic: The expert (pert) could tell which person was small and well-shaped. She thought he was being cheeky.
english.question: What does the term "pert" describe in relation to a young woman?

english.definition: Connected with, related or belonging to.
english.mnemonic: The purring container (pertain) belonged to the purring cat.
english.question: What does "pertain" mean?

english.definition: Holding firmly to an opinion or a course of action
english.mnemonic: The expert was tenacious (pertinacious) and would hold firmly to her opinion.
english.question: What does it mean to be pertinacious?

english.definition: Relevant. Relating to the subject being considered.
english.mnemonic: The deposit taken per tenant (pertinent) varied, according to how relevant each prospective tenant was.
english.question: What does pertinent mean?

english.definition: Feeling anxiety or concern
english.mnemonic: The puppy was disturbed (perturbed) while sleeping and is now feeling anxious and concerned.
english.question: What does it mean to be perturbed?

english.definition: To read thoroughly or to scan/browse
english.mnemonic: The puppies and the kangaroos (peruse) visited the library. The puppies just browsed while the kangaroos read the books thoroughly.
english.question: What does it mean to peruse a document?

english.definition: To read thoroughly or to scan/browse
english.mnemonic: Peru's (peruse) llamas can all be found reading carefully and thoroughly.
english.question: What does it mean to peruse something?

english.definition: To spread throughout all parts
english.mnemonic: Persia invaded (pervade) and spread throughout the Middle Eastern lands.
english.question: What does it mean to pervade?

english.definition: To spread throughout all parts
english.mnemonic: They came in person, invading (pervade) and spreading throughout the world.
english.question: What does the term "pervade" mean?

english.definition: Contrary to expected standard or practice; wanting to behave unreasonably
english.mnemonic: Once per verse (perverse) he would shout out. It was contrary to expected practice – he just wanted to behave unreasonably.
english.question: What does it mean to be perverse?

english.definition: Allowing water to pass through
english.mnemonic: The person was oblivious (pervious) to the fact that water was passing through the house.
english.question: What does pervious mean?

english.definition: Believing that the worst will happen
english.mnemonic: There are pests in the mist (pessimism) and I'm telling you, it's going to be bad!
english.question: What is pessimism?

english.definition: Mild seizure marked by diminished awareness, usually with a blank stare.
english.mnemonic: The doctor put the teen's malfunction (petit mal) down to mild seizures indicated by a blank stare.
english.question: What is a petit mal?

english.definition: Of little importance
english.mnemonic: All the petticoats (petty) she left behind she decided were of little importance now.
english.question: What does "petty" mean?

english.definition: Childishly bad-tempered; sulky and easily annoyed.
english.mnemonic: The petal ant (petulant) lived on the petals of a flower. It got very bad-tempered when the petals began to fall off.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as petulant?

english.definition: 1. Fact or situation that can be observed 2. A remarkable person or thing
english.mnemonic: Fur is normal on (phenomenon) models because they think it makes them a remarkable person and it is something rich people can be seen in.
english.question: What is a phenomenon?

english.definition: A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
english.mnemonic: She filled the hand thrust out by the harpist (philanthropist) with money. She wanted to promote his welfare with a generous donation.
english.question: What is a philanthropist?

english.definition: An uneducated person who knows little or nothing about the arts.
english.mnemonic: She filled her time (philistine) educating the uneducated.
english.question: What is a philistine?

english.definition: To accept disappointment calmly
english.mnemonic: Father Christmas filled a sock full (philosophical) of disappointing Christmas presents. The kid took it calmly.
english.question: What does it mean to be philosophical when facing disappointment?

english.definition: To talk for a long time about subjects such as the meaning of life
english.mnemonic: He had a roll filled with lots of fries (philosophise) and explained how that was what life was all about.
english.question: What does it mean to philosophise?

english.definition: 1. The study of how people should live. 2. A particular system of beliefs, values and principles, or the way someone thinks about life and deals with it.
english.mnemonic: She was filled with a sense of loss after her trophy (philosophy) was stolen, but after some deep thought, realised that wasn't what life is all about.
english.question: What does philosophy encompass?

english.definition: Able to remain calm, even when exciting or distressing things happen; not easily excited or emotional
english.mnemonic: Phlegm hit him and automatically (phlegmatic) you thought there would be a fight, but he just stayed calm.
english.question: What does it mean to be phlegmatic?

english.definition: The science of finding out what people's characters and abilities are by measuring the natural bumps on their skulls.
english.mnemonic: My friend acknowledged that he (phrenology) had studied my head and could see from its shape that I had certain characteristics.
english.question: What is phrenology?

english.definition: A wooden frame with holes for the head and hands in which offenders were formerly imprisoned and exposed to public abuse.
english.mnemonic: You can't take a pill or reach (pillory) an itch when your head and hands are imprisoned in a wooden frame.
english.question: What is a pillory used for?

english.definition: Deeply religious and moral
english.mnemonic: The pie given to us (pious) was made in the form of a giant cross. The person who made it was very religious.
english.question: What does it mean to be pious?

english.definition: Interesting and exciting especially because of being mysterious; A pleasantly sharp and appetizing flavour
english.mnemonic: She peeked and could see (piquancy) Father Christmas. How exciting and interesting.
english.question: What does "piquancy" mean?

english.definition: 1. A feeling of anger caused by someone damaging your pride. 2. To excite or cause interest.
english.mnemonic: I peeked (pique) because I thought it would be interesting but I then felt anger and a loss of pride when I saw what my son was doing.
english.question: What does the term "pique" refer to?

english.definition: A very small amount of money
english.mnemonic: In the pit he lost his balance (pittance) and was injured, but the pit owners paid only a small amount of money in compensation.
english.question: What is a pittance?

english.definition: Stop someone from feeling angry
english.mnemonic: A plate of cakes (placate) was used to stop them from feeling angry.
english.question: What does it mean to placate someone?

english.definition: Direct and honest conduct in relationships and transactions
english.mnemonic: A plain-clothed policeman was dealing (plain dealing) the cards, so the players expected he would behave honestly towards everyone.
english.question: What is plain dealing?
