english.mnemonic: She was a nan again (shenanigan) - the old woman would dance and act the fool every time a new grandchild was born: then she'd rob a bank (dishonest conduct) to buy a present for the new baby.
english.question: What is shenanigan?

english.definition: looking dishonest
english.mnemonic: He tried to shift the stolen tea (shifty) but he looked dishonest.
english.question: What does the term "shifty" mean?

english.definition: Fit a horse with shoes
english.mnemonic: The shoes looked odd (shod) on the horse.
english.question: What does it mean to shod a horse?

english.definition: A fault or failure to reach a certain standard
english.mnemonic: "You're too short, so you're not coming (shortcoming) on our team. If you do, we will fail to reach our goal."
english.question: What is a shortcoming?

english.definition: To hide something by covering or surrounding.
english.mnemonic: He couldn't shrug off the crowd (shroud) so he hid under a cover.
english.question: What does it mean to shroud something?

english.definition: An area in a garden planted with shrubs.
english.mnemonic: The shrubs with berries (shrubbery) are only allowed to be in that area of the garden.
english.question: What is shrubbery?

english.definition: your brother or sister
english.mnemonic: Sipping drinks and wearing bling (sibling). You could tell they were brothers and sister.
english.question: What is a sibling?

english.definition: A military blockade of a city or fortified place to compel it to surrender.
english.mnemonic: Let's see just (siege) how long they will last in the fortified place during a military blockade.
english.question: What is a siege?

english.definition: an afternoon rest or nap
english.mnemonic: If I'm by the sea, I estimate (siesta) I'll need a nap by the afternoon. It's too hot to work.
english.question: What is a siesta?

english.definition: A smile that is insincere or unnatural
english.mnemonic: Simply put (simper), I didn't like his insincere smile.
english.question: What does it mean to simper?

english.definition: Wicked, immoral
english.mnemonic: The sink was full (sinful) of her flatmate's dirty dishes. "That's wicked!" She thought, "She's deliberately left them for me to wash!"
english.question: What does the term "sinful" mean?

english.definition: In a remarkable or noticeable way
english.mnemonic: If you sing regularly (singularly) over many years you will improve in a noticeable way.
english.question: What does the adverb "singularly" mean?

english.definition: 1. Having many curves and turns 2. Supple, thin and graceful
english.mnemonic: Sinews allow us (sinuous) to curve and turn; look how supple we can be.
english.question: What does the term "sinuous" mean?

english.definition: Relating to an animal: easily scared. Relating to a human: playful, not serious; unpredictable.
english.mnemonic: Most people would skip the dish (skittish) but the boy played with the soup and the animals ran off scared.
english.question: What does the term "skittish" mean?

english.definition: Quench or satisfy your thirst
english.mnemonic: The snake in the lake (slake) lived in the water so that it could satisfy its thirst anytime it wanted.
english.question: What does it mean to slake your thirst?

english.definition: A false statement against another person (a lie), which damages the reputation of the person. Slander is usually oral (spoken) defamation.
english.mnemonic: He was slammed underground (slander) for telling a lie.
english.question: What is slander?

english.definition: Severely criticise another person
english.mnemonic: It's late (slate) – very late, in fact - and her parents severely criticise her for arriving home so late.
english.question: What does it mean to slate someone?

english.definition: A dirty, untidy woman
english.mnemonic: Wearing slack clothing turned (slattern) inside out, the woman looked dirty and untidy.
english.question: What does the term "slattern" refer to?

english.definition: To walk away from somewhere quietly so that you are not noticed.
english.mnemonic: Slinky (slink) dog walked away quietly so that he wasn't noticed.
english.question: What does it mean to slink?

english.definition: (especially of a piece of work) showing little care, effort, or attention
english.mnemonic: I slipped on the shoddy (slipshod) flooring. Whoever installed this put in little care or effort.
english.question: What does it mean if something is described as slipshod?

english.definition: untidy and dirty (especially of a person's appearance)
english.mnemonic: The lazy slug's oven was never cleaned (slovenly), he just left it dirty and untidy.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as slovenly?

english.definition: Sleep
english.mnemonic: In the slum, birds (slumber) sleep too.
english.question: What does slumber mean?

english.definition: Money used for illegal or dishonest activities, especially political bribery
english.mnemonic: During his Presidential campaign, the snowman was turning into slush and needed more funds (slush fund) to keep the air-cooler on. Bad people gave him the money in return for favours if he was elected – this was money used for political bribery.
english.question: What is a slush fund?

english.definition: Having rigid or set opinions and refusing to consider different ideas
english.mnemonic: I'll have that small mind (small-minded) please. No, I won't consider any other.
english.question: What does it mean to be small-minded?

english.definition: Smile in an irritatingly smug or condescending way
english.mnemonic: He thought he was so smart and it irked (smirk) me. He was smiling in an irritatingly smug and condescending way.
english.question: What does it mean to smirk?

english.definition: To strike
english.mnemonic: She might (smite) hit you at any moment.
english.question: What does it mean to smite?

english.definition: Strongly attracted
english.mnemonic: She wears some mittens (smitten) because she loves having warm hands.
english.question: What does it mean to be smitten?

english.definition: Showing an excessive pride
english.mnemonic: The smuggler (smug) had excessive pride in himself and his achievements - instead he should have been ashamed of the crimes he'd committed.
english.question: What does it mean to be smug?

english.definition: Unpleasant criticism in an indirect way
english.mnemonic: Snip out and hide (snide) the unpleasant criticism used indirectly.
english.question: What does the term "snide" mean?

english.definition: Cry and sniff in a feeble way
english.mnemonic: He was weeping and sniffing because people called him evil (snivel). It wasn't like him to cry in a feeble way.
english.question: What does it mean to snivel?

english.definition: Treat someone rudely by ignoring them or using a cutting remark.
english.mnemonic: She wouldn't let them snuggle or rub (snub) against her, she just ignored them, rudely.
english.question: What does it mean to snub someone?

english.definition: The state of being sober; not intoxicated
english.mnemonic: The duck felt so bright (sobriety) since he stopped drinking alcohol.
english.question: What is sobriety?

english.definition: Enjoy meeting and engaging with other people; friendly.
english.mnemonic: The so-shabby bull was really scruffy – but he was very friendly and enjoyed meeting all the other bulls.
english.question: What does it mean to be sociable?

english.definition: The set of beliefs which states that all people are equal and should share equally in the wealth of the country.
english.mnemonic: The friends decide the social club isn't for them (socialism) because anyone who enters has to give the club their wallet and any money you have is distributed to all members.
english.question: What is socialism?

english.definition: Underside of the overhanging part of the roof
english.mnemonic: She thought he was so fit (soffit) as he hung from the underside of the roof.
english.keywords: so fit (soffit), underside of the roof
english.question: What is the soffit in roofing?

english.definition: A social gathering in the evening
english.mnemonic: The swans raced (soiree) over to the pond for a social gathering in the evening.
english.question: What is a soiree?

english.definition: Ask for or try to obtain (something)
english.mnemonic: A solicitor (solicit) always asks me for money first before carrying out a job.
english.question: What does it mean to solicit?

english.definition: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud by oneself, especially by a character in a play.
english.mnemonic: Solo, the little old queen (soliloquy) spoke her thoughts aloud.
english.question: What is a soliloquy?

english.definition: Self-obsession; acting as if you are the only thing that exists. Self centred
english.mnemonic: Solo lip stick (solipsistic) sessions, were what she called her self-obsession moments.
english.question: What does solipsistic mean?

english.definition: 1. Dark in colour. 2. Feeling of deep seriousness and sadness
english.mnemonic: Stories of the battle of the Somme bear (sombre) witness to a serious and sad conflict, a very dark place.
english.question: What does "sombre" mean?

english.definition: Causing sleep or making someone sleepy
english.mnemonic: Some say no to lentil (somnolent) soup because it makes them sleep.
english.question: What does the term "somnolent" mean?

english.definition: Giving off a deep and pleasant sound
english.mnemonic: The sonar given off by us (sonorous) made a deep and pleasant sound which made the whale fall in love with the submarine.
english.question: What does the term "sonorous" mean?

english.definition: A second-year university or high school student
english.mnemonic: It's soft no more (sophomore) after the first year.
english.question: What is a sophomore?

english.definition: tending to induce drowsiness or sleep
english.mnemonic: He thought soppy films were horrific (soporific). They tend to induce drowsiness.
english.question: What does the term "soporific" mean?

english.definition: 1. Dishonest or immoral behaviour, often caused by a desire to gain money. 2. Unpleasant because dirty or in bad condition.
english.mnemonic: They found the sword hidden (sordid) in a chest. Although it was in a dirty and bad condition, it was worth a fortune - but it would have been dishonest and immoral to take it.
english.question: What does the term "sordid" mean?

english.definition: A supreme ruler, especially a monarch (King, Queen or Emperor)
english.mnemonic: The soviets were in (sovereign) decline: many thought they were better off in the old days when they had royal heads of state.
english.question: What is a sovereign?

english.definition: An argument about something not important
english.mnemonic: She used a spatula (spat) to attack him during an argument over whose turn it was to do the washing up - but it wasn't really important enough to fight over.
english.question: What is a spat?

english.definition: A visually striking performance or display
english.mnemonic: Even in her spectacles (spectacle) she gave a highly visual and striking performance.
english.question: What is a spectacle?

english.definition: To guess possible answers to a question when you do not have enough information to be certain
english.mnemonic: The person with specs, you are late. (speculate) Now you'll have to guess the answers to the quiz because you did not learn enough information to be certain.
english.question: What does it mean to speculate?

english.definition: Based on unproven theory and conjecture rather than knowledge
english.mnemonic: He believed that the spectre of a young relative (speculative) haunted the family home, but this was based on conjecture rather than knowledge.
english.question: What does speculative mean?

english.definition: Hold the complete attention of someone as though by magic; fascinate.
english.mnemonic: The wizard's spell binds (spellbind) them to their chairs so he has their complete attention.
english.question: What does it mean to spellbind someone?

english.definition: Full of energy and enthusiasm
english.mnemonic: A spirit head (spirited) was full of energy.
english.question: What does the term "spirited" mean?

english.definition: A person's husband or wife
english.mnemonic: The Vicar spouted lots of verse (spouse) but then said suddenly: 'Husband and wife!'
english.question: What is the term for a person's husband or wife?

english.definition: False or fake
english.mnemonic: She was especially furious (spurious) when he was presented with a four and a half dollar note. She knew it was false or fake.
english.question: What does the term "spurious" mean?

english.definition: Reject with disrespect or mockery
english.mnemonic: She used her spurs on (spurn) the horse which then rejected and mocked her.
english.question: What does it mean to spurn something?

english.definition: 1. Extremely dirty and unpleasant 2. Showing a lack of moral standards
english.mnemonic: The boys were squabbling over the container when the lid (squalid) came off, making the room dirty and unpleasant. Neither would own up to it, showing a lack of moral standards.
english.question: What does squalid mean?

english.definition: To waste money, supplies or opportunities
english.mnemonic: He's gone and wandered off (squander) – what a missed opportunity. He could have earned so much money.
english.question: What does it mean to squander?

english.definition: An uncastrated adult male horse
english.mnemonic: Standing in the pavilion (stallion) of the park was the giant horse. The people around protested at it being a male horse on full show.
english.question: What is a stallion?

english.definition: Loyal, reliable, hard-working supporter.
english.mnemonic: Behind the stall, the warthog (stalwart) was serving customers while she had a sleep. The warthog was such a loyal, reliable and hardworking supporter.
english.question: What does the term "stalwart" refer to?

english.definition: A situation in which there is no change or developments
english.mnemonic: She still stays with our parents. So my sister's (stasis) living situation has not changed in years.
english.question: What does the term "stasis" refer to?

english.definition: 1. Height (especially of people) 2. Level of achievement
english.mnemonic: The statue you are (stature) carving has height and certainly, your client is pleased with your achievement.
english.question: What are the meanings of stature?

english.definition: The existing state of affairs, especially regarding social or political issues; the current situation; the way things are now.
english.mnemonic: Her status as a much-quoted (status quo) writer was still the same - even at 90, people hung on her every word.
english.question: What does "status quo" refer to?

english.definition: Permitted by law; required
english.mnemonic: State if you're a Tory (statutory) because it's required in this house.
english.question: What does the term "statutory" mean in the context of legal requirements?

english.definition: 1. Loyal in supporting a person, organisation or set of beliefs. 2. To stop something happening, or stop a liquid, especially blood from flowing out.
english.mnemonic: The star came to launch (staunch) the ship and lots of his loyal supporters turned out to watch. When a piece of flying glass from the champagne bottle cut the star's arm, they stopped the bleeding with a tourniquet.
english.question: What does it mean to be staunch?

english.definition: An act or movement done to avoid detection
english.mnemonic: She steals to get wealth (stealth) and she's careful to avoid detection.
english.question: What is meant by "stealth"?

english.definition: Very strong and determined; resembling steel
english.mnemonic: The steel he (steely) was made of meant he was very strong and determined.
english.question: What does the term "steely" mean?

english.definition: Writing in shorthand and transcribing it
english.mnemonic: She stencilled her hand for her biography (stenography) but they produced the book with a short hand.
english.question: What is stenography?

english.definition: Of a person's voice, very loud and strong
english.mnemonic: The sten gun tore into them and the sergeant's reaction (stentorian) was to give orders in a very loud voice.
english.question: What does the term "stentorian" describe in relation to a person's voice?

english.definition: Having a set idea about someone or something, often oversimplified or held by many.
english.mnemonic: The stereo only played typical (stereotypical) Rap music. When they wanted it to play anything else, it just refused because it had a set idea about music.
english.question: What does it mean when something is described as stereotypical?

english.definition: 1. Strict and severe 2. The rearmost part of a ship or boat
english.mnemonic: To steer, you turn (stern) the wheel at the rear of the ship, but you need someone quite strict who can put up with severe conditions.
english.question: What does the term "stern" refer to when discussing the rear part of a ship or a strict demeanor?

english.question: What does the term "trepidation" mean?

english.definition: A cause of great trouble or suffering
english.mnemonic: She had to write a tribute to his relations (tribulation), but the speech was a cause of great suffering for her.
english.question: What does the term "tribulation" mean?

english.definition: A special court chosen to examine a particular problem
english.mnemonic: The tribes communal (tribunal) toilets were destroyed, so a special court was chosen to examine the crime.
keywords: a special court chosen to examine the crime
english.question: What is a tribunal?

english.definition: A three-pronged spear
english.mnemonic: The tricycle was an accident (trident) waiting to happen. It had a three-pronged spear attached to it.
english.question: What is a trident?

english.definition: Unimportant or of little value
english.mnemonic: He wanted his dad to try flinging (trifling) the wellington boot but his dad said he wouldn't because it was a competition of little value.
english.question: What does the term "trifling" mean?

english.definition: Having three leaflets, lobes, or foils
english.mnemonic: He made a triangle of photos of a leaf for his date (trifoliate). She looked at the three small leaves and said 'So, no flowers?'
english.question: What does trifoliate mean?

english.definition: 1. the stomach of a pig or cow (or other ruminant) 2. nonsense; rubbish
english.mnemonic: If you try putting (tripe) a sheep's stomach on a plate for the kids to eat, most of them would throw it in the rubbish.
english.question: What is tripe?

english.definition: done or expressed too often to be of any interest
english.mnemonic: The tiger tried to bite (trite) me, but it was of no interest to me because it was done so often.
english.question: What does "trite" mean?

english.definition: A promise of faithfulness or loyalty
english.mnemonic: The trooper took an oath (troath), promising to be loyal to his commander.
english.question: What does "troth" mean?

english.definition: To defeat heavily
english.mnemonic: "Try!" But there wasn't an ounce (trounce) of energy left – he was completely beaten.
english.question: What does it mean to trounce someone in a competition?

english.definition: A group of dancers, actors, or other theatrical entertainers
english.mnemonic: The army troops (troupe) split up and formed into groups of dancers, actors and other theatrical performers.
english.question: What is a troupe?

english.definition: Quick to argue or fight.
english.mnemonic: That truck you lent (truculent) was too eager to fight all the time.
english.question: What does truculent mean?

english.definition: 1. foolish talk or actions 2. a useless or worthless article
english.mnemonic: The trumpet was very (trumpery) old and broken. It was a foolish action to buy such a useless object.
english.question: What does the term "trumpery" refer to?

english.definition: cut short
english.mnemonic: The trunk of the tree he ate (truncate) left the tree cut very short.
english.question: What does it mean to truncate something?

english.definition: A person who controls property and/or money for another person or organisation
english.mnemonic: They trusted the teenager (trustee), so she now controls the organisation's money.
english.question: What is a trustee?

english.definition: A secret rendezvous between lovers
english.mnemonic: We always try to meet in the mist (tryst) for our secret rendezvous between just us two lovers.
english.question: What is a tryst?

english.definition: 1. A drinking glass with straight sides and no handle. 2. An acrobat, especially one who performs somersaults.
english.mnemonic: Her tummy was a blur (tumbler) while the acrobat performed somersaults holding a drinking glass with straight sides.
english.question: What is a tumbler?

english.definition: Very loud, confused and unruly
english.mnemonic: His brain tumour resulted from continuous (tumultuous) exposure to very loud noises. He became confused and disorderly because he couldn't understand how this could happen.
english.question: What does tumultuous mean?

english.definition: Evil behaviour
english.mnemonic: Turkeys spit on other birds' food (turpitude). It's part of their evil behaviour.
english.question: What does the term "turpitude" refer to?

english.definition: A tropical storm in the region of the Indian or western Pacific Oceans
english.mnemonic: This type of buffoon (typhoon) will sail directly into a tropical storm in the Indian ocean.
english.question: What is a typhoon?

english.definition: Using power over people in a cruel way
english.mnemonic: The 'Tyrannosaurus!' is called upon (tyrannical) to control and have power over people.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as tyrannical?

english.definition: Something that is found everywhere
english.mnemonic: You bit us (ubiquitous) everywhere.
english.question: What does the term ubiquitous mean?

english.definition: a warning to someone that unless they act in a particular way, action will be taken against them
english.mnemonic: Ultimately, you may tumble (ultimatum) to the floor if you keep on drinking. This is a warning that unless you stop, I'm kicking you out.
english.question: What is an ultimatum?

english.definition: Offence or annoyance over something someone has said or done.
english.mnemonic: The umbrella stayed under the bridge (umbrage) because it was offended by what someone said.
english.question: What does it mean to take umbrage?

english.definition: very many, a lot (of)
english.mnemonic: The umpire told the teen (umpteen) that he made a lot of errors.
english.question: What does "umpteen" mean?

english.definition: not embarrassed or ashamed
english.mnemonic: I was unafraid of being bashed (unabashed) by a much better boxer and not embarrassed or ashamed to lose.
english.question: What does it mean to be unabashed?

english.definition: Quiet and showing no desire for attention
english.mnemonic: The undertaker was assuming (unassuming) that people who had died would stay quiet and show no desire for attention forever, but he was wrong!
english.question: What does it mean to be unassuming?

english.definition: Achieving little or nothing; ineffective
english.mnemonic: The toy was unavailable despite waiting (unavailing) two weeks in the queue, achieving nothing.
english.question: What does unavailing mean?

english.definition: Of behaviour not fitting or appropriate
english.mnemonic: At the event, my uncle was becoming (unbecoming) embarrassing. His behaviour was not fitting or appropriate.
english.question: What does the term "unbecoming" describe?

english.definition: Uncontrolled
english.mnemonic: Under the horses bridle (unbridled) was a big horsefly that stung it and made the horse uncontrollable.
english.question: What does "unbridled" mean?

english.definition: Mysterious, beyond the normal
english.mnemonic: Unwrapping candy bars with his knees (uncanny) was a mysterious ability that was certainly beyond the normal.
english.question: What does uncanny mean?

english.definition: 1. excessively full of praise, kindness, or interest but obviously insincere 2. Having an oily or soapy feel; smooth and greasy in texture
english.mnemonic: Our uncle chewed sweets in front of us (unctuous) while praising us excessively for not eating sugary stuff. His praise was insincere - he just wanted the sweets for himself. His oily, greasy wig was annoying too.
english.question: What does "unctuous" mean?

english.definition: Be located under; To lie under; be the cause or basis of something
english.mnemonic: The teacher had to underline (underlie) nearly every word. The line lay under every spelling mistake but the cause of the spelling mistakes was wearing the wrong glasses.
english.question: What does it mean to underlie something?

english.definition: The presentation of something as being smaller or less important than it really is
english.mnemonic: Under the statement (understatement) about the details of the object was a very low price, which made it seem less important than it really was.
english.question: What is an understatement?

english.definition:
1. an underlying quality or feeling
2. a subdued or muted sound, colour, flavour or smell
english.mnemonic: It was difficult to understand them as their tone (undertone) of voice was so muted, but my underlying feeling was to get out of there quickly.
english.question: What is an undertone?

english.definition: To accept financial responsibility for an asset or activity so that you will pay for losses it may make.
english.mnemonic: My house was underwater, so the insurer did the right (underwrite) thing and paid out. They had accepted financial responsibility to pay for any losses.
english.question: What does it mean to underwrite?

english.definition: To have a continuous up and down shape or movement, like a wave
english.mnemonic: He was unduly late (undulate) for his own wedding – he'd been up and down the road dozens of times looking for the ring that the best man had dropped.
english.question: What does it mean to undulate?

english.definition: Unnatural or mysterious; seeming not to belong to this world
english.mnemonic: I unearthed an old leaflet (unearthly) that was mysterious and didn't seem of this world.
english.question: What does "unearthly" mean?

english.definition: Sincere, genuine
english.mnemonic: "I was unfit but I trained (unfeigned) hard!" The claims on her exercise DVD seemed sincere and genuine.
english.question: What does "unfeigned" mean?

english.definition: Move awkwardly, clumsy
english.mnemonic: Until he could gain his liberty (ungainly), the prisoner moved awkwardly and clumsily due to the heavy ball chained to his leg.
english.question: What does "ungainly" mean?

english.definition: a state in which everyone or everything looks the same
english.mnemonic: The kids had to wear their uniform at tea (uniformity) time. The headteacher insisted on everyone looking the same at all times.
english.question: What does uniformity mean?

english.definition: Relating to an action or a decision taken by a person, group, or country without the agreement of other interested parties
english.mnemonic: The new university could be build laterally (unilateral) or vertically; there were supporters for each style, but one side decided on its own that it should be lateral.
english.question: What does "unilateral" refer to regarding actions or decisions?

english.definition: Impossible to understand
english.mnemonic: "Understanding intelligent people is impossible", (unintelligible) said the young student. "They are impossible to understand".
english.question: What does unintelligible mean?

english.definition: having an untidy and uncared for appearance
english.mnemonic: She was unclear which chemical to empty (unkempt) onto the floor to improve its untidy and uncared for appearance.
english.question: What does the word "unkempt" mean?

english.definition: Make (someone) lose courage or confidence
english.mnemonic: The fact that he only wore underwear got on everyone's nerves (unnerve). As a result, they lost confidence in him as a leader.
english.question: What does it mean to unnerve someone?

english.definition: A person, place or thing which is unpleasant
english.mnemonic: Under the saviour's (unsavoury) nose, the fish and bread were very unpleasant. This time the miracle hadn't worked.
english.question: What does "unsavoury" refer to?

english.definition: Too bad to be expressed in words
english.mnemonic: Unfortunately, his plan was an utter disaster leaving the house as rubble (unutterable). For the homeowner it was too bad to be expressed in words.
english.question: What does "unutterable" mean?

english.definition: To find fault with someone or reproach severely
english.mnemonic: Her hair was up and braided (upbraid) but she found fault and severely reproached her hairdresser.
english.question: What does it mean to upbraid someone?

english.definition: Soft, padded textile covering that is fixed to furniture such as armchairs and sofas.
english.mnemonic: I uphol my theory that it's a mystery (upholstery) how the padded covering on the sofa was damaged.
english.question: What is upholstery?

english.definition: Relating to the city
english.mnemonic: Her! She's banned (urban) from the city.
english.question: What does the term "urban" refer to?

english.definition: Polite and comfortable in social situations. Know how to behave in company.
english.mnemonic: They moved to an urban lane (urbane) but wondered if they'd feel comfortable in social situations there.
english.question: What does it mean to be urbane?

english.definition: Take illegally or by force
english.mnemonic: You surprised (usurp) me by just taking my stuff by force.
english.question: What does it mean to usurp?

english.definition: Make practical and effective use of
english.mnemonic: You tell lies (utilise) so I think we can make practical and effective use of you as a politician.
english.question: What does it mean to utilise something?

english.definition: Designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive.
english.mnemonic: The utility belt worn by the librarian (utilitarian) was very useful but not attractive.
english.question: What does "utilitarian" mean?

english.definition: 1. Useful and functional rather than being attractive or fashionable 2. Able to do several things well
english.mnemonic: If you till the land in your city (utility) it would be useful and functional but not very pretty.
english.question: What does "utility" mean as an adjective?

english.definition: Imagined place where everything is perfect
english.mnemonic: You tow (utopia) to a perfect place. The garage is ideal perfection.
english.question: What is a utopia?

english.definition: Showing lack of thought or intelligence; mindless
english.mnemonic: They vacuumed us (vacuous) and all our brains were sucked out, leaving us without intelligence and mindless.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as vacuous?

english.definition: An unexpected or inexplicable change in a situation or in someone's behaviour
english.mnemonic: The vagrant who is hairy (vagary) can inexplicably change: one moment he can be begging, the next doing gymnastics and then even riding a horse!
english.question: What is a vagary?

english.definition: Serving as a farewell
english.mnemonic: The value of the dictator (valedictory) is zero – we must say farewell to everything he stood for.
english.question: What does the term "valedictory" mean?

english.definition: 1. A man's personal attendant, who is responsible for his clothes and appearance. 2. A person employed to park or wash cars.
english.mnemonic: He was great val(ue) for money and never (la)te (valet). My personal attendant responsible for my appearance also parks and washes cars.
english.question: What is a valet?

english.definition: A small travelling bag or suitcase
english.mnemonic: I value the easiest (valise) way to travel which is a small suitcase because I don't have to wait for large luggage at the airport.
english.question: What is a valise?

english.definition: To leave quickly
english.mnemonic: The vampire is loose (vamoose) so leave quickly.
english.question: What does it mean to vamoose?

english.definition: The leading force; the people at the forefront of new developments and ideas.
english.mnemonic: The van had a guard (vanguard) whose dog always sat at the forefront of the vehicle.
english.question: What is the vanguard in terms of new developments and ideas?

english.definition: Defeat thoroughly; convincingly beat the enemy or opposition
english.mnemonic: The van squished (vanquish) him and all his men, therefore defeating them thoroughly.
english.question: What does it mean to vanquish someone or something?

english.definition: Alter in appearance, especially by adding different colours
english.mnemonic: They varied the gates (variegated) opening times and kept altering its appearance, which confused the visitors.
english.question: What does "variegated" mean in terms of appearance?

english.definition: An arched ceiling
english.mnemonic: The bank vault needed a new ceiling (vaulted ceiling) – a curved one shaped like the vault door.
english.question: What is a vaulted ceiling?

english.definition: Praised, especially in an excessive way
english.mnemonic: The very haunted (vaunted) house was praised for its scary experience.
english.question: What does it mean when something is vaunted?

english.definition: suddenly change direction
english.mnemonic: The Goddess Venus steered (veer) suddenly, changing direction and heading towards the God Mars.
english.question: What does it mean to veer?

english.definition: Showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense
english.mnemonic: The builder left a big V in the cement (vehement) showing his strong feeling over not being paid on time for the work.
english.question: What does "vehement" mean?

english.definition: A soft fabric which looks and feels like velvet
english.mnemonic: Velvet for the teen (velveteen) was too expensive, so she found a substitute which looks and feels like velvet.
english.question: What is velveteen?

english.definition: Someone who is selling something
english.mnemonic: The vending machine has a door (vendor) that opens and there's someone who sells things from inside the machine.
english.question: What is a vendor?

english.definition: A thin layer or sheet of material
english.mnemonic: He parked his van near (veneer) so he didn't have to carry the thin sheets of wood far.
english.question: What is a veneer?

english.definition: Regard with great respect. To honour a person or thing.
english.mnemonic: It can vend at such a rate (venerate). It's the world's biggest vending machine and needs to be honoured.
english.question: What does it mean to venerate someone or something?

english.definition: The place where a public event or meeting happens, such as a concert, conference, or sports event.
english.mnemonic: Vending machines get more use (venue) in places where public events or meetings occur.
english.question: What is the term for the place where a public event or meeting happens, like a concert or sports event?

english.definition: accuracy, habitual truthfulness
english.mnemonic: "The veranda overlooks the city" (veracity), the house advert claimed. The couple visited the property to check the advert's accuracy as they weren't sure if the estate agents were known for their habitual truthfulness. But everything was true, it was stunning, the advert was accurate.
english.question: What does veracity mean?

english.definition: Using exactly the same words or word for word
english.mnemonic: Verbs! He hates them (verbatim). But when he wrote out the poem without verbs it wasn't quite the same. He knew he would have to reproduce it word for word.
english.question: What does the term "verbatim" mean?

english.definition: Wordy; Excessively lengthy speech or writing
english.mnemonic: The verb bridge (verbiage): The famous bridge full of words, but only verbs. Can we call it wordy?
english.question: What does the term "verbiage" refer to?

english.definition: Using or containing more words than are necessary
english.mnemonic: His first version boasted (verbose) of a 500-page introduction. However, the publisher said it contained far more words than necessary.
english.question: What does the term "verbose" mean?

english.definition: covered in healthy green plants or grass
english.mnemonic: The verdict? Don't (verdant) do this to your office! Covering your office with healthy green plants and grass is too much.
english.question: What does "verdant" mean?

english.definition: the appearance of being true; quality of seeming true
english.mnemonic: They were very similar and had strange attitudes (verisimilitude), but their story had the appearance of being true.
english.question: What does the term "verisimilitude" mean?

english.definition: Very much so; truly; used to emphasise that something is real
english.mnemonic: I can verify that that table (veritable) is very much a table and she used it for emphasis.
english.question: What does "veritable" mean?

english.definition: The language or dialect spoken by the ordinary people in a particular country or region.
english.mnemonic: His version of the language nearly sounded like Dracula (vernacular), yet that was the dialect spoken by the ordinary people in the region.
english.question: What is vernacular?

english.definition: To have great energy and enthusiasm
english.mnemonic: It veered and swerved (verve) – the drone still had lots of energy.
english.question: What does it mean to have verve?

english.definition: fully and unconditionally guaranteed as a legal right, benefit or privilege
english.mnemonic: "Put on your bulletproof vest, you idiot! (vested) Having one is guaranteed to be of benefit."
english.question: What does the term "vested" mean in legal or financial contexts?

english.definition: A small entrance room between the outer door and the main hall or building.
english.mnemonic: All the vests in the blue mule's (vestibule) collection were kept in the room just inside the entranceway.
english.question: What is a vestibule?

english.definition: A trace of something
english.mnemonic: He wore the vest for an age (vestige) and a trace of all the meals he had could be seen.
english.question: What is a vestige?

english.definition: A person with a lot of experience or service
english.mnemonic: The veterinarian (veteran) had a vast amount of experience and service.
english.question: What is a veteran?

english.definition: Stop it; Prevent a proposed action
english.mnemonic: The giant "V" was being towed (veto) and it clearly showed what she thought should happen to the proposal – stop it!
english.question: What does it mean to exercise a veto?

english.definition: Make someone feel annoyed, angry or worried
english.mnemonic: There were flecks (vex) of red in the actress's eyes – she was angry and worried about how she was going to look when the camera zoomed in on her.
english.question: What does it mean to vex someone?

english.definition: Able to work as intended or able to succeed
english.mnemonic: When it comes to violence, a bull (viable) is always able to succeed.
english.question: What does it mean if something is considered viable?

english.definition: A bridge made of several small spans
english.mnemonic: The prisoner escaped via a duct (viaduct) and a bridge.
english.question: What is a viaduct?

english.definition: A rapid, repeated, slight change in the pitch of a musical note
english.mnemonic: She could vibrate her toe (vibrato) to produce a rapidly changing musical note on the floor.
english.question: What is vibrato in music?

english.definition: Wicked, evil or criminal behaviour; or an immoral or wicked personal characteristic
english.mnemonic: He enjoys trapping people's fingers in vices (vice) and is involved in evil and criminal behaviour that displays his immoral and wicked personal characteristics.
english.question: What is vice?

english.definition: Rule on behalf of a monarch or government
english.mnemonic: The vice of the royals (viceroy) was used to control and rule other kingdoms.
english.question: What does a viceroy do?

english.definition: To make someone a victim; to subject to cruel or harmful treatment
english.mnemonic: The victim's eyes (victimise) were punched and that was just cruel and harmful.
english.question: What does it mean to victimize someone?

english.definition: 1. Food 2. To supply with food.
english.mnemonic: They were given vitamins because they were little (victual), as well as their normal food. Their owners also needed to supply food more often for them.
english.question: What does the term "victual" mean?

english.definition: A period of keeping awake during the time usually spent asleep. Keeping watch or protesting.
english.mnemonic: The invigilator (vigil) had to stay awake all night because this was a 24 hour exam.
english.question: What is a vigil?

english.definition: extremely unpleasant
english.mnemonic: This vial (vile) contains something extremely unpleasant.
english.question: What does the term "vile" mean?

english.definition: to say or write unpleasant things about someone or something
english.mnemonic: This villain isn't fine (vilify). These online trolls say or write things about people without any consequence.
english.question: What does it mean to vilify someone or something?

english.definition: A strong desire for revenge
english.mnemonic: It was vintage cars she found addictive (vindictive), so when her husband damaged her cars, she had a strong desire for revenge.
english.question: What does the term "vindictive" mean?

english.definition: 1. Break or fail to comply with rules 2. Treat with disrespect
english.mnemonic: Violence because you're late (violate)? Perhaps not, but if you fail to get there on time... You might be treated with disrespect.
english.question: What does it mean to violate a rule or agreement?

english.definition: Morally good behaviour and character
english.mnemonic: The virtual (virtue) character displayed morally good behaviour.
english.question: What is the definition of virtue?

english.definition: Someone who is extremely skilled at something, especially at playing a musical instrument.
english.mnemonic: That was virtually perfect and oh so (virtuoso) wonderful. This musician is extremely skilled.
english.question: What is a virtuoso?

english.definition: A person's face
english.mnemonic: It had visible damage (visage). His face was injured after the fight.
english.question: What does the term "visage" refer to?

english.definition: Based on a feeling in your guts rather than intellect
english.mnemonic: This cereal (visceral) caused a massive feeling in her guts.
english.question: What does "visceral" mean?

english.definition: the appearance of a divine or supernatural being
english.mnemonic: He visited the station (visitation) and was shocked at the appearance of supernatural beings.
english.question: What does the term "visitation" refer to in a supernatural context?

english.definition: A beautiful view, especially from a high position
english.mnemonic: Visitors (vista) love the beautiful view.
english.question: What is a vista?

english.definition: Spoil or impair the quality or efficiency of something; make it worse
english.mnemonic: The fish he ate (vitiate) had been spoiled. He felt bad and he was getting worse
english.question: What does it mean to vitiate something?

english.definition: Filled with criticism and anger
english.mnemonic: The vitreous enamel art created by the workaholic (vitriolic) filled the public with much anger and criticism.
english.question: What does the term "vitriolic" mean?

english.definition: Harshly critical language. Full of hate and anger.
english.mnemonic: "Vitamins! Two per ration" (vituperation). "You are evil!" They were full of hate.
english.question: What does vituperation mean?

english.definition: 1. Producing powerful feelings or strong, clear images in the mind. 2. (of a colour) intensely deep or bright.
english.mnemonic: She was visible on the video (vivid) wearing a bright coloured jacket. The old footage and memories produced powerful feelings.
english.question: What is the meaning of the word "vivid"?

english.definition: The use of living animals in tests
english.mnemonic: She had a vivid memory of how a section (vivisection) of a living animal was tested.
english.question: What does vivisection involve?

english.definition: A job or career that a person is particularly drawn to and is regarded as worthy or requiring dedication.
english.mnemonic: The vocal nations (vocation) were called to work in the music industry. They were so good that people felt they were not worthy to listen to them.
english.question: What is a vocation?

english.definition: Crying out noisily; loud and forceful.
english.mnemonic: His voice was ferocious (vociferous) - it was loud and noisy.
english.question: What does vociferous mean?

english.definition: The prevailing fashion or style at a particular time.
english.mnemonic: Vogue magazine has fashion in it.
english.question: What does "Vogue" refer to in terms of trends and style?

english.definition: Likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly, especially by getting worse
english.mnemonic: 'Voila, a tile' (volatile) said the magician. Most magicians would pull out a rabbit but a tile? It was sudden and unexpected and this show was certainly getting worse.
english.question: What does "volatile" mean?

english.definition: The faculty or power to make your own decisions
english.mnemonic: The vole was signing a new edition (volition) of her cook book – readers had the power to choose whether it became her best seller.
english.question: What is volition?

english.definition: Talking incessantly
english.mnemonic: The volume button wasn't able (voluble) to be turned off. She just talked incessantly.
english.question: What does it mean when someone is described as voluble?

english.definition: 1. Curvaceous and sexually attractive (usually used to describe a woman). 2. Characterised by luxury or sensual pleasure
english.mnemonic: Turn that volume up, the tutor told us (voluptuous) as we practised our catwalk style looking curvaceous and sexy. The venue was characterised by luxury.
english.question: What does the term "voluptuous" mean?

english.definition: Wanting or devouring great quantities of food or showing great eagerness and enthusiasm for something.
english.mnemonic: Four acres (voracious)! No problem – this pig will devour the lot because it's so eager.
english.question: What does it mean if someone is described as voracious?

english.definition: A whirling mass of fluid or air; whirlpool, whirlwind that pulls objects towards its centre.
english.mnemonic: The four survivors texted (vortex) everyone pictures of the whirling mass of air.
english.question: What is a vortex?

english.definition: A person who has made vows of dedication to religious service (such as a monk or nun)
english.mnemonic: He wasn't vocal and lived a solitary (votary) life, for he was a monk who had made vows of dedication to religious service.
keywords: made vows of dedication to religious service
english.question: What is a votary?

english.definition: A person who gets sexual pleasure from watching others have sex
english.mnemonic: The voyage to her (voyeur) habitat took ages, but it was worth it to watch her have sex.
english.question: What is a voyeur?

english.definition: Relating to a fox
english.mnemonic: Vultures in the pine tree (vulpine) were spotted by the fox, but he just couldn't get them.
english.question: What does the term "vulpine" refer to?

english.definition: A poor, skinny, homeless child.
english.mnemonic: Wafer thin (waif) is the only description of the poor, skinny, homeless child.
english.question: What is a waif?

english.definition: a strong desire to travel
english.mnemonic: I wandered the earth with a lust (wanderlust) for adventure and a strong desire to travel.
english.question: What does the term "wanderlust" mean?

english.definition: To weaken in strength or influence
english.mnemonic: I wasted away after a painful (wane) illness and was weakened in strength.
english.question: What does it mean when something begins to wane?

english.definition: Child who is legally put under the protection of a law court or a guardian.
english.mnemonic: The warden (ward) took control of the child and put her under his protection as instructed by the law.
english.question: What is a ward in legal terms?

english.definition: To stop or interrupt someone, especially either to attack or talk to that person
english.mnemonic: The way the tiger lays (waylay) in wait means she's ready to stop and attack anyone that passes by.
english.question: What does it mean to waylay someone?

english.definition: The edge of a road
english.mnemonic: If you wait at the side (wayside), make sure you keep away from the edge of the road, otherwise you might get splashed.
english.question: What is meant by the term "wayside"?

english.definition: To cause a baby or young animal to stop feeding on its mother's milk and to start eating solid food
english.mnemonic: She was no longer teeny-weeny (wean), so it was time to get the baby to start eating solid food.
english.question: What does it mean to wean a baby or young animal?

english.definition: a large and especially badly disorganised number of things
english.mnemonic: The well did have water (welter), so a large and disorganised number of people wanted some.
english.question: What does the term "welter" refer to?

english.definition: by which
english.mnemonic: Wear clothes by (whereby) our leading designer, by which we mean the witch.
english.question: What does the term "whereby" mean?

english.definition: The money necessary for a particular purpose. The means with which to do something.
english.mnemonic: Wear with all (wherewithal) your money on the outside of your clothes. This means you can afford to do things because you will never forget your money.
english.question: What does the term "wherewithal" refer to in the context of finances?

english.definition: Unusual in a playful way
english.mnemonic: On a whim, she rode her tricycle (whimsical) to work. It was unusual in a playful way.
english.question: What does the term "whimsical" mean?

english.definition: A person in a political party who ensures everyone in their party turns up to vote for what the leaders want.
english.mnemonic: They were whipped (whip) into parliament to vote for what their leaders wanted.
keywords: vote for what their leaders wanted
english.question: What is the role of a whip in a political party?

english.definition: People who work in office and managerial jobs
english.mnemonic: White-collared shirts (white-collar worker) are the only thing to wear if you work in the office.
english.question: What is a white-collar worker?

english.definition: A printed government document detailing a proposed future law, with information on the issues
english.mnemonic: White wallpaper (white paper) overprinted with details of future laws was suddenly all the rage - but you could run up a big bill because it was expensive.
english.question: What is a White Paper in government terms?

english.definition: To sell to retailers in large quantities.
english.mnemonic: I know this whole lot was for sale (wholesale) but honey, this is for shops to buy, not us.
english.question: What does it mean to sell wholesale?

english.definition: Easily controlled or handled
english.mnemonic: The new wheels worked well despite deep (wieldy) mud and the rider easily controlled the bike.
english.question: What does the term "wieldy" mean?

english.definition: 1. a phosphorescent light seen hovering over marshy ground at night 2. something that seems impossible to catch
english.mnemonic: The wildebeest followed the whispering (will-o'-the-wisp) voice. It seemed impossible to reach the source of the voice, but it led him to a phosphorescent light that hovered over the marshy ground at night.
english.question: What is a will-o'-the-wisp?

english.definition: A person who talks at length, but says little of value
english.mnemonic: The police officer caught a burglar climbing out of a window with a bag (windbag). The burglar talked at length trying to explain but said little of value.
english.question: What is a windbag?

english.definition: On the side facing the wind
english.mnemonic: The wind lifted the tent upwards (windward), and the campers realised they had pitched it on the side of the hill facing the wind.
english.question: What does windward mean?

english.definition: A person who pretends to possess knowledge or wisdom, to the annoyance of others
english.mnemonic: It wasn't wise to plant acres (wiseacre) of crops in the arctic. The farmer pretended to know what she was doing, but it was beginning to annoy the others.
english.question: What is a wiseacre?

english.definition: very thin and light
english.mnemonic: Drinking whiskey at such speeds (wispy) isn't recommended if you're very thin and light.
english.question: What does "wispy" mean?

english.definition: Sad because you want something you can't have
english.mnemonic: Whist against someone who is wonderful (wistful) at the game makes me sad because I know I can't be as good.
english.question: What does it mean to feel wistful?

english.definition: Part of a horse just above its shoulders
english.mnemonic: The horse looked to have very withered skin (withers) where the top of the saddle rubbed just above its shoulders.
english.question: What is the part of a horse just above its shoulders called?

english.definition: Intentionally, with full knowledge and deliberation (as opposed to unwittingly)
english.mnemonic: I witnessed in the street the glee (wittingly) on her face as she scratched the car. She knowingly and deliberately did it.
english.question: What does "wittingly" mean?

english.definition: Engaging in numerous casual sexual affairs with women
english.mnemonic: If any woman's eyes (womanize) meet his, then he wants casual sex with them.
english.question: What does it mean to womanize?

english.definition: A dispute or argument typically one that is long running
english.mnemonic: She ran at a strange angle (wrangle) knocking over everyone and causing an argument. She was on a long run (long running).
english.question: What does it mean to wrangle?

english.definition: In an unhappy or unfortunate state
english.mnemonic: She retched and her head (wretched) felt terrible. She was in a very unhappy state.
english.question: What does the term "wretched" mean?

english.definition: 1. Using dry, sarcastic humour 2. Having a twisted/lopsided facial expression
english.mnemonic: The rider (wry) gave a twisted smile when he saw other people fall off their horses because he has a dry, sarcastic sense of humour.
keywords: a dry, sarcastic sense of humour
english.question: What does the term "wry" mean?

english.definition: An animal (especially a sheep, calf, or foal) that is a year old or in its second year.
english.mnemonic: A year lingering (yearling) with its mum is how the foal spent its time until its first birthday. In its second year, it became more independent.
english.question: What is a yearling?

english.definition: 1. Frothy and restless 2. Similar to or containing yeast (a fungus used in making alcoholic drinks and bread)
english.mnemonic: The yeast jumped free (yeasty) from the bread and was frothy and restless.
english.question: What does it mean if something is described as yeasty?

english.definition: An uneducated person uninterested in any form of culture and from the countryside.
english.mnemonic: She'd rather yoke all (yokel) her oxen than go to school. She was therefore uneducated and wasn't interested in anything but working in the countryside.
english.question: What is a yokel?

english.definition: Great energy or enthusiasm
english.mnemonic: The eel (zeal) gave off a great amount of energy when touched.
english.question: What does "zeal" mean?

english.definition: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their ideals, religion or politics
english.mnemonic: She had Z a lot (zealot) in fact she was fanatical. Her ideal bedroom would be filled with things starting with Z.
english.question: What is a zealot?

english.definition: The general intellectual, moral and cultural climate of an era
english.mnemonic: The sight of the guy stealing (zeitgeist) reminded me of the moral and cultural era of the early 18th century and the highwaymen.
english.question: What does the term "zeitgeist" refer to?

english.definition: The time or point at which something is at its most powerful or successful; also refers to the point on the celestial sphere directly above an observer.
english.mnemonic: Zen (zenith) has to be practised at the top of the mountain.
english.question: What is the zenith?

english.definition: Creation and protection of a country for Jewish people
english.mnemonic: The zoo let the lions out to protect the Jewish people, what heroism (Zionism).
english.question: What is Zionism?

english.definition: Creation and protection of a country for Jewish people
english.mnemonic: The farmer kept his eye on his empty (Zionism) field. He made the protection of the countryside his duty.
english.question: What is Zionism?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of polar bears.
english.mnemonic: The first time she saw the aurora (also known as the Northern Lights), the baby polar bear was so frightened she clung tightly to her mum.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of polar bears?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of turtles.
english.mnemonic: They positioned each bale very carefully so that the turtles couldn't go too far from the beach and get lost.
english.question: What is a bale of turtles?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of camels.
english.mnemonic: The caravan is where the camels go for a break whenever they get tired of the desert.
english.question: What is a caravan?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of rabbits.
english.mnemonic: Going down a hole – that's what rabbits do!
english.question: What is a collective noun for a group of rabbits?

english.definition: A collective noun for pandas.
english.mnemonic: It could be because of embarrassment – pandas poop up to 40 times a day! It must be all that bamboo they eat.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of pandas?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of jellyfish.
english.mnemonic: The kite fluttered over the mother (fluther) – she watched it so closely that she didn't notice she was walking on the jellyfish.
english.question: What is a fluther?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of vipers.
english.mnemonic: Suddenly she came upon all the generations of a family of vipers.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of vipers?

english.definition: Collective noun for a group of trout.
english.mnemonic: They were hovering over the water – the angler had no idea how he was going to catch the trout!
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of trout known as?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of gnus
english.mnemonic: The imps gave their applause for the ability (implausibility) of the gnus to dive in and swim the rapid river.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of gnus?

english.definition: A collective noun for giraffes.
english.mnemonic: It was the start of a long journey and the giraffe was glad she managed to get a seat on the bus.
english.question: What is a journey when referring to giraffes?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of butterflies.
english.mnemonic: She looked through her kaleidoscope and saw a beautiful pattern of butterflies.
english.question: What is a kaleidoscope in terms of butterflies?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of leopards.
english.mnemonic: Because they were so good at leaping, the leopards were always way ahead in the animal Olympics hurdles event.
english.question: What is a leap when referring to leopards?

english.definition: collective noun for a group of crows
english.mnemonic: There had been a murder most foul. The crow crime scene investigation unit was quick to the scene.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of crows?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of crocodiles.
english.mnemonic: When the mother returned to the nest to feed her chicks, she found instead that it was full of crocodiles!
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of crocodiles?

english.definition: A showy display of wealth and luxury in an attempt to impress others, used as the collective noun for peacocks.
english.mnemonic: It was an odd sensation (ostentation) – she knew there were really no peacocks there, but she kept seeing them in the kitchen.
english.question: What is the term for a showy display of wealth and luxury, also used as the collective noun for peacocks?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of parrots.
english.mnemonic: They had to clean the pan with ammonia (pandemonium) because it was full of parrot droppings after the birds got into the kitchen.
english.question: What is the term for a group of parrots?

english.definition: A quiver of cobras.
english.mnemonic: The archer was quivering because she suddenly noticed her quiver was full of cobras!
english.question: What is a group of cobras called?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of otters.
english.mnemonic: After hijacking his raft, the otters took it miles downriver to where they planned to make their new home.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of otters?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of sharks.
english.mnemonic: She started to shiver as she came out of the sea after a shark warning.
english.question: What is a shiver in terms of a group of sharks?

english.definition: A collective noun for goldfish.
english.mnemonic: It was very troubling for the goldfish when the cat got her paw into the bowl.
english.question: What is the collective noun for goldfish?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of ravens.
english.mnemonic: It was a demonstration of real unkindness – the ravens surrounded the newborn lamb with the idea of killing it for food.
english.question: What is a collective noun for a group of ravens?

english.definition: A collective noun for spiders.
english.mnemonic: The venom from the spider's bite made her leg swell and go numb.
english.question: What is the collective noun for spiders?

english.definition: A collective noun for nightingales.
english.mnemonic: Wearing a watch is the way nightingales ensure they only sing at the right times during dawn and dusk.
english.question: What is the collective noun for nightingales?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of larks.
english.mnemonic: The media said the crowd threw eggs to insult his nation (exultation), but really they did it for a lark.
english.question: What is a group of larks called?

english.definition: A collective noun for a group of oxen.
english.mnemonic: He didn't do it for a joke (yoke) – one of the oxen got up onto the cart because he really was afraid of the water.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of oxen?

english.definition: A collective noun for zebras
english.mnemonic: When they broke the seal (zeal) on the box, they found they'd been sent a new zebra!
english.question: What is the collective noun for zebras?

english.definition: A collective noun for frogs.
english.mnemonic: When they joined the army, the frogs had to go through basic training.
english.question: What is the collective noun for frogs?

english.definition: A collective noun for gorillas.
english.mnemonic: The zoo formed a band featuring only gorillas.
english.question: What is the collective noun for gorillas?

english.definition: A collective noun used for a group of dragons.
english.mnemonic: After taking flight the dragons circled above.
english.question: What is the collective noun for a group of dragons known as, specifically a "flight"?

english.definition: A collective noun for mice
english.mnemonic: After flying back to its nest, the bird was surprised to find mice in it.
english.question: What is the collective noun for mice?

english.definition: Poetry in general or several lines of a poem grouped together; a common way of saying stanza.
english.mnemonic: They saw the car reverse (verse) over the General (poetry in general) and then into several lines of troops.
english.question: What is a verse in poetry?

english.definition: A group of lines within a poem, usually set off from other stanzas by a line of space. It’s a posh way of saying verse, meaning several lines of a poem grouped together.
english.mnemonic: The troops were ordered to stand (stanza) in groups of lines, with spaces between them. The paras (paragraphs) were arriving to support them.
english.question: What is a stanza in poetry?

english.definition: A poem’s appearance and how it sounds; this includes the structure, pattern, line length, rhythms, rhyming system, and division into stanzas or verses.
english.mnemonic: Formula (form) 1 racing cars certainly look good (appearance). Formula (form) 1 racing cars are certainly noisy (sound). They can go over any structure.
english.question: What does "form/structure" refer to in poetry?

english.definition: A sonnet is a one-stanza poem of fourteen lines, written in iambic pentameter, and rhyming according to a prescribed scheme. Originally created by Petrarch (Petrarchan sonnet), the form was made famous by William Shakespeare.
english.mnemonic: The son’s net (sonnet) wasn’t used. He was only fourteen (fourteen lines). Dad used his spear (Shakespeare) and caught a pen who said: “I am a pen” (iambic pentameter).
english.question: What is a sonnet?

english.definition: A haiku is a very short form of Japanese poetry consisting of three lines with a 5-7-5 syllable structure.
english.mnemonic: Hike you (haiku) until you bash shoe (Basho) over three peaks (3 lines).
english.question: What is a haiku?

english.definition: A limerick is a five-line poem that uses anapestic foot – two unstressed syllables followed by one stressed syllable (SSL). The rhyme scheme is AABBA.
english.mnemonic: The old sailor lost his limb to rickets (limerick) and a pest (anapest) on his leg. His five toes were preserved and placed on his new leg.
english.question: What is a limerick?

english.definition: Poetry with no rules; it does not contain patterns of rhyme or metre and tends to follow natural speech, providing vivid imagery in short sentences.
english.mnemonic: On the last day of school, the kids were finally FREE – NO MORE RULES!
english.question: What is free verse in poetry?

english.definition: An acrostic poem contains certain letters in each line that, when read downwards, spell out a word, phrase or name. Typically, the first letters of each line are used to spell the word(s), but the letters may appear anywhere in the line, and they are capitalised.
english.mnemonic: A cross tick (acrostic) is not cross, it’s just down.
english.question: What is an acrostic poem?

english.definition: Poetry written with no rhyme, but which has metrical (rhythmic) lines – usually iambic pentameter.
english.mnemonic: The “I am a BiC” (iambic pentameter) pen went blank (blank verse) on the last word (no rhyme).
english.question: What is blank verse?

english.definition: The substitution of a milder, vaguer word for one considered to be offensive or unpleasant.
english.mnemonic: “That’s just a youth’s mist.”
english.question: What is a euphemism?

english.definition: The order in which events happened.
english.mnemonic: The Chronicle newspaper got lodged (chronological) in the door.
english.question: What does chronological mean?

english.definition: A combination of words that have opposite or very different meanings.
english.mnemonic: The ox couldn’t carry any more on (oxymoron) the cart – it was overloaded with wire wool.
english.question: What is an oxymoron?

english.definition: The use of words that mean the opposite of your true feelings, often used humorously or to add emphasis.
english.mnemonic: “Look at that iron (irony) outside the window. What a beautiful view!” (This is irony – saying the words: “What a beautiful view” is the opposite of what you would expect.)
english.question: What is irony?

english.definition: Sarcasm is a form of irony meant to attack, mock, ridicule and generally hurt someone.
english.mnemonic: The Russian Tsar was thrown into a chasm (sarcasm) by the leaders of the revolution. They threw iron (irony) bars at him which really hurt, and he died a painful death.
english.question: What is sarcasm?

english.definition: An overused phrase that labels you as a predictable and unoriginal thinker.
english.mnemonic: The key shaded (cliché) on the tip of the iceberg. The key was very worn out.
english.question: What is a cliché?

english.definition: A short, amusing or interesting story.
english.mnemonic: A heck of a goat (anecdote) was reading a short story.
english.question: What is an anecdote?

english.definition: A phrase that has a meaning not conveyed by the literal meaning of the words used. It often cannot be translated exactly.
english.mnemonic: The idiot’s omelette (idiom) was thrown up in the air and landed on the translator.
english.question: What is an idiom?

english.definition: The text indicating the content or subject of the article below it.
english.mnemonic: Her head had a lion on it (headline) and everyone pointed at it (main point).
english.question: What is a headline?

english.definition: slogan or catchphrase
english.mnemonic: The tag (tagline) on the ring said: “A diamond is forever.”
english.question: What is a tagline?

english.definition: The theme is the central idea in a piece of writing or other work of art. It is the main subject.
english.mnemonic: The seam (theme) of gold went right through the centre (central) of town.
english.question: What is the theme in a piece of writing or work of art?

english.definition: Atmosphere and feeling of the writing.
english.mnemonic: He needed to tone (tone) up before every performance so he could get the right music out of his huge instrument.
english.question: What does the term "tone" refer to in writing?

english.definition: Mood is how we are made to feel as readers after reading an article, story, poem, essay, or any piece of writing.
english.mnemonic: The cows mooed (mood) their anger when the farmer wrote a sign telling them their productivity rate needed to increase. The cows didn’t have a good feeling.
english.question: What does "mood" refer to in literature?

english.definition: The use of words that make an audience feel a particular emotion.
english.mnemonic: Easily remembered because they are practically the same.
english.question: What is emotive language?

english.definition: A humorous way of using a word or phrase so that it has more than one meaning.
english.mnemonic: She was punished (pun) by two meanies (two meanings).
english.question: What is a pun?

english.definition: Language peculiar to a particular group; non-standard words and phrases used by specific groups or in particular situations.
english.mnemonic: Street and language (slang)
english.question: What is slang?

english.definition: A word that has the same or nearly the same meaning as another word.
english.mnemonic: The tattoos were all sin on him (synonym) – words that all meant the same sort of thing covered his body.
english.question: What is a synonym?

english.definition: Language designed to have a persuasive or impressive effect.
english.mnemonic: The retro brick (rhetoric) bouncer couldn’t be persuaded to let them in.
english.question: What is rhetoric?

english.definition: A question asked merely for effect with no answer expected.
english.mnemonic: She retore (rhetorical) the document with a question mark on it.
english.question: What is a rhetorical question?

english.definition: An adage is a short statement or saying that has been used by many generations, expressing a general truth.
english.mnemonic: Add age (adage) and you will know the true meaning of this expression: “If you play with fire you're likely to get burned.”
english.question: What is an adage?

english.definition: Statements that function as commands, instructions, or orders.
english.mnemonic: Give him a pair of teeth (imperative) and then he can command.
english.question: What is an imperative statement?

english.definition: A group or set of three similar things.
english.mnemonic: Triplet babies (triplet) – three of a kind. They are extra-special.
english.question: What is a triplet?

english.definition: The use of words to evoke feelings of pity, sympathy, compassion, and sadness.
english.mnemonic: They paid for candyfloss (pathos) but later in life Emos (emotion) had lots of fillings which filled them with sadness.
english.question: What is pathos in literature or speech?

english.definition: Repetition of similar vowel sounds
english.mnemonic: An ass fed on ants (assonance) and was heard emitting a series of repeated bowel sounds (vowel sounds).
english.question: What is assonance?

english.definition: Words with the same consonant sound at the beginning.
english.mnemonic: The rats had a litter rate (alliteration) of one every second. We had to call in the Pied Piper!
english.question: What is alliteration?

english.definition: The use of similar-sounding consonants anywhere in the words, giving pleasing sounds to sentences.
english.question: What is consonance in literature?

english.definition: A reference intended to call something to mind without directly mentioning it
english.mnemonic: A strange illusion (allusion). I suppose it was a reference to a rabbit in a hat but that wasn't mentioned directly when the magician pulled a mouse from a shoe.
english.question: What is an allusion?

english.definition: A comparison in which an idea or a thing is compared to something familiar.
english.mnemonic: An allergy (analogy) to children is what the show’s compere (compare) had.
english.question: What is an analogy?

english.definition: A comparison in which one thing is said to be 'like' another or 'as' another.
english.mnemonic: There were two similar Bruce Lees (simile), but one always rode an ass (as) and the other always rode a bike (like).
english.question: What is a simile?

english.definition: Comparison of two things without using 'as' or 'like'.
english.mnemonic: Have you met her four (metaphor) sisters? Try comparing them! They are not similar (not simile).
english.question: What is a metaphor?

english.definition: An exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally but highlights a particular point or quality.
english.mnemonic: A high purring cat (hyperbole) was prowling the city, but it sounded like exaggeration to some people…
english.question: What is hyperbole?

english.definition: Figurative writing is not intended to be taken literally. Words or expressions have meanings different from the literal interpretation.
english.mnemonic: The figure (figurative) skater said she was as cold as ice. Good job she didn’t mean it literally...
english.question: What does figurative mean in writing?

english.definition: A word that sounds like its meaning.
english.mnemonic: To remember that onomatopoeia is associated with words like ‘Kerpow’, just think what would happen if you showed someone how to spell the word.
english.question: What is onomatopoeia?

english.definition: The humorous misuse of a word by confusing it with a similar-sounding word.
english.mnemonic: The mall was propped up (malapropism) after the huge explosion. A passing goat denied he was responsible – but referred to an “escape goat” when he meant “scapegoat”.
english.question: What is malapropism?

english.definition: The use of ridicule, exaggeration, mockery, and humor to expose and criticize the vices, follies, and shortcomings of people, especially politicians and public figures.
english.mnemonic: She sat on the tyre (satire) that had fallen off her car and started a tirade of criticism.
english.question: What is satire?

english.definition: Repetition of a word or use of a pronoun referring back to something previously mentioned.
english.mnemonic: And a “fore!” (anaphor) was repeated by each golfer as they teed off.
english.question: What is an anaphor?

english.definition: Giving human characteristics to animals or objects.
english.mnemonic: And throw poem which morphs (anthropomorphism) into a human (human attributes).
english.question: What is anthropomorphism?

english.definition: Personification is giving human characteristics to animals or objects.
english.mnemonic: Personification – human characteristics to an animal or object (think – one part or a bit)
english.question: What is personification?

english.definition: The attribution of human feelings and responses onto non-human objects; objects mirror the mood of people.
english.mnemonic: It was pathetic, she thought it was fabulous that she loved the sea (pathetic fallacy), and was convinced the sea had fallen in love with her, but how could the sea have human feelings?
english.question: What is pathetic fallacy?

languages.mnemonic: I put locks on every door and set traps around my rural (serrure) home.

languages.mnemonic: It's difficult to read a map while driving a go-kart (carte).

languages.mnemonic: This freedom march (March) was very different to most: it was taking place on Mars (mars)!

languages.question: What is the English translation of the French word "mai"?

languages.mnemonic: Another passenger shouted "excuse me!" at the couple making loud mwa (moi) noises as they kissed in the quiet carriage of the train.
languages.question: What does the French term "moi" mean in English?

languages.definition: mean (as in the meaning of something)
languages.mnemonic: This means you can see your new knee from today (signifier).

languages.question: What does the French verb "fondre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The men all chanted om (homme) as they prayed.

languages.mnemonic: We had two microphones so me and my crow (micro) could sing together.

languages.mnemonic: She was a mother of several children but still found time to be the town’s mayor (mére).

languages.mnemonic: He lived in nature and would only eat natural (nature) food.

languages.mnemonic: It was near the time of the garden party and she prayed (près) the rain wouldn't come.

languages.mnemonic: The police arrested the Eiffel Tower.

languages.mnemonic: Imagine the Labrador is working as a police dog.

languages.mnemonic: Pork chops were the only meat the poor (porc) could afford.

languages.mnemonic: Porc is masculine, so it's le porc. Imagine the early learner trying to make pulled pork by pulling on a pig's tail.
languages.question: What does "le porc" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the American port they poured (poor) all the tea away.

languages.mnemonic: My grandmother's post officer/mail carrier was very unreliable, in fact her (facteur) mail hasn't been delivered in weeks.

languages.mnemonic: The poster had a fish (affiche) on it.

languages.mnemonic: The potato loved using pom-poms and so did the dirty terrapin (pomme de terre).
