languages.mnemonic: Pour this liquid on the floor and the vermin will stay away from your safe (verser).

languages.mnemonic: Pooh Bear had little power of resistance. Pooh couldn't stop increasing his reservoir (pouvoir) of honey.

languages.mnemonic: The prawn used a credit card when he took himself to the vet (crevette).

languages.mnemonic: I gave the president a present and he loved the Donald (président) Duck toy.

languages.mnemonic: The price the prehistoric (prix) artwork fetched at auction was incredible.

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower was put in prison.

languages.question: What does "le prix" mean?

languages.mnemonic: A mentor must protect their protégé (protéger).

languages.mnemonic: The students protested after the professor said there would be more tests to take (protester).

languages.mnemonic: I was proud I could feed the people with my airplane (fier).

languages.mnemonic: I went to the pub with pooh bear (pub).
languages.question: What is the French word for "pub"?

languages.mnemonic: I pulled my teeth out before the race (tirer).
languages.question: What does the French verb "tirer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The puppy rounded up the sheep for it's owner (chiot).

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower was made of pure gold.
languages.question: What is the French word for "pure"?

languages.mnemonic: The purple viola was played by the leprechaun (violet).

languages.mnemonic: The dung beetle pushes poo into the safe (pousser).

languages.mnemonic: She put on a brave face when she met the giant rat (mettre).
languages.question: What does "mettre" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I have one question, why is there a kestrel drinking tea on (question) my roof?

languages.mnemonic: She won the race wearing a corset (course).
languages.question: What does "la course" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Course is feminine, so it's la course. Imagine the Labrador is winning a race against two greyhounds.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the French term "la course"?

languages.mnemonic: I could hear the radio blasting out our new rap that we'd just finished in the studio (radio).
languages.question: How do you say "radio" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: It always rains on Pluto's head when he eats (pluie).
languages.question: What does "la pluie" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Using rakes, the rat and the toad (râteau) cleared the garden.
languages.question: What does the French term "râteau" mean as a verb?

languages.mnemonic: The raspberry had to choose from bras (framboise) made of sequins or fur.
languages.question: What is "la framboise"?

languages.mnemonic: The meat was raw, but the ships crew (cru) didn't mind.
languages.question: What does "cru" mean in terms of food preparation?

languages.mnemonic: I wasn't sure if she was reading the magazine or just leering (lire) at the pictures.
languages.question: What does "lire" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The reason stingrays go on (raison) holiday is to rest from all that swimming.
languages.question: What does "la raison" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The recipe called for a rugby ball to be set (recette) in the jelly.
languages.question: What does "la recette" mean?

languages.mnemonic: He was red with anger. I shouldn't have been rude to the huge (rouge) monster.
languages.question: What does the term "rouge" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The referee wore armour because the bees were causing trouble (arbitre).

languages.mnemonic: You can rent a car on the lunar surface from an alien (louer).
languages.question: What is the verb "louer" in French used for?

languages.mnemonic: We needed to repair the red bus, so the parrots raced (réparer) over to help.
languages.question: What is the French word for "repair"?

languages.mnemonic: I won't repeat this recipe because the pigeon tasted (répéter) so bad.
languages.question: What does the French verb "répéter" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The result of her diet meant she had to get a tailor to re-suit her (résultat) before the red carpet appearance.
languages.question: What is the translation of "le résultat" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I was asked to return Ronald McDonald's drum (rendre).
languages.question: What does the French verb "rendre" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She was not going to return the money she took following their romp after a boozy (rembourser) night out.
languages.question: What does "rembourser" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: He was told he had to return (come back) to shore as the rowing boat's veneer (revenir) began to peel off.
languages.question: What does the French term "revenir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: He was trying to return (go back) to the place he had seen a rat turn hay (retourner) in to a house.
languages.question: What does the French word "retourner" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Upon his return home, his wife said he had bought the wrong tray (rentrer).
languages.question: What does the French verb "rentrer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: To write out all of the rhymes, I needed a ream (rime) of paper.
languages.question: What is "la rime" in poetry?

languages.mnemonic: She poured out the rice and I could read (riz) a message.
languages.question: What is the French word for rice?

languages.mnemonic: No one else could ride this horse, only the monster could tame (monter) it.
languages.question: What does "monter" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Put all the rings in the bag! (bague)" said the robber.
languages.question: What is "la bague" in English?

languages.mnemonic: What a rip-off! The arcade charges so much for a snack (arnaque).

languages.mnemonic: I took a risk by parachuting near the Eiffel Tower.
languages.question: What is the French word for "risk"?

languages.mnemonic: The road was blocked by tree roots (route).
languages.question: What is "la route"?

languages.mnemonic: In the play, my role was the Eiffel Tower.
languages.question: What is the English equivalent of the French word "rôle"?

languages.mnemonic: He rolled down the hill; this kangaroo was late (roule) for work.
languages.question: What does the French verb "rouler" mean?

languages.mnemonic: On my roof, penguins like to waddle (toit) around.
languages.question: What does "le toit" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: From this room, the people had to escape (pièce).
languages.question: What does "la pièce" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I used the rope to cordon (corde) off the crime scene.
languages.question: What is the French term for rope?

languages.mnemonic: "This is rotten pork, read (pourri) the date!"
languages.question: What does "pourri" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: Round tables are wrong (rond) for today's (ronde) meeting because where does the chair person sit?
languages.question: What does "rond" (m)/"ronde" (f) mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: The farmer's rubber boots where ruined after the cow chewed (caoutchouc) them.
languages.question: What is caoutchouc?

languages.mnemonic: The rubbish went everywhere because the awful bin bags weren't durable (ordures).
languages.question: What is the French term for rubbish or garbage?

languages.mnemonic: The rugby posts were small Eiffel Towers.
languages.question: What is the French word for rugby?

languages.mnemonic: "You said you were going to break the world record for the deepest (dit) hole in a garden."
languages.question: What does "dit" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: I gave my dog a salad, but he was sad that it wasn't lamb or duck (salade).
languages.question: What is "la salade" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The rabbit's wages were paid in salad for flying the aeroplane (salaire).
languages.question: What does "salaire" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There was a sale on and they sold (solde) everything.
languages.question: What does "solde" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: The salt was kept on the table in a large salt cellar (sel).
languages.question: What does "le sel" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The sisters had exactly the same memories (même) of growing up.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the French word "même"?

languages.mnemonic: Across the sand, the sack race went by in a blur (sable).
languages.question: What is the French word for sand?

languages.mnemonic: On Saturday they sat in their boat as they sailed in the harbour, but their sampan got caught in an eddy (samedi) and they were swept out to sea.
languages.question: What day is referred to as "le samedi" in French?

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower was a sauce bottle.
languages.question: What does "la sauce" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They realised the sausage boat wasn't suitable when they saw the sea's (saucisse) rough waves leaving the harbour.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la saucisse"?

languages.mnemonic: Say goodbye to the deer (dire).
languages.question: What does "dire" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The woman's scarf got caught on a sharp (écharpe) fence spike causing her to choke.
languages.question: What does "l'écharpe" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If you don't work hard at school, you'll end up in the coal (école) mine.
languages.question: What does "l'école" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I used my scissors to make two seats from one sofa (ciseaux).
languages.question: What is the French term for scissors?

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower was riding a scooter.
languages.question: What is the French word for scooter?

languages.mnemonic: With the score level the Eiffel Tower just needed to shoot beyond the keeper to win.
languages.question: What do you call the tally or total of points in a game?

languages.mnemonic: Staring at the screen, the ape watched the chronicles of Narnia (écran).
languages.question: What is "l'écran" in French?

languages.mnemonic: He screwed the visitor (vis) to the wall.
languages.question: What is the French word for "screw"?

languages.mnemonic: The sea parted as the mare (mer) and her foal walked towards it.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la mer"?

languages.mnemonic: The seafood freed the mayor (fruits de mer) from his cell.
languages.question: What does "le fruit de mer" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: They were searching for food and shouted "yay!" (fouiller) when they found some.
languages.question: What does the French verb "fouiller" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The flat Earther booked a seat on a cruise to see the edge (siège) of the world.
languages.question: What does "le siège" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There was a secret meeting of circus performers in the creche (secret).

languages.mnemonic: This section of the party (partie) is for VIPs only.
languages.question: What does "la partie" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We could no longer see the rabbit when the magician said 'Voila!' (voir) and made it vanish.
languages.question: What does the French word "voir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The seeds grew into grenades (graine).
languages.question: What does "la graine" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Only select people can go up the Eiffel Tower today.
languages.question: What is the French term for "select"?

languages.mnemonic: She didn't look like her normal self once she swallowed (soi) the pill.

languages.mnemonic: The sentence was frazzled (phrase) at the edges.
languages.question: What is "la phase" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The septic tank team member (September) felt really tired and her clothes stank awfully as she walked home through the churchyard. So she took off her clothes and slept on a tomb wearing just her bra (septembre).
languages.question: What is the French word for September?

languages.mnemonic: You can see the serious frown disappear when I am in the sea air with you (sérieux).
languages.question: What does "sérieux" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The shape of this formula (forme) one car was very odd.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the French term "la forme"?

languages.mnemonic: She took up more than her fair share of parking (part) spaces.
languages.question: What does "la part" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Part is feminine, so it's la part. Imagine the Labrador is unwilling to give up its share of the meat pie.
languages.question: What does "la part" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The shark chewed the rudder of my canal (requin) boat.
languages.question: What is "le requin" in English?

languages.mnemonic: To shave, the rabbit uses her favourite barber, the sabre (raser) toothed tiger.
languages.question: What does the French verb "raser" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She could hold up an elephant (elle).
languages.question: What is the French word for "she"?

languages.mnemonic: This sheep is difficult to move, it weighs a ton (mouton).
languages.question: What does "le mouton" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I used my bed sheets to hide my drum (drap) kit.
languages.question: What is "le drap" in French?

languages.mnemonic: The shelter I built was so flimsy that a breeze (abri) knocked it down.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the French term "l'abri"?

languages.mnemonic: The shiny silver tray had brie on (brilliant) it.
languages.question: What does the term "brilliant" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The patient had to unbutton his shirt to show the measles (chemise) rash to the doctor.
languages.question: What is the French term for shirt?

languages.mnemonic: Her shoe got stuck in something unpleasant as she was shown around the sewer (chaussure).
languages.question: What is the French word for shoe?

languages.mnemonic: The elves at the shoe shop made boots out of teak (boutique) - they were very hard-wearing.
languages.question: What is "la boutique"?

languages.mnemonic: She went to the only shop in the village but it only sold magazines about underwear (magasin).
languages.question: What does "le magasin" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower went on a shopping spree.
languages.question: What is shopping when done as a leisure activity?

languages.mnemonic: My food shopping was along an assault course (courses).
languages.question: What French term refers to food shopping?

languages.mnemonic: I pushed the shopping trolley full of champagne up a mountain in Rio (chariot) de Janeiro.
languages.question: What does "le chariot" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: We had to sail back to shore to retrieve (rive) the treasure map.
languages.question: What does "la rive" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: I put on the pair of shorts, but because I was so short (short), they looked like trousers.
languages.question: What is the French term for shorts?

languages.mnemonic: I hurt my shoulder throwing apes into the pool (épaule).
languages.question: What is "l'épaule" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I shouted at the creepy alien (crier) to leave me alone.
languages.question: What is a synonym for crier?

languages.mnemonic: The shovel was used by the pelican (pelle).
languages.question: What is "la pelle"?

languages.mnemonic: I showed her all the monocles that I had on a tray (montrer).
languages.question: What does the French verb "montrer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I needed a signature from a senior teacher (signature) to get a day off school.
languages.question: What is "la signature" in French?

languages.mnemonic: My boat was sinking after the coot in the lake (couler) attacked it.
languages.question: What does the French verb "couler" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Sir, I must now measure (monsieur) the length of your leg.
languages.question: What is the French word for "sir"?

languages.mnemonic: My sister dressed up as a man – people called her sir (soeur).
languages.question: What is the French word for sister?

languages.mnemonic: The size of his tie was far too big for someone so young (taille).

languages.mnemonic: He tried to ski down the side of the Eiffel Tower.

languages.mnemonic: My skin was healed by the potion (peau).
languages.question: What is "la peau"?

languages.mnemonic: A skirt was worn by Jupiter (jupe).
languages.question: What does "la jupe" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Look in the sky and you'll see flying elephants (ciel).
languages.question: What does "le ciel" refer to in French?

languages.mnemonic: I was trying to sleep, but the door kept being slammed by the meerkat (dormir).
languages.question: What does the verb "dormir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I can't stand the smell of that cheese, the odour (odeur) is foul.

languages.mnemonic: The snail escaped with all our cargo (escargot).

languages.mnemonic: The snakes circled the pond (serpent).

languages.mnemonic: When it was about to sneeze, the elephant turned away (éternuer).

languages.mnemonic: The bartender poured so much gin and only a small amount of tonic (tant).

languages.mnemonic: "You're in so much trouble because you broke a law (alors)."

languages.mnemonic: Use soap to clean the wound then use savlon (savon).
languages.question: What is the French word for soap?

languages.mnemonic: The sock watched a TV show sitting on the settee (chaussette).
languages.question: What is the French word for sock?

languages.mnemonic: I sat on the sofa eating all the canapés (canapé).
languages.question: What is "le canapé" in French?

languages.mnemonic: I bought a very soft voodoo (doux) doll.
languages.question: What does "doux" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Soil was dumped on the soldier (sol).
languages.question: What does "le sol" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: The soldier sold my dad (soldat) his gun.
languages.question: What does "le soldat" mean in English?

languages.definition: du (m) or de l' in front of a vowel or h, de la (f) or de l' in front of a vowel or h, des (plural m or f)
languages.mnemonic: Some people say their wedding day (des) is the happiest day of their lives. But do (du) remember to turn up on time. Remember no delays (de l') and tell her (del a) you love her.
languages.question: How is "some" translated in French with respect to gender and number?

languages.mnemonic: The song started when the spotlight shone on the songbird (chanson).
languages.question: What does "la chanson" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Chanson is feminine, so it's la chanson. Imagine the Labrador playing a song on a keyboard.
languages.question: What does "la chanson" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I soon noticed the bee under my toe (bientôt) when it stung me.
languages.question: What does "bientôt" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: I said sorry to the dentist for being so late (désolé).
languages.question: What does the French word "désolé" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The sound of her song (son) made the glass break.
languages.question: What does "le son" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the bowl of soup was a model of the Eiffel Tower.
languages.question: What is the French term for soup?

languages.mnemonic: The sour taste of the lemon made the egg run (aigre) away.
languages.question: What does "aigre" mean in terms of taste?

languages.mnemonic: In the south pole, a penguin sued a (sud) seal.
languages.question: What does "sud" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: You can't get into space unless you have a passport (espace).
languages.question: What does "l'espace" refer to in an astronomical context?

languages.mnemonic: A spatula was the first thing the monster spat out, followed by other tools (spatule).
languages.question: What is the French word for "spatula"?

languages.mnemonic: Her speech was disgusting and course (discours).

languages.mnemonic: Driving at such speed meant the vicar failed his driving test (vitesse).

languages.mnemonic: To spell a word, a pulley (épeler) was used to put all the letters in the correct positions.

languages.mnemonic: There was so much spice on every piece (épice) of food.
languages.question: What does "l'épice" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The chilli was spicy, I heard a pea say (épicé) as it ate a piece (épicé).
languages.question: What does "épicé" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He tried to remove the splinter with a shard (écharde) of glass.
languages.question: What is the French word for a splinter?

languages.mnemonic: This was the national sport of the fairies to catch as many spores (sport) from this fern as they could.

languages.mnemonic: It was a very popular spot, but there was only one seat (site).
languages.question: What does "le site" refer to in French?

languages.mnemonic: He sprained his wrist on my torso (entorse) when he punched me.
languages.question: What is l'entorse?

languages.mnemonic: When spring arrived everything pranced around, it scared the tomato (printemps).
languages.question: What season does "le printemps" refer to in French?

languages.mnemonic: Square packages are much easier to carry (carré/carrée).

languages.mnemonic: The squid's calligraphy marks (calmar) on the wall did not impress his housemate.
languages.question: What is "le calmar"?

languages.mnemonic: In the stadium everyone had to stand (stade).
languages.question: What is "le stade" in French?

languages.mnemonic: On this stage they had to spray a scent (scène) after the performance.
languages.question: What is the French term for stage?

languages.mnemonic: The stain was from his moustache (tache).
languages.question: What does "la tache" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I traded my stamp collection for a tambourine and a paint brush (timbre).
languages.question: What is "le timbre" in French?

languages.mnemonic: The station was expecting trouble from some passengers, so a guard (gare) was mounted.
languages.question: What is the French term for a train station?

languages.mnemonic: The Statue of Liberty was holding up the Eiffel Tower.
languages.question: What is "la statue" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The Eiffel Tower ate a steak.
languages.question: What does "le steak" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They decided to construct the building from steel after seeing the apes (arier) destroy the previous one.
languages.question: What is l'acier in English?

languages.mnemonic: He had a jellyfish sting and thought peeing on it would cure (piqûre) the pain.
languages.question: What does the term "piqûre" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: You couldn't miss her stockings as she sat at the bar (bas).
languages.question: What is the French term "le bas" referring to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Bas is masculine so it's le bas. Imagine the early learner is inside a pair of Christmas stockings.
languages.question: What is "le bas" in French clothing terms?

languages.mnemonic: It wasn't good for my stomach, so I was told to eat less tomato (estomac) ketchup.
languages.question: What does "l'estomac" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The stone people were too heavy for the hot air (pierre) balloon.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la pierre"?

languages.mnemonic: "Can we stop? I need a rest from carrying this table (arrêter)".
languages.question: What is the French verb for "stop"?

languages.mnemonic: During the storm, Tom and Jerry were petrified (tempête).
languages.question: What does "la tempête" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The strawberry used a phrase (fraise) book on holiday.
languages.question: What is "la fraise" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Along the street I raced the kangaroo (roo).
languages.question: What is "la rue" in French?

languages.mnemonic: He was strong enough to lift all four (fort) of us, but she could lift the whole fort (forte).
languages.question: What does "fort (m) / forte (f)" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: The students all crammed into the elevator (élève).
languages.question: What does "l'élève" refer to in the context of primary and secondary education?

languages.mnemonic: My style was to wear stainless steel (style) clothes.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "le style"?

languages.mnemonic: On the subway train we met rowers (métro) coming the other way.
languages.question: What does "le métro" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Such a big telephone (tel/telle).
languages.question: What does "tel/telle" mean in French?

languages.mnemonic: Under the suit, he wore a Superman costume (costume).
languages.question: What is "le costume" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The suitcase went on holiday in the Welsh valleys (valise).
languages.question: What does "la valise" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Valise is feminine, so it's la valise. Imagine a litter of Labrador puppies in a suitcase.
languages.question: What does "la valise" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Mum made summer puddings and they were so hungry they ate a (été) whole one each.
languages.question: What season does "l'été" refer to in French?

languages.mnemonic: The postman climbed to the summit to give me some mail (sommet).
languages.question: What does "le sommet" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The sun's out, so I'll lay (soleil) down and get a tan.
languages.question: What is "le soleil"?

languages.mnemonic: On Sunday, they planned to go to church as usual, but when they got there they found workmen had started to demolish (dimanche) it!

languages.mnemonic: For supper I want soup, but I'm not paying (souper).
languages.question: What does "le souper" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: I love this sweater. I even wear it in the pool (pull).
languages.question: What is another term for a sweater, especially in British English?

languages.mnemonic: I had to sweep the floor before the ballet-dancing apes (balayer) began their performance.
languages.question: What does the French verb "balayer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: If you eat lots of sweet foods, your teeth will soon crumble (sucré).
languages.question: What does "sucré" mean in terms of taste?

languages.mnemonic: She loved sweets and candy so much that she had them stuck to her bonnet and to the bonnet (bonbon) of her car.
languages.question: What is "le bonbon"?

languages.mnemonic: You'd swim faster than your nan if you just shaved (nager) your beard.
languages.question: What does the French verb "nager" mean?

languages.mnemonic: At the swimming pool a pea was seen (piscine) jumping in by the lifeguard.
languages.question: What does "la piscine" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They told me the sword was edible, but I found it quite painful (épée).

languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "answer"?

languages.mnemonic: The ant cooked an awful meal that made me gag (hormiga).
languages.question: ¿Qué es la hormiga?

languages.mnemonic: Hormiga is feminine, so it's la hormiga. Imagine a lady being carried away by ants.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "ant"?

languages.mnemonic: As the ghosts appear through the castle wall, it is soon apparent they're (aparecer) not there to frighten us.
languages.question: What does the verb "aparecer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The farmer had to applaud a ploughing deer (applaudir).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the French verb "applaudir"?

languages.mnemonic: She gave him an apple. The man thanked her appreciatively (manzana).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for apple?

languages.mnemonic: She suddenly remembered her appointment at the dentist's as she sat in the audience at the theatre (cita).
languages.question: What does "cita" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine a lady being late for an appointment:
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la cita" en español?

languages.mnemonic: Some people claim that with a pill (April) you can have a brilliant (abril) time.
languages.question: What month is referred to as "abril" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Are they committing arson (son)?
languages.question: What does the term "son" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The target area was totally destroyed – the army had a ray gun that annihilated (aréa) everything.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el aréa"?

languages.mnemonic: Her arm was cut badly on the bramble thorns (brazo).
languages.question: What is "brazo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: At around seven o'clock I start watching my favourite TV show. I watch about ten episodes a day (a eso de).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la expresión "a eso de"?

languages.mnemonic: They waited ages for their car to arrive and shouted "Yay! – here's the car" (llegar) as it finally drove in to view.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el verbo "llegar"?

languages.mnemonic: Their son was very good at art - after all, they were a very arty (arte) family.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el arte"?

languages.mnemonic: The artist only created art about Easter (artista).
languages.question: What does "artista" mean?

languages.mnemonic: As expected, he looked like a much older man with his comb-over (como) hairstyle.
languages.question: What does "como" mean in English as a conjunction or preposition?

languages.mnemonic: As smelly as a commode (como).
languages.question: What does "como" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I tried to ask the predator in the lagoon to stop targeting (preguntar) me, but it didn't work.
languages.question: What does "preguntar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A gust of wind (August) blows us up into the sky just as I go to tow (agosto) the caravan.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "agosto"?

languages.mnemonic: My aunt loves to wear a tiara (tia) where ever she goes.
languages.question: What does "la tia" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: In the autumn the leaves of the oak create tones that must be videoed (otoño).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for autumn?

languages.mnemonic: This baby better start betting (bebé) on the right numbers, or I'm ruined.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "baby"?

languages.mnemonic: Her back pain was caused by her best pal dancing (espalda) on her.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "back"?

languages.mnemonic: In my backpack, I kept more cheese than would last (mochila) a lifetime.
languages.question: What is "la mochila" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It had definitely gone bad – the marshmallow (malo) had mould growing on it!
languages.question: What does "malo" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Her bag was made of balsa (bolsa) wood, so broke easily when she dropped it.
languages.question: What does "la bolsa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: All of the bald people featured in this calendar wear bow (calvo) ties.
languages.question: What does "calvo" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The ball was caught by a pelican driving a smart motor (pelota).
languages.question: What is "la pelota"?

languages.mnemonic: I loved ballet, but I was so bad that they wouldn't let (balet) me dance.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el ballet?

languages.mnemonic: Ballet is masculine, so it's el ballet. Imagine an elephant ballet dancer.
languages.question: ¿Qué forma de danza clásica es conocida en español como "el ballet"?

languages.mnemonic: We went to see the band play, but we were banned from dancing (banda).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la banda"?

languages.mnemonic: Being covered in bandages, he couldn't bend at (venda) all.
languages.question: What is "la venda" in medical terms?

languages.mnemonic: It was just his luck that the bank had decided to ban coins (banco) on the day he tried to pay in his savings.
languages.question: What is "el banco" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: This is the bull's favourite bar (bar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "bar"?

languages.mnemonic: They were such a bargain that I bought the whole gang a (ganga) new pair of shoes.
languages.question: What does "la ganga" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The trick was anything but basic. It was a backflip into the sea out of a helicopter (básico).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "basic"?

languages.mnemonic: In his shopping basket, the thespian had tangerines (cesta).
languages.question: What does "la cesta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Cesta is feminine, so it's la cesta. Imagine a lady hiding in a basket.
languages.question: What is "la cesta"?

languages.mnemonic: The bull was terrible at basketball (básquetbol).
languages.question: What is básquetbol in English?

languages.mnemonic: When he went to bat, the batter tensed up when he saw the arms (batear) of the pitcher.
languages.question: What does "batear" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I wish you would be serious (ser), especially here Tarzan (estar).
languages.question: What do "ser" and "estar" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: On the beach, the handle came off her bucket, but her dad had a pair of pliers (playa) to fix it.
languages.question: What does "la playa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bear was oh-so (oso) clever when it came to catching fish.
languages.question: What does "el oso" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They beat him with a bat and he had tears (batir) in his eyes.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "batir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At the audition for the female lead in Beauty and the Beast, the director said: "You're the best yet, thank you!" (belleza).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for beauty?

languages.mnemonic: Belleza is feminine, so it's la belleza. Imagine a lady who uses so many beauty products she can hardly move around her house for them.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for beauty that is feminine?

languages.mnemonic: Because the bee caused so much trouble, Porky (porque) pig fled the room.
languages.question: What does "porque" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Before he went to bed he would always set the security camera (cama) on.
languages.question: What is "la cama"?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine your bedroom being turned into a dormitory (dormitorio) with lots of strange people sleeping in it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el dormitorio"?

languages.mnemonic: Dormitorio is masculine, so it’s el dormitorio. To remember this, imagine an elephant sleeping in the bedroom (dormitorio).
languages.question: What is "el dormitorio" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Buy a beer for their baby that (cerveza) has just finished its last one.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for beer?

languages.mnemonic: Before the ant was weak, now the ant tears (antes) a book in half with ease.
languages.question: What does the term "antes" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Can we begin? Can we commence? You're all too lethargic!" (comenza).
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "comenza" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Behind the garden fence I detect a rascal (detrás) rabbit eating my carrots and lettuce.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "detrás"?

languages.mnemonic: I don't believe that flight will be going today: a big crevice has appeared in the aeroplane's (creer) wing.
languages.question: What does the verb "creer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A bell ringing at the camp means it's time to eat a banana (campana).
languages.question: What does "la campana" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Every berry in my bag had been eaten by the yak (baya).
languages.question: What does "baya" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It is better to stay indoors today. There are menacing hordes (mejor) of wasps about.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "mejor"?

languages.mnemonic: Between the skaters she entered on a tray (entre).
languages.question: What does the term "entre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Riding the bicycle across the bumps, she knew there was going to be a thick pool of sick later (bicicleta).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la bicicleta" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Bicicleta is feminine, so it’s la bicicleta. Imagine a lady worrying about getting her dress caught in a bicycle.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for bicycle?

languages.mnemonic: The big house was their family home - it was a grand day (grande) when they moved in.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "grande" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bill for the wine would have been extortionate so to quench our thirst we asked for tap (cuenta) water.
languages.question: What is "la cuenta" in a restaurant?

languages.mnemonic: The little bird sat with the panda happily rowing (pájaro) on the lake.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for bird?

languages.mnemonic: You want me to bite into that? You'll have to give me more for that dare (morder).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "morder" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If you were sucked into a black hole, your neck would grow (negro) longer as your body is stretched.
languages.question: What does "el negro/la negra" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Around the giant block of ice was a naval blockade (bloque).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "block" as a noun?

languages.mnemonic: As the blood poured from her cut, her new sandals weren't grey (sangre) anymore.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la sangre"?

languages.mnemonic: She could blow soap bubbles so large (soplar).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el término "soplar"?

languages.mnemonic: She was blue with the cold, this athlete was not fit to swim in the pool (azul) again.
languages.question: What color does "azul" represent?

languages.mnemonic: The crew board the plane, but already aboard are (abordar) the captain and his co-pilot.
languages.question: What does "abordar" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: They don't call that a boat. They call that a barge carrying coal (barco).
languages.question: What is "el barco" in English?

languages.mnemonic: On his body, he created a slot where post (cuerpo) goes in.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "cuerpo"?

languages.mnemonic: The dogs bone was wedged under the sofa (hueso).
languages.question: What does "hueso" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The book did a giant leap, landed on a bookcase and broke it (libro).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "book"?

languages.mnemonic: Libro is masculine, so it's el libro. Imagine an elephant reading a book in a library.
languages.question: What does "el libro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When the baby was born, nan came to see her dressed in a tuxedo (nacido).
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "nacido"?

languages.mnemonic: The boss is heavy and the stairs failed (jefe).
languages.question: Who is referred to as "el jefe"?

languages.mnemonic: Both said, "I am the boss" at the same time.
languages.question: What does "ambos/ambas" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I bought a bottle of champagne on the boat to celebrate taking my yak (botella) on his first luxury cruise.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for bottle?

languages.mnemonic: At the bottom of the pond lived a beautiful fish – she was very fond of it after over (fondo) 20 years living there.
languages.question: What does "el fondo" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: Fondo is masculine, so it's el fondo. Imagine an elephant falling into the bottom of a ravine and getting trapped.
languages.question: What does "el fondo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Look at this bowl (bol) full of bulls.
languages.question: What is "el bol" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: It was her tenth box of tissues – the catarrh (caja) was really bad.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "box"?

languages.mnemonic: The boy was angry that the cheetah was wearing his coat (chico).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "boy"?

languages.mnemonic: His brain was hurting after the difficult exam he'd sat that day, then his friend said, 'Look at the ray, bro!' (celebro), and he felt a lot better.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for brain?

languages.mnemonic: I was clinging to the tree branch after I ra-n away from the ma-ssive (rama) dog.
languages.question: What does "la rama" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The new brand is unremarkable (marca).
languages.question: What does "marca" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I cook my bread in a frying pan (pan). Pan is masculine, so it's el pan. Imagine an elephant baking a loaf of bread.
languages.question: What does "el pan" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If you break that bed with all your romping, a repair (romper) will be very costly.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "romper" mean?

languages.mnemonic: He couldn't breathe properly so they put him on an artificial respirator (respirar).
languages.question: What does the term "respirar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In bright sunshine, I ate brie with my aunt all day (brillante).
languages.question: What does "brillante" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She couldn't bring herself to admit to a sudden release of trapped air (traer).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish verb "traer"?

languages.mnemonic: Her brother always said yes but her ma always said no (hermano).
languages.question: What does "hermano" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The brown chocolate left a mark on (marrón) my new dress.
languages.question: ¿Qué color es "el marrón / la marrón"?

languages.mnemonic: Brush their peas off my yard (cepillar).
languages.question: What does "cepillar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I turned the bucket into a cool looking boat (cubo).
languages.question: What is "el cubo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: In order to build you need the construction drawing to be true here (construir).
languages.question: What does "construir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Their building was completely edible, and they each feasted until the only (edificio) thing left was the front door.
languages.question: What does "el edificio" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bull told me to row (toro) faster.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for bull?

languages.mnemonic: Be careful not to burn your arm on the kettle or it will mark (quemar) you permanently.
languages.question: What does "quemar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bus driver told the passenger he'd throw him out of the bus (autobús) if he didn't behave.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for bus?

languages.mnemonic: His business made necklaces for goats; the only (negocio) problem was that he had no customers.
languages.question: What does "negocio" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They liked to keep busy, so they occupied themselves by cleaning the island of dodos (ocupado).
languages.question: What does "ocupado/ocupada" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They thought they looked beautiful but really they looked like a pair of ogres (pero).
languages.question: What does "pero" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If the Register Office were to buy a new computer system, the Registrar (comprar) would be able to update births and deaths far more efficiently.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "comprar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: By having by-pass surgery, he hoped to improve his poor (por) health.
languages.question: What does "por" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The cabbage attended college every day.
languages.question: What is "la col" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The café was a cybercafé with a terrier (cafeteria) dog serving behind the counter.
languages.question: What is another word for a small, informal restaurant often self-service, like a cafeteria?

languages.mnemonic: The cakes were all passed to the telephone (pastel) to eat.
languages.question: What does "el pastel" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Why don't you answer when I call? Don't you want to speak to ya ma? (Llamar)
languages.question: What does "llamar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This camel can make yoyos (camello) do amazing tricks.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el camello/la camella?

languages.mnemonic: I prefer to camp in the mountains, as campsites are (acampar) too crowded.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "acampar" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: This can of soup or this can of soup? I chose the latter (lata).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "can" (noun)?

languages.mnemonic: Lata is feminine, so it's la lata. Imagine a lady wearing earrings that look like cans.
languages.question: What does the word "lata" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This candle is so much better than a lamp (bela).
languages.question: What is "la vela" in English?

languages.definition: el capital (monetary capital), la capital (capital city)
languages.mnemonic: The bull invested all its capital in the capital city's regeneration fund, but never got a penny in return.
languages.question: What is the difference in meaning between "el capital" and "la capital" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Capital (as in monetary capital) is masculine, so it's el capital. Imagine an elephant losing all his capital in an investment fraud.
languages.question: What is the masculine term for monetary capital in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Capital (as in capital city) is feminine, so it's la capital. Imagine a lady winning the election to be mayor of the capital city.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "capital city"?

languages.mnemonic: The ship's captain chased the cat after it peed on his tanning (capitán) lotion.
languages.question: What does "el capitán" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Her car looked more like a coach with hay (coche) sticking out of it.
languages.question: What is "el coche" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I received a birthday card from Tarzan. He needed help with the task (tarjeta) because he couldn't spell his name.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for card?

languages.mnemonic: Tarjeta is feminine, so it's la tarjeta. Imagine a lady buying everything with her credit card.
languages.question: What does "la tarjeta" mean?

languages.mnemonic: You carry all the yea votes because they are vast (llevar) and I'll carry the nay votes.
languages.question: What is the verb "llevar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The cash machine robbery was prevented as a super cartoon hero automatically (cajero automático) swooped down and stopped it!
languages.question: ¿Qué es el cajero automático?

languages.mnemonic: Cajero automático is masculine, so it’s el cajero automático. Imagine an elephant getting money from a cash machine.
languages.question: What is "el cajero automático"?

languages.mnemonic: The cashier lost count as the car hit the hedgerow (cajero).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a cashier?

languages.mnemonic: The cat couldn't wait to eat some of the chocolate gateau (gato).
languages.question: What does "el gato" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To catch them we laid a trap beneath the paratroopers (atrapar).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el verbo "atrapar"?

languages.mnemonic: The cause of climate change is that cows are (causa) producing methane gas.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "la causa"?

languages.mnemonic: What a way to celebrate – their levitating bras (celebrar) were putting on quite the show!
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "celebrar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the centre of the crowd were the winners. They stood on the podium and then trophies (centro) were presented.
languages.question: What does "el centro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I'm certain I never want to see a theatre show done by toes (cierto) again!
languages.question: What does "cierto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She just wanted to sit in her easy chair all day so everyone else said "See-ya" (silla)
languages.question: What does "la silla" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There's a chance that this is the job opportunity I've been waiting for, but my dad (oportunidad) doesn't think so.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "oportunidad"?

languages.mnemonic: Oportunidad is feminine, so it's la oportunidad. Imagine a lady with a chance of winning.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "the opportunity"?

languages.mnemonic: Change into your warmest clothes, because our campsite will be in the arctic (cambiar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "to change"?

languages.mnemonic: The clown character arrived in the big top on a car roof rack and managed to tear (carácter) his baggy trousers as he jumped off.
languages.question: What does "carácter" mean in English?

languages.definition: charge (as in to charge a fee)
languages.mnemonic: The props department charge more for cobras because they are (cobrar) dangerous.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "cobrar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Making a chart was his task, but he handed in a blank (tabla) piece of paper.
languages.question: What is "la tabla" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The inspectors' check on the school found the head had little control (control).
languages.question: What is a synonym for control that also means check as a noun?

languages.mnemonic: My cheese is kept so (queso) safe.
languages.question: What does "el queso" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Do you think the new chef will cope with the 'Desert menu' theme next week of rattlesnake (cocinera) dishes?
languages.question: What is "el cocinero" or "la cocinera" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Go to the chemist, a farmer who is a pharmacist will give you something for the ankle (farmacia) pain.
languages.question: What does "la farmacia" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I wrote a cheque to buy a cherry cake (cheque).
languages.question: What is another term for a check in banking?

languages.mnemonic: The chick posed for his employee of the month photo (polito).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a baby bird known as a chick?

languages.mnemonic: This chicken rides a pony and yoyos (pollo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for chicken?

languages.mnemonic: Pollo is masculine, so it's el pollo. Imagine an elephant riding a giant chicken.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for the chicken when using the masculine article?

languages.mnemonic: The child really needed to be in the yo-yo (niño) competition, said her mum, because she thought she was the best in the world.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "child" when referring to a boy or girl?

languages.mnemonic: This chocolate shop serves chocolate with a latte (chocolate) only.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el chocolate" en español?

languages.mnemonic: Chocolate is masculine, so it's el chocolate. Imagine an elephant made of chocolate.
languages.question: ¿Cómo se dice "chocolate" en español?

languages.mnemonic: He will often choose to switch off his electronic hearing (elegir) aid so he didn't have to listen to the office chitter chatter.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "elegir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: For Christmas, I received some nasty bees from Dad (navidad).
languages.question: ¿Cuál es la celebración conocida como "la navidad"?

languages.mnemonic: Navidad is feminine, so it's la navidad. Imagine a lady who was obsessed with Christmas.
languages.question: ¿Qué es la navidad?

languages.mnemonic: The church was perched on the top of a glacier (iglesia).
languages.question: What does "la iglesia" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She was the star they all wanted to see at the cinema - but wasn't she thin, eh? (cine)
languages.question: What does "el cine" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: Among his circle of friends, his theory that the world was cooling rated low (círculo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "circle"?

languages.mnemonic: The city's design was themed around food and Dad (ciudad) loved it.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "city"?

languages.mnemonic: Ciudad is feminine, so it’s la ciudad. Imagine a city with a lady on top of every building.
languages.question: What does "la ciudad" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: She would claim first prize with her reckless ma (reclamar).
languages.question: What does "reclamar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The class groaned as their teacher told them they were having a test on the classic novel, Sense (clase) and Sensibility by Jane Austen.
languages.question: What does "la clase" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They had to clean the gallery from top to bottom after the lemur did a pee all over the artwork (limpiar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to clean"?

languages.mnemonic: Exposed to the clear blue skies in the desert, she desperately had to go (despejado) and find water.
languages.question: What does "despejado" mean in terms of weather?

languages.mnemonic: It was clear by the classy way she rode (claro) to victory that she was a great jockey.
languages.question: What does "claro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The climate in the valley was very rainy, so they had to clean Ma (clima) up when she arrived back home.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el clima"?

languages.mnemonic: Once we climb to the top of this mountain Superman will give us a cold beer (subir).
languages.question: What does the verb "subir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There were clocks everywhere on the railway's oldest locomotive (reloj).
languages.question: What is "el reloj" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Close the curtain so people can't see you with your therapist (cerrar).
languages.question: What does "cerrar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To clothe my large family I will have to sell my best steer (vestir) at market.
languages.question: What does the verb "vestir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Instead of clothes, she coiled a long rope (ropa) around herself.
languages.question: What does "la ropa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A huge cloud came over and there was a violent storm – then they saw that a new bay (nube) had formed where the shore had been washed away.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la nube"?

languages.mnemonic: In the cloudy water of the pond, his new toy boat sank (nubosa).
languages.question: What does "nuboso/nubosa" describe when referring to a liquid?

languages.mnemonic: He thought it was just cloudy weather but it was nuclear blast damage (nublada).
languages.question: What's the meaning of "nublado/nublada"?

languages.mnemonic: To live by the coast can cost a (costa) lot of money.
languages.question: What does "la costa" refer to in geography?

languages.mnemonic: You'll need a coat on a cold, breezy day like this, so go (abrigo) and find one.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "coat"?

languages.mnemonic: They were desperate for coffee, but unfortunately the cafe (café) had run out.
languages.question: What is "el café"?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine drinking coffee out of an elephant mug.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el café"?

languages.mnemonic: It was so cold her hand stuck to the car door handle - it took a lot of antifreeze to free her (fria).
languages.question: What does "frio" or "fria" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I need to collect some long hair to make a wig. Can you recommend a hair (recoger) salon locally?
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "recoger" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The colony in the arctic found it cold and lonely living near (colonia) the North Pole.
languages.question: What is the translation of "colonia" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The colour of the cup's floral (color) design was very bright.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el color" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine an elephant with very colourful make-up.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "colour" in its masculine form?

languages.mnemonic: On top of the column was a koala with a bloom of flowers. She shared them with my nan (columna).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "column"?

languages.mnemonic: This comb causes pain every (peine) time I use it.
languages.question: What is a "peine" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Peine is masculine, so it's el peine. Imagine an elephant using a comb.
languages.question: What is "el peine" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Come see the veneered (venir) woman!
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "venir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's not common to see a comet hit the moon (común).
languages.question: What does "común" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The company was run by the empress and (empresa) the emperor.
languages.question: What does "la empresa" refer to in a business context?

languages.mnemonic: Compare these two combat forces. I think the parrot army (comparar) has the edge.
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to compare"?

languages.mnemonic: These paintings really complement our home. I've had many compliments on the artwork (complementar).
languages.question: What does the verb "complementar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was a complete disaster – she complained it was on her toe (completo) but no one could hear her.
languages.question: What does "completo/completa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The expensive computer was bought by an ordained priest who adores (ordenador) all the latest technology.
languages.question: What does "el ordenador" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The car was in poor condition. The con decided the only (condición) way to sell the car was to lie.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "condition"?

languages.mnemonic: Condición is feminine, so it's la condición. Imagine a lady in peak physical condition.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "condición"?

languages.mnemonic: The driver was also a conductor – he waved his baton while driving the bus.
languages.question: What is another term for a driver in the context of transportation?

languages.mnemonic: I connect cola bottle caps to make necklaces, and it's starting (conectar) to catch on.
languages.question: What does "conectar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Consider a considerably large "R" (considerar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "consider"?

languages.mnemonic: She couldn't contain her joy when she found out that the contents of the box were aeroplanes (contener).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "contener" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: While in the continent of Asia, you can consume tea in linen table (continente) restaurants.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "continente" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: I'll continue to contain this teenager because there's a warrant (continuar) for her arrest.
languages.question: What does the verb "continuar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To control the flow of aircraft at airports, traffic controllers are (controlar) key.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "controlar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I hope I remain cool at the fresher's disco (fresco).
languages.question: What does "el fresco" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's easy to copy if you have a photocopier (copiar) machine.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "copiar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The corn on the cob had ma's false teeth (maíz) left on it.
languages.question: What is the English word for "maíz"?

languages.mnemonic: Turning a corner, the Eskimo spotted a hyena (esquina), so quickly aimed his harpoon.
languages.question: What does "esquina" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Give correct answers to all of the questions to win the jackpot. Each correct answer (correcta) is worth £1,000.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "correct"?

languages.mnemonic: The shopping trip cost me a fortune because my toe (costo) caught a glassware display and all the breakages had to be paid for!
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el costo"?

languages.mnemonic: My white cotton sheets were ruined; I shouldn't have allowed the goat and donkey (algodón) on my bed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for cotton?

languages.mnemonic: He agreed to count them all before considering how many stars (contar) there are.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "contar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Whenever we visit another country, Pa takes it easy (país).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for country?

languages.mnemonic: This course is making me curse so (curso) much. I hate it!
languages.question: What is "curso" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Curso is masculine, so it's el curso. Imagine an elephant enrolling for a dance course.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a course?

languages.mnemonic: To cover the hole in her jeans, she sewed a cube on her rear (cubrir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "cubrir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The cow tried to back the car (vaca) into the garage.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for cow?

languages.mnemonic: The Lord wanted to create a new family crest, so an artist (crear) was employed to design one.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "crear" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Cross to America on a cruise ship through the arctic (cruzar) circle.
languages.question: What does "cruzar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The crowd weren't booing; they were mooing. A multitude (multitud) of cows were in the audience.
languages.question: What does the term "multitud" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Multitud is feminine, so it's la multitud. Imagine a crowd of screaming ladies.
languages.question: What does "multitud" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She started to cry because the yoke was rather (llorar) hard - she liked her eggs runny so she could dip her bread.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "llorar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: After giving him a cup of tea, the Tasmanian devil thanked (taza) me.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "cup"?

languages.mnemonic: Taza is feminine, so it's al taza. Imagine a lady in a giant cup.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la taza"?

languages.mnemonic: The customer must clean as they enter then they can take (cliente) a seat.
languages.question: What does "cliente" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They cut it open and its core was full of tar (cortar)!
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish verb "cortar"?

languages.mnemonic: Dad made a living as one of the paparazzi (papá).
languages.question: What does "el papá" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Why are all my clothes damp?" – "Oops, I slept in the meadow" (húmedo).
languages.question: What does "húmedo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They dance so well they are tipped to win the contest by a large (bailar) margin.
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "dance"?

languages.mnemonic: Danger signs when the pelican grows (peligro) angry are the raising of her wings and the snapping of her beak.
languages.question: What does "el peligro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Peligro is masculine, so it's el peligro. Imagine an elephant in danger.
languages.question: What does "el peligro" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We painted them dark brown. The Oscars look cool all in a row (oscuro) painted dark brown instead of gold.
languages.question: What does "oscuro/oscura" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: My daughter eats handfulls (hija) of sweets.
languages.question: What does "la hija" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Day dawns, and here's your first cup of tea of the day, dear (día).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "day"?

languages.mnemonic: The dead man was wearing a toga (muerto).
languages.question: What does "muerto" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: My dear grandmother wants to keep reading, so don't (querido) disturb her.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "querido" in English?

languages.mnemonic: You'll have an early death if you move where bombs are te sted (muerte).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for death?

languages.mnemonic: At Christmas (December), the reindeer wear themed costumes and embrace (diciembre) the holiday spirit.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es el nombre en español del mes de diciembre?

languages.mnemonic: The hunter tried to decide if the deaths of three deer (decidir) were purely sport or a necessary evil.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "decidir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His knowledge is deep - although he professes to be a buffoon, don't (profuno) underestimate him.
languages.question: What does "profundo/profunda" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When it's forty degrees Celsius outside, my gran will doze (grado) in the shade.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es el significado de "el grado" en términos de unidad de medida?

languages.mnemonic: The dentist gave me new dentures; now each one of my teeth has been replaced with a star (dentista).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el/la dentista"?

languages.mnemonic: I depend on my deputy to make sure my enemies dare (depender) not attack me from behind.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "depender" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Can you describe what happened? Yes, I was eating my dessert when a man with a cream shirt and a black beard (describir) stole it.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "describir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: In the desert, I was desperate for water but all I could see was a pair of toads (desierto).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el desierto"?

languages.mnemonic: What a design! It's a decent-sized radio (diseño) too!
languages.question: What is the term "el diseño" used to describe?

languages.mnemonic: The dessert has gone - who could possibly have taken it off the tray (postre).
languages.question: What does "el postre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "It's difficult to determine the day they'll tear me open" said the banana (determinar).
languages.question: What does determinar mean?

languages.mnemonic: I checked in the dictionary for the correct word and declare my theory correct, that nasty man is a lothario (diccionario).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for dictionary?

languages.mnemonic: Diccionario is masculine, so it's el diccionario. Imagine an elephant looking up the word trunk in a dictionary.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el diccionario?

languages.mnemonic: The panda cubs will not die – as long as their mother rears (morir) them well!
languages.question: What does "morir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was difficult to defeat the seal (difícil) at volleyball.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for difficult?

languages.mnemonic: If we dig, we can go under the barbed (cavar) wire fence.
languages.question: What does the term "cavar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The direct attack by the dog left him with a deformed wreck of a toe (directo).
languages.question: What does "directo (m)/directa (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The restaurant's kitchen was so dirty that I'm suing the owner (sucio).
languages.question: What does "sucio" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: We need to discuss my destroyed scooter. You steered (discutir) directly into it!
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish verb "discutir"?

languages.mnemonic: She remained distant from one side of the family because of her distrust of her aunty (distante).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "distante"?

languages.mnemonic: We could divide the room into those who decided that the beer was too dear (dividir) and those who didn't.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "dividir" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Do you know an athlete with a lot of hair (hacer)?
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "hacer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The doctor thought the medicine was correct (médico), but the patient responded badly.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for doctor?

languages.mnemonic: The little dog tried to hide in the pear row (perro).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for dog?

languages.mnemonic: "The lad done well" was etched over (hecho) the top of the stone of the football star's grave.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "hecho"?

languages.mnemonic: The donkey said "Boo!" to the roman (burro).
languages.question: What is "el burro" (m)/"la burra" (f) in English?

languages.mnemonic: Outside the door there was a smell of poo in the air from the tank (puerta) of manure at the nearby farm.
languages.question: What does "la puerta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I wasn't seeing double, both of the dogs were carrying blades (doble).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "double"?

languages.mnemonic: My favourite thing to draw is a deer in boots playing a harmonica (dibujar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "dibujar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I used to dream that I had sewn a world made of yarn (soñar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to dream"?

languages.mnemonic: You must wear a smart dress because this is the best tea house in the world, so don't (vestido) wear shabby clothes.
languages.question: What does "vestido" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Vestido is masculine, so it's el vestido. Imagine an elephant wearing a dress.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "the dress"?

languages.mnemonic: I drink the best beer when my dad (bebida) isn't looking.
languages.question: What is the verb for "to drink" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I want to be able to drive a bus but I confess doing the theory (conducir) test fills me with dread.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "conducir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bus driver conducted a spooky tour (conductor).
languages.question: Who is referred to as "el conductor/la conductora"?

languages.mnemonic: Drop down, the goats are (gota) coming.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la gota"?

languages.mnemonic: You play the drum, and I'll play the tambourine (tambor).
languages.question: What is "el tambor" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It will be dry for the next few days, said the weather forecast: within seconds clouds came over (seco) and it rained.
languages.question: What does "seco" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You can't serve duck pâté; that's totally (pato) insensitive.
languages.question: What does "pato/pata" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: During work you can guarantee he will do a rant every day (durante).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "durante"?

languages.mnemonic: Each of the wizards said abracadabra (cada), and they each made a different animal appear.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "each"?

languages.mnemonic: It's a joy to my ear - that beautiful organ recital music makes me so happy (oreja).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "ear"?

languages.mnemonic: Ear is feminine, so it's la oreja. Imagine a beautiful lady, but with giant ears.
languages.question: What is "la oreja" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Early in her career, the teacher would lose her temper with the soprano (temprano) student.
languages.question: What does "temprano" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The Earth shed tears over the errors (tierra) humans were making.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es el significado de "la tierra"?

languages.mnemonic: What's best to ease a headache? I think the best ways to alleviate are (aliviar) aspirin or paracetamol.
languages.question: What does the verb "aliviar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If we trade with the East, I estimate (este) it's worth billions.
languages.question: What does "el este" refer to in terms of direction?

languages.mnemonic: Eating on this commercial airline (comer) was never going to be possible.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "comer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He drives us over the edge - we have to listen to the old bore all day (borde).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "edge"?

languages.mnemonic: Tom paused for dramatic effect. It was amazing how the special effects team had enlarged his toe (efecto).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el efecto"?

languages.mnemonic: She always cracked her egg on a whale bone (huevo) that she kept for that very purpose.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for egg?

languages.mnemonic: The hungry eight-legged spider opened the chocolate (ocho) bar.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for eight?

languages.mnemonic: His bid to get around the world in eighty days was in jeopardy – the border guards said his coach could not enter (ochenta).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for eighty?

languages.mnemonic: The electrics were turned on by the electrician and the tree cafe (eléctrica) lit up!
languages.question: What does "eléctrico/eléctrica" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The eleven-man team of footballers who lost the match still had to attend an online therapy (once) session
languages.question: What is the number of players typically on a football team at once?

languages.mnemonic: Is there anything else, before you have your massage (más), that I need to know?
languages.question: What does "más" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At the end of the safari tour, the visitors are charged a fee for every animal they've seen (fin).
languages.question: What does "el fin" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My enemy's enemy won't go (enemigo) away!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "enemy"?

languages.mnemonic: His energy has run out. To boost his energy he accepts (energía) a chocolate bar.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for energy?

languages.mnemonic: The engine on the boat will make too much noise - they will have to cross the moat using oars (motor).
languages.question: What is "el motor" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Motor is masculine, so it's el motor. Imagine an elephant repairing an engine.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el motor"?

languages.mnemonic: She liked the English so much, she put a giant Englishman, in glaze (inglés) outside her house.
languages.question: What does "inglés" or "inglesa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I can't get enough of the sun! I will bask until I tan, even if I stay (bastante) all day.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "bastante" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I always enter a room in an entertaining way rather (entrar) than just walking in.
languages.question: What does "entrar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The envelope looks scary, so be brave (sobre) and open it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el sobre"?

languages.mnemonic: Equal to the challenge was the iguana who was bilingual (igual).
languages.question: What does "igual" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Even Sherlock Holmes is asking if I've seen any clues, so (incluso) it must be a complex case.
languages.question: What is the Spanish translation for the word "even"?

languages.mnemonic: I don't remember the event because I spent the entire time bent over (evento) looking for my glasses.
languages.question: What does "el evento" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Every day, a deer with a trio (a diario) of birds on its antlers come into my garden to sing.
languages.question: What does "a diario" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Every cadaver (cada) has medical students around them.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "cada" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The exact weight of your eggs should match the exact amount (exacta) of your other ingredients for the perfect sponge cake.
languages.question: What does "exacto" (m)/"exacta" (f) mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They looked exactly the same, had the exact same clothes, and wouldn't let men take (exactamente) them on dates.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "exactamente"?

languages.mnemonic: Here is an example of a hemmed pillow (ejemplo) sewn very badly.
languages.question: What does "ejemplo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Except them! I'll make an exception because of their poorly toes (excepto).
languages.question: What is the Spanish equivalent of the word "except"?

languages.mnemonic: I don't want to excite you too much, but at the exit to the theatre is the star (excitar) of the show.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "excitar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The monks were a weird lot. They did exercise every day, every hair on the top of their head was removed and they had to study theological theory (ejercicio).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el ejercicio"?

languages.mnemonic: Ejercicio is masculine, so it's el ejercicio. Imagine an elephant doing so much exercise he's perspiring and out of breath.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el ejercicio?

languages.mnemonic: She ran for the exit whilst eating the salad, leaving her dad (salida) with the bill.
languages.question: What does "la salida" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The police didn't know what to expect as the escaped pair entered the arcade (esperar) brandishing their weapons.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "esperar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was a terrible experience. I was expected to re-enter the apartment (experiencia) that was on fire.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la experiencia"?

languages.mnemonic: Experiencia is feminine, so it's la experiencia. Imagine a lady enjoying a wonderful experience.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la experiencia"?

languages.mnemonic: He got a poke in the eye with an old hoe (ojo).
languages.question: What is "el ojo" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Despite being made from fabric, the television (tela) worked.
languages.question: What is la tela in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Tela is feminine, so it's la tela. Imagine a lady made of fabric.
languages.question: What is "la tela"?

languages.mnemonic: I decided to have my face painted on the side of my caravan (cara).
languages.question: What does "la cara" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine a factory entirely devoted to making fabric for a car (fábrica).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la fábrica"?

languages.mnemonic: This isn't fair! Whose tax (justa) bill am I paying? There's got to be a mistake!
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "justo/justa" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The fall caused the cat to drop through the air (caer) for a mile.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "caer" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The family didn't flinch when grandma took up pole-dancing: they were familiar (familia) with her ways.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for family?

languages.mnemonic: This famous family are oh-so-talented (famoso).
languages.question: What does "famoso (m)/famosa (f)" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It's not that far, let me carry you to the hospital (lejos).
languages.question: What does "lejos" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We don't go to the farm anymore, not since Gran lost her hat there (granja)!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "farm"?

languages.mnemonic: You'll become fat if you gorge on doughnuts (gordo).
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "gordo" mean in English?
