languages.mnemonic: She was surprised to find her father dressed as a padre – she hadn't known he was going to a fancy dress party.
languages.question: What does "padre" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They favour the fastest boat when rescuing their (favorecer) stranded friend.
languages.question: What does "favorecer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was their favourite holiday location and they went there every year, but they had to travel far for a burrito (favorito).
languages.question: What does "favorito" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I fear they won't let me enter the donut (miedo) shop.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el miedo"?

languages.mnemonic: Their water supply was fed by a brewery (February), so every St Valentine's Day they bathed in beer and ate Ferrero (febrero) Rocher chocolates.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for February?

languages.mnemonic: Go feed the alley men who are under the tarpaulins (alimentar).
languages.question: What does the verb "alimentar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I didn't feel very well, so I was sent here (sentir) to see the doctor.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "sentir"?

languages.mnemonic: A few men are brave enough to poke cobras (poco) with their fingers. Women think it's more sensible to use a stick as a poker (poca).
languages.question: What does "poco/poca" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The field was full so they had to camp over (campo) the road.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "campo"?

languages.mnemonic: Campo is masculine, so it's el campo. Imagine an elephant having a field all to itself.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "field"?

languages.mnemonic: The game was fifteen-love. He was keen that they (quince) win this match for the championship.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for fifteen?

languages.mnemonic: She had a fifty-fifty chance of survival with only a drop of water left in her polythene bottle to quench her thirst and her clothes were already in tatters.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for fifty?

languages.mnemonic: They had to fight to use the loo on the charter (luchar) flight.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "luchar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: To fill a vase with a generous array of sunflowers was the artist's objective (llenar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "llenar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Can you find the end of the contract (encontrar).
languages.question: What does "encontrar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I broke my finger giving a demo at a judo (dedo) club.
languages.question: What does "el dedo" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: They will never finish cleaning all the glass at the airport terminal because the windows are (terminar) endless.
languages.question: What does "terminar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The fire was halfway up her leg before she decided to go (fuego) and jump into the lake.
languages.question: What is "el fuego"?

languages.mnemonic: To be first, she had to pray she stayed on the mare (el primero).
languages.question: What does "el primero / la primera" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When he got over the finish line the pretty mare was such a (la primera) poser.
languages.question: What does "el primero / la primera" mean?

languages.mnemonic: One, two, three, four, five, once I caught a fish alive! He was ever so petite though (pez)!
languages.question: What does "la pez" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Pez is feminine, so it's la pez. Imagine a lady catching a fish with a rod.
languages.question: What does "la pez" mean?

languages.mnemonic: That fish was a pesky carp but I don't (pescado) care because I'm now going to eat it.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for fish as a food item?

languages.mnemonic: I love to fish but this pesky carp (pescar) keeps getting away from me!
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "pescar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: In the Indy 500 race, one of the drivers was cleaning the end of their toes (quinientos).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for five hundred?

languages.mnemonic: She high-fived him when he bought her a very thick coat because the thin coat (cinco) wasn't working.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "cinco" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The floor was covered in his suede loafers (suelo).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el suelo" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: They seemed to flow through the sky - strange creatures that flew using their ears (fuir) as wings.
languages.question: What does "fluir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The flower he tried to impress her with ended up on the floor (flor).
languages.question: What does "la flor" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Chasing a fly is a favourite hobby of most cats (mosca). Mosca is feminine, so it's la mosca. Imagine a lady swatting a huge fly.
languages.question: What is "la mosca" in English?

languages.mnemonic: You can fly with a bowler hat – but it has to be large (volar).
languages.question: What does "volar" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The flying boat landed on my table (volante).
languages.question: What does "volante" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The fog was so thick I nearly blacked (niebla) out when I hit my head on a wall.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for fog?

languages.mnemonic: Fold your clothes and don't blast (doblar) out your music.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "doblar" mean in English when used as a verb?

languages.mnemonic: If you want to follow me up the mountain, you'll need several more gears (seguir) on your bike.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the verb "seguir"?

languages.mnemonic: Food was thrown at the comedian (comida).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "comida" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The foot of my new PA (pie) was on my head – it wasn't the best start.
languages.question: What does "el pie" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What is this pull-cord for? To open your parachute (para) of course.
languages.question: What does "para" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The force of the flood took me somewhere that (fuerza) I'd never been.
languages.question: What does "la fuerza" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Fuerza is feminine, so it's la fuerza. Imagine a lady using a lot of force.
languages.question: What does "la fuerza" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The weather forecast was terrible. This prognosis meant we wore tea cosies (pronóstico) to stay warm.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el pronóstico"?

languages.mnemonic: She was on great form at the party until she spotted her former (forma) partner with his new girlfriend.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la forma"?

languages.mnemonic: It rained for forty days and nights. Quasimodo charged rent at (cuarenta) the top of Notre Dame Cathedral.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for forty?

languages.mnemonic: We moved forward in a daze after we landed, taking (adelante) our first steps on this alien world.
languages.question: What does "adelante" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It looked like a four-leaf clover had won the quad bike trophy (cuatro) race.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number four?

languages.mnemonic: On the fourteen of February the room was all prepared for Valentine's day until the cat tore their (catorce) bed sheets.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for fourteen?

languages.mnemonic: The fox helped Thor row (zorro) the boat.
languages.question: What does "el zorro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The free samples of Gran's teas (gratis) were going quickly.
languages.question: What does "gratis" mean?

languages.mnemonic: You're going to freeze in that t-shirt; we're expecting large (helar) amounts of snow and ice.
languages.question: What does "helar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The artist painted a fresh fruit fresco (fresco) on the wall.
languages.question: What does "fresco" mean in Italian?

languages.mnemonic: Friday is the day work finishes and we go straight down to the bar - beer's nice (viernes) there.
languages.question: What day of the week does "viernes" refer to in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: If your fridge is being raided, never stop a bear from getting a (nevera) meal!
languages.question: ¿Qué quiere decir "la nevera"?

languages.mnemonic: My friend and me go (amigo) everywhere together.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el amigo / la amiga"?

languages.mnemonic: I went with my friend to a restaurant but they gave me such a meagre (amiga) portion.
languages.question: What is the term for "friend" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The frog ran a (rana) marathon.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for frog?

languages.mnemonic: From the middle of the desert, she demanded (desde) a three-course meal.
languages.question: What does "desde" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Fruit? The only way to eat it is as a fruit tart (fruta).
languages.question: What does "la fruta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The room was full of yellow Post-It notes (lleno).
languages.question: What does "lleno" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was fun with the deer and the bear, drinking tea and eating doughnuts (divertido).
languages.question: What does "divertido" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Because this was the funeral director's wake, the food would be at the funeral (funeral) parlour.
languages.question: What is the term for a ceremony honoring a deceased person, often held in a funeral parlour?

languages.mnemonic: That's so funny. Gran's the only one who's soaked (gracioso).
languages.question: What does "gracioso" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the future all food must be served with two roses (futuro), said the Queen.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "future"?

languages.mnemonic: I want to watch the football game at the party, but they don't (partido) want to.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el partido" en el contexto de los deportes?

languages.mnemonic: The game of darts is the decider, whoever wins goes (juego) through to the final.
languages.question: What does "el juego" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My garage was guaranteed to be full of hay (garaje).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el garaje" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Her garden was full of hardy (jardin) annuals.
languages.question: What is the French word for garden?

languages.mnemonic: This dish needs garlic - a whole (ajo) bulb of it.
languages.question: What does "el ajo" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: As a general rule this hen lays several (general) eggs a week.
languages.question: What term means commanding officer or one of widespread application?

languages.mnemonic: A gentle breeze blew and the gentleman looked very suave in the bay (suave).
languages.question: What does the term "suave" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The crops are going to get wet, we need to get most of the harvest in to save (mojarse) it before it's ruined.
languages.question: What does "mojarse" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He gave the girl a kiss on the cheek and (chica) ran!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for girl?

languages.mnemonic: Give me a kiss, darling (dar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "dar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He was glad that she was still content despite him accidentally (contenta) flooding their house.
languages.question: What does "contento (m)/contenta (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I dropped my glass as I moved from the bar, so (vaso) I had to buy another drink.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el vaso" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Wear a glove when feeding this iguana, or it'll take (guante) your finger off.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el guante" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: "Go!" Immediately the ear (ir) was in front.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: A goat stole a cab, and the driver ran (cabra) after it.
languages.question: What is "la cabra" in English?

languages.mnemonic: God was so annoyed when he lost a race against the ostrich (dios), he put a curse on it, so it could no longer fly.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for God?

languages.mnemonic: Gold was used to make the ornaments that stood in a row (oro).
languages.question: What does "el oro" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bull enjoys playing golf (golf).
languages.question: ¿Qué deporte se refiere con el término "el golf"?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine an elephant playing golf.
languages.question: ¿Qué palabra se traduce como "golf" en español?

languages.mnemonic: They were enjoying the good life – but when oh when (bueno) would their hens start laying eggs?
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "good"?

languages.mnemonic: Before saying goodbye to the patient, the nurse agreed to add a dose (adiós) so that she would sleep better.
languages.question: What does "adiós" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The goose joined a gang so (ganso) it would get more respect.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for goose?

languages.mnemonic: The Government official was accused of being loudmouthed, but gobby, er no (gobierno) – he just had to deliver his advice.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for government?

languages.mnemonic: Now my grandfather has great abs, but he used to weigh loads (abuelo).
languages.question: What is "el abuelo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: My grandmother was absolutely wasted last (abuela) night!
languages.question: What does "la abuela" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: As he cut the grass, he erred badly (hierba) and cut off his toes with the mower.
languages.question: What does "la hierba" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My great gran (gran) just turned 100 but still enjoys skydiving.
languages.question: What does "gran" mean in terms of a very special family member?

languages.mnemonic: The green grass is nice and cool. I like to walk barefoot on a hot day (verde) to cool my feet down.
languages.question: What color does the term "verde" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: The grey on my overalls was grease (gris).
languages.question: What does "el gris/la gris" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The wedding group picture had to be taken quickly as storm clouds grew and posed (grupo) a real threat.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el grupo"?

languages.mnemonic: Grupo is masculine, so it's el grupo. Imagine some elephants forming a pop group.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "group"?

languages.mnemonic: Learning to grow plants at the creche is great therapy (crecer) for the little children.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term meaning "to grow"?

languages.mnemonic: They don't just guess where they are; in a deep-sea vehicle, they use the beep of sonar (adivinar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "adivinar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I had to guide the geese through the art (guiar) gallery.
languages.question: How do you say "guide" in Spanish using the verb form?

languages.mnemonic: Brandishing a gun, the pea stole a (pistola) car.
languages.question: What is "la pistola"?

languages.mnemonic: Hair was her area of expertise – even though the pay was low (Pelo).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el pelo" en español?

languages.mnemonic: Half a glass of water will help this medicine go (medio) down.
languages.question: What does "medio (m) / media (f)" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: They will shut you down in half an hour. This government can meddle with the news, media or a (media hora) popular website.
languages.question: What does "media hora" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Half man - half beast – meet goliath (mitad), the main attraction at the circus.
languages.question: What does "mitad" mean?

languages.mnemonic: He raised his hand to let his Ma know (mano) he could see her in the crowd.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "hand"?

languages.mnemonic: Mano is feminine, so it's la mano. Imagine a lady with lots of hands.
languages.question: What does "mano" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Should a big fish happen to pass a sardine (pasar), it might swallow it whole.
languages.question: What does the verb "pasar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She was happy to be out of the dentist's chair - her mouth felt numb but her teeth (feliz) were shiny and white.
languages.question: What does "feliz" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bread was hard, there was nothing she could do but throw (duro) it away.
languages.question: What does "duro" (m) or "dura" (f) mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: He owned many types of hats, including a sombrero (sombrero)
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for hat?

languages.mnemonic: I have ten aeroplanes (tener).
languages.question: What does the verb "tener" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He was startled when he woke up and saw that he'd grown an elephant (él) trunk.
languages.question: What does the Spanish pronoun "él" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: On her head was a car with a sunbather (cabeza) on the roof.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for head?

languages.mnemonic: She put her fantastic health and fitness down to the fact that salad was the only food (salud) she ate.
languages.question: What does "salud" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His heart stopped in the cold of the Arctic marathon (corazón).
languages.question: What does "corazón" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Providing heat with just a candle was against the law (calor) she thought.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el calor"?

languages.mnemonic: On our picnic, we get caught in a heavy shower just as we were about to chew on our bass coated (chubasco) in breadcrumbs.
languages.question: What is an el chubasco?

languages.mnemonic: There were heavy odds against victory - a pessimist sighting the armada (pesada) might have been more concerned.
languages.question: What does "pesado/pesada" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If you aren't the correct height, you won't be allowed to rap (altura).
languages.question: What does the term "altura" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: Hola rhymes with cola. Imagine saying hello to someone and pouring them a cola (hola) drink as a way of welcoming them.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for hello?

languages.mnemonic: The soldiers only wore helmets when attacking the castle, as cola (casco) cans were being thrown at them from the castle walls.
languages.question: What is the term "el casco" used to refer to in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Help! Are you any good at darts (ayudar)?
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ayudar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: "Here! Come here!" he shouted, and the dog came bounding back with a key (aquí) – it was a giant one!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "here"?

languages.mnemonic: In the male voice choir, the high notes are sung by alto (alto) singers.
languages.question: What does "alto" mean in musical terms?

languages.mnemonic: After running up and down the hill several times a day, the koalas were much leaner (colina).
languages.question: What is a colina?

languages.mnemonic: They had his and her suits (su).
languages.question: What does "su" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: History is easy – you could start with Queen Victoria (historia).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la historia"?

languages.mnemonic: Historia is feminine, so it's la historia. Imagine a lady that's gone back in history.
languages.question: What does "la historia" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She hit the golf ball so hard it broke a pane in the art (golpear) gallery a quarter of a mile away.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "golpear" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They had hold of the man as he rescued the mountaineer (mantener).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "mantener" mean?

languages.mnemonic: My home has an ogre guarding (hogar) the entrance.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el hogar"?

languages.mnemonic: To meet this bull was an honour (honor).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el honor"?

languages.mnemonic: The horse took a cab to buy some oats (caballo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for horse?

languages.definition: a health facility where patients receive treatment
languages.mnemonic: The injured bull was taken to hospital.
languages.question: What is a hospital?

languages.mnemonic: In the hotel, a bull was checking in!
languages.question: ¿Cómo se dice "hotel" en español?

languages.mnemonic: She spent a magical hour in the palace, captivated by its aura (hora).
languages.question: What does "la hora" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: On my house, you can see I'm a massive fan of 'Casa'blanca (casa) because there is a mural of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman on the side. Casa is feminine, so it's la casa. Imagine a lady shaped house.
languages.question: What does "la casa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She just wanted to know how - she hadn't intended to cause a commotion (cómo)
languages.question: What does "¿cómo?" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: It's huge! The enormous cake I made (enorme) is bigger than a house!
languages.question: What does "enorme" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: All the humans turned as the woman walked by. "That woman is oh (humano) so beautiful."
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "humano" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Celebrating one hundred years, the century-old theatre's entrance (cien) was decorated with flowers and balloons.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "hundred"?

languages.mnemonic: The hunt for a job wasn't going well, so the busker kept dancing (búsqueda) and singing to earn a few pennies.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "búsqueda"?

languages.mnemonic: "Could you hurry up with the ceremony?" "No," said the priest, who wanted to finish his sax (prisa) solo.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for hurry?

languages.mnemonic: My husband exposes so (esposo) much of his bum when he works.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el esposo"?

languages.mnemonic: I like yo-yos (yo).
languages.question: What does "yo" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Give an ice cream to the excellent lad over (helado) there.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el helado"?

languages.mnemonic: Helado is masculine, so it's el helado. Imagine an elephant made of ice cream.
languages.question: What is "el helado"?

languages.mnemonic: The ice on the pond has turned yellow (hielo) - I wonder why?
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el hielo"?

languages.mnemonic: His idea was to redate a (idea) batch of food that had passed it's use-by date.
languages.question: What is another word for a concept or thought, often referred to as an "idea"?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine a lady announcing a great idea to a boardroom of boring men.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "idea," specifically the feminine form?

languages.mnemonic: If I was taller, I might be able to see (si) the football match.
languages.question: What does "si" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His father was suffering from a serious illness. He said: 'It's unfair me dad (enfermedad) has to suffer like this'.
languages.question: What does the term "enfermedad" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Enfermedad is feminine, so it's la enfermedad. Imagine a lady who comes up with a cure for a serious illness:
languages.question: What does the term "enfermedad" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine each man here snarling (imaginar) at one another.
languages.question: What does "imaginar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's important that we import ants able (importante) to build houses.
languages.question: What does "importante" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the envelope there was a large sum of cash!
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "en" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: He lost an inch off this finger - that's what can happen if you pull the guard off a (pulgada) power tool.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for inch?

languages.mnemonic: Include this person, said the quest master in the computer game because I've seen a clue in his ear (incluir) that will help you in your quest.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "incluir"?

languages.mnemonic: There was an increase in the number of our men who were tarred and feathered for not bowing to the king.
languages.question: What does "aumentar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To indicate her dislike of him, she wrote an indecent message on his car (indicar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "indicar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A serious injury resulted when a reader (herida) at the library removed a large book from the shelf.
languages.question: What does "la herida" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Herida is feminine, so it's la herida. Imagine a lady causing injury.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la herida"?

languages.mnemonic: The toad taunted the insects, singing "eeny, meeny, miny, moe, catch an insect by its toe" (insecto).
languages.question: What is "insecto" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The instant that teenager stands on the wobbly table (instante), it'll fall over.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "instante"?

languages.mnemonic: Instante is masculine, so it's el instante. Imagine an elephant becoming an instant success.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "instante"?

languages.mnemonic: I was trying to hold my instrument up when the instrument fell over (intrumento).
languages.question: What does "el instrumento" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They couldn't help but show an interest in her because the teen looked like an extra-terrestrial (interés).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el interés"?

languages.mnemonic: Interés is masculine, so it's el interés. Imagine an elephant that has an interest in extra-terrestrials.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el interés"?

languages.mnemonic: The young man invents pointless products; the teenager is currently working on a bendy guitar.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "inventar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Iron Man was outside cooking a barbecue on a large griddle. Lots of meat was being cooked because he planned to have a big charity (plancha) event.
languages.question: What does "la plancha" refer to in cooking?

languages.mnemonic: I bought myself a new iron, my old one still works so I plan to donate it to a cha(rity) (plancha) shop.
languages.question: What does "la plancha" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Is it me you're looking for?" he asked. She decided to make a quick es-cape (es).
languages.question: What is the English equivalent of the Spanish word "es"?

languages.mnemonic: The island was very small, so it would not be easy to land (isla) the plane. Isla is feminine, so it's la isla. Imagine a lady stranded alone on a desert island.
languages.question: What is "la isla"?

languages.mnemonic: The janitor (January) had a huge clear up operation when an aero plane (enero) crashed into the grounds of the building he looked after.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for January?

languages.mnemonic: For my job I travel a lot, but the best journey is when I travel back home (trabajo).
languages.question: What does "el trabajo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When you join our holiday club, you get a souvenir (unir) from every destination we go to.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "unir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The joy of her night turned to drunkenness - she later alleged the sangria (alegría) had been spiked.
languages.question: What does "alegría" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The orange juice threw the sumo (zumo) wrestler over its head.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for juice?

languages.mnemonic: He's due a lie down (July) – but whose leotard (julio) is that?
languages.question: What month is referred to as "julio" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I can now jump since I've been on salads and stopped eating jam tarts (saltar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "saltar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The dune (June) was big, but who could know (junio) it would take a day to travel over it?
languages.question: ¿Cuál es el significado de "junio" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: In the jungle, orangutans sell baguettes (selva).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la selva"?

languages.mnemonic: "Just one question, who's toe (justo) is in my drink?"
languages.question: What is another word for fair or equitable that sounds like "just"?

languages.mnemonic: He was trying to keep his luscious locks but now the man has only got ten hairs left (mantener).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to keep"?

languages.mnemonic: I need the key to lock the door to the back yard, a bear's (llave) got in there!
languages.question: What is "la llave"?

languages.mnemonic: The kill at bullfights has ceased in many areas but the matador's artistic (matar) display is still the main feature.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "matar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The bull lost ten kilos (kilo) on the diet.
languages.question: What does the term "kilo" refer to in measurement context?

languages.mnemonic: King Henry VIII had six wives and reigned (rey) over England for 36 years.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el rey"?

languages.mnemonic: The kitten loves gateaux, and can eat a (gatita) whole one.
languages.question: What does "el gatito / la gatita" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I injured my knee while rodeo riding a yak (rodilla).
languages.question: ¿Qué es la rodilla?

languages.mnemonic: He bought a knife with a coupon. It was cheap, and Yoda (cuchillo) didn't like it.
languages.question: What is "el cuchillo"?

languages.mnemonic: I know where the sad bear (saber) is. Let's cheer her up.
languages.question: What does the verb "saber" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I know the con who owned up to his therapist (conocer) about his crimes.
languages.question: What does "conocer" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: A lady is causing a scene in reception. I've sent your assistant (señora) to escort her out of the building.
languages.question: What does "la señora" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The lake was guarded by a large golden (lago) eagle.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for lake?

languages.mnemonic: While holding a lamp, the lamb parachuted (lámpara) down.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for lamp?

languages.mnemonic: In this strange land, teapots fly through the air with raccoon (tierra) pilots.
languages.question: What does "la tierra" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Our language is full of idioms: my Ma (idioma) always says things like "Break a leg" and "Under the weather".
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for language?

languages.mnemonic: Idioma is masculine, so it's el idioma. Imagine an elephant teaching a language.
languages.question: What is the term for a language in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Last night, they had to over-tip the taxi driver with a note because they had no change (anoche).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "anoche"?

languages.mnemonic: "This is the last time!" she gave him an ultimatum (última) over his heavy drinking: give it up or leave.
languages.question: What does "último/última" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I was late so they tarred me and left me all day (tarde) tied to the lamp post.
languages.question: What does "tarde" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The horse had a laugh every time I had to resaddle (risa).
languages.question: What does "la risa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She was a law student, but she didn't learn much because she lay (ley) in bed most of the day.
languages.question: What does "ley" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The lawn's great, just watch for the cesspit ahead (césped).
languages.question: What is "césped" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The lawyer had a boa that guarded a (abogada) door.
languages.question: What is the term for "lawyer" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I want to lay that colourful carpet (colocar) on my stairs.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "colocar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The bull was a natural leader (líder).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "líder"?

languages.mnemonic: To learn the trade, you start as an apprentice but don't you dare (aprender) cut corners.
languages.question: What does "aprender" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Her least favourite job at the barbers was trimming men's nostril (menos) hair.
languages.question: What does "menos" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Leave, immediately! You've put the salad in your ear (salir)."
languages.question: What does the verb "salir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My leg was sunburnt after sitting on the pier having a nap (pierna)
languages.question: What does "la pierna" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The lemon was leaping over the monster (limón).
languages.question: ¿Qué fruta se refiere el término "el limón"?

languages.mnemonic: Limón is masculine, so it's el limón. Imagine an elephant finding a lemon too sour.
languages.question: What is "el limón"?

languages.mnemonic: The entire length of the ship was filled with very large cargo (largo).
languages.question: What does "el largo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She wanted less hassle so took an easier job. Her main loss (menos) was financial, but she felt she gained in other ways.
languages.question: What does "menos" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The only reason she lets him play is that she's practically deaf and can't hear his awful harp (dejar) playing!
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "dejar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: He thought he had received a love letter but really it was the car tax (carta).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la carta" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: I experienced a high level of pain after being kneed in the belly (nivel).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el nivel" en español?

languages.mnemonic: The reference library had a whole section on bible texts (biblioteca) because it was run by the church.
languages.question: What is the term for "library" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: She is going to lie and say she saw the men in tears (mentir) when she declined to go out with them but the truth is she'd never been asked out.
languages.question: What does the verb "mentir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Life is just as precious for animals as it is for us, says my vegan dad (vida) and he let all his animals go free.
languages.question: What does "la vida" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Vida is feminine, so it's la vida. Imagine a lady being sentenced to life by a judge.
languages.question: What does "la vida" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: He tried to lift my presents into the trees, so let's ban Tarzan (levantar) from the party.
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to lift"?

languages.mnemonic: We need more light to get that loose tooth (luz) out.
languages.question: What does "la luz" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Lightning struck me under the red street lamp; I was in agony (relámpago).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for lightning?

languages.mnemonic: Relámpago is masculine, so it's el relámpago. Imagine an elephant shooting lightning from its trunk.
languages.question: What is "el relámpago"?

languages.mnemonic: This incredibly low speed limit leaves me taking (límite) hours to get to work.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el límite"?

languages.mnemonic: On the washing line hangs lots of linen ears (línea).
languages.question: What is "la línea" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Línea is feminine, so it's la linea. Imagine a line of ladies walking a slack-line.
languages.question: What does "la línea" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If lions lay on (león) you, remain perfectly still.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el león" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: The liquid was coming through the leaky door (liquido).
languages.question: What is "liquido" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The billionaires made a list of places with the least tax (lista), so they could decide where to move.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "lista"?

languages.mnemonic: Lista is feminine, so it's la lista. Imagine a list of famous ladies.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for list?

languages.mnemonic: We listened on the estate to the cuckoo's charming (escuchar) call.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "escuchar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The little boy learnt not to poke the ogre (poco).
languages.question: What does "poco" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Since he went to live in the pub, the bee's favourite drink was beer (vivir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "vivir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The living room was turned into a hairdressing salon (salón).
languages.question: What does "salón" refer to in a house?

languages.mnemonic: We have to locate them before we can lower the cargo and leave the army (localizar) with the tanks they need.
languages.question: What does the verb "localizar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The lone wolf was a solitary figure moving over (solitario) the scrubland.
languages.question: What does "solitario" or "solitaria" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This was the longest lager (larga) she'd ever attempted to drink.
languages.question: What does "largo/larga" mean when referring to length?

languages.mnemonic: "Look for the booster seat for the car! Can you see it anywhere?"
languages.question: What does the verb "buscar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They weren't lost, the pair of deer were looking for a doe (perdido).
languages.question: What does "perdido/perdida" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There is one loud voice in our choir, the alto (alto) in the back row drowns everyone else out.
languages.question: What does "alto/alta" mean in terms of volume level?

languages.mnemonic: I love you in your armour more (amor).
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "amor" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The bridge was too low so he couldn't get back home (bajo).
languages.question: What does "bajo" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: My loyal dog stays up late and sounds the alarm (leal) if he hears anything.
languages.question: What does "leal" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It may seem like pure luck, but I swear it takes (suerte) skill.
languages.question: What does "la suerte" mean?

languages.mnemonic: After sorting all this mail, I think the company really owes (correo) me a raise.
languages.question: What does "el correo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The main reason the prince thinks his pal (principal) betrayed him is that he found him in bed with his wife.
languages.question: What does "principal" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The man ate his meal as normal – even though they had served his omelette in a beret (hombre).
languages.question: What does "el hombre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We manufacture fabric cars (fabrica).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "fabricar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The map confused my Ma and Pa (mapa) - we were well and truly lost.
languages.question: What is "el mapa" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It wasn't a normal map. This map actually (mapa) led to buried treasure!
languages.question: What is "el mapa" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Mapa is masculine, so it's el mapa. Imagine an elephant reading a map on a walk.
languages.question: ¿Qué es "el mapa"?

languages.mnemonic: The elephants were on the march (March) but they stopped when they saw ma throw (marzo) some food for them.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es el mes que se traduce como "el marzo" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: At the market for cars, he bought a car but he had to say: "Me car don't go!" (mercado).
languages.question: What does "mercado" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There was too much mass. The fat man sank (masa) the boat. Masa is feminine, so it's la masa. Imagine a lady measuring her mass.
languages.question: What is "la masa" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: As she's a master of the written word, ma's essay won the trophy (maestro).
languages.question: What is the meaning of maestro (m)/maestra (f) in English?

languages.mnemonic: Different materials had been used to make different Spanish bulls.
languages.question: What is meant by the term "material"?

languages.mnemonic: It didn't matter to her that she wasn't famous - it wasn't important to be a star (importar).
languages.question: What does "importar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I danced around the maypole (May) with my yo-yo (mayo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for May?

languages.mnemonic: Me? I'd like to be the mayor (me).
languages.question: Who does "me" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: I didn't mean to cause significant damage to your car (significar). It was an accident.
languages.question: What does "significar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They measure everything in your medical, even the length of your ears (medir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "medir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Meat is the main diet of carnivores (carne) like wolves and mountain lions.
languages.question: What is "la carne" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was a haunting melody that she mellowed to and held dear (melodía) for the rest of her singing career.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "melodía"?

languages.mnemonic: We waited for a menu for so long, we thought the waiter had gone by car or taxi (carta) to fetch it.
languages.question: What is "la carta" in a restaurant?

languages.mnemonic: Carta is feminine, so it's la carta. Imagine a lady holding a menu the wrong way up and saying she can't understand it.
languages.question: What is "la carta" in a restaurant?

languages.mnemonic: The bull was made of metal.

languages.mnemonic: Metal is masculine, so it's el metal. Imagine an elephant made of metal.
languages.question: ¿Qué palabra en español se usa para "metal"?

languages.mnemonic: The method to stop toes being damaged on building sites is to use metal toecaps which don't (método) allow them to be crushed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "method"?

languages.mnemonic: Método is masculine, so it's el método. Imagine an elephant using the same method as humans to protect its feet, i.e. metal toecaps that don't crush.
languages.question: What does "el método" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At midday, because it was so hot, the men took a swim in the deep ocean; it was a bad idea (mediodia).
languages.question: What does "mediodia" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My middle child is the only one that doesn't want to be a medic out of the trio (medio).
languages.question: What does "medio / media" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At midnight, you must check his pills. Last night, the meds he had were not checked (medianoche) and he turned into a werewolf.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la medianoche?

languages.mnemonic: It was mild weather but the temperature was dropping as a large tornado (templado) approached.
languages.question: What does "templado" mean in terms of weather?

languages.mnemonic: It's a "Trust the customer Milk Bar" – you take your drink then lay some change (leche) on the bar.
languages.question: What is "la leche" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Take the word million and mill the word out except the two L's leaving mi ion (millón).

languages.mnemonic: I was a million miles from anywhere – just me on (millón) a mountain.

languages.mnemonic: If he's even a minute late meeting me at noon I'll stamp on his toe (minuto).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "minute"?

languages.mnemonic: This mirror was espe cially large in this ho me (espejo).

languages.mnemonic: Espejo is masculine, so it's el espejo. Imagine an elephant looking at itself in a mirror.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for mirror?

languages.mnemonic: Miss! Can you please send your heater (señorita) to me?
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "Miss"?

languages.mnemonic: Don't mix any meths with claret (mezclar), it's dangerous.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "mezclar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They talk on their mobile phones. Most bees and eels (móvil) have them.

languages.mnemonic: Móvil is masculine, so it's el móvil. Imagine an elephant with a mobile phone.

languages.mnemonic: He wanted a modern car as his old motor was now derelict and no (moderno) longer ran.
languages.question: What does "moderno/moderna" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: One moment it was sunny, the next moment the skies opened (momento) and down came the rain.

languages.mnemonic: On Monday mornings, this is how we all turn up for work, dressed as 'loonies' (lunes).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for Monday?

languages.mnemonic: With all your money, dear Nero (dinero) please stop playing the violin and help rebuild the city.

languages.mnemonic: Dinero is masculine, so it's el dinero. Imagine an elephant printing his own money.
languages.question: What is the word for money in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The monkey on the moped has no (mono) license.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for monkey?

languages.mnemonic: They got the months in a complete mess (mes) on the calendar.
languages.question: What does "el mes" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He swore the moon was talking to him - his friends thought he was a lunatic (luna).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for moon?

languages.mnemonic: More devout you couldn't get – she went to mass (más) three times every Sunday.
languages.question: What does "más" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the morning I get up for the special day when all long-haired men have to donate for man yarn (mañana) day.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for morning?

languages.mnemonic: The mother was angry with the mad ray (madre) for attacking her daughter.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for mother?

languages.mnemonic: If you go on the mountain make sure you monitor the tan on ya (montaña).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for mountain?

languages.mnemonic: Montaña is feminine, so it's la montaña. Imagine a lady on the summit of a mountain.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "mountain"?

languages.mnemonic: He was wearing a fake moustache, so the bee told the goat to take (bigote) it off.
languages.question: What is "el bigote"?

languages.mnemonic: With her mouth wide open, she showed her surprise at receiving a bouquet and card (boca) for Valentine's Day.
languages.question: What is "la boca" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I moved to a town where everyone had mauve hair (mover).

languages.mnemonic: I made quick movements and avoided most of the bees, but a mean one stung the end of my toe (movimiento).
languages.question: What is the meaning of "el movimiento"?

languages.mnemonic: Movimiento is masculine, so it's el movimiento. Imagine an elephant's movements being tracked by motion capture.
languages.question: What is the term "el movimiento" used to describe?

languages.mnemonic: The movie is about a pelican who's cooler (película) than anyone else.

languages.mnemonic: Película is feminine, so it's la película. Imagine a movie starring ladies.

languages.mnemonic: How much did you make the cow moo? Are you sure you chose (mucho) the right prodding stick?
languages.question: What does "mucho (m)/mucha (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If you multiply 10 by 2, that's how many cars he's got. The multi-millionaire looks very pleased with his new sports car (multiplicar).

languages.mnemonic: It was listening to music, so the moose didn't see the car (música) coming.
