languages.mnemonic: Música is feminine, so it's la música. Imagine seeing ladies in musical notation.
languages.question: What is "la música" in English?

languages.mnemonic: You must defend the bears (deber) from Goldilocks.
languages.question: What does "deber" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My favourite portrait is this one of me (mi)!
languages.question: What does "mi" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The name of my nomination for bravest (nombre) person in the world is...
languages.question: What does "nombre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Nombre is masculine, so it's el nombre. Imagine an ele-phant writing its name.
languages.question: What is "nombre" in English?

languages.mnemonic: In a nation full of ancient buildings, Rome's national treasure, the Panthoen (nación), is a legacy of a powerful empire.
languages.question: What does "la nación" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Nearby was a very thirsty cat (cerca).
languages.question: What does "cerca" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Is it necessary to sit next to the punks? It's my worst case scenario (necessario).
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Italian word "necessario"?

languages.mnemonic: I have neck pain after seeing a questionable yoga (cuello) instructor.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el cuello"?

languages.mnemonic: Cuello is masculine, so it's el cuello. Imagine an elephant with a really long neck.
languages.question: ¿Qué parte del cuerpo se llama "el cuello"?

languages.mnemonic: You need to go to the Netherlands to see this strange tarantula (necesitar).
languages.question: What does the verb "necesitar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Using a needle and thread, a goose has (aguja) patched up my clothing.
languages.question: What is "la aguja" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Aguja is feminine, so it's la aguja. Imagine a lady who is terrified of needles.
languages.question: What is "la aguja" in English?

languages.mnemonic: My neighbours are the best thieves. I know (vecino) everything in their house is stolen.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "neighbour"?

languages.mnemonic: In her nest, the bird kneads dough (nido).
languages.question: What does "el nido" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In my net, I caught a red (red) fish.
languages.question: What does "la red" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You'll never see him before noon, he's a night cat (nunca).
languages.question: What is the translation of "nunca" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It wasn't really new, even though they described their sound as new wave (nuevo).
languages.question: What does "nuevo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The front page news said "NO TEETH!" He has (noticias) had them all removed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for news?

languages.mnemonic: He used newspapers to make a house in the woods during his period as an eco (periódico) warrior.
languages.question: What is "el periódico" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Next year we need approximately (Próxima) twice our sales to stop us going bust!
languages.question: What is the meaning of "próximo/próxima" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Night came, but there was no change (noche) in the temperature – it was still so hot.
languages.question: What is "la noche" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Noche is feminine, so it's la noche. Imagine the shape of a lady in the sky at night.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for night?

languages.mnemonic: The cat with nine lives trembled as she carefully crossed the nuclear weapon base (nueve).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number nine?

languages.mnemonic: To go through ninety degrees you go from no bent arm (noventa) to a bent arm.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for ninety?

languages.mnemonic: It was definitely a "No" from the bull.
languages.question: What is the opposite of "yes"?

languages.mnemonic: Making a loud noise is rude when we are dozing (ruido).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for noise?

languages.mnemonic: At noon she takes her medicine and spills it – it's all over you, dear! (mediodía)
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for noon?

languages.mnemonic: My nephew doesn't like me, nor does my niece (ni).
languages.question: How is "ni" used in a sentence to connect negative alternatives?

languages.mnemonic: To get to our home in the North we normally take (note) the scenic route.
languages.question: What is "el norte" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The nose of the narwhal is not the sword-like spike – that is one of its teeth (nariz).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la nariz"?

languages.mnemonic: The note on the packet said there was no tar (nota) in the cigarettes, but her cough was as bad as ever.
languages.question: What does "la nota" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Nothing could stop my nan from dancing (nada).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "nada" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Notice how the gravel on the road flies everywhere because there is no tar (notar) laid on the road yet.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "notar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The supernova was one to remember (November). No beam of light, ember or ray could be brighter (noviembre).
languages.question: ¿Qué mes es conocido como "noviembre"?

languages.mnemonic: Now is not the time to show people you have a massive aura (ahora).
languages.question: What does "ahora" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There were a number of bowls of noodles the mayor ate in a row (número). It was a massive amount.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "number"?

languages.mnemonic: We couldn't make out what the object was until we got closer, then it was obvious: a hen attacking a toad (objeto).
languages.question: What is "el objeto" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Objeto is masculine, so it's el objeto. Imagine an elephant holding a strange object in its trunk.
languages.question: What does "el objeto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He didn't observe the rules so, even though he objected, they wouldn't serve him and he was barred (observar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "observar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Fox attacks will occur. They will climb over the chicken coop's rear (occurir) fence.
languages.question: What does "ocurrir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the middle of the ocean they found a raft with a bunch of old thespians singing along to a piano (océano).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "océano"?

languages.mnemonic: The octopus (October) could get through the octagonal tube to see her friend the ray (octubre).
languages.question: What does "el octubre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: An octopus is in my pool posing (pulpo).
languages.question: What is "el pulpo"?

languages.mnemonic: Of all the things he was afraid of, going to the dentist (de) was by far the worst.
languages.question: What does "de" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Your offer is far too low. It's only fair that you tack (oferta) on a few more zeros.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la oferta"?

languages.mnemonic: It's not a regular office, it's got free coffee, theatre and nachos (oficina).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la oficina"?

languages.mnemonic: You'll often find that Americans love new types of doughnuts (a menudo).
languages.question: What does "a menudo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The oil made the athlete slip. I say take (aceite) more care and go around it.
languages.question: What is aceite?

languages.mnemonic: Aceite is masculine, so it's el aceite. Imagine an elephant slipping on oil while trying to hold on to everything around him.
languages.question: What is "aceite" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The old vehicle had a hole (viejo) in it.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "old"?

languages.mnemonic: He would start on time, but after the teenage musician's tempo (a tiempo) sped up, the conductor couldn't control him.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "a tiempo"?

languages.mnemonic: Once upon a time, who's napping in a manger in Bethlehem (una vez)?
languages.question: What does "una vez" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She has won (one) every game of uno (uno) she has ever played.
languages.question: What does "uno" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: It was the only wound of its kind the doctor had ever seen: blood oozed from his knee which had swollen into a big cone (único).
languages.question: What does "único/única" mean in English as an adjective?

languages.mnemonic: The aeroplane flew only inches above their heads - it was so low (sólo) they felt they could have reached up and touched it.
languages.question: What does the adverb "sólo" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You could open up a war if you confirm your partner has a big rear (abrir).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "open"?

languages.mnemonic: To operate the curtains at the opera, you need strong arms (operar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "operar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I starred opposite an opera singer in the West End; it was a total (opuesto) dream come true.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "opuesto"?

languages.mnemonic: Would you like an apple or an orange? (o).
languages.question: What does the letter "o" represent in logical expressions?

languages.mnemonic: The orange tiger started an attack and they ran harder (anaranjada) than they ever had before.
languages.question: What color is described by the Spanish term "anaranjado/anaranjada"?

languages.mnemonic: She was eating an orange when her nan rang her (naranja) so she was unable to speak for a moment.
languages.question: What is "la naranja"?

languages.definition: to give an order, to order, to sort, to command
languages.mnemonic: My order, ordinarily (ordenar), is fish and chips, but today I'll just forget it.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ordenar" mean?

languages.definition: Order as in: to place an order, to ask, ask for, request.
languages.mnemonic: He decided to order a surprise present for his wife, a new pet, a reindeer (pedir)! What will she say.
languages.question: What does "pedir" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You need to organise an organic diet to stop feeling so lethargic (organizar).
languages.question: What does "organizar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was an original idea; the only real issue he had was that it would be criminal (original).
languages.question: What word describes something that is the first or unique of its kind?

languages.mnemonic: The others looked on in envy as the clever otters rowed (otro (m)) down stream in their canoe. The other otters ran (otra (f)) alongside.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "other"?

languages.mnemonic: Here is our newest troll (nuestro), Mike.
languages.question: What does "nuestro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I'm going out like this because I'm not afraid of wearing a (afuera) leotard in public.
languages.question: What does "fuera/afuera" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I need to get this oven working, or no (horno) one will eat.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el horno" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Horno is masculine so it's el horno. Imagine an elephant taking a roast out of the oven.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el horno?

languages.mnemonic: I owe you a debt of gratitude. You were the only one that dared to stop the bear (deber).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the verb "deber"?

languages.mnemonic: I gave the owl some new boots, and she was overjoyed (búho).
languages.question: What is "búho" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Even in your own apartment, it's inappropriate to pee over (propio) the side of the balcony.
languages.question: What does the adjective "propio" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The owner of the dwelling got pneumonia (dueña) because it was a cold and damp place.
languages.question: What does "el dueño" (m)/"la dueña" (f) mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Using oxygen tanks, the ox goes deep-sea diving with a hare that knows (oxigeno) the way.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es la traducción de "el oxígeno" al inglés?

languages.mnemonic: The pages were being ripped out of the book by pa's hyena (página).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "página"?

languages.mnemonic: He said he could relieve her pain but it would cost her a dollar (dolor)
languages.question: What does "el dolor" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They would paint the target then pin the target (pintar) to their friend's back without him knowing.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "pintar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The pair of golfers played a great round. They both finished 3 under par (par)
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el par"?

languages.mnemonic: A paper boat needs a paddle to propel (papel) it through the water.
languages.question: What is "el papel" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The park had been covered in parquet (parque) flooring.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el parque"?

languages.mnemonic: Her favourite part was playing the part of an ape (parte).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "parte"?

languages.mnemonic: The farmer wanted that particular (particular) bull.
languages.question: What does 'particular' mean?

languages.mnemonic: The party is expensive to get into. The fee is estimated to be a (fiesta) weeks salary for me.
languages.question: What does "la fiesta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Fiesta is feminine, so it's la fiesta. Imagine a ladies-only party that gets out of hand.
languages.question: What is "la fiesta"?

languages.mnemonic: Can you pass these to the panda. He loves sardines (pasar) for lunch.
languages.question: What does the verb "pasar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He ran out of space to have his passport stamped as they passed through a port a day (pasaporte) on the cruise.
languages.question: What is "el pasaporte"?

languages.mnemonic: Some say, in the past, to pass exams was harder, but I don't (pasado) believe it.
languages.question: What does "el pasado" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Pasado is masculine, so it's el pasado. Imagine an elephant travelling into the past in a time machine.
languages.question: What does "el pasado" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At twenty past six, I received an email (y), but it was just a big letter Y.
languages.question: What does "y" represent when telling the time after the hour?

languages.mnemonic: I thought we were on the right path, but my cat had led me into the middle of nowhere (camino).
languages.question: What does "el camino" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Camino is masculine, so it's el camino. Imagine some elephants creating a path through the jungle.
languages.question: What does "el camino" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They said they liked his pattern ideas, but the artist wondered if he was being patronised (patrón).
languages.question: What is the translation of "el patrón" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Patrón is masculine, so it's el patrón. Imagine an elephant covered in a spotty pattern.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el patrón"?

languages.mnemonic: On the pavement was a therapist (acera) with her couch ready to talk to anyone.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la acera" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Acera is feminine so it's la acera. Imagine a lady with her stiletto heels stuck in the cracks of a pavement.
languages.question: What does "la acera" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I cannot believe that I had to pay my pa to guard (pagar) my dog.
languages.question: What does "pagar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He hadn't made payment despite repeated reminders, so they took his pagoda (pago) away.
languages.question: What is a pago?

languages.mnemonic: Peace is at the end of the path (paz).
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish term "la paz"?

languages.mnemonic: Paz is feminine, so it's la paz. Imagine a lady giving the peace sign.
languages.question: What does "la paz" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The pen caused the boat to leak so I grabbed the phone (bolígrafo) to call for help.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el bolígrafo?

languages.mnemonic: Using a pencil, she sketched a lapdog with vicious looking teeth (lápiz).
languages.question: What is "el lápiz" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I cashed in my pension and bought the gold and diamond encrusted pen you can see on (pensión) the table.
languages.question: What is "la pensión"?

languages.mnemonic: The people were surprised to see a hen take (gente) part in a marathon.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "people"?

languages.mnemonic: I was buying some pepper and the pepper made me sneeze. I suddenly wanted a pee, but they wouldn't let me enter (pimienta).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for pepper?

languages.mnemonic: He won't eat it if it's not perfect. It has to be perfect toast (perfecto).
languages.question: What does "perfecto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Perhaps you can give me a key that's (quizás) actually going to fit the lock.
languages.question: What does "quizás" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A person who is unwelcome in a country is known as a persona (persona) non grata.
languages.question: What does "la persona" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Every photograph she took was on the same subject – they were all photos of raffia (fotografía), but they created a lot of interest at the gallery.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for photograph?

languages.mnemonic: A phrase can get you into a fracas if you say (frase) the wrong thing.
languages.question: What is the English equivalent of the Spanish term "frase"?

languages.mnemonic: The bull loves playing the piano (piano).
languages.question: What is a musical instrument that the bull loves playing?

languages.mnemonic: It was easy to pick the winner. She had record hair (recoger) length.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "recoger" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Picture or imagine a hen (imagen).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for picture?

languages.mnemonic: He gave a piece of cake to his PA to thank (pieza) her for working late.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "piece"?

languages.mnemonic: The three little pigs built a house with help from their dad (cerda).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el término "el cerdo (m) / la cerda (f)" en español?

languages.mnemonic: The Pink Panther is very upset. His prize roses are damaged (rosada) by the hailstones.
languages.question: What does "el rosado/ la rosada" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The only place the dog could go really loopy was in the garden (lugar).
languages.question: What is the translation of "lugar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The best place to see the lunar eclipse, I guarantee (lugar), is in the countryside.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "lugar"?

languages.mnemonic: The garden was very plain. It was a yard with no (llano) colour.
languages.question: What is a llano?

languages.mnemonic: She presented the business plan (plan) to the bull.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el plan" en español?

languages.mnemonic: On a distant planet, a plant ate an (planeta) alien.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "planeta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The plant planted a (planta) beanstalk.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la planta" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Don't play football with these hooligan gargoyles (jugar).
languages.question: What does "jugar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Please" said the poor boy, "can I have an ice cream?" So his poor father (por favor) got him one, even though he couldn't really afford it.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "por favor"?

languages.mnemonic: The plural of bull is bulls.
languages.question: ¿Cómo se dice "plural" en español?

languages.mnemonic: Plural is masculine, so it's el plural. Imagine an elephant reciting the plural forms of different animals.
languages.question: What is "el plural" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The poem calmed the mad (poema) lion.
languages.question: What is "el poema" in English?

languages.definition: point (noun) - specifically the sharp end of a tool
languages.mnemonic: The point of the spoon dragged on the floor while being towed (punto).
languages.question: What does "punto" mean in the context of tools?

languages.mnemonic: She couldn't help but point at the man playing the giant spoon guitar (puntar).
languages.question: What does the verb "puntar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The police polygraph test showed the thief was a (policía) liar.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la policía"?

languages.mnemonic: The man was so poor. Not even his poems would buy bread (pobre) to feed his family.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "pobre" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They decided to populate mars with polar bears. so they were blasted (poblar) off in a rocket.
languages.question: How do you say "populate" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: In the port, park your boat where it won't be towed (puerto) away.
languages.question: What does "el puerto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The photographer took a great shot as the model posed on a pole in a sarong (posar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to pose"?

languages.mnemonic: Placed in position, the posse grabbed the thief on (posición) his way to the next bank.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la posición en español?

languages.mnemonic: It's possible that your posture could be to blame (posible) for your backache.
languages.question: What does "posible" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His new diet forbade him eating potatoes, so pa said ta-ta (patata) to them.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "potato"?

languages.mnemonic: She gave the impression of great power as she stood on the podium and gave her address, but all she was talking to was thin air (poder)
languages.question: What does "poder" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They went out for a practice drive but she practically wrote the car (práctica) off!
languages.question: What is the English definition of "práctica"?

languages.mnemonic: At precisely six o'clock an enornous spoon totally (en punto) destroyed my house.
languages.question: What does "en punto" mean when referring to time?

languages.mnemonic: Prepare to be amazed, the present from your pa is a rah-rah (preparar) skirt and he was wearing one too.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "preparar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: This was not the present he was expecting. He was not ready for the gallows (regalo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for a present or gift?

languages.mnemonic: There's no time like the present to give a presentation (presente) on what climate change is going to do to us. Presente is masculine, so it's el presente. Imagine an elephant that likes to live for the present.
languages.question: What is "el presente" in terms of time?

languages.mnemonic: The press were so busy they took on a new apprentice, sadly (prensa) he wasn't really interested in the work.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la prensa"?

languages.mnemonic: She's pretty, but she's a bone eater (bonita).
languages.question: What does "bonito/bonita" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I wanted to buy it, but the price of the present was the only (precio) thing stopping me.
languages.question: What does "el precio" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Precio is masculine, so it's el precio. Imagine an elephant with a price tag.
languages.question: What does "el precio" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Print the image of the priest holding a meerkat (imprimir) on my shirt.
languages.question: What does "imprimir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The problem with these maths problems is my ma (problema) can't solve them.
languages.question: What is "el problema" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The process of becoming a professional therapist takes so (proceso) long, but it's worth it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el proceso" en español?

languages.mnemonic: The product they produce is a hook to tow (producto) trucks.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for product?

languages.mnemonic: Producto is masculine, so it's el producto. Imagine a production line where an elephant is the end product.
languages.question: What is "producto" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Proper doughnuts please, not just adequate doughnuts (adecuardo).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "adecuardo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This is private property; it's inappropriate to peer at my dad (propiedad) through the window.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la propiedad"?

languages.mnemonic: To protect her she had a fireproof suit but there was nothing to protect her hair (proteger).
languages.question: What does "proteger" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To prove how brilliant she was, she demonstrated on the Stradivarius (demostrar) violin with her feet.
languages.question: What does "demostrar" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: At this pub the tab can burn a (taberna) hole in your wallet.
languages.question: What is "la taberna"?

languages.mnemonic: She had to pull my teeth out. 'Hurrah' (tirar) she shouted as each one came out, while I shouted 'Arhhh!'.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "tirar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The puppy escaped, and I had to catch it before it ran over the road (cachorro).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for puppy?

languages.mnemonic: The purple heather on the moor was changed by Leonardo (morado) because it was too much of a distraction.
languages.question: What does "el morado/la morada" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They stole our wallet and purse and drove off in a car, terrorizing (cartera) people.
languages.question: What does "la cartera" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Push the handle down on the toilet and that will empty the poop out, but press hard (empujar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "push"?

languages.mnemonic: Put the pony's hair (poner) into a ponytail.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "poner" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A quarter of the quarantined toads (cuarto) escaped.
languages.question: What does "cuarto" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Their question for the construction boss was: "Pray, why did you fill our lagoon with tar?" (Pregunta).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "question"?

languages.mnemonic: He went as quick as lightning on the water rapids at (rápida) the amusement park.
languages.question: What is the Spanish adjective for "quick"?

languages.mnemonic: She was quiet now because she had been given a tranquiliser (tranquilo).
languages.question: What does "tranquilo" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I haven't quite taken enough, the basket on the front of the tandem will take (bastante) more.
languages.question: What does "bastante" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Entering the race with that car was an error (carrera) - it broke down on the first lap.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "race"?

languages.definition: The communication of programmes or messages (el radio) / the device (la radio).
languages.mnemonic: I could hear the radio blasting out our new rap that we'd just finished in the studio (radio).
languages.question: What is radio?

languages.mnemonic: Travelling by rail, the ferocious carnivore made a really (ferrocarril) short meal of all its fellow passengers.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el ferrocarril"?

languages.mnemonic: It started to rain on Yogi Bear (llover) - he and Boo Boo were getting soaked in the Jellystone Park downpour.
languages.question: What does "llover" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When the rain comes down heavily, you veer (lluvia) off the road in some places if you're not careful.
languages.question: What is "la lluvia"?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine that it's raining ladies.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for rain?

languages.mnemonic: They shouldn't reach down and touch the alligator; it can bite their arm (alcanzar) off.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "alcanzar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I'll read you a bedtime story, just lay there (leer) and listen.
languages.question: What does the term "leer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Ready, steady, go! The least obese (listo) was favourite to win the race.
languages.question: What does "listo/lista" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The reason he didn't wear boxers was that they were baggy – he'd rather wear thongs (razón).
languages.question: What is the translation of "razón" from Spanish to English?

languages.mnemonic: Razón is feminine, so it's la razón. Imagine a lady giving a reason why she can't go out on a date.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "razón"?

languages.mnemonic: To receive his well-kept secret recipe for these beers (recibir) was an honour.
languages.question: What is the translation of "recibir"?

languages.mnemonic: The recipe wasn't right, and they wouldn't rest until their tart (receta) was perfect.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "recipe"?

languages.mnemonic: Receta is feminine, so it's la receta. Imagine a lady stealing a secret recipe.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "recipe"?

languages.mnemonic: The temperatures were the highest on record: there were warnings of strong sun rays causing heat stroke (registro).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "record" as a noun?

languages.mnemonic: From the red planet, they brought a rock home (rojo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "red"?

languages.mnemonic: In many a region of Spain, you can see a bull on the hillside.
languages.question: What is "la región" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I can't remember how to play the recorder (recordar) even after numerous lessons.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "recordar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We need to repair the red bus, and these parrots are (reparar) here to help.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "reparar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Repeat the routine!" - The rehearsal was so repetitious it left us in tears (repetir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "repetir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She didn't reply to my correspondence. How dare (responder) she.
languages.question: What does the term "responder" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It seemed to represent a load of black goo, said the critics – they didn't realise her painting was meant to represent tar (representar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "representar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I require you to be perfect. Any errors can wreck a career (requerir).
languages.question: What does the term "requerir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: You can reserve a table, but you can't reser ve the whole bar (reservar).
languages.question: What does "reservar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The boss had gone to rest - people were calling him but all they got was his desk answer (descansar) phone.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "descansar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The restaurant agreed we could rest our aunty (restaurante) there when she got tired during our shopping trip.
languages.question: What does "el restaurante" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What a result! The red sultanas don't (resultado) put people off.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "result"?

languages.mnemonic: Resultado is masculine, so it's el resultado. Imagine an elephant opening an envelope to see his exam result.
languages.question: What does "resultado" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The rice got in a froth (arroz) when she found out she would be boiled.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for rice?

languages.mnemonic: He was so rich he could afford to have his walls recoated (rico) in real gold paint.
languages.question: What does "rico" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I'd like to ride through the jungle just like monkeys and Tarzan (montar) do, swinging through the vines.
languages.question: What does "montar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We turned right and came to a derelict house. It was clear we chose (derecho/derecha) the wrong direction.
languages.question: What does "derecho/derecha" mean in terms of direction?

languages.mnemonic: As the king of the jungle had a ring placed on his paw all the animals yodelled (anillo).
languages.question: What is "el anillo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The river cruise company had been closed for years, but they decided to reopen (rio) it with a big fanfare when the river cruise became popular again.
languages.question: What does "rio" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Rio is masculine, so it's el rio. Imagine elephants swimming across a river.
languages.question: What does the term "rio" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The road was not suitable for the carriage, the terrain (carretera) was too rugged.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la carretera"?

languages.mnemonic: A huge rock has rolled onto their caravan (roca) completely flattening it.
languages.question: What does "la roca" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the tiny room, there was a bee triathlon (habitación) taking place.
languages.question: What does "la habitación" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The roots of my plants have been ruined, that rabbit with it's big teeth (raíz) has chewed through them all.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la raíz?

languages.mnemonic: The rope shows he must have climbed out the window. The question is, where has Dad gone?
languages.question: What does "la cuerda" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The rose rows a (rosa) boat along the river.

languages.mnemonic: Rosa is feminine, so it's la rosa. Imagine a lady holding a huge bouquet of roses.
languages.question: What is "la rosa" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The round bouncing bombs were used in the raid on dams (redonda) in Germany during World War 2.
languages.question: What does "redondo" or "redonda" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A row of eager children were waiting to feed the lambs (fila) at the farm zoo.

languages.mnemonic: Rub your hands together if they're frozen, or you won't be able to play the guitar.

languages.mnemonic: The pile of rubbish attracted bad super-rats (basura).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "basura" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They could see that the rule about each colour being refracted by a different amount was true when they aimed the ray at the glass (regla).

languages.mnemonic: Regla is feminine, so it's la regla. Imagine a lady who writes the rules.

languages.mnemonic: Run – the cork is going to go off and fly through the air (correr).

languages.mnemonic: She was addicted to salt - her mother told her off for getting saliva (sal) on the cellar.

languages.mnemonic: I'm sick of using the same miserable mower (mismo) everyday!

languages.mnemonic: Made out of sand, the children's brilliant art piece was a replica of a hyena (arena).

languages.mnemonic: I finally sat down on Saturday, but the kids sabotaged me with dough! (sábado).

languages.mnemonic: Sauce was dripping off his suit – he hadn't realised while he was dancing the salsa (salsa).

languages.mnemonic: I competed in the 'sausage, salad and cheese' challenge (salchicha).
languages.question: What does the term "salchicha" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Don't say – there has been a death here (decir).

languages.mnemonic: 'I say, have you been looking for me'? The death theory (decir) was ruled out by the police – the missing person appeared to be alive and well.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "decir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Don't be scared, but this animal pursues anyone that runs, so stand still and don't (asustado) move.

languages.mnemonic: The school for the eskimos was a whaler (escuela) – a ship they had once used for hunting whales but which now had classrooms inside and a playground on the deck.

languages.mnemonic: The science show has audience participation at the end of the theatre (ciencia) session.

languages.mnemonic: The sea was so calm they could see Mars (mar) reflected in it.

languages.mnemonic: She wants a seafood feast when she marries on the coast (marisco).

languages.mnemonic: Each season, this establishment changes the theme on (estación) its walls.

languages.mnemonic: This seat isn't great. I would prefer a seat away from these enormous toads (asiento).

languages.mnemonic: I needed to select several electric eels; the only issue was the narwhal (seleccionar) guarding them.

languages.mnemonic: They couldn't sell Big Ben after it had become derelict (vender).

languages.mnemonic: Trying to send an envelope can be hard (enviar) when the post box keeps running away.

languages.mnemonic: We had to separate the septuplets at the party - they were arguing (separar) over who should blow out the candles.

languages.mnemonic: The septic (tank) team member (September) needed a good bath, so it was a really septic embrace (septiembre) when she gave the customer a big hug.

languages.mnemonic: They serve it in a ceramic beer (servir) mug.

languages.mnemonic: Her set of golf clubs was consumed by the typhoon and were totally (conjunto) lost.

languages.mnemonic: Glam rock started in about Nineteen-Seventy, but you wouldn't find ABBA - famous for their hits in the Seventies - setting a tent up (setenta) once they made the big time.

languages.mnemonic: She moved into the shade to practise her gymnastics. As she did a somersault, her bra (sombre) flew off.

languages.mnemonic: The shape of the biscuits formed a map (forma) of the world.

languages.mnemonic: Forma is feminine, so it's la forma. Imagine a lady forming a shape with her lips.
languages.question: What does "la forma" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He offered to share some champagne from the glove compart ment, but she ran away and he was left in tear s (compartir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "compartir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Tiburón is masculine, so it's el tiburón. Imagine an elephant in shark infested waters.

languages.mnemonic: As it's incredibly sharp, a goose shouldn't be trusted with a dagger (aguda).

languages.mnemonic: She's Luke Skywalker's sister, Princess Leia (ella).

languages.mnemonic: Oveja is feminine, so it's la oveja. Imagine a lady sheep.

languages.mnemonic: The shine of the lightsaber meant the battle was brief. Yoda (brillo) quickly defeated the droids.

languages.mnemonic: Brillo is masculine, so it's el brillo. Imagine an elephant with a shine.

languages.mnemonic: They couldn't let him on to the ship because the barcode (barco) on his ticket was wrong.

languages.mnemonic: It matched the colour of my shirt when the chameleon sat (camisa) on it.

languages.mnemonic: The shoe that pa was wearing didn't hide his toe (zapato).

languages.mnemonic: After a trip to the shop, she had a cup of tea to end her (tienda) outing.

languages.mnemonic: I rarely catch a fish on the shore – I only reel in yaks.

languages.mnemonic: Orilla is feminine, so it's la orilla. Imagine a lady washed up on the shore of a desert island.

languages.mnemonic: You will have to shout to greet Tarzan (gritar) in the jungle - it's quite noisy in there.

languages.mnemonic: "I'm shy. You can teach me, but don't (tímido) shout."

languages.mnemonic: He jumped to the side just before the ladder fell over (lado).

languages.mnemonic: NOTE: There's a feminine equivalent of hijo – hija (pronounced ee-hah), which means daughter. So if you're talking or writing about a daughter rather than a son, use la hija.

languages.mnemonic: Singing a happy song, can the thief on (canción) the verge of getting away, really escape the law?

languages.mnemonic: She came over with the foreign sport team but the authorities deported (deporte) her because she couldn't actually perform.

languages.mnemonic: I like to spread a spoonful of tar (untar) on my toast.

languages.mnemonic: In spring the priests march, as the weather is fairer (primavera).

languages.mnemonic: In the town square there is a large platform that (plaza) they use for entertainment in the summer.

languages.mnemonic: Plaza is feminine so it's la plaza. Imagine a lady drawn on the surface of a town square.

languages.mnemonic: They prayed for stable, calm weather while the tornado destroyed the establishments (estable) along the street.

languages.mnemonic: The shooting star was a stray asteroid (estrella) crossing the night sky.

languages.mnemonic: She was in a state of shock after her well-established doughnut (estado) shop burnt down.

languages.mnemonic: A station was esta​blished in the sea, but trains couldn't make it far on (estación) water.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la estación"?

languages.mnemonic: The living statue was excellent; he even stood static with a wasp (estatua) on his nose.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "statue"?

languages.mnemonic: I like to stay in the cave where it's dark and safe (quedarse).

languages.mnemonic: She tried to steal a row of chocolate bars (robar).

languages.mnemonic: She kept telling herself one step higher, but she also kept telling herself if I pass out, it's all over (paso).

languages.mnemonic: Paso is masculine so it's el paso. Imagine an elephant doing step aerobics.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "step"?

languages.mnemonic: If you had a broom stick you could get into the party at the local (palo) pub.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for stick?

languages.mnemonic: It's still there. The toad in dad's beard asked (todavía) to stay.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "todavía" in English?

languages.mnemonic: A lord threw a stone at a rat as it crossed the chamber - all the peers said the rat (piedra) problem needed sorting.
languages.question: What does the term "piedra" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Piedra is feminine, so it's la piedra. Imagine a lady carrying a giant stone in a weight lifting contest.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for stone?

languages.mnemonic: We've tried to stop him but the parrot keeps eating the artwork (parar).
languages.question: What does "parar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The department store sells everything you need - almonds, maths books, envelopes (almacén), anything you can think of.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el almacén" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Almacén is masculine, so it's el almacén. Imagine an elephant shopping in a store.
languages.question: What is "el almacén"?

languages.mnemonic: A storm will torment a (tormenta) town before it destroys it.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "la tormenta" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: This stormy weather torments me oh-so (tormentoso) much.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "tormentoso/tormentosa" mean when describing weather?

languages.mnemonic: What's your story? His story is a (historia) great story.
languages.question: What does "la historia" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My toe is no longer straight. I have wrecked my toe (recto).
languages.question: What does "recto/recta" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She sensed a strange person watching her so she took an extra companion (extraño) on her quest.
languages.question: What does "extraño" or "extraña" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The stream was too small for a rowing race, so they played with their yo-yo's (arroyo) instead.
languages.question: What is an arroyo?

languages.mnemonic: Parked on the street was her new car, and she shouted 'yay!' (calle) when she saw it.
languages.question: What does "calle" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Strong as she is, the World's Strongest Woman looks the worse for wear as she takes (fuerte) the trophy.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for strong?

languages.mnemonic: Students! I would like you to write an essay today about my aunty (estudiante).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "student"?

languages.mnemonic: They want to send their daughter to study at boarding school but it's too dear (estudiar).
languages.question: What does "estudiar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The subject of the talk is children's rights – I'll have to take ma (tema) to that.
languages.question: What does "el tema" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Tema is masculine, so it's el tema. Imagine an elephant deciding which subject to take at university.
languages.question: What is "el tema" in English?

languages.mnemonic: After using a strange chemical substance on him, he sues the tanning salon when the active (sustancia) ingredient turns him blue.
languages.question: What is the translation of "sustancia" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The charity event was a success, and we're excited to see the total (éxito) amount raised.
languages.question: What does "éxito" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Éxito is masculine, so it's el éxito. Imagine an elephant achieving great success.
languages.question: ¿Qué palabra en español se utiliza para "success" y es masculina?

languages.mnemonic: He'd been in prison for such a long time that he'd lost count of his tally (tal).
languages.question: What does "tal" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The gambler had a sudden urge to repent and leave the casino (repentino).
languages.question: What does "repentino" or "repentina" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They love sugar, but don't get out. Throw a sugar cube through the car (azucar) window.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "azucar"?

languages.mnemonic: I suggest you sue her for rear-ending (sugerir) you.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "sugerir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His suit was ruined after the tractor dumped hay (traje) on him.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "suit" (clothing)?

languages.mnemonic: No one can touch her suitcase; Ma won't let a (maleta) single person near it.
languages.question: What is "la maleta" in English?

languages.mnemonic: In summer she sits out on the veranda, but her nose (verano) sometimes gets burned.
languages.question: What is "el verano"?

languages.mnemonic: At the mountain's summit, we had a party. The theme was animals (cima).
languages.question: What is referred to as the "cima" in mountain climbing?

languages.mnemonic: Cima is feminine, so it's la cima. Imagine a lady stood on a mountain's summit.
languages.question: What is "la cima"?

languages.mnemonic: The sun turns ice cream from solid (sol) into liquid.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el sol"?

languages.mnemonic: Sol is masculine, so it's el sol. Imagine an elephant bathing in the sun.
languages.question: What does "el sol" refer to?

languages.mnemonic: On Sundays, we use a sundial to time our games of dominoes and Go (domingo).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el domingo"?

languages.mnemonic: He hates going to the supermarket. Superman thinks it's a nightmare because he can't do (supermercado) his shopping in peace.
languages.question: What is a "supermercado" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Supermercado is masculine, so it's el supermercado. Imagine an elephant working in a supermarket.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "supermercado"?

languages.mnemonic: I support the campaign to let people keep a polar bear in their yard (apoyar).
languages.question: What does the verb "apoyar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Are you sure each segment costs a euro (seguro)? That makes it a very expensive fruit!
languages.question: What does "seguro (m) / segura (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What a surprise present. The saw impressed her (sorpresa). No one else would have thought to get her one.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "sorpresa"?

languages.mnemonic: I began to sweat as soon as the darts (sudar) started flying.
languages.question: What does "sudar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They love sweet foods so much that they drool when they (dulce) see any.
languages.question: What does the Spanish adjective "dulce" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I like to swim, but my nan prefers darts (nadar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "nadar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: In the swimming pool, the peas dressed up as Athena, (piscina) the Greek goddess of war.
languages.question: What does "la piscina" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The system helped solve my sister's dilemma (sistema).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "system"?

languages.mnemonic: The table was all messed up (mesa) after the kids' party got out of hand.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "table"?

languages.mnemonic: The tail of each animal had a cola (cola) can on it.
languages.question: What is referred to as "la cola" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: "Can you help me take these boxes to the car?" "Yeah, as long as it's not too far away (llevar)."
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "llevar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: People usually do a double take when they see the tomato art (tomar).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the verb "tomar"?

languages.mnemonic: We started to talk about the dangers of living in a war-torn city when a blast (hablar) went off.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "hablar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The tall lady at the back of the choir is an alto (alto) - she's taller than all the men!
languages.question: What does "alto/alta" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The tap was pouring green liquid, so I phoned (grifo) the plumber for help.
languages.question: What does "el grifo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "Taste this!" Every day the goose works in the kitchen to make the best egg custard tarts (degustar) in the world.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "degustar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It was lively at the tavern last night – the men drinking were in full song (mesón).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a tavern?

languages.mnemonic: Mesón is masculine, so it's le mesón. Imagine an elephant drinking in the tavern.
languages.question: What does "el mesón" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The bull hailed a taxi (taxi). Note: The bull is a Spanish icon, and whenever you see it on our images, it means that the word sounds similar in both English and Spanish.
languages.question: ¿Qué medio de transporte es "el taxi" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: My tea tasted funny after the monkey had dangled its tail (té) in it.
languages.question: What does "té" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I teach yoga to the residents of the care home. I encourage senior (enseñar) people to keep active.
languages.question: What does "enseñar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The rest of the team wondered why the heck he posed (equipo) like that on the pitch.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "team"?

languages.mnemonic: Why did she tear them up? The little rascal has ruined my garments (rasgar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "rasgar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: While watching television, I tell a bee the show is on (televisión).
languages.question: ¿Qué es la televisión?

languages.mnemonic: The temperature control in the hutch is temporarily broken, so it's too cold for these rabbits (temperatura).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la temperatura" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Temperatura is feminine, so it's la temperatura. Imagine a lady with a high temperature.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es la palabra en español para "temperature"?

languages.mnemonic: In the ten-pin bowling alley there was a strange fatality. The police were there to take details of the death (diez).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number ten?

languages.mnemonic: While playing tennis, I had to tell my niece (tenis) to go easy on me.
languages.question: What is "tenis"?

languages.mnemonic: Tenis is masculine, so it's el tenis. Imagine an elephant playing tennis.
languages.question: What is the masculine form of "the" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: If lots of people put their hands up, that would be tens, but have you noticed every person putting their hands up? You can see details of a death theme (dieci) going.
languages.question: How do you say "tens" for counting in Italian?

languages.mnemonic: In the long term, it would be a mistake to plant those (plazo) plants there.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "el plazo" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: A test is being carried out to see which is more beneficial - a prune or a banana (prueba).
languages.question: What is the meaning of "prueba" in English?

languages.mnemonic: More than just a kettle (que).
languages.question: What does "que" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Thank you for cutting the grass off the ass (gracias).
languages.question: What does "gracias" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: That is the question, which came (que) first, the chicken or the egg?
languages.question: What does "que" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The theatre performance was tasteless and atrocious (teatro).
languages.question: What does "teatro" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Their straw house soon (su) collapsed under the heavy rain.
languages.question: What does "su" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The cowboy tried to catch them, but he'd lost (los) his lasso (las).
languages.question: What are "los" and "las" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: He then entered the stage on a unicycle. This thesbian (entonces) was going off-script.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "entonces"?

languages.mnemonic: "That doesn't belong there – ah-ee!" (ahí) he screamed.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "ahí" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I burn; therefore, I pour plenty of sun lotion on to tan evenly from head to toe (por lo tahn toh).
languages.question: What does "por lo tanto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: These prisoners were trying to escape by tossing (estos) rope over the wall to climb up.
languages.question: How do you say "these" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: They loaded the hay onto the ostrich (ellos).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "they"?

languages.mnemonic: The thick hedge defied any attempt to cut through it – it grew ever so (grueso) quickly.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "grueso" or "gruesa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He might be thin and delicate, but he guards the dodo well.
languages.question: What does "delgado (m) / delgada (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: All the things cost a (cosa) million pounds in this shop.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "la cosa"?

languages.mnemonic: I think this pen looks like a sardine (pensar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "pensar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Thirteen locks on the safe door they said - must have been unlucky because they did not prevent the treasure theft (trece).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for thirteen?

languages.mnemonic: After winning thirty pieces of silver in the competition, he could afford to take a train or taxi (treinta) home instead of walking.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for thirty?

languages.mnemonic: This was his last will and testament – he had agonised over what to do with his estate (este) for a long time.
languages.question: What does the term "este" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Those expired sausages (esos) will make you sick.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "those"?

languages.mnemonic: Even though we could hear a raccoon who kept growling (aunque), it was mostly quiet outside.
languages.question: What does "aunque" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He could only lift a one-kilogram (one thousand grams) weight – it was time to eat better meals (mil) and put on some muscle.
languages.question: What does "mil" stand for in numeric terms?

languages.mnemonic: The three little pigs told the wolf he was trespassing (tres) on their land.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number three?

languages.mnemonic: She didn't get through to the next round of the quiz show: it was a travesty (a través de).
languages.question: What is the meaning of "a través de"?

languages.mnemonic: He wouldn't throw my ball back after it landed in his garden because he was too lethargic (lanzar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "throw"?

languages.mnemonic: The thunder scared the enemy troops away. They were nowhere (trueno) to be found.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for thunder?

languages.mnemonic: On Thursday he was so thirsty that he drank a huge wave (jueves).
languages.question: What day of the week is jueves?

languages.mnemonic: With the correct ticket, the boat's captain will let toads (boleto) onboard.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for ticket?

languages.mnemonic: Wearing a suit and tie, the corporate bat has (corbata) to dress sharp.
languages.question: What does "la corbata" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The dentist said the tiger's teeth are great (tigre).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el tigre (m)/ la tigra (f)"?

languages.mnemonic: He was always checking the time because his watches had such a lovely aura (hora) about them.
languages.question: What is "la hora"?

languages.mnemonic: The waiter wanted a tip but the diner just produced peanuts (propina).
languages.question: ¿Qué es la propina?

languages.mnemonic: The seal never seems to tire of eating his favourite cans of sardines (cansar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "cansar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They felt really cold after their swim in the freezing ocean (hacer frío).
languages.question: What does "hacer frío" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was so hot that even with ten air conditioners, we all collapsed on the floor (tener calor).
languages.question: What does "tener calor" mean?

languages.mnemonic: At twenty to nine, the men's boss (menos) was getting angry. Where were they?
languages.question: What does "menos" indicate in time-telling in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I wake up in the desert to a pair of guitarists (despertar) serenading me.
languages.question: What does "despertar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Let's go to a (a) different restaurant!
languages.question: What is the French word for "to"?

languages.mnemonic: Today we ran out of oil (hoy).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for today?

languages.mnemonic: We lay together on the beach sunbathing – who can tan (junta) faster?
languages.question: What does "junto (m)/ junta (f)" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The toilet attendant was playing his banjo (baño).
languages.question: What is "baño" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Tomorrow I will put a row of man yarn (mañana) out on display.
languages.question: What does "mañana" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I dropped a ton of bricks on my toenail, and Dad (tonelada) just laughed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "ton" in weight?

languages.mnemonic: His tone was anguished when she stubbed her toe on his nose (tono).
languages.question: What does "tono" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Tonight, we established the bar staff did not check (esta noche) customers' ages – we could be taken to court if we serve underage people.
languages.question: What does "esta noche" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's too late; you're already a dead man if you see a torpedo (demasiado) coming straight at you.
languages.question: What does "demasiado" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She threw the tools in the air at me, and we started juggling; it was really entertaining (herramienta).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "herramienta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: That tooth, I've decided it's enormous, and I have to take (diente) it out.
languages.question: What does "el diente" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My pet tortoises were impressive. I taught two of them to gamble (tortuga).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tortoise?

languages.mnemonic: The bull's visit to the china shop was a total (total) disaster.
languages.question: What is the term that means the complete amount?

languages.mnemonic: I can touch my toes but it kills my calves (tocar).
languages.question: What does the verb "tocar" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: They are unusual tourists, but the two priests are (turista) loving it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el/la turista"?

languages.mnemonic: He contributed towards what would become a theory (hacia) that changed modern science.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "toward" or "towards"?

languages.mnemonic: The town was full of dog's droppings: she washed the poo off her wellington boots then blow-dried (pueblo) them.
languages.question: What does "el pueblo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Pueblo is masculine, so it's el pueblo. Imagine an elephant being elected town mayor.
languages.question: What does "el pueblo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: See this toy? Well, whoever's best behaved gets to take (juguete) it home!
languages.question: What is a "juguete"?

languages.mnemonic: The race track is not a peaceful place to tan (pista).
languages.question: What does "la pista" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The farmer's bull drives a tractor (tractor).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tractor?

languages.mnemonic: She liked trade to commence early, her theory (comercio) being that starting at 6:00 AM would catch the morning commute.
languages.question: What does "el comercio" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I caused a traffic jam after I trapped my feet in a cone (tráfico). Tráfico is masculine, so it's el tráfico. Imagine an elephant stuck in traffic.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el tráfico?

languages.mnemonic: The train came off the track and caused a huge trench (tren).
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "tren" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She wanted to travel through the jungle on her bike – even though she knew it would be a hard (viajar) way of doing it.
languages.question: What does "viajar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I had to climb the tree because our ball (árbol) had got stuck in its branches.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el árbol"?

languages.mnemonic: Flying in a triangle above the treetops, the anxious goose thought they were too low (triángulo)
languages.question: ¿Qué forma geométrica es el triángulo?

languages.mnemonic: They were enjoying the trip, but did wonder why they had to go via a hay field.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a trip?

languages.mnemonic: The dog was no trouble today-he obeyed all of his commands without any problem at (problema) all.
languages.question: What does "problema" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Problema is masculine, so it's el problema. Imagine an elephant causing lots of trouble.
languages.question: What does "problema" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The thief was stealing his trousers, so he shouted: "Leave my pants alone!" (pantalón).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el pantalón" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: This lorry wasn't made to ca rry me on (camión) the back.
languages.question: What is "el camión"?

languages.mnemonic: It was the moment of truth – the verdict on his Dad (verdad) was "guilty".
languages.question: What does "la verdad" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Trying to keep dry in the tent was hard (intentar).
languages.question: What is the verb "intentar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The tube was so big that it took two boats (tubo) to carry it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el tubo" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Tuesday is a great day to chew (Tue) all day on the different varieties of food down at the mart (martes).
languages.question: What day of the week is martes in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: He had two pet turkeys, and pa loved them both (pavo).
languages.question: What animal is referred to as "el pavo" or "la pava" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Turn around, I've got a surprise for you - here you are! (Girar).
languages.question: What does "girar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The twelve Apostles liked to bake - they were always making dough for their (doce) saviour.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for twelve?

languages.mnemonic: In the roaring 20's (the 1920's) people had a great way to dance but they didn't have great dentists so the bane of their life were their teeth (veinti).
languages.question: What does "veinti" refer to in counting?

languages.mnemonic: If you have twenty-twenty vision, you shouldn't have tripped over the bench – there's tape (viente) all over it as a warning!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for twenty?

languages.mnemonic: Two by two they were allowed on to Noah's Ark as long as they had a complete dossier (dos) of their lives so far.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number two?

languages.mnemonic: What type of teapot (tipo) is that?
languages.question: What does "el tipo" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She used an umbrella like a parachute and glided down; it was (paraguas) an amazing sight.
languages.question: What does "el paraguas" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My Uncle Sam always spills his tea over (tío) everything.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el tío" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Under the train, it will only take a day to get back home (debajo).
languages.question: What is the meaning of "debajo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: They formed a close unit, who needs a Dad? (Unidad).
languages.question: What does "la unidad" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Until they emerged from the dark side of the moon, the astronaut's view was as black as tar (hasta).
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "hasta" mean?

languages.mnemonic: "Look at us, getting all nostalgic (nos) at old these old photos".
languages.question: What is "nos" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I'll use the goose's feathers on my arm (usar) to fly.
languages.question: What does "usar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Make yourself useful and find who's stealing (útil) from me!
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "útil"?

languages.mnemonic: It is usual for me to find horror films a bit too alarming!
languages.question: What is the meaning of "habitual"?

languages.mnemonic: When the sheep in the valley say "baa!" the kids shout "yay!" (valle).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el valle"?

languages.mnemonic: The value of her gold bar was lower (valor) since the price of gold had dropped dramatically.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "value"?

languages.mnemonic: In order to vary the racecourse, they place barriers (variar) on some corners to change the route.
languages.question: What does the verb "variar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It was the vegetable that he couldn't bear. "I'll do anything, just don't make me eat radishes!" (verdura)
languages.question: What is "la verdura"?

languages.mnemonic: Although it was very late, the moonlight made it easy (muy) to see.
languages.question: What does "muy" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I watch this video of a bee every day over (video) and over.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for video?

languages.mnemonic: Video is masculine, so it's el video. Imagine a video of an elephant.
languages.question: What is the gender of the Spanish word for video?

languages.mnemonic: The view was great but the bees seemed to target (vista) them.
languages.question: What does "la vista" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We went to visit the interior of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome but it was so busy by the altar (visitar), we couldn't get a good look.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "visitar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: In a loud voice, the headmaster told both (voz) boys to go to his office. Voz is feminine, so it's la voz. Imagine a lady with such a loud voice that her audience have to cover their ears.
languages.question: What is "la voz" in English?

languages.definition: volume (sound), also refers to size or quantity
languages.mnemonic: After turning up the volume and turning off the lights, both luminous (volumen) speakers shone out across the crowd.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el volumen"?

languages.definition: volume (sound), also refers to size or quantity
languages.mnemonic: Volumen is masculine, so it's el volumen. Imagine an elephant playing at a loud volume.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa el término "el volumen"?

languages.mnemonic: I had to vote for my favourite, but both tarts (votar) were delicious.
languages.question: What is the verb "votar" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The cat was happy to wait until the desperate rats (esperar) tried to escape from their hole.
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "to wait"?

languages.mnemonic: The waitress had a camera that was much rarer (camarera) than any camera she had ever had, so she always wore it around her neck.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a waiter or waitress?

languages.mnemonic: It's hard to walk with a camel in your arms (caminar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "caminar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: On top of the wall pa read (pared) a story to me.
languages.question: What does "la pared" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We want you posters went up everywhere – they wanted more carers (querer) now!
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "querer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: During the war, we had to get a ration (guerra) book.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "guerra" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She was so warm in her calico dress, she entered the pool to lower her temperature (caliente).
languages.question: What does "caliente" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You need to wash your hair and lather it well so the barber (lavar) can cut it for you.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "lavar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The wasps and the bees hated each other with a passion (avispa).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for wasp?

languages.mnemonic: We watch the world go by sitting on our veranda (ver).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ver" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Mixing the water with the special ingredient resulted in a goo...ah!
languages.question: What does "el agua" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The waterfall was spectacular – it cascaded (cascada) right down the side of the building.
languages.question: What is a "cascada"?

languages.mnemonic: The wave was huge, but it couldn't disturb us while we sipped our cola (ola).
languages.question: What is "la ola"?

languages.mnemonic: Ola is feminine, so it's la ola. Imagine a lady being drenched by a huge wave.
languages.question: What does "la ola" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We had no soap to wash the albatross (nosotros) after the oil spill.
languages.question: What does "nosotros/nosotras" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I felt weak when I realised my account had been debited, why did they steal (débil) from me?
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "débil" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What to wear to the yellow bar (llevar) was a big decision – she hoped she'd got it right!
languages.question: What is the verb "llevar" used to mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The weather was terrible, so they put up a teepee temporarily (tiempo).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for weather?

languages.mnemonic: At the wedding, both dads (boda) had a dance-off.
languages.question: What does "la boda" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Boda is feminine, so it's la boda. Imagine a lady ruining a wedding.
languages.question: What is "la boda"?

languages.mnemonic: Wednesday is the day I get wed, and it's a miracle (miércoles) I ever managed to persuade him to marry me.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for Wednesday?

languages.mnemonic: He works 70 hours per week - that's seventy hours manacled (semana) to a desk.
languages.question: What does "la semana" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: That weekend, despite a fiendish cold, he did the two-day seminar (fin de semana).
languages.question: What does "el fin de semana" mean?

languages.mnemonic: If I weigh myself and I'm too heavy, I have to pay the sergeant (pesar).
languages.question: What does the term "pesar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The weight of the rucksack will affect her pace o(ver) (peso) the trial.
languages.question: What does "peso" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Peso is masculine, so it's el peso. Imagine an elephant checking its weight on the bathroom scales.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "weight," and is it masculine or feminine?

languages.mnemonic: From the west came a fierce storm and they had to send an S.O.S. to be taken (oeste) offboard.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "west"?

languages.mnemonic: In wet weather, most hats don't (mojado) protect you.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "mojado"?

languages.mnemonic: What came (qué) first, the chicken or the egg?
languages.question: What does "¿qué?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The wheel on the racing car came flying off; the runaway tyre causing damage (rueda) as it rolled down the track.
languages.question: What is "la rueda" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: When she saw the thief she decided to use her taekwondo (cuando).
languages.question: What does "cuando" mean in Spanish when it's not a question?

languages.mnemonic: When will she stop the thief? As soon as she kicks him with her taekwondo (cuándo).
languages.question: What does "cuándo" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: No matter where you go on your donkey day (donde) you will need your satnav.
languages.question: What does "donde" mean in Spanish when it's not used in a question?

languages.mnemonic: Where does your satnav take you on your donkey day's (dónde) out?
languages.question: What is the English translation of "¿dónde?"?

languages.mnemonic: I don't know whether to go to the seaside (si) or the mountains in this hot weather.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish conjunction "si"?

languages.mnemonic: She will choose the one which she loves the most, but both are equal (cual) in looks and kindness.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "cual" when used non-interrogatively in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Which one should she choose? They were equal (cuál) in looks and kindness, but which one did she love the most?
languages.question: What does "¿cuál?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: While the farmer was asleep me and my family ate the entire raspberry (mientras) crop.
languages.question: What does "mientras" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Everywhere was white. He pulled a white blanket over himself and disappeared.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for white, either in masculine or feminine form?

languages.mnemonic: Dr Who couldn't get going until she used the key to the engine (Quien)?
languages.question: What does "quien" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Who is the doctor putting the key in the en-gine (Quién)?
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "who"?

languages.mnemonic: If we picked our whole crop of strawberries, there would be enough to fill an entire aeroplane!
languages.question: What does the term "entero" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Whose is that? It's such a cool yoyo (cuyo).
languages.question: What is the English meaning of "cuyo" or "cuya"?

languages.mnemonic: Why did his trousers no longer fit? He'd got porky (por qué) because he'd been stuffing his face too much.
languages.question: What does "¿por qué?" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Not a wide fish, the anchovy (ancho) is in fact small and narrow.
languages.question: What does "ancho (m)/ancha (f)" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: My wife especially dislikes posers (esposa).
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for wife?

languages.mnemonic: The wild animals loved the barbeque, but the salad bar they hated (salvaje).
languages.question: What does "salvaje" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Want to win the lottery? This conman guarantees you will if you attend his seminar (ganar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ganar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The wind was so strong. She was being towed (viento) by the power kite.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el viento?

languages.mnemonic: In the window there was a vent and the air coming through was like anaesthetic (ventana).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for window?

languages.mnemonic: For the wine bar opening, they used a big bow to decorate the garden (bodega). Bodega is feminine, so it's la bodega. Imagine a lady getting very drunk in a wine bar.
languages.question: What is the term "la bodega" commonly used to refer to?

languages.mnemonic: The wine is of the highest quality; the bee knows (vino) by the smell.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el vino?

languages.mnemonic: The wing of the old plane came a-part as it crash-la-nded (ala).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la ala" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: It must be winter, there's a nip in the air, no? (invierno).
languages.question: What is "invierno" in English?

languages.mnemonic: With a wire trolley, the drunk stopped a cab then lay (cable) down in the back.
languages.question: What is the translation of "el cable"?

languages.mnemonic: I wish that one day they'll say I'm a great artist (desear).
languages.question: What does the verb "desear" mean?

languages.mnemonic: With a little help from your friends you can conquer (con) your fears.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the term "con" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: Let he who is without sin (sin) cast the first stone.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "sin" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The wolf collected loads of bones (lobo).
languages.question: What is "el lobo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The woman's hairstyle reminded people of a cow – they called her moo hair (mujer).
languages.question: What does "la mujer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We admired the wonder of nature while ma ran from the bees attacking (marabilla) her. Maravilla is feminine, so it's la maravilla. Imagine a lady posing by one of the Wonders of the World.
languages.question: What does "la maravilla" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Even in the woods my boss came (bosque) through the trees – I couldn't get away from work.
