languages.mnemonic: It was a simple task– I sent you to see how much a yo-yo (sencillo) costs, not to buy every yo-yo they had!
languages.question: What does "sencillo/sencilla" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Since yesterday I've decided that every day is dessert day (desde).
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "desde"?

languages.mnemonic: As the rider began to sing, her horse broke into a canter (cantar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "cantar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They were all single and playing solitaire, all seated in a row (soltero).
languages.question: What does "soltero" or "soltera" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Sir, you can't send your (señor) letter to Santa.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el señor"?

languages.mnemonic: She looked very different to her sister and her manner (hermana) was totally different too.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "sister"?

languages.mnemonic: I want you to sit in the centre (sentar) of the circle of people.
languages.question: What does "sentar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Roll a double six at the casino says (seis) Simon and you will win the jackpot!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for six?

languages.mnemonic: The bomb would go off in sixty seconds - several senators were targets (sesenta) of the radical group.
languages.question: ¿Qué número representa la palabra sesenta?

languages.mnemonic: Its size was enormous - the tart stretched across the whole yard (talla).
languages.question: What does "la talla" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Talla is feminine, so it's la talla. Imagine a lady who's concerned about her size.
languages.question: What does "la talla" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Her skin got so hot in the sun it was beginning to peel (piel).
languages.question: What is "la piel" in English?

languages.mnemonic: A skirt was worn by the falcon dancing (falda) the flamenco.
languages.question: What is "la falda" in English?

languages.mnemonic: In the sky, they could see a low (cielo) aeroplane disappearing over the horizon.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el cielo" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: The slave escaped after clambering over both (esclavo) fences.
languages.question: What is the translation of "esclavo/esclava" in English?

languages.mnemonic: You can sleep in this dormitory but it's full of meerkats (dormir).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "dormir" mean?

languages.mnemonic: You're likely to slip if you rest on a balance beam covered in lard (resbalar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "resbalar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: To avoid having to slow, the riders leant over (lento) at an acute angle on the bends.
languages.question: What does "lento/lenta" mean in music?

languages.mnemonic: It was only a small bird - but its peck caused a pain in my knee - 'Oh!' (pequeno)
languages.question: What does "el pequeño / la pequeña" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The smell was terrible. "Oh lord! (olor) Where is that odour coming from?" he said.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el olor"?

languages.mnemonic: Her smile and song are the reason I'm so happy (sonrisa).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "smile"?

languages.mnemonic: Sonrisa is feminine, so it's la sonrisa. Imagine a lady painting a smile on her face.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "smile"?

languages.mnemonic: The smoke was coming from the sumo (humo) wrestler.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el humo"?

languages.mnemonic: The snake was deadly, but she wasn't scared to confront the serpent, enter it's cage, and ta ke (sepiente) it for a walk.
languages.question: What is "la serpiente"?

languages.mnemonic: The snow was above her knees and this caused her strength to ebb away (nieve).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la nieve"?

languages.mnemonic: It's going to snow tonight according to my neighbour's barometer (nevar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "nevar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: This bar of soap has bones (jabón) in it.
languages.question: What does "el jabón" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The sock calculated that they'd been walking seventeen miles (calcetín).
languages.question: What does "el calcetín" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: On the soft sand, he looked very suave in the bay (suave).
languages.question: What does "suave" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Digging out soil makes you sweat more the lower (suelo) you get.
languages.question: What does the term "suelo" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The soldier sold my dad doughnuts (soldado).
languages.question: What is "el soldado" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Soldado is masculine, so it's el soldado. Imagine an elephant soldier.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for soldier?

languages.mnemonic: Wearing a belt might be the solution. Those trousers are so loose I can see the underwear you've got on (solución). Solución is feminine so it's la solución. Imagine a lady coming up with a great solution.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "solución"?

languages.mnemonic: To solve the problem, the council passed a resolution to bear (resolver) the cost of the new litter bins.
languages.question: What does the verb "resolver" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Some alligators live in lagoons: you can just see their nostrils (algunos) above the water.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "some" when referring to a few items or people?

languages.mnemonic: He had a way of dealing with his naughty son – he hosed (hijo) him down.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "son"?

languages.mnemonic: Hijo is masculine, so it's el hijo. Imagine someone's son invites a friend home – and it turns out to be an elephant!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "son"?

languages.mnemonic: The song is coming from the bugs that I can see on (canción) the ground.
languages.question: What does "la canción" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I soon realised that gardening barefoot was a bad idea when the fork's prong went through my toe (pronto).
languages.question: What does "pronto" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The sound was so near you couldn't doze (sonido).
languages.question: What does "sonido" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Imagine eating soup that tastes like soap, "ah" (sopa) imagine.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for soup?

languages.mnemonic: In South Africa where it's hot, the sewers (sur) don't half smell.
languages.question: What does "sur" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: There's not enough space for his Pa's yoga (espacio) class.
languages.question: What is the translation of the Spanish term "espacio"?

languages.mnemonic: She couldn't speak their language, so to join in their chanting she just did a "blah blah blah" (hablar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "hablar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: All holidays are special, but especially (especial) Christmas!
languages.question: What is another word for special?

languages.mnemonic: She broke her spectacles, but managed to fix them with gaffer (gafas) tape.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for spectacles?

languages.mnemonic: Her speech was indecent, coarse and offensive (discurso).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el discurso"?

languages.mnemonic: He doesn't drive at great speed, so I bet there are lots of seething people stuck behind Grandad (velocidad).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la velocidad"?

languages.mnemonic: Velocidad is feminine, so it's la velocidad. Imagine a lady getting caught breaking the speed limit.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la velocidad?

languages.mnemonic: She can finally spell her name! Every day the ladybird trained hard (deletrear), and now she can finally do it.
languages.question: ¿Cómo se dice "spell" en español?

languages.mnemonic: I spend my time gathering starfish (gastar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "gastar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The spicy pecans tasted (picante) awful!
languages.question: What does "picante" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The spider was scared and ran away from the yak (araña).
languages.question: What does "la araña" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The chickens had an egg and spoon race around their coop. The champion ran (cuchara) a new record time.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for spoon?

languages.mnemonic: She came over with the foreign sport team but the authorities deported (deporte) her because she couldn't actually perform.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "sport"?

languages.mnemonic: I like to spread a spoonful of tar (untar) on my toast.
languages.question: What does the verb "untar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: In spring the priests march, as the weather is fairer (primavera).
languages.question: What does "primavera" mean when referring to a season?

languages.mnemonic: In the town square, the platypuses sat (plaza) and watched the show.
languages.question: What does "la plaza" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The squirrel thought she was an artist but she had no idea (ardilla) how to draw.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la ardilla" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: They prayed for stable, calm weather while the tornado destroyed the establishments (estable) along the street.
languages.question: What does "estable" mean in terms of weather?

languages.mnemonic: I've got a big stain on my shirt after that man challenged (mancha) me to an eating contest.
languages.question: What does "la mancha" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This stamp says yoyos (sello) rule.
languages.question: What is a "sello" in the context of mail?

languages.mnemonic: Don't just stand there daydreaming; help me with this piano - my arms are aching (de pie).
languages.question: What does "de pie" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The shooting star was a stray asteroid (estrella) crossing the night sky.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for star?

languages.mnemonic: Estrella is feminine, so it's la estrella. Imagine a lady with a star painted on her forehead.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for a feminine star?

languages.mnemonic: To start the event, the emperor released the sardines (empezar).
languages.question: What does the verb "empezar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: As they ate their starters, the entire place tremored, but they escaped (entremés) injury.
languages.question: What is "el entremés" in a meal?

languages.mnemonic: She was in a state of shock after her well-established doughnut (estado) shop burnt down.
languages.question: What does "estado" mean when referring to a condition?

languages.mnemonic: A station was esta blished in the sea, but trains couldn't make it far on (estación) water. Estación is feminine, so it's la estación. Imagine a lady missing her train at the station.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "estación"?

languages.mnemonic: The living statue was excellent; he even stood static with a wasp (estatua) on his nose.
languages.question: ¿Qué es una estatua?

languages.mnemonic: I like to stay in the cave where it's dark and safe (quedarse).
languages.question: What does "quedarse" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: She tried to steal a row of chocolate bars (robar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "robar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: If too much steam comes from your bath, pour (vapor) in some ice-cold water.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el vapor"?

languages.mnemonic: Vapor is masculine, so it's el vapor. Imagine an elephant blowing steam from its trunk.
languages.question: ¿Qué es el vapor?

languages.mnemonic: We decided to use a steel one after several ropes (acero) snapped.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el acero"?

languages.mnemonic: She kept telling herself one step higher, but she also kept telling herself if I pass out, it's all over (paso).
languages.question: What does "paso" mean?

languages.mnemonic: If you had a broom stick you could get into the party at the local (palo) pub.
languages.question: What does "el palo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's still there. The toad in dad's beard asked (todavía) to stay.
languages.question: What does "todavía" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A lord threw a stone at a rat as it crossed the chamber - all the peers said the rat (piedra) problem needed sorting.
languages.question: What is the translation of "la piedra" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Piedra is feminine, so it's la piedra. Imagine a lady carrying a giant stone in a weight lifting contest.
languages.question: What is "la piedra"?

languages.mnemonic: We've tried to stop him but the parrot keeps eating the artwork (parar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "stop"?

languages.mnemonic: Although she was far too young, she went to the store to buy alcohol. "My Ma sent (almacén) me," she told the cashier.
languages.question: What is an "almacén"?

languages.mnemonic: A storm will torment a (tormenta) town before it destroys it.
languages.question: What does "la tormenta" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This stormy weather torments me oh-so (tormentoso) much.
languages.question: What does "tormentoso / tormentosa" describe in terms of weather?

languages.mnemonic: What's your story? His story is a (historia) great story.
languages.question: What is the definition of "la historia" in English?

languages.mnemonic: My toe is no longer straight. I have wrecked my toe (recto).
languages.question: What does "recto (m), recta (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She sensed a strange person watching her so she took an extra companion (extraño) on her quest.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "extraño" en español?

languages.mnemonic: The stream was too small for a rowing race, so they played with their yo-yo's (arroyo) instead.
languages.question: What is an arroyo?

languages.mnemonic: Parked on the street was her new car, and she shouted 'yay!' (calle) when she saw it.
languages.question: What does "calle" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Calle is feminine, so it’s la calle. Imagine ladies dancing all the way along the street:
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "street"?

languages.mnemonic: Strong as she is, the World's Strongest Woman looks the worse for wear as she takes (fuerte) the trophy.
languages.question: What does "fuerte" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Students! I would like you to write an essay today about my aunty (estudiante).
languages.question: What does "el/la estudiante" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They want to send their daughter to study at boarding school but it's too dear (estudiar).
languages.question: What does the verb "estudiar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The subject of the talk is children's rights – I'll have to take ma (tema) to that.
languages.question: What does "el tema" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Tema is masculine, so it's el tema. Imagine an elelephant deciding which subject to take at university.
languages.question: What does "el tema" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: After using a strange chemical substance on him, he sues the tanning salon when he sees a (sustancia) serious problem.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la sustancia"?

languages.mnemonic: The charity event was a success, and we're excited to see the total (éxito) amount raised.
languages.question: What is the meaning of "éxito"?

languages.mnemonic: He'd been in prison for such a long time that he'd lost count of his tally (tal).
languages.question: What does "tal" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The gambler had a sudden urge to repent and leave the casino (repentino).
languages.question: What does "repentino" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They delivered the sugar cane to the pandas in a zoo car (azucar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for sugar?

languages.mnemonic: I suggest you sue her for rear-ending (sugerir) you.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "sugerir" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: His suit was ruined after the tractor dumped hay (traje) on him.
languages.question: What does "el traje" refer to in clothing?

languages.mnemonic: No one can touch her suitcase; Ma won't let a (maleta) single person near it.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la maleta"?

languages.mnemonic: In summer she sits out on the veranda, but her nose (verano) sometimes gets burned.
languages.question: What does "el verano" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: From the mountain's summit, we could see ma (cima) waving to us.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for the summit?

languages.mnemonic: The sun turns ice cream from solid (sol) into liquid.
languages.question: ¿Qué es "el sol"?

languages.mnemonic: On Sundays, we use a sundial to time our games of dominoes and Go (domingo).
languages.question: What day of the week is referred to as "domingo"?

languages.mnemonic: He hates going to the supermarket. Superman thinks it's a nightmare because he can't do (supermercado) his shopping in peace.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "supermercado"?

languages.mnemonic: Supermercado is masculine, so it's el supermercado. Imagine an elephant working in a supermarket.
languages.question: What is a supermercado?

languages.mnemonic: I support the campaign to let people keep a polar bear in their yard (apoyar).
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb that means "to support"?

languages.mnemonic: Are you sure each segment costs a euro (seguro)? That makes it a very expensive fruit!
languages.question: What does "seguro" or "segura" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What a surprise present. The saw impressed her (sorpresa). No one else would have thought to get her one.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "sorpresa" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I began to sweat as soon as the darts (sudar) started flying.
languages.question: What does the verb "sudar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He loves sweet foods so much that he'll drool if I say (dulce) I've got some.
languages.question: What does "dulce" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I like to swim, but my nan prefers darts (nadar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "nadar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Going to the swimming pool is fun, but the person who pees in a (piscina) pool can spoil things for everyone.
languages.question: What is "la piscina" in English?

languages.mnemonic: The system helped solve my sister's dilemma (sistema).
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish term "sistema"?

languages.mnemonic: The table was all messed up (mesa) after the kids' party got out of hand.
languages.question: What does "la mesa" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The tail of each animal had a cola (cola) can on it.
languages.question: What is "la cola" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: "Can you help me take these boxes to the car?" "Yeah, as long as it's not too far away (llevar)."
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "llevar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: People usually do a double take when they see the tomato art (tomar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "tomar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We started to talk about the dangers of living in a war-torn city when a blast (hablar) went off.
languages.question: What does "hablar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The tall lady at the back of the choir is an alto (alto) - she's taller than all the men!
languages.question: What does "alto/alta" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The tap was pouring green liquid, so I phoned (grifo) the plumber for help.
languages.question: What is a "grifo"?

languages.mnemonic: "Taste this!" Every day the goose works in the kitchen to make the best egg custard tarts (degustar) in the world.
languages.question: What does "degustar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It was lively at the tavern last night – the men drinking were in full song (mesón).
languages.question: What is "el mesón"?

languages.mnemonic: The bull hailed a taxi (taxi).
languages.question: ¿Qué es el taxi?

languages.mnemonic: My tea tasted funny after the monkey had dangled its tail (té) in it.
languages.question: What does "té" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I teach yoga to the residents of the care home. I encourage senior (enseñar) people to keep active.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "enseñar"?

languages.mnemonic: The rest of the team wondered why the heck he posed (equipo) like that on the pitch.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "team"?

languages.mnemonic: Why did she tear them up? The little rascal has ruined my garments (rasgar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "rasgar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: While watching television, I tell a bee the show he wants to see is on (televisión).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for television?

languages.mnemonic: The temperature control in the hutch is temporarily broken, so it's too cold for these rabbits (temperatura).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "temperatura"?

languages.mnemonic: Temperatura is feminine, so it's la temperatura. Imagine a lady with a high temperature.
languages.question: ¿Cuál es la palabra en español para "temperature"?

languages.mnemonic: In the ten-pin bowling alley, there was a strange fatality. The police were there to take details and establish (diez) the cause.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for ten?

languages.mnemonic: While playing tennis, I had to tell my niece (tenis) to go easy on me.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "tenis"?

languages.mnemonic: Tenis is masculine, so it's el tenis. Imagine an elephant playing tennis.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "tenis" en español?

languages.mnemonic: If lots of people put their hands up, that would be tens, but have you noticed every person putting their hands up? You can see details of a death related scene (dieci).
languages.question: What does "dieci" represent in counting terms?

languages.mnemonic: In the long term, it would be a mistake to plant so (plazo) many plants there.
languages.question: What does "plazo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: A test is being carried out to see which is more beneficial - a prune or a banana (prueba).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la prueba"?

languages.mnemonic: More than just a kettle (que).
languages.question: What does "que" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Thank you for trimming the grassy ass (gracias).
languages.question: What does "gracias" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: That is the question, which came (que) first, the chicken or the egg?
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "que" translate to in English?

languages.mnemonic: The theater performance was tasteless and atrocious (teatro).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for theater?

languages.mnemonic: Their straw house soon (su) collapsed under the heavy rain.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "their"?

languages.mnemonic: The cowboy tried to catch them, but he'd lost (los) his lasso (las).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "them"?

languages.mnemonic: Then she ended the dispute by lifting her up with tongs. What she says (entonces), we do.
languages.question: What does "entonces" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: "That doesn't belong there – ah-ee!" (ahí) he screamed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "there"?

languages.mnemonic: I burn; therefore, I pour plenty of sun lotion on to tan evenly from head to toe (por lo tahn toh).
languages.question: What does "por lo tanto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: These prisoners were trying to escape by tossing (estos) rope over the wall to climb up.
languages.question: What does "estos (m)/estas (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They loaded the hay onto the ostrich (ellos).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "they"?

languages.mnemonic: The thick hedge defied any attempt to cut through it – it grew ever so (grueso) quickly.
languages.question: What does "grueso/gruesa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He might be thin and delicate, but he guards the dodo well.
languages.question: What does "delgado" or "delgada" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: All the things cost a (cosa) million pounds in this shop.
languages.question: What does "la cosa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The lady said she'd never seen such a thing before.
languages.question: What does "la cosa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I think this pen looks like a sardine (pensar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "pensar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Thirteen locks on the safe door they said - must have been unlucky because they did not prevent the treasure being stolen from the safe (trece).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for thirteen?

languages.mnemonic: After winning thirty pieces of silver in the competition, he could afford to take a train or taxi (treinta) home instead of walking.
languages.question: What does "treinta" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: This was his last will and testament – he had agonised over what to do with his estate (este) for a long time.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "this"?

languages.mnemonic: Those expired sausages (esos) will make you sick.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "esos (m), esas (f)" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Even though we could hear a raccoon who kept growling (aunque), it was mostly quiet outside.
languages.question: What does "aunque" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He could only lift a one-kilogram (one thousand grams) weight – it was time to eat better meals (mil) and put on some muscle.
languages.question: What does "mil" refer to in terms of numbers?

languages.mnemonic: The three little pigs told the wolf he was trespassing (tres) on their land.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number three?

languages.mnemonic: She didn't get through to the next round of the quiz show: it was a travesty (a través de).
languages.question: What does "a través de" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: He won't throw my ball back after it lands in his garden (lanzar) because he's too lazy.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "lanzar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The thunder scared the enemy troops away. They were nowhere (trueno) to be found.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "trueno" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: On Thursday he was so thirsty that he drank a huge wave (jueves).
languages.question: What day of the week is "jueves" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: With the correct ticket, the boat's captain will let toads (boleto) onboard.
languages.question: What does the term "boleto" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Wearing a suit and tie, the corporate bat has (corbata) to dress sharp.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa la palabra "la corbata" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: The dentist said the tiger's teeth are great (tigre).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tiger?

languages.mnemonic: He was always checking the time because his watches had such a lovely aura (hora) about them.
languages.question: What does "la hora" refer to in terms of daily measurement?

languages.mnemonic: Hora is feminine, so it's la hora. Imagine a lady who can tell you the time in numerous time zones.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la hora"?

languages.mnemonic: The waiter wanted a tip but the diner just produced peanuts (propina).
languages.question: ¿Qué es "la propina"?

languages.mnemonic: The seal never seems to tire of eating his favourite cans of sardines (cansar).
languages.question: What does the verb "cansar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: They felt really cold after several hours in the freezing ocean (hacer frío).
languages.question: What does "hacer frío" mean?

languages.mnemonic: It was so hot that even with ten air conditioners, we all collapsed on the floor (tener calor).
languages.question: What does "tener calor" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: At twenty to nine, the men's boss (menos) was getting angry. Where were they?
languages.question: What does "menos" mean in the context of telling time in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: I wake up in the desert to a pair of guitarists (despertar) serenading me.
languages.question: What does "despertar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Let's go to a (a) different restaurant!
languages.question: What does the letter "a" translate to in this context?

languages.mnemonic: Today we ran out of oil (hoy).
languages.question: What does "hoy" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We lay together on the beach sunbathing – who can tan (junta) faster?
languages.question: What does "junto (m)/ junta (f)" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The toilet attendant was playing his banjo (baño).
languages.question: What does "el baño" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Tomorrow I will put a row of man yarn (mañana) out on display.
languages.question: What does "mañana" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I dropped a ton of bricks on my toenail, and Dad (tonelada) just laughed.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "ton" in weight?

languages.mnemonic: His tone was anguished when she stubbed her toe on his nose (tono).
languages.question: What does "el tono" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Tonight, we esta(blished) the bar staff did no(t) che(ck) (esta noche) customers' ages – we could be taken to court if we serve underage people.
languages.question: What does "esta noche" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It's too late; you're already a dead man if you see a torpedo (demasiado) coming straight at you.
languages.question: What does "demasiado" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She threw the tools in the air at me, and we started juggling; it was really entertaining (herramienta).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "tool"?

languages.mnemonic: That tooth, I've decided it's enormous, and I have to take (diente) it out.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el diente" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: My pet tortoises were impressive. I taught two of them to gamble (tortuga).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tortoise?

languages.mnemonic: The bull's visit to the china shop was a total (total) disaster.
languages.question: What word is synonymous with complete or entire, often used to describe the sum or aggregate of something?

languages.mnemonic: I can touch my toes but it kills my calves (tocar).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish verb "tocar"?

languages.mnemonic: They are unusual tourists, but the two priests are (turista) loving it.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "tourist"?

languages.mnemonic: He ran towards us, screaming that he'd actually seen an (hacia) alien.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "hacia" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The town was full of dog's droppings: she washed the poo off her wellington boots then blow-dried (pueblo) them.
languages.question: What is "el pueblo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Pueblo is masculine, so it's el pueblo. Imagine an elephant being elected town mayor.
languages.question: What is "el pueblo"?

languages.mnemonic: "See this toy? Well, whoever's best behaved gets to take (juguete) it home!"
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el juguete"?

languages.mnemonic: The race track is not a peaceful place to tan (pista).
languages.question: What does "la pista" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The farmer's bull drives a tractor (tractor).
languages.question: What is "tractor" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The car trade is a complete nightmare for me because I can't see over (comercio) the steering wheel.
languages.question: What is the term "comercio" in English?

languages.mnemonic: I caused a traffic jam after I trapped my feet in a cone (tráfico).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el tráfico"?

languages.mnemonic: The train came off the track and caused a huge trench (tren).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "train"?

languages.mnemonic: She wanted to travel through the jungle on her bike – even though she knew it would be a hard (viajar) way of doing it.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "viajar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: I had to climb the tree because our ball (árbol) had got stuck in its branches.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tree?

languages.mnemonic: Flying in a triangle above the treetops, the anxious goose thought they were too low (triángulo)
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for triangle?

languages.mnemonic: They were enjoying the trip, but did wonder why they had to go via a hay field.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "viaje" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The dog was no trouble today-he obeyed all of his commands without any problem at (problema) all.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "trouble"?

languages.mnemonic: Problema is masculine, so it's el problema. Imagine an elephant causing lots of trouble.
languages.question: What is the English translation of "el problema"?

languages.mnemonic: The thief was stealing his trousers, so he shouted: "Leave my pants alone!" (pantalón).
languages.question: What does "el pantalón" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: This lorry wasn't made to carry me on (camión) the back.
languages.question: What is "el camión" in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was the moment of truth – the verdict on his Dad (verdad) was "guilty".
languages.question: What does "la verdad" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Trying to keep dry in the tent was hard (intentar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "intentar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The tube was so big that it took two boats (tubo) to carry it.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for tube?

languages.mnemonic: Tuesday is a great day to chew (Tue) all day on the different varieties of food down at the mart (martes).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for Tuesday?

languages.mnemonic: He had two pet turkeys, and pa loved them both (pavo).
languages.question: What does "el pavo / la pava" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: Turn around, I've got a surprise for you - here you are! (Girar).
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish verb "girar"?

languages.mnemonic: The twelve Apostles liked to bake - they were always making dough for their saviour (doce).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for twelve?

languages.mnemonic: In the roaring 20's (the 1920's) people had a great way to dance but they didn't have great dentists so the bane of their life were their teeth (veinti).
languages.question: How do you say "twenties" for counting in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: If you have twenty-twenty vision, you shouldn't have tripped over the bench – there's tape (viente) all over it as a warning!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for twenty?

languages.mnemonic: Two by two they were allowed on to Noah's Ark as long as they had a complete dossier (dos) of their lives so far.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for the number two?

languages.mnemonic: What type of teapot (tipo) is that?
languages.question: What does "tipo" mean?

languages.mnemonic: She used an umbrella like a parachute and glided down; it was (paraguas) an amazing sight.
languages.question: What does "el paraguas" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: My Uncle Sam always spills his tea over (tío) everything.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for uncle?

languages.mnemonic: Under the train, it will only take a day to get back home (debajo).
languages.question: What does "debajo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: They formed a close unit, who needs a Dad? (Unidad).
languages.question: What is the English translation of "unidad"?

languages.mnemonic: Until they emerged from the dark side of the moon, the astronaut's view was as black as tar (hasta).
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "until"?

languages.mnemonic: "Look at us, getting all nostalgic (nos) at all these old photos."
languages.question: What does "nos" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I'll use the goose's feathers on my arm (usar) to fly.
languages.question: What does "usar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Make yourself useful and find who's stealing (útil) from me!
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "useful"?

languages.mnemonic: It is usual for me to find horror films a bit too alarming!
languages.question: What is another word for something that is habitual?

languages.mnemonic: When the sheep in the valley say "baa!" the kids shout "yay!" (valle).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el valle"?

languages.mnemonic: Valle is masculine, so it's el valle. Imagine a valley full of elephants.
languages.question: What does "el valle" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The value of her gold bar was lower (valor) since the price of gold had dropped dramatically.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for value?

languages.mnemonic: In order to vary the racecourse, they place barriers (variar) on some corners to change the route.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "variar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: It was the vegetable that he couldn't bear. "I'll do anything, just don't make me eat radishes!" (verdura)
languages.question: What does the term "verdura" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Verdura is feminine so it's la verdura. Imagine a lady that's half vegetable.
languages.question: What is "verdura" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Although it was very late, the moonlight made it easy (muy) to see.
languages.question: What does "muy" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I watch this video of a bee every day over (video) and over.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el video" en inglés?

languages.mnemonic: Video is masculine, so it's el video. Imagine a video of an elephant.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el video"?

languages.mnemonic: The view was great but the bees seemed to ta rget (vista) them.
languages.question: What does "la vista" mean?

languages.mnemonic: We went to visit the interior of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome but it was so busy by the altar (visitar), we couldn't get a good look.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "visitar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: In a loud voice, the headmaster told both (voz) boys to go to his office.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for "voice"?

languages.definition: volume (sound), but also refers to volume meaning size or quantity
languages.mnemonic: After turning up the volume and turning off the lights, both luminous (volumen) speakers shone out across the crowd.
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el volumen" en español?

languages.mnemonic: I had to vote for my favourite, but both tarts (votar) were delicious.
languages.question: What does "votar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The cat was happy to wait until the desperate rats (esperar) tried to escape from their hole.
languages.question: What is the Spanish verb for "wait"?

languages.mnemonic: The waitress had a camera that was much rarer (camarera) than any camera she had ever had, so she always wore it around her neck.
languages.question: What is the Spanish term for a waiter or waitress?

languages.mnemonic: It's hard to walk with a camel in your arms (caminar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "caminar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: On top of the wall pa read (pared) a story to me.
languages.question: What is "la pared" in English?

languages.mnemonic: "We want you" posters went up everywhere – they wanted more carers (querer) now!
languages.question: What does "querer" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: During the war, we had to get a ration (guerra) book.
languages.question: What does the term "guerra" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: She was so warm in her calico dress, she entered the pool to lower her temperature (caliente).
languages.question: What does "caliente" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: You need to wash your hair and lather it well so the barber (lavar) can cut it for you.
languages.question: What does the verb "lavar" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The wasps and the bees hated each other with a passion (avispa).
languages.question: What does the term "avispa" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We watch the world go by sitting on our veranda (ver).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ver" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Mixing the water with the special ingredient resulted in a goo...ah!
languages.question: What is "el agua"?

languages.mnemonic: The waterfall was spectacular – it cascaded (cascada) right down the side of the building.
languages.question: What is the translation of "la cascada" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Cascada is feminine, so it's la cascada. Imagine a lady going down a waterfall in a barrel.
languages.question: What is "la cascada"?

languages.mnemonic: The wave was huge, but it couldn't disturb us while we sipped our cola (ola).
languages.question: What does "la ola" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: We had no soap to wash the albatross (nosotros) after the oil spill.
languages.question: What does "nosotros/nosotras" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I felt weak when I realised my account had been debited, why did they steal (débil) from me?
languages.question: What does "débil" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What to wear to the yellow bar (llevar) was a big decision – she hoped she'd got it right!
languages.question: What does "llevar" mean in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The weather was terrible, so they put up a teepee temporarily (tiempo).
languages.question: What does "el tiempo" refer to in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: At the wedding, both dads (boda) had a dance-off.
languages.question: What is "la boda"?

languages.mnemonic: Boda is feminine, so it's la boda. Imagine a lady ruining a wedding.
languages.question: What is "la boda"?

languages.mnemonic: Wednesday is the day I get wed, and it's a miracle (miércoles) I ever managed to persuade him to marry me.
languages.question: What is the English translation of the Spanish word "miércoles"?

languages.mnemonic: He works 70 hours per week - that's seventy hours manacled (semana) to a desk.
languages.question: What does "semana" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: That weekend, despite a fiendish cold, he did the two-day seminar (fin de semana).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el fin de semana"?

languages.mnemonic: If I weigh myself and I'm too heavy, I have to pay the sergeant (pesar).
languages.question: What does the verb "pesar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The weight of the rucksack will affect her pace over (peso) the trial.
languages.question: What does "el peso" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Peso is masculine, so it's el peso. Imagine an elephant checking its weight on the bathroom scales.
languages.question: What does the term "el peso" refer to in English?

languages.mnemonic: From the west came a fierce storm and they had to send an S.O.S. to be taken (oeste) offboard.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "west"?

languages.mnemonic: In wet weather, most hats don't (mojado) protect you.
languages.question: What does "mojado" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: What came (qué) first, the chicken or the egg?
languages.question: How do you say "what" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: The wheel on the racing car came flying off; the runaway tyre causing damage (rueda) as it rolled down the track.
languages.question: What does the Spanish word "rueda" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: When she saw the thief she decided to use her taekwondo (cuando).
languages.question: What is the meaning of "cuando" in Spanish?

languages.mnemonic: When will she stop the thief? As soon as she kicks him with her taekwondo (cuándo).
languages.question: What does "¿cuándo?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: No matter where you go on your donkey day (donde) you will need your satnav.
languages.question: What is the meaning of the Spanish word "donde"?

languages.mnemonic: Where does your satnav take you on your donkey day's (dónde) out?
languages.question: What does "¿dónde?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: I don't know whether to go to the seaside (si) or the mountains in this hot weather.
languages.question: What does "si" mean in this context?

languages.mnemonic: She will choose the one which she loves the most, but both are equal (cual) in looks and kindness.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word "cual" used for when not asking a question?

languages.mnemonic: Which one should she choose? They were equal (cuál) in looks and kindness, but which one did she love the most?
languages.question: What does "¿cuál?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: While the farmer was asleep me and my family ate the entire raspberry (mientras) crop.
languages.question: What does the Spanish term "mientras" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Everywhere was white. He pulled a white blanket over himself and disappeared.
languages.question: What is the Spanish adjective for the color white?

languages.mnemonic: Dr Who couldn't get going until she used the key to the engine (Quien)?
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "who"?

languages.mnemonic: Who is the doctor putting the key in the engine (Quién)?
languages.question: What does "¿quién?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: If we picked our whole crop of strawberries, there would be enough to fill an entire aeroplane!
languages.question: What does "entero" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Whose is that? It's such a cool yoyo (cuyo).
languages.question: What does "cuyo/cuya" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Why did his trousers no longer fit? He'd got porky (por qué) because he'd been stuffing his face too much.
languages.question: What does "¿por qué?" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Not a wide fish, the anchovy (ancho) is in fact small and narrow.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "wide"?

languages.mnemonic: My wife especially dislikes posers (esposa).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "la esposa"?

languages.mnemonic: The wild animals loved the barbeque, but the salad bar they hated (salvaje).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "salvaje"?

languages.mnemonic: Want to win the lottery? This conman guarantees you will if you attend his seminar (ganar).
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "ganar" mean?

languages.mnemonic: The wind was so strong. She was being towed (viento) by the power kite.
languages.question: What is the Spanish word for "wind"?

languages.mnemonic: In the window there was a vent and the air coming through was like anaesthetic (ventana).
languages.question: What is "la ventana"?

languages.mnemonic: For the wine bar opening, they used a big bow to decorate the garden (bodega).
languages.question: What is "la bodega"?

languages.mnemonic: The wine is of the highest quality; the bee knows (vino) by the smell.
languages.question: What does "vino" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: Vino is masculine, so it's el vino. Imagine an elephant drinking a glass of wine.
languages.question: What is "vino"?

languages.mnemonic: The wing of the old plane came apart as it crash-landed (ala).
languages.question: What does "ala" mean in Latin?

languages.mnemonic: It must be winter, there's a nip in the air, no? (invierno).
languages.question: ¿Qué significa "el invierno"?

languages.mnemonic: With a wire trolley, the drunk stopped a cab then lay (cable) down in the back.
languages.question: What is "el cable"?

languages.mnemonic: I wish the waiter would take our order! The desserts are (desear) looking scrumptious.
languages.question: What does the Spanish verb "desear" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: With a little help from your friends you can conquer (con) your fears.
languages.question: What does the term "con" mean?

languages.mnemonic: Let he who is without sin (sin) cast the first stone.
languages.question: What does "sin" mean in Latin?

languages.mnemonic: The wolf collected loads of bones (lobo).
languages.question: What is "el lobo" in English?

languages.mnemonic: Lobo is masculine, so it's el lobo. Imagine an elephant chasing off a wolf.
languages.question: What does "el lobo" mean in English?

languages.mnemonic: The woman's hairstyle reminded people of a cow – they called her moo hair (mujer).

languages.mnemonic: He decided to write a poem about his girlfriend but she didn't like the way he described her (escribir).

languages.mnemonic: Their backyard is tiny - it's just a little patio (patio).

languages.mnemonic: This year, the annual yoga (año) contest returns to London.

languages.mnemonic: Año is masculine, so it's el año. Imagine an "elephant never forgets" calendar for the year.

languages.mnemonic: Yellow had been painted on the back of the armadillo (amarillo). Was it a coward?
