music.definition: Quietly
music.mnemonic: The tiny mouse played the piano so quietly so that she didn't wake anyone up.
music.question: What does "piano (P.)" mean in musical notation?

music.definition: Very quiet
music.mnemonic: Will she pee on this sumo (pianissimo)? The baby is very quiet, but she is full of surprises!
music.question: What does "pianissimo (PP.)" mean in music?

music.definition: A little
music.mnemonic: Their Thursday night poker (poco) game was a little treat after a hard week's scavenging.
music.question: What does "poco" mean?

music.definition: Gradually getting slower
music.mnemonic: As Dad approached the rally on a tandem (rallentando) he got gradually slower.
music.question: What does the term "rallentando" mean in music?

music.definition: Gradually getting slower
music.mnemonic: The roadworkers re-tarred and do (ritardando) repairs on the road but got gradually slower as they become tired.
music.question: What does ritardando mean in music?

music.definition: An immediate, or sudden, reduction in speed or tempo
music.mnemonic: Please believe that I have written you too (ritenuto) but the postal service strike may suddenly slow down my letter.
music.question: What does the musical term "ritenuto" mean?

music.definition: An immediate, or sudden, reduction in speed or tempo
music.mnemonic: She had written a new song with her toes (ritenuto), but it took ages; writing like this suddenly reduces the speed you can write.
music.question: What does the musical term "ritenuto" mean?

music.definition: Each note detached or separated from each other
music.mnemonic: The stack of cards were oh (staccato) so high but then suddenly tumbled and the cards became detached.
music.question: What does staccato mean in music?

music.definition: The rate of speed of a musical piece, indicated by directions like largo or allegro, and often by metronome markings.
music.mnemonic: He was so naughty he lost his temper (tempo) all the time.
music.question: What does tempo refer to in music?

music.definition: The speed at which you tap your foot along to the music.
music.mnemonic: You could see she had a temper going. Oh (tempo) this was going to be bad. Mum was at the front door, scowling, folded arms and tapping her foot.

music.definition: To be played in the style of a march
music.mnemonic: A lamb archer (alla marcia) marched into battle.
music.question: What does "Alla Marcia" mean in music?

music.definition: Becoming gradually slower
music.mnemonic: A large Gandalf outfit became overly (allargando) heavy in the rain and gradually slowed me down.
music.question: What does the musical term "allargando" mean?

music.definition: With
music.mnemonic: The theatre had columns made with concrete.
music.question: What does "Col" or "Con" mean in English?

music.definition: (to be performed) in a brisk or lively manner
music.mnemonic: I was conned. They took my motor and towed (con moto) it away briskly.
music.question: What does "con moto" mean in musical terminology?

music.definition: Played with a mute on the instrument
music.mnemonic: The concert I saw was deemed inaudible. No (con sordino) one could hear at the back because they were playing with mutes.
music.question: What does "con sordino" mean in music?

music.definition: And

music.question: What is the Italian word for "and"?

music.definition: To be performed expressively
music.mnemonic: I gave the huge espresso a heave-ho (espressivo) because I needed the room to perform expressively.
music.question: What does "espressivo" mean in music?

music.definition: Loud, then immediately quiet.
music.mnemonic: The battle at the fort was a (forte) loud one. The tiny mouse played the piano so quietly so that she didn't wake anyone up.
music.question: What does fortepiano mean in musical terms?

music.definition: Very slow
music.mnemonic: My grandad couldn't evade (grave) the police because he could only move very slowly.
music.question: What does the musical term "grave" mean?

music.definition: To be performed in a graceful, smooth or elegant style
music.mnemonic: The crowd was full of gratitude after seeing my oh-so (grazioso) graceful and elegant routine.
music.question: What does "grazioso" mean in music?

music.definition: Slow, steady
music.mnemonic: I drank so much lager that when I had to go (largo) home, I could only move slowly.
music.question: What does "largo" mean in musical terms?

music.definition: Used in an instruction, meaning 'but' (e.g., 'largo ma non trappo' means slowly but not too slowly).
music.mnemonic: Ma (ma) read a bedtime story but fell asleep halfway through.
music.question: What does "ma" mean in musical instructions?

music.definition: Less (proceeding another term to make the instruction clear)
music.mnemonic: The men over (meno) there are doing less than the others.
music.question: What does "meno" mean in musical terms?

music.definition: less movement (less quickly)
music.mnemonic: They are men made of moss over (meno mosso) there, no wonder there is less movement.
music.question: What does "meno mosso" mean in music?

music.definition: Very, much
music.mnemonic: I have a mole on my toe (molto) that I'd very much like to get rid of.
music.question: What does "molto" mean?

music.definition: Not too much (when following an instruction)
music.mnemonic: Although we were offered nonstop tropical cocktails over (non-troppo) our stay, I knew I should not drink too much.
music.question: What does "non-troppo" mean in music?

music.definition: More
music.mnemonic: The church pew (piu) was far more uncomfortable.
music.question: What does "piu" mean in music terms?

music.definition: more quickly
music.mnemonic: There was only one pew (piu) in the church, and the new priest demanded more.
music.question: What does "piu-mosso" mean in music?

music.definition: quickly
music.mnemonic: The moss is growing over (mosso) the lawn. Watch its movement and how quickly it spreads.
music.question: What does "mosso" mean in music?

music.definition: little by little
music.mnemonic: A is for apple and you should buy (by) one every day to keep healthy.
music.question: What does "poco a poco" mean?

music.definition: Fast (quicker than allegro)
music.mnemonic: After I felt something heavy press on my toe (presto), I jumped up fast.
music.question: What does the musical term "presto" mean?

music.definition: Without (to be performed without), used before another term to indicate that music should be performed without it.
music.mnemonic: I was sent sandwiches (senza) without any filling.
music.question: What does "senza" mean in musical terms?

music.definition: Lively (quickly)
music.mnemonic: I wouldn't eat the vividly green cheese (vivace). It looked too lively, so I ran away quickly.
music.question: What does "vivace" mean in music?

music.definition: Lively (Quick)
music.mnemonic: I'm a vegan, so if they only serve meat I'll vote (vivo) with my feet and get out quick.
music.question: What does "vivo" mean in a lively context?

music.definition: The performance by a singer or a singing group without instrumental accompaniment
music.mnemonic: All I need is a cap and an umbrella (a cappella) I don't need an instrument, I just need my voice.
music.question: What is the term for singing performed without instrumental accompaniment?

music.definition: A note or sequence of notes which precede the first strong beat of a musical phrase, particularly at the start of a piece.
music.mnemonic: I have a knack for ruining my sisters (anacrusis) performances by playing a strange sequence of notes at the start of the songs.
music.question: What is an anacrusis in music?

music.definition: Written notes and instructions within sheet music to assist the performer
music.mnemonic: A note stationed (annotation) over the notes of the sheet music gives extra instruction.
music.question: What is the purpose of annotation in sheet music?

music.definition: A vocal piece that has a special importance for a particular group of people or country, often performed on a special occasion
music.mnemonic: Annually, the thumbs (anthem) will sing a vocal piece that is special to them.
music.question: What is an anthem?

music.definition: Alternate call and response between different groups of singers or instruments
music.mnemonic: The ants in the symphony (antiphony) used alternating call and response between different instruments.
music.question: What is antiphony?

music.definition: An instruction given to string players to use the bow
music.mnemonic: For this section, arc over (arco) the strings using the bow.
music.question: What does the term "arco" instruct string players to do?

music.definition: A song for solo voice with an instrumental accompaniment, typically one in an opera or large piece of musical work
music.mnemonic: Are sounds going to reach up (aria) into the highest balcony of the opera house? Will one person singing overcome the orchestra and the distance? Yes is the answer.
music.question: What is an aria?

music.definition: Music that is not written or played in any key or system of scales
music.mnemonic: The ape was tone-deaf and always (atonal) performed out of key.
music.question: What does "atonal" describe in music?

music.definition: An adult male singing voice between tenor and bass
music.mnemonic: The bar had one tone (baritone) coming from the middle.
music.question: What is a baritone?

music.definition: Using the voice to produce musical and rhythmic sounds (e.g., drum beats, hi-hat or cymbal noises)
music.mnemonic: As I beat my opponent with my boxing (beat boxing) skills, he made a sound with his voice. It was quite rhythmic.
music.question: What is beat boxing?

music.definition: Unit of measurement used to measure the tempo of a piece of music
music.mnemonic: She beat her foot on the floor for a few minutes (beats per minute) and we used that beat as our tempo for the music.
music.question: What does "beats per minute" measure in music?

music.definition: The structure of a piece of music which is divided into two different sections
music.mnemonic: Don't buy this ordinary (binary) song, it only has two sections.
music.question: What is binary in music?

music.definition: A short instrumental solo, often improvised and used in pop, jazz or funk.
music.mnemonic: The rest of the musicians took a break (break) while the drummer did a short instrumental solo.
music.question: What is a break in music?

music.definition: A passage usually towards the end of a song where a soloist plays an elaborate and showy flourish.
music.mnemonic: The cadet has influenza (cadenza). She had to perform solo because no one would go near her, but at least she did it with a flourish.
music.question: What is a cadenza in music?

music.definition: A feature of instrumental and vocal music where the leader plays or sings a melody and the rest of the group plays or sings in response
music.mnemonic: The call of the songbird led to a response (call and response) from the others.
music.question: What is "call and response" in music?

music.definition: A musical piece in which a melody is imitated by one or more parts after a delay
music.mnemonic: The cannon (canon) was imitated by the drums after a short delay.
music.question: What is the definition of a canon in music?

music.definition: A social gathering with music and dancing that is associated with Scottish and Irish folk music.
music.mnemonic: Everyone came to leap (ceilidh) and dance to Scottish and Irish folk music at the social gathering.
music.question: What is a ceilidh?

music.definition: A part of a song that is repeated after each verse
music.mnemonic: There was only a core of us (chorus) that sang after each verse.
music.question: What is the chorus in a song?

music.definition: Musical notes which do not belong to the key of the piece they are played in
music.mnemonic: The chrome-plated notes were automatically (chromatic notes) removed, as they did not match the key of the music.
music.question: What are chromatic notes in music?

music.definition: To write or make a piece of music
music.mnemonic: My teacher was completely opposed (compose) to me writing music during class.
music.question: What does it mean to compose?

music.definition: A secondary melody that is sung or played simultaneously with the main melody
music.mnemonic: From the counter top they picked two different melodies (countermelody) by accident. They played the melodies at the same time and they sounded great.
keywords: played the melodies at the same time
music.question: What is a countermelody?

music.definition: The effect produced when two conflicting rhythms are heard together
music.mnemonic: The singer was cross because the rhythms (cross rhythm) that the drummers were playing were conflicting.
music.question: What is cross rhythm?

music.definition: Chords or notes which exist within a given key
music.mnemonic: While on a diet of gin and tonics (diatonic), the musician struggled to play chords and notes within a given key.
music.question: What does diatonic refer to in music theory?

music.definition: Notes that sound harsh or unpleasant when played together and at the same time; unpleasant sound
music.mnemonic: It was a disturbing and resonant (dissonant) sound that I found unpleasant.
music.question: What does "dissonant" mean in music?

music.definition: The alteration of an audio signal to create a fuzzy, gritty sound; most commonly applied to heavy metal rock guitars
music.mnemonic: I disturbed a large portion (distortion) of the neighbours while making a loud fuzzy sound with an amplified guitar.
music.question: What is distortion in the context of audio signals and heavy metal rock guitars?

music.definition: A harmonic effect or accompaniment where two notes are continuously sounded through most of a piece
music.mnemonic: The drones (drone) emit a harmonic effect continuously throughout the piece of music.
music.question: What is a drone in music?

music.definition: Used to describe the volume changes in a piece of music.
music.mnemonic: The sound of dynamite was mixed (dynamics) into the song. It added huge changes in volume.
music.question: What are dynamics in music?

music.definition: A group performance of two or more musicians
music.mnemonic: After putting on sombreros, the bulls (ensemble) performed as a group, playing instruments.
music.question: What is an ensemble?

music.definition: Short for equalisation, it's the lessening or boosting of different frequencies to add more bass or treble to a musical track.
music.mnemonic: Each queue (EQ) of people represents a different frequency. Lessening or boosting their size affects bass or treble.
music.question: What is EQ in the context of music production?

music.definition: A method of singing used by males to sing higher notes than their highest normal singing voice.
music.mnemonic: Wearing false hair and stiletto (falsetto) heels, the man joined a girl group and sang higher than the normal male vocal register.
music.question: What is falsetto in singing?

music.definition: A fusion genre is music that combines two or more styles.
music.mnemonic: The band did a few versions (fusion) in different styles and combined them.
music.question: What is a fusion genre in music?

music.definition: A pitch sliding from one note to another seamlessly
music.mnemonic: The dew glistened over (glissando) the pitch, making it very slippery. People were sliding from one side to another seamlessly.
music.question: What is a glissando in music?

music.definition: Refers to a rhythm that deviates from the straight beat of the music.
music.mnemonic: When carving a groove (groove) into the wood, I deviated from the straight line.
music.question: What does the term "groove" refer to in music?

music.definition: A repeated bass pattern that occurs throughout a composition, used by composers as a foundation for more complex work.
music.mnemonic: On the ground was a bass (ground bass) painted with a repeating pattern.
music.question: What is ground bass?

music.definition: An already ringing note is changed by placing down hard on another fret.
music.mnemonic: You don't have to use a hammer on (hammer on) the guitar; just press your finger onto the fretboard to cause a note to sound.
music.question: What is a guitar hammer on?

music.definition: An already ringing note is released by the player's finger to play a lower note on the same string.
music.mnemonic: Pull off a note you are holding down.
music.question: What is a guitar pull off?

music.definition: The combination of simultaneously sounded musical notes to produce a pleasing effect
music.mnemonic: When busking, they didn't find it hard to earn money (harmony). They combined to produce a pleasing sound.

music.definition: A short melodic phrase used to catch the listener's attention and make a song memorable
music.mnemonic: Captain Hook (hook) got up on stage and did a short melodic phrase. The way he looked made the song memorable.
music.question: What is a hook in music?

music.definition: The spontaneous and creative performance of musical ideas
music.mnemonic: She improved the songs with her ideas. It was sensational (improvisation) to watch her spontaneous and creative performance.
music.question: What is improvisation in music?

music.definition: The degree to which the notes of a piece of music are played or sung exactly in tune.
music.mnemonic: This international singing contest had one nation (intonation) which brought their own tuning forks. You just know they were going to be in tune.
music.question: What is intonation in music?

music.definition: Informal musical activity where musicians improvise together
music.mnemonic: The different musicians were all stuck in a traffic jam (jam) so decided to get out of their cars and improvise together.
music.question: What is a jam session?

music.definition: The scale on which the piece is based
music.mnemonic: On the keychain (key) were some scales.
music.question: What is the key in music?

music.definition: A short contrasting section in the middle of a pop song, usually eight bars in length.
music.mnemonic: The middle eight (middle eight) bars of the jail cell were a contrasting section.
music.question: What is the middle eight in a pop song?

music.definition: The move from one key to another
music.mnemonic: The model was told 'congratulations' (modulation) after leaping from one key to another.
music.question: What does modulation refer to in music?

music.definition: Musical symbols, notations and terminology
music.mnemonic: She spoke in a musical language (musical language) of only symbols and terminology.
music.question: What does "musical language" refer to?

music.definition: A device attached to a musical instrument which changes the instrument's tone quality or lowers its volume.
music.mnemonic: The mutant (mute) stuffed things into his trumpet to reduce the volume and change the tone.
music.question: What is a mute in music?

music.definition: The embellishments of a melody, either by adding notes or modifying rhythms
music.mnemonic: The shiny ornaments (ornaments) were hung on the music to embellish the melody.
music.question: What are ornaments in music?

music.definition: The process of adding additional tracks or sounds to a recording
music.mnemonic: Her trainset was over double (overdub) the size of mine, and she's still adding additional tracks.
music.question: What is the process called when you add additional tracks or sounds to a recording?

music.definition: A guitar technique where the sound of the guitar is muted by resting the back of the picking hand across the strings while playing
music.mnemonic: To remember what palm muting is, it's essentially in the name: Rest the side of your palm on the strings you are picking to create a muted sound
music.question: What is palm muting in guitar playing?

music.definition: The lowness or highness of a note, such as bass (low) and treble (high)
music.mnemonic: Where to pitch the tent? High up or low down? Look at the notes in the guide.
music.question: What is pitch in music?

music.definition: A combination of two or more rhythms played simultaneously while moving at the same tempo/pulse/beat
music.mnemonic: We know what poly means and we know what rhythm means. Poly - Many And Rhythm - A pattern of sounds of different lengths. So Polyrhythm must be two or more rhythms (played simultaneously).
music.question: What is polyrhythm?

music.definition: Many
music.mnemonic: Polly (poly) the parrot had many friends.
music.question: What does the prefix "poly" mean?

music.definition: A simple chord played on a guitar, typically at loud volumes with high levels of distortion
music.mnemonic: The amp's power cord (power chord) was enormous which allowed me to play a simple cord at a very loud volume.
music.question: What is a power chord in guitar playing?

music.definition: Rhythmic spoken word
music.mnemonic: She rapped (rap) on the door and decided the rhythm was so excellent she would recite words rapidly and rhythmically in time to it.
music.question: What is rap known for?

music.definition: Beats that are repeated a particular number of times within a tempo/beat/pulse; a pattern of sounds of different lengths.
music.mnemonic: Repeat 'What is rhythm' or 'A pattern of sounds of different lengths' three times at a set beat to create a rhythm.
music.question: What is rhythm?

music.definition: A short, repeated musical pattern used in popular music; short melodic phrase
music.mnemonic: "No riff-raff (riff) allowed" I was told after playing a short melodic phrase, and then I was thrown out.
music.question: What is a riff in music?

music.definition: The temporary abandonment of strict tempo, allowing the performer to be more flexible with their pace.
music.mnemonic: He rues the day he threw the baton over (rubato) to him, because the orchestra then kept going away from the strict tempo.
music.question: What does rubato mean in musical performance?

music.definition: A number of notes arranged in a specific order of their pitch (frequency).
music.mnemonic: I scaled (scale) the wall using the notes arranged in a specific order.
music.question: What is a scale in music?

music.definition: The singing of nonsense sounds and syllables instead of words
music.mnemonic: Everyone scattered (scat) when she started singing nonsense sounds and syllables.
music.question: What is scat in music?

music.definition: A piece of music that has been written specifically for a film or theatrical production.
music.mnemonic: The silent movie showed someone scoring (score) a goal, and the live orchestra accompanied this with a musical composition written specifically for the film.
music.question: What is a score in the context of film or theatrical production?

music.definition: A rhythm consisting of a short note followed by a long one.
music.mnemonic: He asked for more scotch and snapped (scotch snap) his fingers. He wanted a short glass followed by a long glass.
music.question: What is a Scotch Snap in music?

music.definition: A DJing technique where two decks are required. One deck plays a track whilst on the other, rhythmic patterns are produced by pushing the record forwards and backwards.
music.mnemonic: The cat was scratching (scratching) the record in a rhythmic pattern.
music.question: What is the DJing technique called where two decks are used, one for playing a track and the other for creating rhythmic patterns by moving the record?

music.definition: Where a passage of music is repeated at a higher or lower pitch.
music.mnemonic: I can see the different frequencies (sequence) of the repeated passage of music, one higher and one lower, even in the British National Anthem.
music.question: What is a sequence in music?

music.definition: A stringed instrument used in Indian music that has a long neck, a round body and moveable frets
music.mnemonic: You must sit down to play this guitar-like (sitar) instrument, just like these Indian musicians with long necks and round bodies.
music.question: What is a sitar?

music.definition: A bass guitar playing technique which involves both pulling up and off with the fingers, while 'slapping' the strings, with the thumb to create a musical, percussive sound.
music.mnemonic: To remember what slap bass is, it's essentially in the name: Slapping the string with your thumb and then pulling the string with your index finger creates a percussive sound along with the note that is fretted further down the neck.
music.question: What is slap bass?

music.definition: A guitar technique in which a metal or glass tube placed on the finger is slid across the strings to create a glissando effect.
music.mnemonic: To remember what slide guitar is, it's essentially in the name: Sliding a metal or glass tube along the guitar strings while plucking them creates a sound that can continually shift between notes.
music.question: What is slide guitar?

music.definition: A musical piece played or sung by one person, with or without accompaniment.
music.mnemonic: The bridge was so low (solo), it was a good job he was on his own.
music.question: What is a solo in music?

music.definition: Highest singing voice for a young boy or woman
music.mnemonic: The soap ran out. 'No!'(soprano) she screamed as high as she could.
music.question: What is a soprano?

music.definition: Refers to music in which every verse and every chorus is the same tune. The tune is repeated throughout the song.
music.mnemonic: She had a strop that was horrific (strophic). Every time I tried to put other music on she just wanted the same tune again and again for every verse and chorus.
music.question: What does "strophic" mean in music?

music.definition: A rhythm style where a single straight beat is relaxed into a more triplet feel.
music.mnemonic: On the swing (swing) the triplets feel full of joy.
music.question: What is the rhythm style in music where a single straight beat is relaxed into a more triplet feel called?

music.definition: A pair of small different sized hand drums used in Indian music
music.mnemonic: The stories in the tabloids say that I love (tabla) to play Indian music with small hand drums.
music.question: What is a tabla?

music.definition: Highest adult male voice
music.mnemonic: Ten or (tenor) 100% was the highest score and he wouldn't accept anything less.
music.question: What is the highest adult male voice known as?

music.definition: The structure of a piece of music which is divided into three sections
music.mnemonic: Turn a really (ternary) complex song into a simple one by using a structure of three sections.
music.question: What is a ternary structure in music?

music.definition: The perceived sound quality of a musical note from a voice or instrument
music.mnemonic: This tambourine (timbre) has an odd sound quality.
music.question: What is timbre?

music.definition: A chord of three different notes
music.mnemonic: The tricycle had (triad) three different wheels.
music.question: What is a triad in music?

music.definition: Two adjacent notes that are played rapidly one after another a few times.
music.mnemonic: The trilby (trill) went back and forth between the two notes a few times rapidly. They each wanted to wear the hat.
music.question: What is a trill?

music.definition: Playing two or more musical parts which are either identical or separated by an octave simultaneously.
music.mnemonic: While on unicycles, the two identical sons (unison) sang the same tunes.
music.question: What does unison mean in music?

music.definition: Repeating a musical pattern as accompaniment
music.mnemonic: The vampire bat kept pinging (vamping) off the window pane. He just kept repeating this pattern.
music.question: What does the term vamping mean in music?

music.definition: A rapid and slight back and forth variation in pitch when singing or playing an instrument; a vibration of pitch.
music.mnemonic: I know it's vulgar, but if a bra that's stretch is plucked, it makes a wonderful tone (vibrato). You can see it vibrate.
music.question: What is vibrato?

music.definition: A set of notes of a lower register played on each beat of the bar, usually with a repetitive melodic pattern
music.mnemonic: The walking bass (walking bass) made a sound every time it took a step. Which made it a very repetitive beat and being a bass very deep sound.
music.question: What is a walking bass?

music.definition: An effect that simulates the sensation of sound bouncing off the surfaces in a confined environment. It creates a dense collection of echoes that blend together, adding depth and warmth to a sound.
music.mnemonic: Think of reverb as reversing and bouncing (reverb) around a room.
music.question: What is reverb in audio production?

music.definition: A musical interval consisting of 8 notes. The eighth note in the scale is considered a repetition of the first but in a higher register.
music.mnemonic: One of the eight tentacles of the octopus waved (octave) while the others held up the seven letters, A to G.
music.question: What is an octave in music?

music.definition: On a piano, the C key is located to the left of the D key. Notes are organized using the letters A B C D E F G.
music.mnemonic: If we can imagine the big set of three black notes is Grandma's house and the smaller set of two black notes is the dog house. Inside the dog house is the dog and 'D' is for dog. Inside Grandma's house is Grandma's famous apple pies just freshly baked, 'G' for Grandma and 'A' for apple pies.
music.question: Where is the C key located on a piano?

music.definition: A set of five horizontal lines used in music notation, where each line and space represents a different musical pitch.
music.mnemonic: "Please stay!" – But she just gave them a wave (stave), even the staff couldn't get her down as she climbed up the 5 horizontal fencing lines.
music.question: What is the term for the set of five horizontal lines used in music notation?

music.definition: Also known as the G-clef, it is used to indicate the pitch of written notes.
music.mnemonic: Think of treble (treble clef) trouble. Treble the trouble to draw than the bass clef. Treble the amount of curves than the bass clef. Imagine 'three (treble) wise gorillas' for G clef.
music.question: What is the treble clef?

music.definition: The bass clef is also known as the F clef.
music.mnemonic: Think of the double bass (bass clef) being played by a frog (F clef).
music.question: What is another name for the bass clef?

music.definition: The notes on the lines of the treble clef staff are EGBDF.
music.mnemonic: Every Good Boy Deserves Football.
music.question: What are the notes on the lines of the treble clef staff?

music.definition: The notes in the spaces of the treble clef staff are FACE.
music.mnemonic: FACE.
music.question: What notes are represented by the spaces in the treble clef?

music.definition: The notes on the lines of the bass clef staff are DBDFA.
music.mnemonic: Green Buses Drive Fast Always.
music.question: What are the notes on the lines of the bass clef staff?

music.definition: The notes in the spaces of the bass clef staff are ACEG.
music.mnemonic: All Cows Eat Grass.
music.question: What are the notes in the bass clef spaces?

music.definition: (USA: whole note)
music.mnemonic: Dragged out of the hole (whole note) is a lady who has just finished her freediving session but she is only semi breathing (semibreve).
music.question: What is the American term for semibreve?

music.definition: (USA: half note)
music.mnemonic: But imagine that the 'd' for dog is half dog and half Minnie Mouse (minim).
music.question: What is the American term for a half note in music?

music.definition: (USA quarter note)
music.mnemonic: But a quarter of the golf club players (one of the players) has been using a croquet (crotchety) mallet instead of a club.
music.question: What is the musical term for a quarter note in the USA?

music.definition: (USA: eighth note)
music.mnemonic: Imagine the bird landing and grabbing an 8-ball (eighth note) from a pool table but the bird is so big it causes an earthquake (quaver).
music.question: What is a quaver called in the USA?

music.definition: (USA: eighth note)
music.mnemonic: If we can remember a quaver then a semiquaver is not quite a quaver, so it is the next one down on the musical note tree.
music.question: What is a semiquaver (USA sixteenth note) in relation to a quaver (USA eighth note)?

music.definition: Musical time signatures are the fractions at the beginning of each stave just after the treble clef and bass clef.
music.mnemonic: It's such a beautiful fraction. It's about time you put your signature (time signature) on the painting.
music.question: What are musical time signatures?

music.definition: The most common time signature in music, represented as 4/4.
music.mnemonic: The 𝄴 symbol stands for the 'c' in common time (the most common time signature).
music.question: What is common time in music?

music.definition: Half the common time, half of the 4/4 time signature.
music.mnemonic: The 𝄴 symbol cut in half stands for half the common time (half the most common time signature).
music.question: What is the meaning of half time in music?

music.definition: A mechanical or digital device used by musicians to keep a consistent tempo, typically marked by a ticking sound.
music.mnemonic: I met a gnome (metronome) swinging on a metronome.
music.question: What is a metronome used for in music?

music.definition: An accidental modifies the pitch of a musical note. The three most common accidentals are the flat, sharp, and natural.
music.mnemonic: I accidentally (accidental) hit a naturally sharp Rock and got a flat tyre.
music.question: What are accidentals in music?

music.definition: A symbol that indicates you should play the note one step up from the indicated note.
music.mnemonic: The sharp sign (which is very similar to a hashtag sign) looks like a ladder that you can climb up i.e. go up one.
music.question: What does the sharp sign indicate in music notation?

music.definition: A symbol in music notation indicating that the note should be played one semitone lower.
music.mnemonic: The b (♭) stands for back i.e go back one.
music.question: What does a flat sign indicate in music notation?

music.definition: It indicates that you should play the note without any sharps or flats. It cancels out any previous accidentals.
music.mnemonic: The natural sign can be split into a b and a q which stands for 'ban and quit' the last flat or sharp.
music.question: What does a natural sign indicate in music notation?

music.definition: A key signature is a set of sharp (♯) and flat (♭) symbols, placed immediately after the clef sign.
music.mnemonic: All of these keys are sharp and fit into the locks of flats.
music.question: What is a key signature in music notation?

music.term: Order of the key signatures – sharps
music.definition: The order of the key signatures for sharps is F C G D A E B.
music.mnemonic: Fat Cats Go Down Alleys Eating Bacon.
music.question: What is the order of the key signatures for sharps?

music.definition: The order of the sharps are always F C G D A E B.
music.mnemonic: Fat Cats Go Down Alleys Eating Bacon.
music.question: What is the order of sharps in music notation?

music.definition: A minor key is determined by going down a minor third from the major key.
music.mnemonic: "Which way?" said the miner. "Down the 3rd," said the other miner (go down a minor third).
music.question: What determines the structure of a minor key in music?

music.definition: The necessary sharps and flats to know for a grade 1 music exam.
music.mnemonic: 'Cars Going Downhill Fast'
music.question: What are the sharps and flats for a Grade 1 music exam?

music.definition: The first note of the scale. Whatever the scale is called, that is the first note of the scale, and therefore the tonic.
music.mnemonic: Give yourself a tonic and you will feel better for the first time in ages.
music.question: What is the tonic in music theory?

music.definition: Any combination of two or more notes together
music.mnemonic: Quasimodo, pull those two cords together at the same time.
music.question: What is a chord in music?

music.definition: A group of three notes that form a chord.
music.mnemonic: A triangle – add (triad) them up and there are three corners.
music.question: What is a triad in music?

music.definition: A group of three notes starting on the tonic, composed of the first (tonic), third, and fifth notes of a given scale played simultaneously.
music.mnemonic: To remember this, recall the following: Tonic triad starts on the tonic note.
music.question: What is a tonic triad?

music.definition: The metal strip on the fingerboard of a guitar; the area behind it towards the headstock is known as that fret.
music.mnemonic: Imagine your fingers when bored (fingerboard) threatening (fret) you.
music.question: What is a fret on a guitar?

music.definition: A pickguard is a shield for your guitar. It prevents scratches and wear from aggressive strumming.
music.mnemonic: If you use the pick too hard (pickguard) you can get a hole in the guitar so you should have a pickguard.
music.question: What is the purpose of a pickguard on a guitar?

music.definition: The bridge attaches the strings to the body of a guitar using bridge pins, while the saddle is the strip of hard material that lifts the strings off the top of the guitar face.
music.mnemonic: From this vantage point on the bridge we can now saddle up the six horses (six saddles).
music.question: What role do the bridge and saddle play on a guitar?

music.definition: A small piece of material that lifts the strings off the top of the guitar face, fitting between the headstock and the frets, at the end of the fingerboard.
music.mnemonic: The nut was at the end of her finger and was stuck because she screwed it on when she was bored. (Nut at the end of the fingerboard).
music.question: What is the guitar nut?

music.term: Order of the strings on a guitar
music.definition: The order of the strings from a guitarist's point of view is E B G D A E.
music.mnemonic: Every Body Gets Dinner At Eight
music.question: What is the order of the strings on a guitar from a guitarist's point of view?

music.definition: The order of strings on a guitar tuned to standard tuning.
music.mnemonic: Every Body Gets Dinner At Eight (E B G D A E).
music.question: What is the guitar string order in standard tuning?

music.definition: To change the pitch of a musical piece up or down while keeping the space between the notes the same
music.mnemonic: Transport your posies (transpose) to the window display you can move them up or down, but keep the space between them the same.
music.question: What is transposing in music?

art.definition: Swiss artist known for creating abstract, tall, slender sculptures.
art.mnemonic: His sculptures were too small so they were jacked up so they met me (Giacometti) at eye level, but in so doing they were stretched and became tall and slender.
art.question: Who was Alberto Giacometti?

art.definition: Carefully balanced wire hanging sculptures that move even in the lightest breeze, known as mobiles.
art.mnemonic: If cold air (Calder) blows through the art museum, the hanging sculptures (mobiles) will move around.
art.question: What type of art is Alexander Calder famous for creating?

art.definition: Land artist and sculptor involving natural materials
art.mnemonic: He used hands on the land (Andy) that gave a golden opportunity to show how worthy (Goldsworthy) natural materials are as an artistic medium.
art.question: Who is Andy Goldsworthy?

art.definition: Famous for taking basic items like Campbell's Tomato Soup cans and turning them into artwork.
art.mnemonic: He used his hands (Andy) to carry back bags of Campbell's Tomato Soup cans but wore a hole (Warhol) in the bag.
art.question: Who was famous for turning basic items like Campbell's Tomato Soup cans into artwork?

art.definition: Founder of impressionist sculpture. Created famous sculptures like The Thinker and The Kiss.
art.mnemonic: A gust of wind blew off all of his clothes and so he sat down by the road and had a think (The Thinker) about his situation.
art.question: Who was Auguste Rodin?

art.definition: A world-renowned graffiti artist and political activist known for creating the most expensive stencil art.
art.mnemonic: On the South Bank of the River Thames, or on the Palestine West Bank wall, or known for defacing banknotes (Banksy).
art.question: Who is Banksy?

art.definition: Modern sculpture using curves and string.
art.mnemonic: Barbara Hepworth – Barbed wire and hemp didn't work but string did. She tried barbed (Barbara) wire across the stone, she tried hemp but that wasn't worthwhile (Hepworth) either – but string was just perfect!
art.question: Who was Barbara Hepworth?

art.definition: Book illustrator featuring human-like watercolour animals.
art.mnemonic: Be it rabbits up to tricks (Beatrix) or just pottering (Potter) around a garden, her watercolour animals in her novels became world-famous.
art.question: Who was Beatrix Potter?

art.definition: The greatest painter who used foreshortening, chiaroscuro, and real people in his paintings.
art.mnemonic: Caravans where people have had a go (Caravaggio) at painting religious stories on the sides.
art.question: Who was Caravaggio?

art.definition: Large-scale, site-specific environmental installations.
art.mnemonic: Imagine Christopher (Christo) Columbus standing talking to a janitor with a bin that has been clawed (Jeanne-Claude) and suddenly they are wrapped.
art.question: What kind of art installations are Christo and Jeanne-Claude known for?

art.definition: Bright patterns and art deco feel on ceramic (clay) pots.
art.mnemonic: She clad clay in bright risky (Clarice) patterns. Sales nearly dropped off the cliff (Cliff) but her ceramics went the other way and became extremely successful.
art.question: Who was Clarice Cliff and what is she known for in ceramics?

art.definition: Painted the same scene at different times of the day in an impressionist style.
art.mnemonic: He clawed (Claude) himself out of bed early on Mon(day) (Monet) morning so that he could set his easel up ready to paint a field of haystacks at different times of the day.
art.question: Who was Claude Monet?

art.definition: Famous for preserving animals in formaldehyde in glass showcases and creating spot and spin paintings.
art.mnemonic: The day they put me on (Damien) show in art museums, I burst onto the scene taking animal bodies from their hearse (Hirst) and popping them into a glass showcase full of formaldehyde.
art.question: Who is Damien Hirst?

art.definition: Painting people in an impressionist style
art.mnemonic: In a gallery, head towards (Éduard) the paintings of a man and a (Manet) woman in an impressionist style.
art.question: Who was Édouard Manet?

art.definition: Famous for aboriginal art of dots and stripes.
art.mnemonic: When I go to war I paint. Many of her paintings look like a view from an aeroplane that has dropped hundreds of bombs onto the landscape.
art.question: Who is Emily Kame Kngwarreye?

art.definition: A Mexican artist known for self-portraits showing emotion, influenced by Mexican culture.
art.mnemonic: Freed (Frida) from an electric streetcar accident where loads (Kahlo) of people died.
art.question: Who was Frida Kahlo?

art.definition: Pointillism and breaking of component colours down into separate colours
art.mnemonic: The jaw (Georges) of the sewer rat (Seurat) spat out dots onto the canvas.
art.question: Who is Georges Seurat?

art.definition: Gilded in gold, art nouveau portraits with symbolism.
art.mnemonic: The gust of (Gustav) wind made the gold he used shimmer. He clearly never skimped (Klimt) on gold.
art.question: Who was Gustav Klimt?

art.definition: Created artwork with colourful blocks of colour, scissor art, and the art movement called "fauves."
art.mnemonic: As he lay on his mattress, it was easier (Matisse) to cut out shapes with scissors than to do full-scale artwork. He even cut out a hen (Henri).
art.question: Who was Henri Matisse?

art.definition: An art movement led by Matisse known as "fauvism," which translates from French to English as wild beasts.
art.mnemonic: To connect fauves to mats (Matisse) imagine a foe that roves (a wild beast) trying to get into the house past the mattress (Matisse).
art.question: What was the art movement led by Matisse known as "wild beasts" in English?

art.definition: Sculptor known for abstract large sculptures of stones, bronze, or wood, usually depicting mother and child with smooth curves and hollow spaces with very little shape.
art.mnemonic: Moore – more? No, less! Less shape to the sculpture. He didn't do more (Moore) shape. His sculptures have less detail but more curves and hollows.
art.question: Who was Henry Moore?

art.definition: An artist known for drip art, a leading force in abstract expressionism.
art.mnemonic: When thinking of Jackson think Jack the Dripper.
art.question: Who was Jackson Pollock?

art.definition: Abstract self portraits of bright and dark contrasting colours with a crown in the picture.
art.mnemonic: A basket of art (Basquiat) carried Basquiat around whilst he wore a yellow crown. To remember that it was also Jean Michel imagine John the Baptist carrying the basket and the basket is covered in shells. John the Baptist is saying look at me and my shells (Michel).
art.question: What characterizes the artwork of Jean Michel Basquiat?

art.definition: Pop culture sculptures, famous for stainless steel balloon animals in a kitsch style.
art.mnemonic: A chef (Jeff) he was not, but creating cool cartoon balloon (Koons) sculptures that looked like joined-up sausages was his style.
art.question: Who is Jeff Koons?

art.definition: Surrealist, colourful with lines coming out of shapes that look like a biro made them.
art.mnemonic: One (Joan) pen was always used, a mere biro (Miró) in his paintings.
art.question: Who was Joan Miró?

art.definition: Keith Haring was an artist known for combining graffiti and pop culture, characterized by bold black silhouettes and vibrant, limited color palettes.
art.mnemonic: In his work, people are hairless and ringed (Haring) by a thick silhouette line.
art.question: Who was Keith Haring?

art.definition: Famous for painting industrial scenes with no shadows and no weather effects, using only five colors.
art.mnemonic: His pictures were far from flowery (Lowry), being mostly stark industrial scenes with crowds of featureless people. To remember the L. S. stands for Laurence Stephen think: People in the scenes look like lots of ants (Laurence) and some of the streets were steep and uneven (Stephen).
art.question: Who was Laurence Stephen Lowry?

art.definition: An artist known for paintings of large rectangles of color, blurred at the edges, part of abstract expressionism.
art.mnemonic: A mark (Mark) with a bit of froth and bold colours (Rothko).
art.question: Who was Mark Rothko?

art.definition: Bright childlike depictions of her Canadian surroundings
art.mnemonic: Her house looked like it had been mauled (Maud) and was like a Lewis (Lewis) Carroll Mad Hatter's tea party.
art.question: What style of art is Maud Lewis known for?

art.definition: Creator of cubism in paintings, sculpture, ceramics, and collages. A key figure in modern art.
art.mnemonic: You have to peek at them in so (Picasso) many ways to realise the skill of his cubist paintings.
art.question: Who was Pablo Picasso?

art.definition: One of the greatest portrait artists ever, known for his realistic self-portraits and capturing various emotions.
art.mnemonic: RememBer he could paint portraits of people being tyrants, tolerant, arrogant, errant, ignorant, migrant, itinerant (Rembrandt).
art.question: Who was Rembrandt Van Rijn?

art.definition: Bright and bold, Ben Day comic strip paintings
art.mnemonic: Licked on tons of dots and was a style that came to shine (Lichtenstein).
art.question: Who is Roy Lichtenstein?

art.definition: A system invented to increase the range of colours available to newspaper printing, clear from a distance but look like tiny dots close up.
art.mnemonic: He spent all day (Ben Day) toying (Roy) where to place each of the dots.
art.question: What are Ben Day dots?

art.definition: Spanish surrealist exploring subconscious imagery
art.mnemonic: If he salvaged a door he would still be a darling
art.question: Who was Salvador Dalí?

art.definition: Artist known for her autobiographical and confessional work
art.mnemonic: Her art leaves a trace (Tracey) of her self and could be described as art that's not very feminine (Emin).
art.question: Who is Tracey Emin?

art.definition: Noted for portraying beauty, emotion, and color; known for using thick application of paint called impasto.
art.mnemonic: VINCENT VAN GOGH – Used a van to go over his paintings. You will be convinced (Vincent) that he used a van to go (Van Gogh) over his paintings to get thick lines.
art.question: Who was Vincent Van Gogh?

art.definition: An artist most famous for designs of patterns for internal furnishings, particularly wallpaper.
art.mnemonic: I'm willing to say that this snake not only has more hiss (William Morris) but more pattern too.
art.question: Who was William Morris?

art.definition: A way of presenting a three-dimensional object in 2D by applying a 30 degree angle to its sides.
art.mnemonic: I so loved it when I met the magician who did this trick (isometric) where all the drawings were turned into three dimensional models.
art.question: What is an isometric drawing?

art.definition: The visible effect that perspective has on shapes.
art.mnemonic: These four shapes look shorter when (foreshortening) they are pushed over.
art.question: What is foreshortening in art?

art.definition: A guideline in art and photography for creating balanced compositions by dividing the image into nine equal parts using two vertical and two horizontal lines.
art.mnemonic: There was an Englishman, an Irishman and a Scotsman... "Where is the Irishman?" asked the Englishman. "We are only allowed two," said the Scotsman.
art.question: What is the Rule of Thirds in art and photography?

art.definition: The colour wheel primary colours are yellow, blue, and red.
art.mnemonic: Think of primary school kids creating the scenery for a school production of 'The Wizard of Oz'. They are creating the Yellow Brick Road and getting paint everywhere.
art.question: What are the primary colours on the colour wheel?

art.definition: The colour wheel secondary colours are orange, green and purple.
art.mnemonic: When I went to secondary school, I was allowed to go by bus, but it kept breaking down and the bus driver was always shouting: 'OK kids, GET (green) OUT (orange) and PUSH (purple)!'
art.question: What are the secondary colours on the colour wheel?

art.definition: One of six primary and secondary colours on a colour wheel. They are the underlying base colours for a mixture and the dominant colour family.
art.mnemonic: That's a huge (hues) rainbow! I can see all the colours: red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple.
art.question: What is a hue in the context of a colour wheel?

art.definition: Refers to the surface quality in a work of art. It can be physical or perceived texture.
art.mnemonic: Text your (texture) friend asking her to name her five favourite surface qualities, and this is what she might reply.
art.question: What does texture refer to in a work of art?

art.definition: Art that does not represent a tree, or a person, or something. Instead, it uses shapes, colours, forms, and gestures.
art.mnemonic: The absence of anything to distract (abstract) is the key to abstract art. That is, there is no solid form you recognise.
art.question: What is abstract art?

art.definition: A device using compressed air to spray a liquid such as paint or ink.
art.mnemonic: Her hairbrush (airbrush) sprayed colour onto her hair - she sprayed on a different colour every day.
art.question: What is an airbrush?

art.definition: The positioning of visual elements so they line up in a composition, be it text or an image.
art.mnemonic: They were supposed to be in a line, it wasn't meant to be all over the place.
art.question: What is alignment in design?

art.definition: Already existing light surrounding a subject, whether natural or artificial, as long as it's continuous.
art.mnemonic: I am being lent some light (ambient light) but the light already present is all I need.
art.question: What is ambient light?

art.definition: Excessive garnishes but in a humorous, knowing way
art.mnemonic: The big American fridge-freezer in the kitchen (American kitsch) is so excessively garish, it's almost funny.
art.question: What is American Kitsch known for?

art.definition: The early phase of cubism, from about 1908 to 1912. The subject was viewed from multiple viewpoints and recreated in fragmented and overlapping shapes.
art.mnemonic: An annual literary and cultural event was being advertised on cubes and prisms (Analytical Cubism) that could be seen from many angles and viewpoints.
art.question: What is Analytical Cubism?

art.definition: Making successive images by drawing or photographing puppets or models in different positions to create the illusion of movement when the images are shown in sequence.
art.mnemonic: Walt Disney's animal creations (animation) were once the most popular moving images in the world.
art.question: What is animation?

art.definition: The technique where one fabric is layered or applied on-top of another and secured in place by hand or machine-stitching.
art.mnemonic: The application (applique) of one piece of material on another can give beautiful results.
art.question: What is applique?

art.definition: A technique in etching to create tonal areas of shade resembling ink washes. It entails exposing a copper plate to acid around a layer of melted granulated resin.
art.mnemonic: The water in the aqueduct was tinted (aquatint) after she washed acid and granulated resin off her copper plates to reveal a watercolour effect.
art.question: What is aquatint?

art.definition: A rigid framework, often wood or steel, used to support a sculpture or large work while it is being made.
art.mnemonic: Instead of my arm, I'm going to use a structure (armature) to hold up the sculpture.
art.question: What is an armature used for in sculpture?

art.definition: Decorative art style of the 1920's and 1930's, characterised by bold lines, strong colours and geometric shapes.
art.mnemonic: She specialised in art decoration (Art Deco) with bold lines and strong colours.
art.question: What is the Art Deco style known for?

art.definition: Art that is made by assembling miscellaneous objects which are often scavenged by the artist.
art.mnemonic: The artist assembled the objects to form an image (assemblage). The objects had been scavenged from the beach.
art.question: What is assemblage in art?

art.definition: Ideas, styles and methods which are original or modern in comparison to the period in which they happen.
art.mnemonic: She always had an avatar on guard (avant-garde) to make sure no one stole her ideas, styles and methods for leading-edge art.
art.question: What is avant-garde?

art.definition: Lighting from behind the subject.
art.mnemonic: From the back of the subject came the lighting (backlighting).
art.question: What is backlighting?

art.definition: Sculpture in which figures project only slightly from a background, as on a coin.
art.mnemonic: The basset hound relieved (bas-relief) itself on the sculpture where figures only slightly project.
art.question: What is bas-relief?

art.definition: The application of hot wax onto cloth to create a pattern or design. When dye is applied, the waxed area resists the color, allowing for intricate patterns.
art.mnemonic: The bat was seeking (batik) a way to wax its wings.
art.question: What is batik?

art.definition: A method of printing, usually on fabric, using carved wooden printing blocks.
art.mnemonic: The block of wood was used to print a beautiful pattern on the cloth.
art.question: What is block print?

art.definition: The typeface used in the main text of printed matter
art.mnemonic: Her body type was pear-shaped, and there was plenty of interest in the main text of the tattoos that adorned her skin.
art.question: What is body type in the context of printed material?

art.definition: The decorative design or edge of a surface, line, or area that forms its outer boundary
art.mnemonic: We put a border guard here to stop people going over the edge of the world.
art.question: What is a border in design?

art.definition: A Japanese textile created or reworked using patchwork, mending, and stitching processes.
art.mnemonic: I would love to borrow (boro) your jacket! The colours and different textiles in the patchwork are perfect in their imperfection.
art.question: What is Boro?

art.definition: The process of creating a unique name and image for a product.
art.mnemonic: In branding the cow, she used a unique name and image each time.
art.question: What is branding?

art.definition: A construction or artwork using only found materials.
art.mnemonic: I found a brick which was covered in camouflage (bricolage) and it made a perfect centrepiece for my artwork made from found materials.
art.question: What is bricolage?

art.definition: A designer's brief, or creative brief, is what a client will give to a designer to help them come up with a creative solution.
art.mnemonic: The client was brief and that was all the designer had to help her come up with a creative solution.
art.question: What is a brief in the context of design?

art.definition: The way paint is applied in a painting, describing the texture of the paint surface applied with a brush.
art.mnemonic: She used a yard brush to work (brushwork) the colour into her huge canvas, leaving distinct lines in the paint. It showed great texture on the paint surface.
art.question: What is brushwork in painting?

art.definition: Unbleached cotton
art.mnemonic: The calibre of his coat (calico) was very poor - it was only made of unbleached cotton.
art.question: What is calico?

art.definition: A technique used by sculptors using tools to cut or scrape away a solid material such as stone or wood.
art.mnemonic: The car I'm giving (carving) you was made by cutting away material from a solid block of stone.
art.question: What is the sculpting technique called carving?

art.definition: The use of strong contrasts between light and dark in a painting.
art.mnemonic: The quayside artist sketched a schooner and a rowing (chiaroscuro) boat in a race. The schooner was very light coloured but the rowing boat was dark by contrast.
art.question: What is chiaroscuro in art?

art.definition: Indian cotton fabric decorated using block printing or hand painting techniques.
art.mnemonic: "Chin" hints (chintz) at the way to remember this: Imagine a wooden printing block strapped to an Indian woman's chin and she uses this to print on to cotton fabric.
art.question: What is chintz?

art.definition: Art form in which various materials are arranged and stuck to supporting fabric.
art.mnemonic: She collided after seeing a mirage (collage) and all the contents of her van ended up stuck to the surface.
art.question: What is a collage?

art.definition: A method of direct printing in which materials such as string, cardboard, and other found materials are stuck to card or board to enable prints to be taken.
art.mnemonic: On his collar he printed a graph (collagraph) from materials he'd stuck to a board.
art.question: What is the art technique known as collagraph?

art.definition: Painting large areas in a more or less flat single colour, prioritising the colour as the subject.
art.mnemonic: The colour of the field needed painting (colour field pattern) so she added just one, flat colour.
art.question: What is Colour Field Painting?

art.definition: A thin coat of water-based paint, a mixture of paint and water used to produce a very thin, pale colour.
art.mnemonic: The colour came out in the wash (colour wash) - all the lighter clothes looked like they had a thin coat of paint over them.
art.question: What is a colour wash?

art.definition: Art for commercial purposes, primarily advertising, to sell products, services, and goods.
art.mnemonic: Commerce shall (commercial) always find a way of using art to sell products and services.
art.question: What is commercial art?

art.definition: The arrangement of elements within a work of art
art.mnemonic: Compare positions (composition) and decide on the best arrangement.
art.question: What does composition refer to in art?

art.definition: An art form in which the artist is trying to make a point. The underlying idea and the process are more important than the tangible product.
art.mnemonic: Was it a con or was this septic tank an actual (conceptual) art piece in the art museum? It looked like the idea behind it and the process used were more interesting than the finished item.
art.question: What is conceptual art?

art.definition: Yarn or other material is laid across a fabric and fastened in place with small stitches.
art.mnemonic: Crouching (couching) on the sofa, she secured her husband, who lay across the surface of the couch, with small stitches.
art.question: What is couching in embroidery?

art.definition: Randomly shaped patches of fabric stitched together and often embellished with embroidery stitches.
art.mnemonic: These crazy patches need a lot of work (crazy patchwork) to put together.
art.question: What is crazy patchwork?

art.definition: The action of removing the outer areas of a picture to give a greater emphasis to the main subject.
art.mnemonic: The farmer showed me her crop but a lot of the outer edges had been removed.
art.question: What does it mean to crop an image?

art.definition: Style of art which shows different viewpoints of a person or object in a single image. Items represented look like they are made of cubes and other geometrical shapes.
art.mnemonic: He's using cube and prism (cubism) shapes, experimenting with different views in a single picture.
art.question: What is Cubism?

art.definition: An art movement formed during the first World War in reaction to the horrors and folly of the war, often satirical and nonsensical.
art.mnemonic: She said 'Da da' (Dadaism), which made me laugh and made no sense because I am her grandmother.
art.question: What was Dadaism?

art.definition: A method in which paint is squeezed between two surfaces to create chance effects
art.mnemonic: They decided to calculate what a kleptomaniac (decalcomania) stole but the workings out were ruined because somebody spilt ink on the workings and tried to remove it with another piece of paper.
art.question: What is decalcomania?

art.definition: Art that is meant to be useful as well as beautiful. It includes crafts, such as ceramics, furniture, interior design, jewellery, and textiles.
art.mnemonic: Over the past decade business has been lucrative (decorative) for her interior design firm and every item she uses is functional yet beautiful.
art.question: What is decorative art?

art.definition: An art movement formed by Dutch abstract artists whose work is based on horizontal and vertical stripes and primary colours.
art.mnemonic: The dirty stile (De Stijl) was made up of horizontal and vertical shapes and, when cleaned, came up in bright primary colours.
art.question: What was De Stijl?

art.definition: A method in which a metal die, or cutter, is used to cut repeated, sometimes intricate, shapes.
art.mnemonic: Press directly down to cut (die cut) through materials such as paper and card, and you can make numerous identical, intricate shapes.
art.question: What is the die cut method in printing and crafting?

art.definition: A painting technique in which primary colours are placed side by side to create a range of different colours and effects. It was later applied to pointillism by Seurat, Signac, and others.
art.mnemonic: Division of light occurs with a prism (Divisionism) and so too if you divide your palette into primary colours you can create different optical effects.
art.question: What is Divisionism in painting?

art.definition: An artwork made in the form of two painted or carved panels.
art.mnemonic: She dipped both feet and got two ticks (diptych) for making two paintings by pressing each foot onto a different canvas. They looked great side-by-side.
art.question: What is a diptych?

art.definition: In the open air; the act of painting outdoors.
art.mnemonic: She was on the plane and in the air (en plein air) – she was certainly outside!
art.question: What does "En Plein Air" mean in painting?

art.definition: Art that effectively conveys thoughts and feelings; emphasizes the process and style of creation rather than the final product.
art.mnemonic: The express checkout gives (expressive) me a quick way to purchase thoughts and feelings.
art.question: What is expressive art?

art.definition: Printed letters and numbers of the same style.
art.mnemonic: In the baby's font just before the baptism, they found a whole bunch of letters, all of the same style.
art.question: What is a font?

art.definition: Painting done rapidly in watercolour on wet plaster so that the colours penetrate and become fixed as the plaster dries.
art.mnemonic: She painted a giant fresh cream scone (fresco) on her kitchen wall straight onto the plaster. The plaster wasn't even dry yet.
art.question: What is a fresco?

art.definition: The process of making rubbings on paper of objects or textures underneath.
art.mnemonic: She used rubbings of fern fronds to make a montage (frottage) on her living room wall.
art.question: What is frottage?

art.definition: An artistic and social movement that originated in Italy in the early 20th century. It emphasised speed, technology, youth and violence, and objects such as the car, aeroplane and the industrial city.
art.mnemonic: Your kid's future is them (Futurism) driving a speeding, high technology supercar around an industrial city.
art.question: What is Futurism?

art.definition: A type of water-soluble paint that is opaque, unlike watercolour.
art.mnemonic: It's goo'd to wash (gouache) your brushes out regularly but change the water colour once it can't be seen through.
art.question: What is gouache?

art.definition: The technique of laying on paint or pigment thickly so that it stands out from a surface.
art.mnemonic: The image of the pasta and tomato (impasto) sauce looked so real and stood out so much, I could almost pick it up.
art.question: What is the technique called where paint is laid on thickly to stand out from the surface?

art.definition: A style of painting associated mainly with French artists of the late 19th century, characterized by expressive brush strokes that portray the energy of a scene rather than realism.
art.mnemonic: The impression I got was that realism (Impressionism) wasn't an important factor.
art.question: What is Impressionism?

art.definition: Putting materials such as wood, gold, or silver into the surface of an object to create decorative images or patterns.
art.mnemonic: Into the surface layer (inlay) she put wood, gold and silver.
art.question: What is inlay?

art.definition: Printing technique in which the image is etched into a surface and the cut-out area holds the ink for printing.
art.mnemonic: The inn was called the Tally Ho! (intaglio) – it's sign looked like an etched printing plate.
art.question: What is intaglio?

art.definition: A format for compressing digital image files.
art.mnemonic: A jumbo peg (JPEG) was used to compress things.
art.question: What is JPEG?

art.definition: Quilted and embroidered cloth made from recycled fabrics often found in the textiles of India and Pakistan
art.mnemonic: Can't thank (kantha) her enough for giving me an embroidered quilt to keep me warm.
art.question: What is Kantha?

art.definition: Art that is made directly in the landscape, sculpting the land itself into earthworks or making structures using natural materials such as rock or twigs.
art.mnemonic: She landed first place for art (land art), she produced this using just the landscape.
art.question: What is Land Art?

art.definition: A painting of a view across an area of land.
art.mnemonic: The land in the painting allowed the desk worker to escape (landscape) for a few moments, pretending she was there, with a view across an area of land.
art.question: What is a landscape in art?

art.definition: A drawing in which there are only lines and no shading.
art.mnemonic: Only lines have been used for this drawing (line drawing) - where is the shading?
art.question: What is a line drawing?

art.definition: A traditional patchwork technique that originated in the USA, where strips are sewn around a central square in a special way: light-colored strips on two sides and dark-colored strips on the other two, creating a diagonal line effect.
art.mnemonic: The log cabin was entirely covered in patchwork (log-cabin patchwork) quilts. Each patch had a diagonal line with one half light and the other half dark.
art.question: What is log-cabin patchwork?

art.definition: A symbol of the company that doesn't contain the business name, designed in a customised way.
art.mnemonic: Low is the only way to go through this room because there are cymbals (symbol) in the way.
art.question: What is a logomark?

art.definition: A symbol of the company in customised letters, used to identify an organisation, company, corporation, or even a product or service.
art.mnemonic: Low is the only way to go through this room because there are cymbals (symbol) in the way.
art.question: What is a logotype?

art.definition: A small-scale model or rough draft of an unfinished sculpture.
art.mnemonic: Before the sculptor started his mammoth kettle (maquette), he made a smaller model as a prototype.
art.question: What is a maquette?

art.definition: Having only one color, where one hue predominates with variations of value and intensity.
art.mnemonic: The monarchy only liked chrome. If asked what colour he would like his portrait painted, he automatically (monochromatic) said only the one colour.
art.question: What does "monochromatic" mean?

art.definition: An assembly of images that relate to each other in some way to create a single work or part of a work of art.
art.mnemonic: After the monkey has sabotaged (montage) my art display, I was able to assemble what was left into a new work of art.
art.question: What is a montage in art?

art.definition: A substance that combines chemically with dyestuff to fix a colour into cloth.
art.mnemonic: The more abundant (mordant) the dye, the more intensive the colour that can be fixed into the cloth.
art.question: What is a mordant used for in dyeing?

art.definition: A picture made up of small parts, traditionally tiny tiles made out of terracotta, piece of glass, ceramics or marble.
art.mnemonic: Moses in archaic (mosaic) times is depicted in tiny tiles in this inlayed work of art.
art.question: What is a mosaic?

art.definition: A painting executed directly onto a wall.
art.mnemonic: "Music for all" (mural) was the message and to let everyone know she painted it across the wall.
art.question: What is a mural?

art.definition: A form of art that tells a story.
art.mnemonic: Her long, narrow installation told the story of native people through art (narrative art) that everyone could understand. It was such an interesting story.
art.question: What is narrative art?

art.definition: The space around an object rather than the object itself.
art.mnemonic: I don't want to be negative about this, but there's hardly any space (negative space). You won't get in this space.
art.question: What is negative space in art?

art.definition: A style of abstract art that focuses on optical illusions, often giving the illusion that the image is moving, flashing, has hidden elements, or gives the impression of depth.
art.mnemonic: Hop over this art (Op art) but it's really unnecessary because it's an optical effect.
art.question: What is Op Art?

art.definition: Moulded sticks made of pigment and chalk particles, and a binding material to hold the particles together.
art.mnemonic: She passed us all (pastels) a stick.
art.question: What are pastels?

art.definition: A textile constructed by sewing together small pieces of fabric. The design is often in geometric composition.
art.mnemonic: We only had patches of cloth but we worked (patchwork) with them to make a perfect geometric composition.
art.question: What is patchwork?

art.definition: A design in which lines, shapes, forms or colours are repeated.
art.mnemonic: One half of the class had produced beautiful patterns (pattern), some with lines, others with shapes, forms or colours. The other half of the class needed a set of instructions.
art.question: What is a pattern?

art.definition: The feeling that a work of art provokes in you, or how your own work of art responds to an idea or issue.
art.mnemonic: It was nothing personal, but her response (personal response) to the artist's work for this exam was to run out of the gallery and hide behind a wall.
art.question: What is a personal response in art?

art.definition: An imaginary flat surface that is assumed to be identical to the surface of a painting.
art.mnemonic: Picture a plane through a grid or window and the picture plane can be thought of as the glass of the window.
art.question: What is the picture plane in art?

art.definition: A substance (usually an organic compound) that gives paint, ink or crayon a colour.
art.mnemonic: The pigs weren't meant (pigment) to eat the organic material – the peas, blackberries and blueberries – but they did, and it gave each of them a strange colour.
art.question: What is pigment?

art.definition: Assembling photographic images that relate to each other in some way to create a single work. This can be done physically or digitally and can result in realistic, imaginative, or abstract images.
art.mnemonic: To remember photomontage, split the word to realize that it is photos that are used to make the montage.
art.question: What is photomontage?

art.definition: A genre of art that encompasses painting, drawing, and other graphic media in which an artist produces an image that looks as realistic as possible.
art.mnemonic: He goes to take a photo until he realises it is not them (photorealism). Art can look so real!
art.question: What is photorealism?

art.definition: refers to a solid base or box on which a sculpture is placed
art.mnemonic: She planted a hyacinth (plinth) in a pot and placed it on a solid base, as if it were a statue.
art.question: What does the term "plinth" refer to in architecture or art?

art.definition: The body or collection of work done by an artist
art.mnemonic: The people at the port focused on the man in the leotard (portfolio). He had a large body and he was trying to work (body of work).
art.question: What is a portfolio in the context of an artist's work?

art.definition: An art movement at the end of the 19th century that followed on from Impressionism and included Cezanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh and Georges Seurat. It moved further away from realism, focusing more on emotion and using unnatural colours.
art.mnemonic: She posted a note on the impressionist's (post impressionism) painting which said: "Use more unnatural colours and emotions".
art.question: What art movement at the end of the 19th century included Cezanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh, and Seurat, focusing on emotion and using unnatural colors?

art.definition: Representing a person, location or thing in a way that is accurate and true to life.
art.mnemonic: My only real criticism (realism) is that the painting looks so real.
art.question: What is realism?

art.definition: The application of an opaque or semi-opaque color over an area of a painting without completely obscuring the underpainting.
art.mnemonic: The scum on the side of the bath was so thick you were barely able (scumble) to see the color underneath, but it didn't quite obscure it.
art.question: What does it mean to scumble in painting?

art.definition: Technique in which fabric is folded, gathered, wrapped and bound prior to the application of dye. Often seen in the textiles of Japan and commonly thought of in the west as tie-dye.
art.mnemonic: She bored him so much he (shibori) wanted to die (dye).
art.question: What is shibori?

art.definition: Small pieces of mirrored glass used on fabric, often seen on textiles from India and Pakistan.
art.mnemonic: As the sun came out, she shut (shisha) the blinds because the reflections from the mirrored beads on her dress were blinding everyone.
art.question: What is shisha in the context of textiles from India and Pakistan?

art.definition: A painting or drawing of an arrangement of objects that do not move, such as flowers or fruit in a bowl.
art.mnemonic: Will you please sit still and remain lifeless (still life). I don't want you to move.
art.question: What is a "Still Life"?

art.definition: Art that aims to express imaginative dreams and visions free from conscious rational control, often as irrational juxtaposition of images. It was a movement in art and literature that flourished in the early twentieth century.
art.mnemonic: My dream was so real, with images of symbolism (surrealism) that seemed illogical and bizarre.
art.question: What is surrealism?

art.definition: Art form in which objects are flattened out into a 2D image with no depth, using simple shapes and bright colours. It was a stage of cubism from around 1912 to 1914 in which Picasso, Braque, and Jean Gris composed their work, using collage materials.
art.mnemonic: It was a sin not to consider the aesthetics of the cubes (synthetic cubism) – someone flattened them into two dimensions, and they looked like a collage.
art.question: What is Synthetic Cubism?

art.definition: Water-based painting medium in which the color pigment is mixed with egg yolk.
art.mnemonic: When she got in a temper, she seized upon (tempera) an egg and threw it into pigment. Nobody saw it as a joke (yolk).
art.question: What is tempera?

art.definition: A technique of drawing that dispenses with outlines, creating instead areas of light and dark which represent reality better than outlined edges.
art.mnemonic: The toes are phenomenal (tonal) – she drew them in various tones and not giving them an outline makes them so much more realistic.
art.question: What is tonal drawing?

art.definition: An artwork made in the form of three painted or carved panels
art.mnemonic: The paintings got a triple tick (triptych) from me because there were three panels.
art.question: What is a triptych?

art.definition: The style and appearance of letters when printed; the arrangement of type, including letters, numbers, and symbols.
art.mnemonic: The giant typed the words "I want to be a photographer" (typography) and stood the page up in front of us. The letters really stood out.
art.question: What is typography?

art.definition: Still life containing symbols of death or change as a reminder of their inevitability
art.mnemonic: She finds vanity units and tars (vanitas) them in situ in the bathroom. This is supposed to symbolise the death of animals from oil slicks.
art.question: What is a vanitas in art?

art.definition: A type of white clay known as China pottery, baked at high temperatures.
art.mnemonic: This person was wearing a white (porcelain) hat, stones (stoneware) for a tunic and the earth (earthenware) had formed clumps on her shoes.
