business.definition: Most commonly refers to the money needed to invest in a new project or investment. Capital investment is the money used for the acquisition of physical assets by a company for use in furthering its long-term business goals and objectives.
business.mnemonic: The capital (capital) city is the best place to find the money to invest in the company's next project.
business.question: What does the term "capital" most commonly refer to in business and finance?

business.definition: the total amount of money being transferred into and out of a business
business.mnemonic: Rivers of cash flow (cash flow) money in and out of the business.
business.question: What is cash flow?

business.definition: The amount of money available to a business in a bank account at the end of an accounting period.
business.mnemonic: After closing the business at the end of the year, I checked the bank balance (closing balance). The amount that remained in the account wasn't much.
business.question: What is a closing balance?

business.definition: The money that a business spends in order to make goods and/or provide services; anything that a business pays for
business.mnemonic: You cannot just say 'What are the costs,' without being more precise.
business.question: What does a business spend money on to make goods and provide services?

business.definition: The costs that change as the business’ output changes
business.question: What are variable costs?

business.definition: Costs that stay largely the same regardless of output
business.question: What are fixed costs?

business.definition: A supplier who is owed money and therefore money will be going OUT of your bank account to pay them.
business.mnemonic: Don't take your credit card or (creditor) any other card out (out), you can pay them later.
business.question: What is a creditor?

business.definition: The practice of funding a business by raising money from a large number of people online.
business.mnemonic: The whole crowd helped by funding (crowdfunding) the business. A large number of people giving a small amount of money added up quickly.
business.question: What is crowdfunding?

business.definition: A customer who owes money to your business and therefore money will be going into your bank account.
business.mnemonic: The debt of my organisation (debtor) meant that I'm now IN prison.
business.question: Who is considered a debtor in business terms?

business.definition: A portion of the (after-tax) profits that is paid to shareholders (the owners) according to the number of shares they own.
business.mnemonic: Think of dividing a portion of the profits at the end (dividend) of the financial year and distributing it among shareholders. DIVIDe at the END = Dividend.
business.question: What is a dividend in the context of a company's profits?

business.definition: Money paid by the government or a private organisation to fund projects that it wants to support and which doesn't need to be paid back.
business.mnemonic: The genie granted (grants) him his wish. Instead of paying the government taxes, the government gave him money in the post every week without needing to pay it back.
business.question: What are grants?

business.definition: Company's turnover minus the cost of sales related to manufacturing and selling the products, excluding bank, computer, rent, or other charges.
business.mnemonic: The grocery shop cost me all my profits, (gross profits) but thankfully I didn't have to go into the bank (bank charges), the computer store (software charges), the housing office (rent) or any other shops (other costs). (It's NOT these costs)
business.question: What is gross profit?

business.definition: A method where instead of buying a product outright, you pay for it with monthly regular payments until the final installment, upon which it becomes your purchase.
business.mnemonic: I hired a product but only fully purchased it (hire purchase) when I had finished the last payment instalment.
business.question: What is hire purchase?

business.definition: Money received on a regular basis; e.g., your wages for working for a company
business.mnemonic: In comes my weekly wage through the letterbox. The money I earn working for the company isn't much.
business.question: What is income?

business.definition: A key yearly financial statement of a company's performance held by the Government for anyone to see.
business.mnemonic: All my incoming money and outgoings for the year were stated on the form, but it meant (income statement) that I didn't make much money, it was a poor company performance.
business.question: What is an income statement?

business.definition: The state of being insolvent, or when a company cannot pay its debts, also known colloquially as having gone bust.
business.mnemonic: If the industrial plant operators can't solve the emergency (insolvency), the business will lose money and will no longer afford to pay its debts.
business.question: What is insolvency?

business.definition: Is the amount of money you pay to borrow money or the amount of money you get paid for depositing money.
business.mnemonic: I paid no interest to the small print about the monetary charge for borrowing money.
business.question: What is interest when it comes to borrowing or depositing money?

business.definition: The money a company owes, whether it's a bank loan, mortgage, or unpaid bills.
business.mnemonic: He lied about his abilities (liabilities) to run the business, there are an awful lot of unpaid bills.
business.question: What are liabilities in a business context?

business.definition: The efficiency or ease with which an asset can be converted into ready cash.
business.mnemonic: The cash floats on the liquid (cash is liquid) but the brick just sunk and was not affected by the liquid (bricks and mortar not liquid).
business.question: What is liquidity?

business.definition: The difference between the actual or estimated level of sales and the company’s break-even-point. It acts as a safety net for a company, ensuring it can withstand potential fluctuations while remaining profitable.
business.mnemonic: Ma loved the gin so much that the financial safety (margin of safety) of the company was endangered. The difference between our sales and the break-even-point was very small because she was drinking all the product.
business.question: What is the margin of safety in a company's financial analysis?

business.definition: A type of loan to purchase property or land, which gives the lender the right to take your property if you fail to repay the money.
business.mnemonic: The morgue fridge (mortgage) contained the robber. Robbing banks is not the way to get money to buy a house.
business.question: What is a mortgage?

business.definition: The final profit made by a business after all costs have been paid, including Government tax bill.
business.mnemonic: What was left in the fishing net (net profit) was the final profits after all costs have been paid.
business.question: What is net profit?

business.definition: The amount that is in the account at the beginning of an accounting period.
business.mnemonic: The opening act balanced (opening balance) on a beam while checking the amount in her bank account.
business.question: What is the opening balance in accounting?

business.definition: The negative amount of money in a current account
business.mnemonic: He went into debt over draught (overdraft) beer. He drank so much that his current account balance became less than zero.
business.question: What does the term "overdraft" refer to in banking?

business.definition: The difference between the money received from the sale of goods/services and the amount that remains after all costs have been paid
business.mnemonic: You can not just say "what are the profits", without being more precise. You need to ask for one of the following: Gross profit, Net profit, Operating profit, Profit before tax, Profit after tax.
business.question: What is profit?

business.definition: Getting the money to pay for starting a business or developing it.
business.mnemonic: The farmer was raising fine ants (raising finance) but wanted to get some money to develop the business.
business.question: What does raising finance involve?

business.definition: The value of all sales made by selling goods and services over a certain period.
business.mnemonic: She charged them to rev a new (revenue) sports car and the income generated paid for it.
business.question: What is revenue in business?

business.definition: When a LTD company or corporation decides to issue more shares in the company in exchange for a payment from the sale. It is a type of equity finance.
business.mnemonic: Sharing control of the company is the main issue (share issue) when issuing shares, but you would get loads of money to invest.
business.question: What occurs when a company decides to issue more shares as a form of equity finance?

business.definition: Another term for a balance sheet; a document that reports the assets, liabilities and shareholder's equity of a business; a financial document of how much a company is worth.
business.mnemonic: This written statement says the financial position (statement of financial position) of the business is strong. The company is worth a lot of money.
business.question: What is a Statement of Financial Position?

business.definition: Costs that have already been incurred and cannot be recovered.
business.mnemonic: After our boat was sunk, the cost (sunk cost) of it could not be recovered.
business.question: What does the term "sunk cost" refer to in economics?

business.definition: The value of all sales made by selling goods and services over a period (revenue) plus any rent in, any money from interest, charging other companies for expenses etc.
business.mnemonic: The farmer turned over (turnover) every bit of the company's money in his field.
business.question: What is turnover in a business context?
